I can appreciate some of the visual craft in the film, but the violence is so pervasive that either you should be disgusted by the film and turn it off (or fast-forward, as I did, hoping that it would get better) or you will become numbed to the violence (which presents a moral problem of an entirely different stripe). If someone wants to complain about violence in comic book creations, this would be a prime example.

Manipulation of black-and-white scenes with intense color highlights can only take a viewer so far. This might have been a great film, but the artistry of it sometimes feels self-indulgent. Characterization may appear to be good, but fundamentally the movie lacks any depth.

Go watch the Spider-man films or _Batman Begins_ instead.

title: A Film for a Generation of Utter Morons
review: This film was so bad I actually was yelling at the movie screen. All the while, the underage teenage lobotomy cases that had snuck in "ooooed and awwwwwed" at this "masterpiece". I can't believe there is anyone above the age of 12 who liked this piece of crap. It seems there is a new generation of movie-goers who have had their last brain cells popped by too many millisecond jump cuts used in the latest music videos and were wowed in their youth by the gawdy colours of the Teletubbies that they have been conditioned to respond positively to this kind of cinema. If someone says to me they liked Sin City I immediately think "aha your brain must be made out of sh*t pudding!" and never listen to anything they have to say again. Sin City is likely the worst film I have seen in 5 years. To see it in the top 100 is laughable... the world is full of utter morons and apparently they have all seen Sin City.

title: Same as always when Tarantino is involved
review:
I don't get it why everybody seems to like this movie... I couldn't find ANY continuing storyline and had real trouble trying to figure out why everybody had to die (basically that's what happened after all)

I like horror/thrillers etc etc and don't look back at violence, however here it seemed to senselessly overkilled and sometimes useless. I cannot understand this could even be close to the comic.(admitted I have not seen/read it, but if it is that it's even worse)

The best part in my opinion was Elija Woods. His role was mysterious but still without background. As most characters. Also I never managed to find out the connection between the main stories in the movie... I watched it with my girlfriend and we couldn't figure out why everybody likes this movie so much *shrugs*

I give it a 1/10 because basically anybody could make a better storyline, even a 5 yr old...

title: Horrible
review: If I could I would give Sin City a 0 out of 10. It was poorly done, with a stupid plot that was (if you didn't read the books and have a good background knowledge of what was happening) left you totally guessing. It shifted from person to person so quickly that it made it seem that all of the different people's stories were just on big story, but in fact they are different. Bruce Willis, cracked up to be a main star, turned out to have a minimal part at best. Instead, the main character was a big, oaf that didn't understand the concept of annunciation. I am a fan of Willis and Quentin Tarrentino, but I absolutely hated this movie and would say it's one of the worst I've seen. I wouldn't recommend it to anyone that even likes Tarrentino or Willis, I'd recommend it to someone who wanted to waste over 2 hours of their life with a pointless movie. Absolutely horrible!

title: Not really even a feature film
review: I had a hard time sitting through the film. The narration is endless, and after a while grating. The film is really not a feature length motion picture, instead it's three short films with a few common characters. The actions of the common characters do not effect the through line to each short story so it's really a cheat to bill as a feature what is essentially a collection of vignettes thrown together for length. One of the stories bookends the other two. One story involves a huge guy who is framed for killing his one true love. It's great. I wish they had expanded it into a feature picture. The protagonist was interesting and the story was compelling. The other two stories were all style and no substance. I was bored. I very nearly walked out of the theater, and seldom do I like a film so little. When I go to see a feature, I want to see a feature. A compelling story with a through-line told over about two hours. This was not that, and I think selling it as such is misleading. Skip Sin City you're not missing much, or rent it and watch the one worthwhile short film within it.

title: The level of violence is unnecessary for any movie - ever!
review:
I just finished watching Sin City and can honestly say this is the worst movie ever - (that I've seen). The disturbing amount of cheesy one-liners could make this movie laughable, except for the grossly offensive and excessive use of violence. To what theatrical end? Who knows.

I cannot say enough bad things about this movie. There may be someone who likes it and tries to indicate some redeeming value can be derived from it. I am not artsy enough, dark enough or deranged enough to agree. I can liken recommending this movie to a friend - the same way one would encourage a non-smoker to pick up a pack of cigarettes.

There is nothing more to say about this movie except; don't see it.

title: Another movie passing only by boobs and bullets
review:
For two hours I was bored out of my mind, watching characters shoot each other, topless girls walk around that needn't be topless. A complete waste of my time. I don't care how closely it followed the graphic novels, it was crap.

Tarantino obviously had a hand in it whether you spot his name in the credits or not, with a few indirect references to Kill Bill. Notice how it is a mainly people under 18 that thought highly of this movie. All they wanted to see was tits, sex and people punching others up into a bloody pulp. Kitano fans will be disappointed, especially comparing it to a much better bloody film, Zatoichi.

I'm normally a fan of Graeme Revell. He certainly made Titan A.E. what it was. He's one of the very few New Zealanders to arise into something good in the film industry. Sadly though, this film didn't really do him any justice. Too much influence from Robert Rodriguez led him to compose a somewhat crappy score.

Never mind. If boobs, bullets and strange is what you like, see it. If you are after something with any depth at all, don't bother.

2/10.

title: Don't know what the hype is about.
review:
I honestly do not see what the big deal was supposed to be about this film. I've not read Miller's graphic novels (and apparently now I don't have to), but I am a fan of gritty, dark comic books. However, I think they may have lost something in the transition from page to screen.

The story, or rather stories, in the movie are not bad, but nothing particularly groundbreaking.

Hardigan's 'out for justice at all costs' storyline (That Yellow Bastard) is probably the best, in my opinion. Willis also turns in the best performance in the movie. Madsen, on the other hand, has the worst lines, both in this movie, and his entire career. Jessica Alba is cute, but I think she looks better in the Fantastic Four previews. Nick Stahl is uniformly if generically evil.

Mickey Rourke as Marv was a good choice, and I think Rourke is a good actor, but the lines he was given... ouch. His dialogue was clichéd and unbelievable. It looks good on paper, but spoken, it just sounds kind of stupid. As for the storyline, its pretty formulaic revenge fare, the highlight being the villain, Frodo Baggins as a razor-clawed-ninja-charlie-brown-harry-potter-cannibal (don't ask).

The final segment was my favorite, with Rosario Dawson and Clive Owen. But it had the worst line in the film. (RENEWED SPOILER WARNING) The "I thought she told me to stop, what she was saying was 'COP'" I wanted to shove knitting needles through my eardrums. I found this was a recurring problem throughout the film.

Having not read the comics, I don't know, maybe this is explained there, but I was left with several questions, such as: Why is Marv almost superhuman? Why can Dwight jump off a building ledge, land on his feet, and survive? I thought Sin City was not a superhero-type book. What did Shelly mean by Dwight's "new face"? Who the heck is "The Salesman"? Just a hired gun that specializes in seducing and killing women? Oh, and how do all those coats just happen to fit the gargantuan Marv? All that being said, I have to say I really liked Bruce Willis in this film. Of course, he had the best lines ("There's wrong, then there's wrong, then there's _this_" "When it comes to consoling 19-year-old girls, I'm about as useful as a palsy patient performing brain surgery with a pipe wrench.") but had some of the worst (talking to himself, calling himself 'old man', giving himself a pep talk while hanging from his neck). Also, the two thugs that Willis beats down (twice) are very watchable. I would actually watch the film again for these two.

I didn't love this movie, and I didn't hate it. I'm glad I didn't have to pay to see it. There seems to be some serious passion surrounding this film. I've seen numerous comments about "Best film of the year" and "Worst film of the year." Depends on who you are, I guess.

The violence and misogyny so berated by many reviewers did not seem so prevalent to me. Maybe because I wasn't watching the film looking for such 'flaws.' Yes, the movie was bloody, but it was either a.) inconsequential, b.) conducive to the story, or c.) comical, like kill-bill injuries. Yes, just about every woman in the film was scantily clad or nude, and either a prostitute or a stripper. But on the flip side of that, just about every man in the film was a psychopath, sexual predator, overtly violent, or a corrupt businessman, politician, or clergyman. The film is not misogynistic so much as misanthropic. Only a few people in Sin City have any redeeming moral values.

I give it 5 out of 10. I would watch it again, but I probably would never pay to do so.

~Pellucidar

title: Way too overrated
review:
Who would have thought a movie like this can go straight to 250 top? Imean what's so special about it? It's got nothing more than a bleak idea and an unbelievable gore,things that should not make people feel any better but it actually does because where there's no sanity there's nothing! What's the plot? Why are the events so stupidly going on? This is just like Kill Bill volumes..bleak,with empty action ,no feeling kinda movie,and BTW,i have a colour TV..what's so interesting to see a movie B/W with three colours of blood? It's just my opinion,not a fact. The actors played almost perfect and the make-up was supreme but this is'n enough to be there in the top spot.Probably the large variety of actors in this movie made it so good .

Watch it but with no high expectations!

title: The most faithful comic book adaptation ever made
review:
You've got to give Sin City something: it's the most faithful comic book adaptation ever made. The grisly comic-book noir has never been shown on the big screen so well. If you have the maturity of a twelve year-old, then you will love the glorified violence, and over- the-top gore. However, if you're looking for any substance, you will be sorely disappointed.

At first the filming style is somewhat amusing to watch, the very first scene in the film shows a hit man seducing a beautiful girl, and then shooting her. The colors in contrast to the monotones, and the striking CGI backgrounds are awe-inspiring for about five minutes, but once you've gotten past all of that you realize that you feel nothing for the characters on screen, you have gained no uplifting (or depressing) insight, and you would have been better off spending your five minutes clipping your toe-nails. The rest of the movie is even worse.

The over-the-top violence, which could have been disturbing, is anything but stimulating. Seeing the soulless serial killer of the story (whose one-sided character has more depth than any other's) have his arms and legs sawed off, and then fed to a wolf didn't even make me twitch. And it's far from an aestheticization of violence, after watching the film I'm just about as exited about ripping off someone's testicles as I am watching paint dry.

Rather than add any resemblance of depth to the two-hour film, the story is split up into three sections, only one of which is worth sitting through, for Bruce Willis's performance (which is decent despite the film). Though I don't see how anyone could find the film exciting, the only reason to see it is if you have a violence fetish. In which case it is about as high quality as any pornographic film at the dirty video store down the street.

title: 101 Gratuitous Maimings for Dummies
review:
A comment on violence. I've seen a lot of violence in films. I've never liked gratuitous violence and I've found that as I've gotten older (I'm early 20's) that I like it less and less. People will automatically jump on me for watching and then low-grading this film. They'll tell me that I'm a fool and if I knew anything about the source material and creative team behind the film, then I shouldn't have bothered watching it.

It's true that I didn't know anything about the comics, but I've seen Tarantino's films and 'Pulp Fiction' is one of my favourite films. I found it to be the perfect balance between style and substance. However, I did not like his 'Kill Bill' movies as much. Part 1 - too much violence/style and not enough story. Part 2 - too much plot and exposition. With tighter editing he should have turned it into the one film it was meant to be. After all, 'Pulp Fiction' was originally about 550 pages long before he pretty much cut it in half. I blame the Weinsteins ....

'Sin City' is just so over-the-top in its blood, guts and gore. An alternative title for the film could be '101 Gratuitous Maimings for Dummies.' The other problem with the film is that it tries so hard to be slick that it is just cheesy. All the hookers in Old Town looked like Models from Lingerie catalogues. Not hot at all because its just so flashy and overstated.

The responses to the above complaints will likely be - "it is not meant to be real, its meant to be cheesy and over-the-top, it's meant to be fantasy, it was made for a specific audience and they loved it, what were you expecting? " Well just because they meant for it to be like this, it doesn't mean it is enjoyable. Just because they went for corn and cheese does not mean it tastes good. Just because its fantasy doesn't mean it should sacrifice all probability for bullshit. Just because this was made for testosterone-fuelled-youngsters doesn't mean its not a disappointment that the people behind this film are capable of a lot more. I hope 'Grindhouse' is more fun than blood and guts. If not, one day Tarantino's substance and nuance will rise from the ashes.

Final point. So why not a 1-star? The acting from the all-star cast is satisfactory, Alexis Bledel is hot (good casting) and it looks good (but my dislike for the film soon soured that).

title: could steal your soul - the result of arrogant pretension
review:
I had written a review and left it at work. Now i have the urge to comment, so here's a short version of the review. Weirdos, but particularly Mickey Rourke, hyperkill a bunch of people.

Mickey Rourke hyperkills someone again, then, uh, Mickey Rourke hyperkills someone. Various violent sociopaths and demented victims say brainbeatingly dumb crap in hyperlurid noir-talk, which could kill your brain cells and steal your soul.

As Joe Bob Briggs would have said, it has blood,breasts, bimbo-fu, mutant-fu. So, maybe it has bad-movie charm, right? No such luck. It's not live action, which changes a lot and, much worse, it seems to have been made to be in some way, art, so instead of being able to smile at how goofy and awful it is, you're very cheesed off, then overwhelmed by the arrogant pretension of the sadists who gave us this steaming celluloid turd.

Watching this movie is like whizzing in the wind and then proclaiming "damn i love being this wet and smelly!"

You are warned.

title: Storyboard sketcher with no imagination
review: Sin City is another example of how not to make a movie. It relies completely on highlight scenes to be shown in trailers. There's no comment on the acting because the script doesn't call for acting, just a bunch of lines thrown together. As near as I could make out the plot is just about revenge, over and over and over, which would make it attractive to adolescents, but the script is so bad, and the plot so badly delineated, that it can only qualify as a farce. However, the farce is hampered by poor directing, which makes it look only serious. It tries to get by on block looks and the one moderately funny scene where a guy is being dragged by a car; and looks like a drawing. In effect, its the result of a good sketch artist for storyboards with no imagination, creativity, or talent. If you watch it any way, don't say I didn't warn you. I do challenge anyone to stay awake and watch it in one sitting. I don't think it can be done by any animal.

title: a brilliant job of producing something completely unnecessary
review:
It is true: Sin City is the most faithful adaptation of a comic or graphic novel to date. And yet, and yet Back in the old days, about a decade ago, comic-book movies were not respectable, Joel Schumacher hammering the last nails in the coffin. And then the renaissance: Unbreakable (not an adaptation, unless you count the steal from Grant Morrison's Doom Patrol), the Spider-Man movies, and Hulk (most people thought that fell badly between two stools  too artsy for the explosions crowd, too explosive for the artsy crowd  but I love it). These were movies giving us what we loved about comics. And now here comes Sin City, essentially Frank Miller's work converted directly from page to screen. Which is the movie's biggest problem. In their heroic efforts to stay faithful to the source material, Miller and Rodriguez seem to have missed a rather banal truism: movies are not comic books. What worked so well on paper does not necessarily succeed on film (or computer, as the case may be). On paper, the whole thing is literally two-dimensional, and the stylisation is pretty much the raison d'etre. But when you actually get real people (well, actors, at any rate) saying the lines and doing the things the characters do, this brings a whole new level of meaning to light. The graphic novels could get away with the violence and the stock situations (clichés, if you like) and the intense misanthropy because they were firmly rooted in a particular kind of pulp fiction. But if you start looking at Sin City the movie in the context not of comic books but of other movies, what were once virtues now look horribly like flaws. In a movie with so many characters, and fine actors, it's a shame that only two of them (Marv and Hartigan) are anything other than cardboard cutouts  and in both those cases, the depth of character comes more from their thoughts rather than their actions. Both of these stories involve violent revenge and the search for redemption through the love of a beautiful blonde. The middle story involves ah, I got bored at this point gun-toting prostitutes feminism's not my strong point but alarm bells were ringing at the idea of women who seem fully in control of their own lives and yet choose to be sleazy hookers which gets me thinking about Nancy  was there any particular reason, plot-wise I mean, that she had to be a table-dancer and not, say, a law student? You can get away with these things in comics but in the cold light of cinema it all starts to seem a bit adolescent. As for the male characters, there is, intriguingly, rather a lot of crotch-related violence. Oh the violence. Again, a still image of violence is one thing, but on screen it careers between too-real and too-cartoony. "I didn't scream, Hartigan", breathes Nancy after getting a sound whipping from a psycho. Good for you, love, they could have done with you back in Billy Budd's time.

Which is not to say I hated the film. I did quite like most of it. I haven't addressed the technical aspects here, because I think it goes without saying that Sin City is technically brilliant. There is a time and place for style over substance, though, and while I hate to admit it, I think possibly that at 34 I'm getting too old for this sh*t.

title: Stupid narration
review: What was up with the stupid narration. There was absolutely no reason for it and it basically killed the movie. I could see how it tried to be like a comic book with all the insight, BUT IT'S A MOVIE!!! And if they actually do the narration, they might as well not act, it feels like listening to the radio, or a movie for a def guy. Movies such as "Goodfellas" and "Fight Club" both have amazing narration because it gave some sort of insight. The part that was most bothersome was when Bruce Willis was narrating. He's a decent respected actor but when he narrates, it takes away from the performance. The occaisonal narration could be pretty funny like when the guy in the first third of the film talks about how with Carla Gugina's body, she could have any man she wants. Why did he put the narration in, someone please inform me. WHY!?!?!?!??!

title: just so overrated....
review:
Crowds are strange and odd things. They love and adore, hate and repel in equal measure and often without little thought. Nothing could be more applicable for the praise that has been heaped upon this seemingly 'epic', 'brilliant' and 'masterful' film.

This is simply a shallow movie that has been dressed up by directors, fans and critics alike to be a great critique of humanity, modern society and amorality. A complete contradiction is what I would ideally see as a kind translation of the truth.

There is no point to this film. The violence is repetitive and eventually banal, the acting decent and appalling in equal measure, the characters (oddly enough) so badly formed and unoriginal.

But wait, say my inevitable army of detractors, this is a great saga of good vs evil, of humanity vs evil, this is a great display of acting, cinematography of immensely talent and above all original film-making. Well I say, no no NO NO. The supposed 'goodguys' are just thugs with no compassion or mercy; what this film is basically a great advertisement for misanthropicism - no great case study of people struggling to fight their morals. All Rourke, Willis are fighting for is to 'look' cool and glamorise violence - its just so prosaic and deficient in any depth whatsoever.

All this film wants to achieve is that teenage boys will gawp at Jessica Alba's body, cheer at Mickey Rourke's gruesome atrocities and revel in the constant and unrelenting bloodbath. All this film is good for is some interesting camera shots and use of colour. Otherwise it is one immensely powerful deterrent to disregard any critic who labels this movie anything near decent.

This is one stupid and unintelligent movie, and anyone who thinks it is anything resembling a masterpiece is as bereft of logic and depth as this film.

title: Not even 2 dimensional characters.
review:
The characters are so flat in this movie that they are beyond 2 dimensional, more like 1 dimensional if thats even possible.

I left this 'movie' feeling like I had read a comic book for 2 hours, or rather that I had watched a movie of someone reading a comic book to me, and not a very good comic book either.

There is also a very sick scene of an 18 year old girl kissing a 70 year old man passionately just because he saved her from a rape 10 years previous. Why would anyone want to see children necking with the elderly??? I'm confused as to why thats entertaining.

Avoid this film at all costs, super bad and super boring.

-Lobo

title: What a violent & useless piece of garbage this movie was
review:
I was practically forced into seeing this movie as my friend is an artist & lover of the original comic books. I have to admit that I'm not a fan of film noir or Quentin Tarantino and I should have listened to my stomach before having it heave all over the lady ahead of me in the theatre.

There is no use for this kind of useless mind numbing violence ..the story line jumped around more than a frog on hot pavement and the tie-in towards the end of the movie was just absurd .. I mean really, the yellow guy was the serial killer from the first segment? He turned into a Ferengi from some medical procedure meant to re-attach his genitals .. OKAY .. time to leave .. when the theatre went dark between scenes, I was praying out loud that this was the end of it? I left the theatre immediately during the Elijah Wood/Rutger Hauer segment .. a young man with razors for nails who kills & eats prostitutes .. YUCK ..

Elijah Wood is quoted as saying that he took this role to make people forget him as Frodo .. well with any luck, Hollywood & all the innocent young following of fans that he managed to build with his portrayal as the innocent Frodo will do just that, forget about him. Elijah, bad move man. Be like Orlando or Cate or Marton & get a real agent who will find you real work.

I woke up in the middle of the night from nightmares because of this film.

I managed to yell loud enough at the theatre manager who gave me my money back and thankfully I saved a group of young souls from seeing this filth.

Movies like this belong on the indie circuit so only those people who think Ted Bundy is cool & still live in their parents' basement at the age of 43 should watch this.

I've lost all faith in Hollywood movies & have resigned myself to not spending another hard earned dollar to contribute to its longevity.

title: Cringe City
review: What a complete and utter bore of a movie. I cannot believe that the fan boys/girls are so entrenched in the idolatry of the graphic novels that they cannot admit that this movie is a mess. It is completely disjointed. What works in a graphic novel does not work on film. I have read all of the graphic novels of Sin City and found that my imagination went along way in making them work. What was put on screen was tiring and tired. How many stories of a man seeking revenge of the scorn of a woman can one watch? This was one retread after another and made the film way too long. How many toilet bowl dunking scenes does a film need to show its lack of creativity. I admit the film looks really neat, but gloss does not equal substance and this film has zero depth. This movie is rife with horrible dialogue. "I tied those ropes myself it's my specialty." Cheeeeeeeeese!!! What the hell was with the woman in the zorro costume? I know it is in the books, but she looked so utterly silly. Every time she showed up on screen the theater lost it. This is going down as one of the biggest disappointments I've seen on screen. This is a movie without heart and is so loyal it trips all over its own self. Lastly, for a film drenched in gratuitous sex and violence I find it highly amusing that the star attraction at the local "strip" club is a girl doing rope tricks. That is quite possibly the lamest choice of directing I've ever seen. If the actress doesn't want to get naked for the stripper role get another actress. I don't care how hot Jessica Alba is, that is lame.

title: Little boys with big cameras
review:
Although I respectfully agree that the film makers have brought a graphic novel to the screen with great respect and panache, I left this movie sickened and infuriated. Not only was this an exercise in futile idolatry, but I felt I was watching the work of male filmmakers who had directed with a camera in one hand while the other was vigorously stroking below the belt.

Not a reader of Miller's graphic novels, I found nothing to engage me in this cinematic world--no characters, no themes, no story, not even an aesthetic (after ten minutes, the movie's look frankly lost its sheen; I needed more). Why make a slavish photocopy of the books when the film makers had an opportunity to translate this material into something that truly lived in the cinematic genre? And also, in this day and age, why hew to the stereotype of women so simultaneously nasty and beautiful that they have to be degraded and/or killed? To the men who made this movie and to the men out there who liked this movie, grow up!

title: huh?
review:
So, i saw Sin City and i don't get what the big deals about. i was skeptical when i heard that they where making the movie, though miller was still in creative control. once i saw the trailer, i was extremely excited, to say the least. from what i saw in the trailer they got the concept of how the the books look and felt.

fast forward a couple of months, and I'm sitting in the theater watching the movie. Marv's story was just about to start, so far i was not impressed nor disappointed. for some reason it just didn't feel right, i couldn't put my finger on it. this doesn't have to do with the petty stuff (ie Marv's head being bigger than his torso and it looked like he's going to fall over). this bothered me for the rest of the movie. reflecting on the movie i realized it was the pacing. none of the from the novels, in my opinion, where kept. it seemed as if it had a constant beat and every once and a while kicked it up a notch.

another odd part was the movement of the characters, it seemed as if they thought they where superheros. these are just normal people in an insane condition, no powers. the exception to this is Kevin he was the only character who's movements where as portrayed in the book.

the part of the movie i enjoyed was the jail scene, every thing moved just as the book did and i enjoyed it. as for the rest of the movie it wasn't anything special other than the way it was shot, it wasn't really a noir it was just careful with colors.

title: Please spare us
review: Well after all the hype surrounding it, I expected something far better. How can stars of the likes of Bruce Willis, Mickey Rourke and Rutger Hauer participate in this crazy venture? The movie begins with a scene that has absolutely no connection to the rest of the movie. The use of black and white and a narrative feel is good, and probably the only point to be appreciated about the movie. The outlandish fight scenes with limbs flying all over the place are almost laughable. In fact, most of the audience where I viewed it on its first day of release was either shell-shocked or laughing. The character of Marv (Rourke) could have been explored further - we know nothing about his background before he embarks on his crazy revenge romp. Shellie (Britanny Murphy) also kind of disappeared into the background. Altogether a media-hyped movie that reveals Hollywood's lack of good stories.

title: A little weak
review:
I really was looking forward to this, especially after reading who was in the cast and who was directing. Now I will say I have never read the graphic novel or whatever, but the premise sounded really cool and considering nothing has come out worth anything recently, I was looking forward to checking this out. I was pretty let down.

The film tried too hard to be in the same style as "Pulp Fiction" - an opening part...a few stories about different people that overlap each other...and then and end scene that kind of goes back to the first. The problem was, In Pulp Fiction everything somewhat revolved around Marcellus Wallace...in this one there really wasn't anything of substance to tie everything together outside of the location. The segment with Micky Rourke was by far my favorite and could have been a movie unto itself...but the rest just seemed too thrown together.

Maybe I'm missing something since I never read what it was all based on...but at the same time I never thought that should be any kind of pre-requisite to enjoy a movie. I wouldn't waste my time at the theater, just wait until it comes out on video if you have to see it.

I just have this feeling this movie will be one of those that people rave about "just because", and if you didn't like then you just "didn't get it" if you know what I mean.

title: I know I won't be the only one
review:
I just got out of the advanced screening about 3 hours ago and I have to say I wasn't shocked or surprised. The movie was a complete piece of garbage...it did look kinda cool but then again that doesn't mean much.

The acting was horrible, the writing (which may or may not have come directly from a comic book was laughably ridiculous) and the above all else the movie was simply booooorrring.

I am an avid comic book fan but even I realize that transposing a comic book directly to a movie screen isn't by itself a good idea. This movie could have severely benefited from a rewrite of the source material. What sounds cool in a paneled comic book just sounds silly when coming from flesh and blood characters.

Comicphiles are going to love this movie despite its many faults -- more power to you. But if you are an individual who wants to be entertained for two hours in exchange for your nine bucks. Look elsewhere 3 out of 10

title: Pretty Visuals, Ugly Story
review:
I swear the Satan himself must have made this movie. It is so vile, so filled with meanness and hate, you can just feel evil oozing out of the TV set as you watch the DVD. I felt like taking a shower after watching this filth.

The only reason I stayed with it were the fantastic visuals. A fan of film noir, I just loved the photography in here, although a bunch of it was computer-generated, or had that look. Nonetheless, it was fascinating to view.

The story, however, is so ugly and so anti-God and particularly anti-Catholic (and I'm not Catholic) that it's disgusting. Imagine a movie this prejudiced against Jews, Muslims, Buddhists, etc. But - give scumbag filmmakers a cross to make fun of (or a bunch of the nastiest women alive all wearing big crosses around their necks) and/or a story where the clergy are the worst villains in the movie, as we have here - and, oh boy, they're more than happy to make a movie with that as a main part of the story.

I have no problem with violence on film, but this is so overdone it is absurd. If you've followed the Robert Rodriquez "El Mariachi" films, you know that he has become more and more violent with each movie. This Rodriguez dude (the director of this film) cannot have enough blood, guts, explosions and general mayhem in his movies.

Everything about this film is nasty....way too nasty, which is why it wasn't a success at the box office. It was violent film-making extremism at is worst. What a shame to waste those fabulous visuals with trash like this.

title: zzzzzzzzz
review:
Fade in: VO (deep gruff voice) blah blah blah blah blah. And more tough-guy talk from straight out of the schoolyard. And even more.

Cut to: CU Woman's head falls off.

VO (another deep gruff voice) blah blah blah blah blah. And yet more tough-guy talk from straight out of the schoolyard. And some more.

Cut to: CU A man's head falls off.

VO (yet another deep gruff voice) blah blah blah blah blah. And yet more tough-guy talk from straight out of the schoolyard. And even more.

Repeat for 120 minutes.

Fade out

Send staff into theatre to wake up audience.

title: Never seen something this pointless and unproductive
review:
I don't personally mind a bit of Hollywood-ketchup dripping and heads or hands hacked off (there they go) here and there in case it is reasonable, or else, appropriate or necessary for the story, really, however very strongly supposing that there IS a story.

I suggest you only go for this masterpiece in case you have nothing better to do, better things in this event including several punches in your face, a car accident and an annoyed rattlesnake locked in with you in an unlit elevator that's just got stuck.

For instance, there is no plot whatsoever unless you consider the fact that everyone gets either wholly or partially eaten up by others or totally or partially killed by the end of the movie, a story.

Characters just wander up and about the place, and if you fear, blood is all over well, as for one thing, you won't see it from the slime sprinkling all around and covering it. As said before, the sprinkling does not lead anywhere. It is a joyful per se sprinkling we have to deal with.

All the blood and lousy horror-effects available have been carefully collected to add up to a pointless and unintelligent massacre, in the end of which the only feeling you will have when leaving the cinema is that of a strong disappointment in both the directors (whom we have thought and seen to be capable of doing better) and yourself for having been brainless enough to sign up for such a waste of time and money, in the present case, your time, and your money.

Don't be fooled by the brilliant cast! Even they can't compensate you for the total lack of sense in this story.

title: Highly overestimated
review:
I waisted two hours on this movie hoping to see why so many people liked it. I didn't, it's just violent and nothing, nothing more... Just because you understand nothing from a thing, does not make it complex or sophisticated, most often there is nothing to see in that thing! If someone could please tell me what is to be liked in this movie, please do, maybe I just don't get it. Anyway, the worst movie I have seen in a while... by a huge margin! Too bad about Bruce Willis and Mickey Rourke, they ruined my impression about them, although the acting was not that bad. Only that I will not go to see another movie again just because it's Bruce Willis...

Don't waist your time like I did, it really isn't worth it!

title: don't go see this.
review: this movie was despicable it. other than being an interesting thing to look at the story was horrible. the writer clearly has moral conception of just what images he was putting into his movie. here is exactly what i mean (and this is the spoiler part so look away if you don't want to know anything) little girls that brutally kill is not entertainment. there is not storyline justification for her age and thus should not have been used. Nazi swastika throwing stars are also Definitely not okay. the regime that that symbol stood for and the action taken by the people of that country during the second world war are not to be used as an implement of entertaining death. if it were justifiable as being used to depict ultimate evil then it would be okay but this is taking a rifle to swat a fly. this was really just a mean and unnecessary way to show evil. on top of that the story line really just kinda stinks. sure its interesting how the plots tie together but in the end its just so unbelievable while trying to be real that its just confusing. i will admit this isn't my kinda movie but i really did try to go in with a open mind but i just couldn't take this in objectively. if i could go back to the night i saw this i would leave after i saw the star wars episode III trailer.

title: This is the Most Horrible Of Movies
review:
The only reason this movie got the rating it did was because of the special effects. The actual story of the movie was totally repugnant. It's about another serial killer (sigh isn't anyone besides me sick of the stupid serial killer movies yet?) who mounts the heads of women on his wall. When will they make a movie where the women aren't all hookers or prey? This movie sucks, sucks, sucks.

If you are a mysogynist you'll love this movie. And it came out of the most mysogynist place of all. Hollywood.

The rating on her proves you should NOT to trust a movies rating. Because most people who watch them are morons.

title: Awful movie that lacks it all
review:
Overrated movie that lacks it all. The story is ridiculous : some kind of monster man running around killing people trying to get revenge for a hooker he barely knew, in fact he makes it clear to the audience he was surprised that he ended up in bed with her at all... So what is the motive for this entire flick ? Beats me.

The lightning is way to dark - I suppose they try to resemble cartoon-alike surroundings. They try to hard - the movie is so gray and dark that it all becomes way too much - one grayish soup of buildings, raindrops and black back alleys.

The voices are good as long as the characters talk themselves, but the problem is that that the movie mostly uses the narrator technique : The main person elaborates his situation at all times with a hilariously deep voice (trying to be tough, e' ?) and reels of loads of bullshit that has no relevance to the story whatsoever.

And I'm usually easy to please with regard to "odd" movies. Save yourself from disaster - get another DVD to avoid spoiling the evening.

title: Yawn!
review:
I am a great lover of cartoons and Sin City is an excellent adaptation of a cartoon - unfortunately of an extremely boring cartoon! The make up and filming is great, the characters very cartoon link and the action shots also. Unfortunately I was unfamiliar with Sin City prior to entering the cinema. If I had known the cartoon I am sure I would have stayed at home. Rarely have I been so bored! I remember watching "Dick Tracey" many years ago, which I thought was a brilliant adaptation of a brilliant cartoon. I had hoped that Sin City would live up to it - how wrong could I be? The line up of brilliant actors looked promising, but the lack of storyline meant that I was checking my watch from twenty minutes into the film.

I sat through to the end, only because I was with my husband who seemed reasonably entertained. More than 20 people left the cinema during the film. I can't remember the last time I went to a film where people walked out before the end.

I am trying to imagine who the target audience for this 18-rated film is. I would imagine 15-year old boys would enjoy it, mainly for the fact that they managed to sneak into an 18-film.

Oh well, I suppose everyone wastes a Saturday night every now and again.

title: ultra violent, degrading towards women, horrible movie
review:
I usually go by the ratings on IMDb, and agree with most of them, but how has this movie gotten an 8.3? I was shocked by how violent the movie was and got pretty angry by the way it glorified violence towards women. Just another film noir piece with guys in trench coats and women who are prostitutes. Who writes these things, and why are we supporting these adolescent male fantasies of women wandering around wearing practically nothing and the men who attempt to "save" them? (Often committing their own acts of violence against women.)

I couldn't believe how many people got hacked up in this movie. Everyone was violent; there weren't any characters I could identify with and say "now that's a good guy" or "I really like her character". Everyone was screwed up. And the dialog sucked.

title: 2 Hours of My Life I Want Back
review:
I give this movie 2 out of 5 stars. Walking out of the theater, I wished that I had given $10 to charity instead of wasting it at the ticket booth. The only reasons I gave this movie any stars at all was for: (1) The Jessica Alba boobie dance scenes  worth one star, and (2) The psycho Harry Potter scenes  worth the other star. Jessica Alba's boobie scenes are the movie's only saving graces.

What was bad about the movie? It was cheesy. The cinematography was cheesy. The dialog was cheesy  yes, yes, I know that it's supposed to be cheesy because it's an "homage" to pulp/comic books. To those who think that, I submit to you that there are two kinds of cheesy. One type is an entertaining type of cheesy (good), and a really cheesy type of cheesy (bad). This movie is the latter. Quentin Tarantino's whole cheeseball, pulp, violence-ridden, time-shifting "style" has moved from being innovative in Pulp Fiction, to being a novelty in Kill Bill, to being a cheap gimmick in Sin City. Enough is enough, I say. Think of something new, Q-boy.

Also, the movie is littered with cheap potshots at the Catholic Church. It's almost near the point where one could accuse it of being anti-Catholic. A lot of the anti-Catholic imagery and innuendos are really insensitive, inflammatory, and considering the Pope's passing yesterday, utterly tasteless. From pulling the trigger of a gun pointed at the head of a statue of a cardinal who surprisingly looks like the Pope, to the allusions of immorality and pedophilia in the next scene, this movie is full of these anti-Catholic images. The filmmakers would probably defend sprinkling the anti-Catholic imagery throughout the movie as a juxtaposition between the Church and the movie's namesake subject matter. But I see what's going on in the movie, and it's borderline Liberal Christian activism married to atheism. I consider myself a Liberal and enjoy movies which provoke thought, but this movie instead cheaply promotes negative feelings and reinforces negative stereotypes towards the Catholic Church. It's like the anti-Catholic version of blackface.

Don't bother watching this movie. I don't even think that it's worth renting on DVD because you could easily download screenshots of Jessica Alba's boobies on the Internet for free.

title: If you rated this movie anything higher than a 4/10 you need counseling ASAP.
review:
Don't be fooled by all of the supposedly good reviews... That's the movie studio pimping it out, shelling out the big bucks to pay people to fill online message boards, and paying off movie critics to write good reviews. Otherwise, there's no justification for straight A's on Yahoo user reviews.

I'm a relatively liberal guy; I like horrors, and I am not squeamish when it comes to violence in the movies. But this movie was in an entirely new category of movies, one in which the directors should be ordered to undergo counseling for the public's safety. This is probably the closest thing to a snuff film marketed for mass audience. "Sin City" gives me reason to wonder if movies do help inspire Columbine-like massacres. There's a basic, predictable plot-line to the movie. 1) Woman is abused. 2) Man takes justice into his own hands. 3) Man chases down everyone involved, killing everything in his path. 4) Man murders, in cold blood, everyone even slightly involved. 5) Man tortures and removes family jewels of "bad guy." 6) Man beheads, dismembers, feeds to dog, etc. bad guy. 7) Man kills himself. (Sound familiar?)

In fact, at the end, I said "let me guess, he (the protagonist) is going to shoot himself." And he did, for no good reason...it was just predictable. The point? Squeeze as much violence into the movie as possible. In other words, violence purely for the sake of it. Not because it would add any dramatic element to the movie...

In fact, the psychological disconnect is what bothers me, it makes me wonder if this movie might actually help to brainwash people into thinking that violence (i.e. beating women) is alright. I don't mean to sound preachy; in fact, I'm not that kind of guy.

The movie glamorizes violence as the way to resolve problems. Images of clean-shaved soldiers at Abu Ghraib, or a man shooting an unarmed enemy combatant, come to mind...are we becoming a society that thinks it's OK to shoot first, and ask questions later? Don't we have any shred of decency that values human life? After seeing people walk out of the movie theater early (I, myself, would have left except that I was the driver for my group of friends), I was relieved to know that I was not the only one asking these kinds of questions.

I'm not advocating censorship; I do, however, believe in boycotting, etc. I regretted not asking for my money back, not because I couldn't sit through the movie, but because I know it's going to fill the pockets of some warp, sick, twisted, perverted, sexist, misogynists and encourage them to make more movies like this one. It's just pure, unadulterated junk, junk, junk, junk, junk!

I've been told it's a comic book story, that's how comic books are. I suppose I just don't "Get It." Sure, and what about Batman, Spiderman, and X-Men, none of which were really awful movies, like "Sin City"?

And another reason why I think this movie is for teenage boys, is because of how it portrays women. In fact, it was almost like a Harlequinn Romance novel/"chick flick" for males.

Look at all the terribly offensive stereotypes: Men with wife-beaters, leather jackets, cigarettes, beating their girls, and taking justice into their own hands. Women with skin-tight leather outfits, breasts exposed, smoking cigarettes, all beaten-up, helpless, and needing to be saved. Even the hardcore-prostitute gang ends up needing to be rescued by a man in the end...

Furthermore, the movie suffers from (in psycho-babble terms) a virgin-whore complex; meaning, if a woman isn't a virgin, then she's a whore. In the movie, if she isn't a prostitute yet, by the end of the movie she's at least become a stripper, while the guys are portrayed as all high-moral and good.

How many shots lingering on a woman's butt or breast before we get the impression the directors are objectifying women? I'm a man, and yet I was still offended! The whole thing is just so dang sexist, it makes me wonder how much society has progressed in the past thirty years.

The poor girls that I went with were traumatized, to say the least. They went home and watched Rudolph the Rednose Reindeer, because it was the most wholesome thing they could find in their apartment. It's too bad I couldn't erase the memories of last night. If you're going to see this movie, any way, stop by a Chinese restaurant first. Then, when you're leaving, take some chop sticks. That way, you'll be prepared when you want to poke your eyes out.

title: dumb violent video game movie and NOTHING more
review:
I was disappointed with Sin City. I guess I'll call this the "Kill Bill effect" because for the life of me I just don't see what people like about this video game movie. It's just perverted reality where cheesy characters you don't care about slaughter each other. That's all this "movie" is. Giving it any more credit then that just isn't warranted.

These Sin City fanatics are delusional. Sin City is nothing more then a violent video game movie. Add black and white, bare breasts, decapitations and blood to Van Helsing and what you have is Sin City.

The only award Sin City personal should qualify for is the Razzie. I haven't seen a movie this dumb or this bad since Catwoman.

title: Strictly for comic book obsessives and misogynists
review: This was a very irritating film. It was full of stereotyped macho men running around trying to help the equally stereotyped damsels in distress. Every female character in this film was without exception treated as a sexual object, and usually as a prostitute who needed a man to protect her. This is a good film for those who have no sense of reality and are ignorant enough to think that the world either is or should be about strong, powerful men protecting weak, sexualised women. Those who love the fantasies presented by comic books, who believe that people are good or bad, and who like the idea that morality is as simple as black and white, will want to watch this movie again and again. For those who are grown up and appreciate films which are more realistic and not so ignorantly simplistic, my advice is to avoid this film at all costs, because it offers nothing to the intelligent, rational-minded adult viewer.

title: Great Comic Book; Horrible Movie
review:
John Carpenter must have taken lessons from Frank Miller. Gory-er sex; bloody mess; torture, perpetual killings, decapitation and castration abound in this blood lust movie.

They tried too hard to make this 2D classic turn 3D. They failed miserably. They failed because they didn't succeed to bring the 2D characters into a 3D world - they left them 2D. Don't get me wrong - the whole story is 2D - like the movie/book = all black and white - no grays. But what they should have done is tried to create the story alive. What they did was weak. It was only a translation from one medium (2D comic book) to another (the big screen). It totally failed for me. (NOTE: the average score for this movie is an 8.4 - very high amongst the other IMDb.com movie scores. E.g. Some major classics, which you would think should be a 10, will only have an average score of a 7.0 or less!)

I think it would have worked if they actually included scenes from the comic book - if at least to remind people the origins of this work. But they didn't. Perhaps the Directory of Photography was to blame... but the Director always has the final say. All movies rise or fail with the Directors... i.e. if the Producers don't put any limits on them or on their creativity. 0 out of 10, although the lowest IMDb.com score is a 1.

Directing - OK,

Acting - stiff,

Photography - very good,

Special Effects - excellent

Story - stiff

-Zafoid

title: Sin City is a really Sh*tty City
review:
This Movie is the worst most over hyped movie I have seen in some time...

Not only was the Acting more plastic than action mans left arm, The story was thin, predictable and so badly linked together you'd think some kid had walked in off the street and last minute and put clips together of unrelated segments of film--- it didn't fit at all. On top of that I felt uneasy throughout the whole friggen movie, constantly shifting in my seat at the sickningly over the top action... I love violent movies but this just made me sick...

This movie should not have been shown in the Cinema--- it should have been shown as a form of torture in the interrogation room to get cons to "fess up". I guarantee they will spill their guts within 10 minutes... God knows I nearly did...

title: Horrific violence, worthless plot
review:
While taste in movies is of course subjective, I feel obliged to send this warning to those of you who have not yet seen "Sin City". In my opinion this was the most worthless and disgusting movie I have ever seen. It was a complete waste of two and a half hours of my life. It was horrifically disturbing and boring at the same time. I honestly cannot speak badly enough about this movie. I hated it and felt I needed to wash my soul after seeing it. Several people told me this movie was "great" so I felt obliged to send this warning.

As a caveat, I must admit the last movie I saw prior to this was the rated G "The Wild Parrots of Telegraph Hill", which I do emphatically recommend.

title: not worth the price of movie theatre air
review:
i found this movie to be absolutely horrendous, incredibly obnoxious, ill-conceived, monotonous, and embarrassing. the dialog was completely terrible, and although the film is packed with names, i argue that there is only three characters: 1. the slut who has been abused her whole life, and has now grown up tough.

2. the good guy who speaks in his action voice in every scene, and throws in a not-so-witty one-liner every two mins.

3. the bad guy who speaks in his action voice in every scene, and is repeatedly at the butt end of various not-so-witty one-liners.

perhaps the easiest criticism of this film is that it seems like a shallow 15 min idea that has been stretched into a feature length film. the visual concept, the characters, the plot, everything is trying so hard to be bada$$ that it is really just shameful. it seems that everything is interesting for about a minute, but you have to be constantly shown the same garbage torture, castration, and "kill 'em quiet" scenes over and over.

title: sin city: lesser than the sum of its parts
review: i'm utterly shocked and even a bit outraged that the general consensus is such a positive one. i mean, an 8.7/10?!?! was i the only one that walked out of the theater feeling cheated out of my 2 hours and $10? for such a dynamic cast and crew, the results were far less than the sum of its parts. the acting( moreover direction of actors) was atrocious, the story seemed really choppy and the plot was pretty much nonexistent. was there a point to this movie? something to be learned? i walked away with neither, almost wishing i had opted to watch that bernie mac movie instead. sin city was a well dressed bum. don't watch this movie.

title: weightless, and worthless
review:
Sin City is everything movies shouldn't be. It's shallow (of picture, character, and themes), monotonous, hostile to morality, witless, pointless, weightless, and worthless. Stop calling this trash cool, because it isn't.

There were certainly things that I liked (ALL the women were fabulous) but the overall tone of the movie just didn't work for me. I've seen this movie called your typical mindless video game movie. While it's certainly not typical, it certainly was mindless.

If you're looking for mindless gore, it works. If you're looking for an artistic and fun film, you'll be disappointed.

title: puts the "duh" in dumb.
review:
I hated this movie. I had no choice in watching it. A friend brought it over. Never let a friend select the DVD for movie night.

This is thoroughly immature masturbation for juvenile-minded males who want to retreat to a comic world populated by tough guys, slutty girls and stoopit violence, as if their actual transformation of the world into those things is taking too long. They exclim in superlatives over it's arty pretensions, without being able to describe a single idea; the definition of "poseur."

It doesn't surprise me that this is from Frank Miller. He seems to have a career goal of making "cool-looking" movies that peg Hollywood someplace even shallower than video games. American entertainment continues to allow man-boys to retain adolescent interests well into late-adulthood, which is just sad.

But hey, finally a role Mickey Rourke can play with his prissy, ruined meatface; a testosterone-driven freak with a visage seemingly made out of lumber. Michael Jackson is his only equal in terms of ill-conceived, recreational plastic surgery.

title: And now I feel very, very low.
review:
God I'm depressed, I don't know what depresses me more; the fact that this film was made, or the fact that so many film enthusiasts liked this movie, more than liked it, rated it very highly.

Last week I went to see Moolaade, a surprisingly uplifting story concerning female circumcision, set in Senegal. This film, written and directed by an 80 some year old African man, was a gossipy, sometimes frightening, at times a little slow, but profoundly memorable film; not only regarding female circumcision but also colonialism, power and the complex relationships between friends, within families and through out societies. Last night, I went to see Sin City.

I appreciated the art direction/cinematography, but this didn't hold my attention for long and after a while I was hardly aware of it. Sin City began at a fast pace and I didn't look at my watch during any point of the film, which is also a good sign. The violence didn't particularly bother me, I've seen loads of films that are extremely violent and though I can admit to being a bit of a girl about it sometimes, I have never been turned off a film purely because of its violence. I could mention the script was quite poor and that the characterisation was quite hammy, but I forgave these aspects early on, due to its comic book style  I wasn't looking for Anton Chekov. What really upset me, the reason why I have awarded this film one star, was the cruel and insidious streak of misogyny running through its woefully misguided core.

I know that there are those of you that say I am taking this too seriously, sure one of the heroes (Clive Owen) punches his girlfriend and apparently she finds this a turn on but "Hey, it's a comic book  it's not meant to be Fried Green Tomatoes". You see, I don't agree, I found this a bit disturbing. There is also that bit where a 50 something year old man saves an 11 year old child from a paedophile only to find sexual reward in her arms 8 years later, now that she is a vacant, plastic 19 year old. Maybe I'm just being a bit touchy, but I don't think so. Considering that my favourite film ever is South Park the Movie, Bigger, Longer, Uncut you wouldn't think I was so easily offended. I've even enjoyed films depicting female humiliation  I thought In the Company of Men, was an incredibly insightful, if harrowing film.

What became disturbingly apparent to me were the mounting associations between violence and sex and a painful plot driven by a fear of women and answered by retribution's physical violence. The violence is not just tolerated at times it is frighteningly celebrated. You may say that the old city prostitutes are portrayed as powerful and vicious but they too are drawn into the camera's voyeurism of women subjected to violence (the Clive Owen bitch slap).When not being portrayed as sexual objects they are terrifying, soulless characters or morally circumspect characters. The serial killer decapitating beautiful prostitutes was not there to scare us but intended to titillate. The moment when the camera focuses on the little Nancy in the grasp of a sexual predator is dark and edgy while the scenes where young adult Nancy is being whipped by the same predator are lovingly fleshed out by the camera. Even Brittany Murphy's beating by evil ex-boyfriend is powerfully sexualised. I'm not so stupid as to pretend that male/female relations are not tinged with the struggles of power and that they shouldn't be explored but I don't expect them to be manipulated in such a women-loathing way and then paraded as harmless, if explicit, fun. You may argue that the heroes were also beaten, punched and degraded but they are portrayed as heroes and winners (troubled and misguided but still heroes) and not, more often than not, victims.

This film is pure and absolute fantasy. Admittedly film is often fantasy, that's what we really want to see: something that is a form of escape from the pressures or tedium of reality. What I would like to know is - if the brutalisation of women is a fantasy that so many people can happily cope with, how would they feel about watching the fantasy of a white supremacist stringing up a black person? Would we watch this as happily? I don't think so.

title: Sin City VS Labyrinth
review: No film in the last ten years has more impact than labyrinth, I made quirky films like this in media school so I no what I'm talking about. David Bowie tells it like it is, how can you beat a master story teller like that, especially when he turns into an owl at the start, man that is so cool! Tell me Sin City fans how can you justify rating this film over the fantastical splendour that is Jim Hensons Labyrinth? And then there's the super smart fox that rides the dog and the bog of eternal stench and Bluto man what about Bluto, ain't he the biggest gayest gingerest hero known to man. Think about it, all Sin City is is some old black and white movie like Casablanca or Sound of Music or something.

title: Overly violent, sexist garbage.
review:
I have not read Frank Miller's comic books that this was based off of (though I was told this was a pretty faithful rendition and he codirected) so these comments are only about the movie (though they may apply to the comics as well).

Let me just get the positive comments out of the way. I liked the style of the movie. The black and white with just touches of colors was very nice. The old film noir style feel, with the old cars, the cheesy dialogue, the references to "broads" and "dames" was all pleasing. Even as I found the constant violence off-putting I was still able to appreciate small touches, like the fact that the blood ran white.

Unfortunately, the rest of the movie is crap. I was just dying to get out of there, so it seemed endlessly long. I should have known there were going to be problems when I saw Robert Rodriguez (having unfortunately suffered through Dusk to Dawn) and Quentin Tarantino (who I feel is a derivative hack) in the credits. Both seem to like to show excessive violence just for shock value. (Don't get me wrong, I don't have an automatic aversion to violence, I like John Woo films - i just don't like the lingering shots of needless/gory violence.)

IMO, the film has three MAJOR flaws, all dealing with the idea of gender. The flaw is that the film is misogynistic - women are nothing but sexual objects and victims. The second (relating to the first) is it's portrayal of men as the rescuers of women. Third, the portrayal of a girl/old man "love" story.

***Spoilers start here***

First problem: Every woman in the film was a whore, a stripper or a woman of loose morals. Even when the men worshiped them as "angels" it was always merely for their physical appearances. And yes, the men weren't all that great themselves, but there was still a wider ranger of character than just sexual object. Furthermore, the women were constantly naked or nearly naked. Even the social worker had to be shown naked. Once again, I don't mind nudity, if it fits the story, if it's tastefully done and if it's both sexes. However in this case, it seemed to be there just because the directors liked to show female T&A whenever possible. There was no male nudity (of course).

Secondly, most of the men in the film (all the main characters) seemed to operate on the assumption that they were rescuing women. Women were helpless (sexual) objects that had to be rescued from serial killers, serial rapists, abusers, pimps, etc. Needless to say there was a disturbing amount of violence against women shown. Even when the film pretended to make a nod towards "empowered women"- they still failed and had to be rescued. For example, the stripper girl needed a 68 year old man to help her; an entire town of armed whores still needed one man to save them; and delusional psychopath goes on a killing rampage to avenge his "love" after a one night stand with a hooker.

Which brings me to the third problem, the incredibly disgusting relationship between the 19 year old and the 68 year old. Now, Harold & Maude is one of my favorite movies, so even though the age difference is disgusting to me, clearly I can overcome that natural revulsion when presented with the right couple/circumstances. Apart from the usual grossness of old men preying on young women, the whole relationship was disturbing. We have a 60 year old cop save an 11 year old girl from rape and gruesome torturous death. The cop is abandoned by everyone, goes to jail and only the girl stays true to him. He clings to her image of innocence and makes her into some sort of ideal image to obsess over. When he is released 8 years later, he goes to find her and make sure she is OK. Where it becomes truly disturbed is when he finds out that she is now a sexy stripper and they decide they are in love. This is a highly inappropriate and sick relationship. She's 19, he's 68. They know nothing of each other (or we can at least presume he thinks he knows her because she wrote him letters - but she knows nothing about him). Shis is clearly suffering from hero worship because he rescued her. He's clearly focused on her as the one last good thing he's done and loves the idea of her as a little girl/and then later as a sexy stripper. It was so revolting I wanted to puke in the theater.

...and they wonder why women comprise a smaller percentage of comic book readers.... maybe if they stopped putting out this kind of sexist crap, we could get into it more. Until then I will continue to avoid this kind of crap and focus on graphic novels that provide *clothed* characters that are not 1 dimensional with a strong plot that does not rely merely on the shock value of graphic violence.

I suggest you avoid this movie and do not pay money to reinforce the notion that these are the kind of comic adaptations we want to see.

There are WAY better noir films out there, fairly good comic book adaptation; WAY better violent films and tons of other T&A movies to watch instead!

title: Should have stayed 2 dimensional
review:
How this movie ever got green-lighted, let alone how it got into the top 250 here, is something I'll never understand. I liked the graphic novels, but they were so dependent on text to tell the story that it was difficult to imagine how they would translate into moving pictures. The answer, of course, was voice overs...which are pretty much always a bad idea even when used sparingly. Here they make up at least a quarter (and possible as much as a half) of the entire dialog of the film, and for the most part are breathtaking in their banality. If I ever hear the phrase "Come on, old man" or anything else like it in a voice-over again, it will be far too soon.

I suspect that people are caught up in the stylistic cinematography, and it is very different and very interesting. It is both noirish and also gives the feel of the comic book roots of the project better than anything I've ever seen. But in the end, the voice overs destroy any good will that the ugly beauty of the camera-work builds up and the lackluster plots finish off any thoughts about ranking the movie above average. In the long run, Sin City will probably fall out of the top 250 in the same ignominious fashion as Titanic (another film that got by on hype and style rather than substance), which was rated #1 for a long, long time. It just bothers me that such a mediocre film could be so much higher than, say, Jaws. They didn't use a voice over to tell us why Quint hated sharks, and that's why it's a classic and why Sin City will be a forgotten curiosity.

title: In The Land Of The Polymorphous Perverse, Sin City Reigns
review: Sin City is the title for a series of stories by Frank Miller, told in comic book form in a film noir-like style. Sin City the movie is based on the comic book series by the same name. For those for whom Sin City would seem nothing more than a glorification of torture, mutilation, and murder, this is due to Miller's penchant for Ero-guro, a genre of Japanese pornography and hentai involving blood, gore, disfigurement, mutilation, urine, enemas, etc.. Miller began to infuse his comics with darker themes and stories heavily influenced by Japanese manga strips during the early 1980's. Sin City is his most notable tribute to this form of Eroguronansensu, lit. meaning erotic-grotesque-nonsense. Oddly, the movie seemed just another of Hollyweird's attempts at castration as vengeance. I suppose 90 minutes of continuous rape where no retribution is attained wouldn't get the thumbs up from Ebert? Personally, I would rather my kids were perusing the internet for the usual porn rather than watching this stuff. Each to his own.

title: The destruction of a good comic
review:
I own Sin City in its original comic book form. All the episodes. And I can't believe how something that nice can be destroyed so thoroughly.

Not only doesn't the comic form fit the movie screen but the sets and actors used are horrible. The CGI is dull and lifeless. Where Miller could draw a stark scene in a few outlines Rodrigues copies it perfectly to the big screen with the result of making it totally unlike the original. It is not possible to copy the aesthetics of still images to motion pictures. The two formats rely on too different premises.

And the actors chosen to fill Millers comic book outlines have managed to do just that - outline the characters without ever making them credible. The acting, with a notable exception of Mickey O'Rourke as Marv, is as dull and lifeless as if showing static comic images on the screen.

Ad to this the fact that Rodrigues has somehow managed to turn the strong women in Millers fiction into cringing damsels in distress and you've got an unappealing paste of bad clichés in a humanity- and female-hating form.

title: Not for the feint of heart
review:
The good - Very stylish, well shot, high production values. The art direction was great and although it really does not break any new ground, it is certainly way above average for cinematography and style The photography is very crisp.

The bad - Too much pointless violence, not enough plot. I sat there waiting for something to happen, often in vain. Lots of action took place on the screen, but it seemed to be more of the filler type of action and did not advance the story. For example, a woman hold up her hands in surrender. The bad guy (and I use the term very loosely) empties his machine pistol into her. Cut to a silhouette of him emptying his machine pistol into her. She falls to the ground, and he empties his machine pistol into her corpse. As if she could be any more dead. All her death did was give the hero the chance to sneak up on the bad guys - but not all the different camera angles and two magazines worth.

Violence in this movie is like sex in a porn film - hold tenuous plot elements together. Contrast this movie with Kill Bill vol 1, which is very violent and stylized, but is effective and entertaining.

The dialog is also pretty bad. I like people to talk like people would - even in highly stylized movies like film noir, the dialog needs to seem natural. But the dialog here seems to be stilted and unreal in the mold of a George Lucas script, though the director is good and gets better performances than in Star Wars 1&2.

Other aspects of the movie I am cool with. No one is really good, everyone seems to be a sadist, kinda like the film noir atmosphere.

But the production values just cannot make up for the lack of plot and lousy dialog.

title: Style over content cause much disappointment
review:
An awful film which i was utterly disgusted with. The rating for 3 comes from the beautiful graphic film work, the style is identical to the comic book. Though I'm not sure if this is a good thing or just laziness on the part of Robert Rodriguez. However, as the comic book was meant to be similar to the film noir detective films of the 1950's the film comes across as taking the mickey out of this rather than an homage.

Since this seems to be what the film concentrates on the direction and the acting is catered to this and comes across as hammy and ludicrous

Though i thought the novel was good enough i don't think the extreme violence from the comic strip worked well in film. The violence seemed comedic, unnecessary and over dramatic. However the worse part of this film is its treatment of women. Once again, though the treatment of women is taken directly from the comic book it doesn't translate well on to film, coming across as much more offencive and vicious than before.

Possibly worth a watch if you can ignore the insistent machismo and excessive violence for the stylish use of colour.

title: Pointless Noir
review:
I got bored, there is some novelty value in the heightened Noir from being mostly black and white (with no greys) and the stylised direction.

It is not a great, or even good movie... there is hype without substance.

The characters are beyond comprehension, empathy is not possible, nor is understanding the motivation for any of the characters to carry out the actions they do. There is nothing engaging here, except perhaps for the truly juvenile.

Successive scenes of extreme violence that each have no meaning eventually merge into waiting for the over stylised movie to end, which it eventually does.

The violence is meaningless in two ways, the first is that the characters are seemingly invincible and keep going forever, making the violence of each character impotent, and the second that there is never a motivation for any of it.

There is nothing in this movie to engage the viewer. It is probably a movie for people who like comics.

Having read the review here, and chanced upon the comic in a bookstore, I understand that it is a close reproduction of a comic, I am not sure why that would make it a good movie...

title: Sin City piles on the sugar...
review:
(Max Payne + Queens of the Stone Age "Go With The Flow" video + film-noir + violence) x Frank Miller = Sin City

Easy viewing fans need not apply. This film was certainly not what I had expected - being a fresh latecomer to this one, free from reading reviews, hearing hype-talk and seeing promos (in fact, all I saw was the poster designs) - I really went into it without any real idea as to where it would go (the reason I mention this is because this rarely happens with me, and if you can, go into it the same way -- ironic, seeing as you're still reading this now). Set in Basin City, the film is made up of 3 Frank Miller novels that loosely interlink with one another in a kind of chronological fashion, mixed with a hint of Pulp Fiction (see, you're still reading this). I hadn't read any of these novels beforehand, but having looked up the content of each book (the script as well as the illustrated frames) the film itself stays extremely true to the original in every way. I can imagine Frank Miller fans loving this film regardless, so if you've read the books, this review isn't for you. The mood itself takes film noir to new depths: and I was surprised at the heavily stylised Basin City being one of the more sinister locations I've seen on film as I didn't think the film had it in it (anyone who has seen Dark City will also relate): in fact, you literally never get to see the light of day during the whole picture (not a good idea to watch this with a reflective TV screen next to window in mid-afternoon). This, though, only lends itself to the equally dark storyline and superb lighting effects that make it intense viewing, bordering on illustrative (remember the novels). The CGI effects, make-up, costumes, prosthetics, stylisation and moody voiceovers also push this to it's outer limits, further than any other comic-come-film has gone. Stylised violence, loud sound effects, big muscles, bigger guns, dominatrix queens and lots of death and revenge - the storyline certainly knows how to get itself noticed (rating this film R was probably the easiest job the ratings office must have ever had) and taken from that point of view this film gets a 10 out of 10. The film's general mood is certainly pulled off by both director and actors throughout, and the big Hollywood stars don't disappoint. So, why a 6 out of 10? Well, as a rule of thumb, I extremely dislike anything that is an excuse to use brilliant aesthetics tapped to a much weaker idea - and there is most definitely a lot of that here. I couldn't shake the feeling that it was a film about violence for the sake of violence. The novels, themselves, can been seen as a separate item in this respect - they are what they are. However, the film differs in the sense that it most definitely falls in love with itself all the way through. It feels like it's more than it is, when in reality it is a brilliant storytelling idea and aesthetic doused in gruesome violence, iconic characters and slick anecdotes all chained to the location in which it is set - nothing much more than that. Although it never tries to be a realistic depiction (in fact, it is the original stylisation that does give it some emotional substance in my opinion); the fact that one story, for example, is entirely based around a man set out to get revenge on a cannabalistic killer who eats a hooker he met that very night ("killing his way up the food chain" as the film openly states) makes me think: what's the point? I got the point after about half an hour, the other hour and a half is just filling the holes and finishing the tale, not showing me anything new or giving me something to take away.
