All of the actors were great in portraying their tough-as-nails characters. The standouts, though, were Owen and Benecio Del Toro (who was also in "The Big Fat Kill"). They're just the coolest characters, played by two of the best modern actors. Their standout scene is the scene that Tarantino directed, with the two of them in a car. That scene can basically sum up the whole movie. It's absurd, violent, weird, and absolutely bloody fantastic.

My rating: 9/10 Rated R for sustained strong stylized violence, nudity and sexual content including dialogue.

title: Absolute Vanity
review:
Sin City is a worthless film. I had high hopes for this film. The cast looked impressive, I like the director, and I had heard good things about the movie.

But this film is a series of senseless violence. There is no purpose or moral to the story. For that matter, there is no story. Two thirds of the film have no point, other than to show those two characters sitting beside one another at a bar.

It has no hero. Everyone is evil. Honestly, my time would have been better spent if I had watched an old Friday the 13th film.

This is one of the first bad reviews that I have ever written. But like the pathetic Hannibal from the late 1990's, Sin City fails miserably.

I would not suggest this garbage for anyone.

title: Amazing Experience!!!!!!!!!!!!
review:
I just saw this movie and maybe it's one of the greatest i've ever seen .. it's amazing, everything from the strong representations of the strong characters from the comics, to the rich environment and visual effects.. it's a movie worth of have in your personal collection, 'cause it's so seamless to the comic, that seems like the pages turned live... so as the comic you will barely get tired of see it...

to the fans of the series maybe it will be a dream come true to see such a great representation of the strong, power, perversions, beauty.. and all of the great personalities and complexities that Miller gives to his heroes and heroins..

to the not so fans or totally newbies.. it will represent a movie to become one..

What the directors do on the screen it's something never do so well, early intents like Captain sky, and others lack the greatest imagination and technical support and development that the directors have in this one... maybe this will be and instant classic and reference point for the movies that will be do on comics from now on.. moreover it must be..

The acting it's very very well done.. Rourke (Marv),Willis(Hartigan) and Owen (Dwight) do an spectacular job giving' life to three of the most representatives characters.. and the girls too do a great work..

definitively this is a MUST SEE and MUST HAVE movie..

title: I film that is different
review:
I went to watch this movie based on hype. I had no idea Sin City used to be a comic. People posted some links about the trailer of this movie, so I watch the trailer, and i was like wow, this is different, so i went to watch the movie.

Spoilers plot: I'm a big believer in a good plot, no matter how bad the movie, a good plot could win me over, I didn't like the plot of this movie. I didn't know that this movie would split into 3 plots. I thought Bruce Willis was the main character throughout the movie, but he was not. So at the end of his scene, I was like, where did he go? And i thought in the second plot, the guy was still Bruce Willis, but he was not, i don't read the comic, so I had no clue. The film then splits into two more separate plots before returning to Bruce Willis plot. I'm thinking this was done to show what Sin City was like through three different views through three different people how bad Sin City is. One things I don't understand was, look, i know its a comic though, but why does some guys get shot 15 times, and nothing happen to them, while some get hit once and there dead. And why is he hurt by gunshot on some scenes and seems to be immune to gunshot on other scenes? This includes some of the main characters, some scenes, they get right up after being shot. Oh yeah, one of the other strange things that bother me, was the characters saying cheesy lines, like, "i'll get em for you, i'll get em good" maybe not exactly those words, but there were a lot of those lines in the movie, for comic relief? i don't know.

Acting: The acting was OK I guess. I felt the guys did a pretty good job. The girls in the movie didn't real do anything for me, especially Britney Murphy, Alexis Bledel, it just didn't seem right.

Sound: Well, its hard to comment on this, seeing that most of the sounds were from gun fire, the visual effects made up for it I guess. The trailer for this movie was done nicely with music.

Visual effects: My comments have been pretty tough on this movie, but I still gave the movie 5 stars because, I felt the movie showed some nice visual effects. Its different to see a black and white film, with all these film these days from Disney and Pixar showing you all these vibrant colors. Color is added to certain objects in this movie only to add to the scene, which i felt looked pretty cool.

title: Overrated
review: Man... after reading all the reviews from fellow spectators as myself. I was pretty disappointed in this film. I mean.. an average of 8 stars out of 10? Come on.... The movie made no sense! No connection between any of the characters. I was starting to fall asleep. And people keep saying that the action/violence of this film was so great(as in a lot) obviously haven't seen a good hong Kong film like "Fulltime Killer". There was even no REAL connection between the 2 killers. And the best actor of the whole movie I thought was King Arthur. Pretty bad I think. Jessica Alba wasn't even in the whole movie!! Come on.... It's like putting a big oil rig on the cover of the movie for Armegeddon instead of meteor. I give it 4 stars out of 10.

title: Childish comic book... Childish movie
review:
Visually fantastic? You betcha, and unfortunately, that's about it. The characters are all virtually interchangeable; all the men are clichéd sociopaths whose only real function is protecting women, who are by the way, all portrayed as half-naked sluts. Make no mistake, this stuff comes straight from the fevered masturbatory fantasies of your average 14 year old.

This isn't necessarily even the fault of the film makers, it comes about naturally from following so closely to the comics. Unfortunately, slavish devotion to an already adolescent comic book does not equal quality. All the dialog is kept intact, and while it may read alright coming off the page, when you have real people saying these lines out loud it becomes downright silly.

title: At least I didn't slit my wrists in the theater
review:
I was conned into hitting the matinée by a buddy and this is where we landed. Boy, if ever I should have came to IMDb and caught a trailer, this would have been the time to do it. I was almost ready to curl up and take a nap in the theater when the hot, albeit black-and-white, girls started showing up. Had it not been for them, I would not have been qualified to write a review of the film. The acting was not very good, the plot was very 1940's. Yadda yadda yadda.... booorrrrr-iiiinnnggggg.

And now for the down-side to the flick: booorrrrr-iiiinnnggggg. I guess there were some comics along the lines of the movie or something? If the movie followed very closely to the comics, the comics had to have been pretty bad.

Well, at least I was only robbed of $6.75 instead of the $8.75 for evening shows. Either way, that little snippet of my life is gone and there is no way to recover it. And to think I was going to spend the morning cutting myself while shaving - this was so much better. Gag-choke-hak! Now where did I put my cyanide???

title: Tails of the City
review:
I love the film Noir of the move; the characters were interesting however the movie as a whole could not keep my interest. There were many good story lines (that I wanted more detail on) but they were not used to their full potential. The choppy story line felt like I was watching it on DVD on fast forward, leaving out the foundation and substance of the story lines. This movie would have been better if they would have focused on fewer characters leaving room for a possible trilogy if wanting to go that route.

The acting was bad due to poor direction, at times the actors/actress' seem to look confused as to where they should be focusing their skills toward. I would have to compare much (not all) of the acting in this movie to be that of a low budget no name B movie. Many minute details where over emphasized leaving some of the more important details to be lost in the shadows.

I was very disappointed with the movie, I can handle slow but the lack of dialog, direction and substance made this a movie that I would only recommend seeing on cable or at the dollar theater.

title: 3 1/2 out of 10
review: This movie is at the very least a half-hour too long. The multiple plots are unbalanced and I had little desire to put the pieces of the stories puzzle together. Midway through the movie I was hoping it would end quickly. I turned to a friend sitting next to me and said, "This move refuses to end." The voice-overs for the most part are monotone and dry. Yes the visuals are superb, maybe even unparalleled, yet it seemed as if the rest of the films elements took a back seat and the audience thrown out the window. A stellar cast could not save this movie, especially when those actors were not in peak form (Rosario Dawson and Clive Owen to name a pair). I really wanted to like this movie. I grew up a fan of comics and I'm a fan of some of the Tarentino style films (Pulp Fiction and Kill Bill). However, 10 minutes into the movie you get past the awe inspiring visuals and ask the movie to deliver more. In my humble opinion, it simply does not. It's a film that takes itself too seriously. It doesn't waste a chance to pat itself on the back. It thinks it's full of poetry when it is not. It assumes that people want to connect the dots and that they will be drawn into its dark characters. I simply did not care. I love great anti-hero's (The Stranger by Albert Camus). These guys, though, do not fall into that category. Lastly, what was the deal with the Nazi symbols? I'm not Jewish, but I was bothered by them. Whoever's idea it was, it simply didn't add anything to the movie other than have me think about the holocaust during the movie. Also, the film would have benefited form some of the cynicism towards the church around the time of the sex scandals rather than a period when the whole world is praising the recently deceased Pope. Unfortunate timing. I only mention this because I saw some people walk out. I also wanted to bail, but not because institutionalized religion gets linked to the world of sin (actually much deserved) but because the only corner I wanted to turn in Sin City was one leading out.

title: Overrated, Over-hyped, and Underdressed
review:
Though visually stunning, Sin City left me quite unsatisfied when I left the theater and I couldn't figure out why. After extensive thought and contemplation, I think I know what's wrong with the film.

Good things in Sin City: Cinematography, visual style, music, Elijah Wood(very good in one of the creepiest rolls ever), Clive Owen.

Okay things: The basic idea of the movie, the set up, the idea of the city.

Bad things: The actual plot, the characters, anything that Frank Miller actually wrote down or drew. The man needs to see a psychiatrist, pronto. He's a pervert obsessed with nearly naked women and grotesque mutilations.

I really think that if anyone other than Frank Miller had taken the good and okay stuff, they could have turned it into a really great movie.

In the end, Sin City is only the indulgence of a man in sexual fantasies and childish dreams of overblown games of cops and robbers. Acting: 7/10 Visual: 9/10 Plot: 5/10 Character Development: 1/10(the downfall of the film!)

Overall: 5.5/10 See it if you can get a cheap ticket, are 15 years or older, and easily amused, but not disgusted.

title: Easily the best yet of 2005
review: Never before has a movie captured such action and style in the way that Sin City did. The visuals were both stunning and original. Sin City featured great acting from Bruce Willis, Clive Owen, Benicio Del Toro and Mickey Rourke. Each actor makes you forget any other character that they ever played. Bruce Willis became Hardigan and Clive Owen made me forget his sex-a-holic doctor from Closer as he became a great former criminal. This may slightly lend itself to the great vision laid down by Rodriguez and Miller. The 'Pulp Fiction' like story was fantastic and made me want to read some of Frank Miller's work. The film kept me grinning and jaw-dropped throughout with some witty humor showcased by Rourkes' character and also Del Toro's character (whom in one scene, while Owen drives, is a talking corpse that resembles a "human pez dispenser" and flip-flops voice tones as his head rolls around his shoulders). Another great aspect of the film which some people may find a flaw would be the unmerciful violence, but this makes the film a great 'guy movie' and added to my personal enjoyment of the film. Amazing work here from Rodriguez and Miller.

title: A finely crafted piece of garbage.
review:
With the most appropriate movie title in recent memory, "Sin City" is likely to be divisive among moviegoers, and more interestingly within a moviegoer. Rarely has such a dichotomy existed between technical prowess and moral & narrative bankruptcy.

"Sin City" is an anthology of three stories set in the noir-ish, crime-riddled metropolis of Frank Miller's graphic novels (he also co-directed). Each segment has its own storyline with unique characters, although they do transpire simultaneously in the same space, running roughly parallel rather than criss-crossing. This gives the movie a fractured and episodic nature that limits its overall narrative power, inexplicably dragging despite its breakneck action and pace.

Shot by jack-of-all-trades Robert Rodriguez in sumptuous black-and-white, high-definition digital video, the movie was done largely in front of green screen, with flashes of color and cityscapes that are primarily CGI meshing seamlessly with the live action to produce some of the best and most pervasive visual effects ever seen. In the process, the sheer visceral look of the picture entrances, as each shot seems worthy of being frozen and hung on a wall due to the slightly out of kilter comic-book style framing. This careful craftsmanship and attention to detail plunges the audience so deep into an alternative world that it's almost enough to distract from the complete absence of any moral compass. Almost.

As fantastic and jaw-dropping as the visuals are, the principles of "Sin City" are equally heinous, emphasizing the dark side of the monochromatic world. There are no white-hat heroes, and even the protagonists are villainous. The only remotely good character is Bruce Willis's detective, who would fill the "bad cop" role in most worlds. But his aggressive approach, which is not by the book to say the least, falls on the tame end of the the movie's violent methods spectrum, which combines the bloodiness of "Kill Bill" with the brutality of "The Punisher". I can sometimes accept such actions if the motives are somewhat pure (the relatively justifiable homicides of either aforementioned movie for instance), but such motives here are minimal at best and predominantly non-existent.

Don't get me wrong. I don't necessarily require high morality out of my movies. I'm not demanding the pure motives of Frodo or Atticus Finch, but give me something to latch onto, some semblance of a moral reference point. Someone like Kevin Bacon's flawed but justice-seeking cop in the murky crime drama "Mystic River", which was based in a right-and-wrong world even as it portrayed a darker side. Even a sliver of ethics will do, but there is nary a sliver to be found in "Sin City". Even people who are "supposed" to be good are likewise black-hearted. Without any sort of orientation, the movie stumbles over itself throughout. I realize that is the nature of the source material; and I accept that, commending Rodriguez and Miller for their cinematic vision, while simultaneously reeling from the depraved soul of the books.

With a cast of familiar names and faces that you can't count using your fingers and toes, the acting of "Sin City" is...well, it's there. No one except perhaps the disappointing Michael Madsen (who apparently thought he was still on "Tilt") detracts from the film, but no one is given much opportunity to supply good work either. Most of the parts are virtually interchangeable, requiring merely an attractive stone face. The casting and appearance are therefore all the more praiseworthy, as image overrides and dwarfs character development. Fortunately the celebrity never distracts from the movie, but rather produces an aura of respectability in what would likely have been regarded as an awful B-grade flick without such star power.

Despite my major ethical issues, I still find myself getting juiced whenever I espy artwork from the film. It looks that good. But I still don't recommend it. The bifurcated "Sin City" excels in every technical aspect, but the heart is cold, and the story is shattered.

Bottom Line: Like Snow White's polished apple, "Sin City" gleams on the outside, concealing a rotten core that ultimately disheartens and disappoints. 6 of 10 at best, exclusively for technical merit.

title: Too Long and too much violence towards women
review: Took my 15 and 17yr old sons to see this thinking it was supposed to be this wildly creative movie. Towards the end I was squirming and wishing for it to be over. The younger one enjoys violence and so was happy most of the way but even he was ready for it to be over, it was just overboard violent with very little storyline. Older son was bored with it and when we left we both agreed that if anyone asked us what it was about we really couldn't tell them. I'm not a sensitive type, but wow, there was a lot of violence towards women in this flick. Very degrading to women. I noticed interestingly that there were only 2 women total in the whole theater. Hmmmm.

title: Save your money unless you are a fan.
review: While Sin City is pretty eye candy, it is a total waste of time and money unless you are a Frank Miller fan and follow the comic book series. There is nothing to draw the audience in. It has some of the worst acting I've seen to date. Don't make me go off on Britney Murphy's "acting". Bruce Willis need to be less wooden. The ladies are just there to be flash in the pants. I can't believe the caliber of actors in this movie would agree to do such dribble nonsense. All you have to do is read the other reviews to know that only fans like the movie and pretty much all others walked out. I wished I had too. So if you value your time and money, rent or buy Spiderman.

title: A beautifully violent, energy charged masterpiece of cinema.
review:
Of course, there are millions out there who would disagree, saying it's too violent and foul. But, if u look at it for what it is, it's more than just and . The (in most cases) is actually very beautiful. Most of the is actually white, because of the color scheme. And the

, among other things, is never gratuitous or , even if it does involve lady's of the evening. The acting, at first seems, odd. When the comic book lines flow from Bruce willis' mouth in his first scene, you are almost embarrassed. It sounds awkward and clunky. But, as the movie progresses, and everyone talks this way, it just seems right. The movie also takes you through a wide range of emotions. From romance, to excitement, to sickened, to horrified. The use of color is clever and amazing. If I had to describe this movie in one word, it would be, crazy. The action is over-the-top and the decapitations are oddly beautiful. Some of the villains are seemingly normal, but some are crazy, ic and disturbing. This is one of the most beautiful, well acted, well directed, and well casted movies I have ever seen. It also is almost frighteningly close to the graphic novels that it is based on.

title: Incredible! Fan of graphic novel & now fan of the film
review:
I had the misfortune to read several critics reviews of the movie before going in to see it and I was a bit worried. I heard things like bad dialogue, poor special effects, and too much violence. I had feared that perhaps, even though Frank Miller partially directed, that the movie would not stick to the graphic and well-written comics of the Sin City series. Why did I ever doubt!?! This movie was fantastic! First off, it's style is original and bold with a huge lot of characters performed by A-list actors that are well cast. Bruce Willis the best in my opinion although I suspect many moviegoers will choose Mickey Rourke's Marv as their favorite. There are no blurry CGI effects like you see in Star Wars and the most recent Sky Captain & the World of Tomorrow. Yes, you can see it's CGI, but it's only noticeable because it's supposed to look like the comic book - not real life. Rodriguez makes sure it's bold and bright and I give him major credit for pulling it off. My fiancé, a graphic designer, raved about the amazing shadow work - something I've never heard him do in the recent CGI films of the past few years.

As for those who dislike the dialogue I counter it was simply sticking to the source material. I would also say if you're unfamiliar with film noir you may be left cold. I am a fan of old Bogart films so I thought the wording was perfect. Sin City doesn't take place in modern day Earth - this is a dimension all to itself and it was written to be very detective-novel-esquire.

As for the violence, it's all there from the novels. I have to give Rodriguez props again for sticking to the source material and steering away from a cheesy 'Hollywood' ending. I loved every minute of the action.

Finally, this movie is a great film for the new anime female generation. The women of Sin City are amazingly strong and when I first read the graphic novels when I was in college I thought it was some of the best female characterizations I'd ever read. I'd say if you're a girl and hesitant to go see it, don't. It's portrayals of women are about a hundred times better than any of the more recent 'sci-fi' genre films.

I can't wait to see it again.

title: I mean.....WOW!
review:
Sin City really delivers. This is by far one of the best and original film i have seen in a very long time. I had all ready reed the issues from Frank Miller and i all ready loved the idea of a place like Sin City already then. The movie is just as good as the comic, and Sin City is really alive on the movie screen. I have to take my hat of to all the actors who did a job very well done. The way the film looked is the thing i was most impressed by, they captured the very essence of Sin City.

So go see Sin City, it don't matter if you reed the comic a hundred time or not at all. It work very well either way.

10 out of 10.

title: What?
review: When I saw the trailer for this movie I thought it looked kind of interesting, but when I saw the movie, I was so confused through out the whole thing that I almost left the movie theater. I am not a comic book reader, I have never even heard of the comic Sin City. I was not impressed with this movie, I was bored, it was long, very gory, and to many characters to remember and remember there stories. The acting was OK but not great Bruce Willis, Jessica Alba, and Rosario Dawson did a pretty good job, but it wasn't that great. If you know the Sin City story and are a fan I think you would like it, but I didn't. I do have to say though this movie probably was the most like a comic book I have seen.

title: The Mahs Bahs Review
review: Going into this movie, I had never seen, read, and barely heard of the comic "Sin City". After seeing this movie, I may just become a fan. "Sin City" sticks out among the poor to semi-poor rash of comic book movies over the past couple of years. While movies like "The Hulk", "The Punisher", and the X-Men series wrestle with each other in mediocrity, (and movies like "Daredevil", "Elektra", and the end of the Batman franchise wrestle for worst-ever title) this movie has outdone all in every possible fashion - including both Spiderman flicks (both of which were done very well). For starters, the movie looks like it has been drawn. Robert Rodriguez has now firmly established himself as a premier director, WHO GETS IT. Some directors may have taken a gem such as "Sin City" and decided to put their own stamp of what has been done (See: roller blading "genius" of Joel Shumacher in "Batman and Robin"). Rodriguez understood what made "Sin City" a popular comic and embraced it. This embracement ends up in long shots of the characters; quick dialog ripped directly from the comics themselves; vibrant and distinct blacks and whites; and an overall ultra-cool feel which the movie easily conveys. The cast is great, with each character matching well. Mickey Rourke has finally returned, and as it turns out his character in "Get Carter" was horribly misplaced and now has resurfaced in "Sin City". The only downfall of this movie, and it is a minor one, is Jessica Alba. Alba's beauty is unquestionable, yet I wonder if her presence is such in real life that she can continually be touted as an up-and-coming star. This roll is clearly a juicy part, same as her roll in the upcoming "Fantastic Four", and yet the girl can not act a lick. Everything that comes out of her mouth sounds as if her acting coach was Jenna Jameson. MAHS BAHS' FIVE GREAT THINGS ABOUT "SIN CITY" 1. The selected color, such as the reds and people with green or blue eyes. 2. Will go down as one of the 10 greatest movies which encourage smoking of cigarettes, (number one still being "Casablanca") 3. The Ultraviolence Kubrick could only wish he had a chance to put into "A Clockwork Orange". 4. An interesting "guest director" credit for Tarantino, and you will recognize the Tarantino-stamped scenes. 5. Carla Gugino totally nude.

title: Brilliance. Another masterpiece from one of the great artists of our time.
review:
Rodriguez has done it again. There are so very few movies made that show such a dynamic range of deep craft and passion. From the basics- story and performance- to the minutae of production design and inside jokes, this masterpiece is pure joy to watch. Films of this quality are tragically rare. The intertwining of 3 key stories from the Sin City novels was seamless. And and extra hurrah to the production of elegantly bowing out of the DGA's constraints and allowing 3 world class storytellers (Rodriguez, Tarantino and Miller) to all have their hand in the direction. With any luck, the success of Sin City will ensure that Watchmen will get made (fingers crossed- get to work Hayter, Levin and Gordon!).

Hopefully there will be a 5 hour DVD.

Thanks and praises to all who helped bring this masterpiece to the screen.

title: Best Comic based movie ever!!!
review: OK, so the first thing that i have to say is WOW!! I went into the movie not knowing much, and was just absolutely blown away. Both technically and acting wise, this movie was superb. Watching the beginning, I knew that Robert Rodriguez directed it, and was happy, for, i liked From dusk till Dawn. But sitting in the theater i was very excited when i saw that Tarantino guest directed. So, for those of you who have not seen the movie, get ready, it definitely has Tarantino flavoring. Now, if you do not like Tarantino, don't not go see the movie. He brings to the screen an artistic side of things. That being said, the plot itself is very cool. It follows the lives of three people in BAsin City. It twists from cops, to old hit men, to defending prostitutes. And it does it with flair. The movie does run long, however, it is well worth it. For in during the duration of the movie, there are many many many one liners, that will, i promise, have you in stitches. So without further ado, i tell all of you, go spend the 8 bucks to see it. It will be money well spent.

title: Wow
review: I went into Sin City with high expectations. I've been waiting 6+ months for this movie. I was blown away. The movie leaks style and coolness. The performances were top notch. Most notably Rourke as Marv. The black and white with color mixed it is just eye-popping. More often than not, I hype up a movie in my head and then, when i see the movie, are disappointed with it. Sin City was not the case. I loved every minute of it. I must caution everyone though. This might put some people off. This is the Sin City comics verbatim. This is the movie version of the comics. It's not like Spider-Man where they change a bunch of crap. The violence is like that which you'd find in a comic. Its over the top and plentiful here. I don't think there is one use of the f-bomb though. If you like movies, comics or both, Run to see this movie. RUN. YOUR NOT RUNNING! **** out of ****

title: Wow!!!
review:
This Movie was excellent. It blended three short stories by Frank Miller and put them into one heck of a movie.

The cast represented the characters in the stories wonderfully. The chose of mostly black and white made this film almost artistic.

This has become one of my favorite movies ever its a classic in my book.

I recommend this film to anyone who wants to see something great just ignore the sex stuff and watch this great film.

I would encourage everyone to see this film who's a fan of great thought provoking plots.

title: Awesome Movie...
review: I just saw this movie and it is one of the best I have ever seen! It's true to the material it is based on and makes me want more, more, more!! Why can't more movies be like this? I love some Alexis Bledel and Devon Aoki! Frank Miller, do more movies!!! The pace was quick and the style never ending. The casting was perfect especially with Mickey Rourke eating up every scene he was in. You just couldn't take your eyes off of his performance as Marv. Carla Gugino was also spot on but with limited screen time, which is understood if you have read the graphic novels. Clive and Bruce brought Dwight and Hartigan right off of the pages and I felt a compassion for them. Oh and of course Jessica Alba-- she is probably the most perfect woman on earth. Little Nancy Calahan....she grew up....she filled out...This movie my friends will keep audiences talking and wanting more for quite a while. 5 out of 5!

title: Absolutely Stunning
review:
"Walk down the right back alley in Sin City, and you can find anything", and isn't that the truth. Sin City has everything a movie goer could want in a film. It has an amazing cast that portray their gritty characters with a distinctful hard edge and compassion, which is helped with a fantastic script. The movie is driven by the actors and their ability to make the audience feel as if though they are in the characters shoes as they describe with vivid details their emotions and conflicts, and the steps they mean to take to make things right.

But it's not only a script or a great cast that makes this new tale of love and revenge come full circle, it's the images. Each scene is painted or drawn just like the pages right out of Miller's comic book that the film is based off of. The black and white makes the mood feel more dark and desolate (as it should be) making the city feel more alive. With it's splashes of color, one can only vast in it's brilliance. The visuals to this movie are unlike any I have seen and they should be recognized.

The movie follows three stories that are interwoven by the characters passions and ambitions. They live in a city of power and murder and they seek what little honor or dignity they can find in such a dark place. The film open up with a sequence with Josh Hartnett and a beautiful women glowing with a red dress and rich red lips. Hartnett's narration of his thoughts are crucial and set the tone. He explains to this woman who is on the run that he is there for her, and that it's not her figure or face, but her eyes that attract her. Her holds a lighter near her cigarette and the flame fades her eyes to green, so that we may see the beauty. He tells he loves her and there's a whisper of the gun. Sin City in a nutshell.

Mickey Rourke play Marv, a large man with a beastly looking face and temper to match. he falls in love with a woman who treats him kindly, but she is murdered and he is framed for it. Marv's quest and story in the film is to find the truth behind the murder and set things straight. Rourke does an excellent job in this movie, which was surprising to me. He brings life to a man that lives to get his answers by violently interrogating men and viciously murdering them. He does this by constantly reminding himself why he does what he does, for the woman that treated him nice.

Clive Owen plays Dwight, who gets caught up in a kill that could shake a truce that keeps young women alive. His story is a little more shallow than the others, but the element that keeps it true is his willingness to see that none of the girls are hurt.

Then there is Bruce Willis, who play Hartigan, the one honest man in the whole city. He rescues a young girl, Nancy, from the harm an lunatic pedophile (Nick Stahl). But Stahl's character is connected. His father (Powers Boothe) is a Senator and takes his anger of what Hartigan left his son out on him, by making Hartigan look responsible for kidnapping all the children his son did. Hartigan spends eight years in prison, helpless to keep Nancy safe, for it becomes his only will. When he gets out, he knows what he must do and knows that whatever it is, it must keep Nancy (Jessica Alba) safe.

Sin City is one of the best movies of the year so far. It goes beyond the expectations of any mere action film and does it well. With a great story, strong cast, and amazing visuals, it will be easy to see why this film is absolutely stunning.

Four out of four stars.

title: Visually arresting nightmare fueled masterpiece!
review: A sick beautiful thrill ride from start to finish! Packed with a marvelous cast, some of which have passed away since release. Drenched with stylized bloody violence, rain, strong men, and babes that are absolutely stunning! I love this movie it's quite a special treat not much like it made by Robert Rodriguez, Frank Miller, and masterful directed the pez sequence with Clive Owen and Benico Del Toro De. Written with the most brilliance that is delightful to hear throughout. Everything in Sin City is superb!

title: A Classic of the comic book genre!
review:
I loved this movie when it first came out, I bought the graphic novel on holiday in Italy (my 2nd language) and the dvd. However, I haven't seen it in years, and forgot how good it actually is!

Visually, this movie is perfect, more so than Kill Bill vol 1, a year earlier. Miller & Rodriguez brought the comics perfectly to life, and the cgi city is eye popping, yet still looks real.

Filmed in B&W, gives it an old school noir feel (as well as the narration) with splashes of colour thrown in for emphasises when needed.

The story and the characters are reminiscent of the noir crime thrillers, it's Grindhouse, it's VERY comic book, with touches of horror, and Marv's story arc feels like a midieval movie.

At times, the dialogue does feel a little jilted on-screen but over all, it's not an issue and doesn't take away from the movie.

All in all, this is a beautifully filmed comic book adaptation and is a much watch for anyone who likes the genre and has the stomach to handle the gore!

title: Very enjoyable noir for the digital age
review: Superbly directed by the perfect stylistic man for the job, Robert Rodriguez. Script crackles with zingers and classic noir schtick and it was hugely enjoyable the first time in 2005 and now again 15! years later.

title: a true gem
review:
All the subtlety is thrown out the window and we are left with a unapologetic beauty. almost everything is over the top, and plays perfecty with absurdist humor. its almost perfect in what its trying to be. a satire noir film with over the top drama, action and story.

8/10: what a beaut

title: Grand visual shaped
review:
What is it worth for

Film : Sin city Directors : Frank Miller Quentin Tarantino Robert Rodriguez Editing and Cinematography by : Robert Rodriguez

The film specially follows unique color processing which rendered most of the film in black and white while retaining or adding color for selected objects. Above all made this one a "Grand Visual Shaped piece"

Loved the Basin City white and black effect !

Sin City is a gloriously stylized world unlike anything you've seen before on screen.

title: Sin City
review: A pulpy and slick noir film that's easy on the eyes and heavy with the blood. Sin City is fun, it's solidly acted and it's very artistically stylized. To me, possibly the best part though is the color. The way certain things are given color in this otherwise black and white world is a treat. It's also very much rated R for blood, violence, language and nudity so if that's a problem, this probably isn't for you.

title: sin city
review: Packed with great character stories and unique and impressive visuals expecly with different style it feels like watching comic book instead reading it, only story based on nancy and callighan is little boring for me but still very impressive they were able to make something like that in a film

title: A violent-filled treasure
review:
Love that its a graphic novel come to life. The effects - beautiful. Something I love to learn and do. Find it awesome that there's no script, only the books were guides for this movie.

My most favorite part of the whole thing, is with Nancy Callahan and frank hartigan's love story. I'm happy to see how much true love they have for each other. Enjoyed it very much.

I give this movie 10/10

title: Unique Action Thriller
review:
I didn't read the comics so my review will suffer from some biases.

Loved how the movie took a different artistic approach to create a unique comic-book noir world. The action was over the top and never underused. Some parts of the story made me lose my suspension of belief.

Also, I was a bit annoyed by the plot armor that surrounded some characters...seriously, some just don't die. But I guess it's all for the sake of the plot.

I wouldn't necessarily watch this again, but I would recommend to a friend or two.

3.5/5

title: It's ok
review: Very stylish and all star cast but no substance in writing. It's still watchable and mildly enjoyable.

title: Comic book fun in live-action
review:
Everyone else gave this movie praise, so I finally decided to check it out. It's good for sure, but some of it isn't really for me. There's some gratuitous nudity and Dwight's story I actually find kinda boring. But Marv's storyline and Hartigon's is what makes this movie for me. The acting is great, the look is great, and the music is really good. As said above, this movie is so comic book, which is definitely what draws people in. It is pretty violent though. If that's not your thing, then you should skip this movie.

7.7/10 (Good)

title: Sim City
review: I thought this was a great movie. Storyline was good lots of action would have loved to seen a 3D version of this movie. I give it a ten star and it's a must-see

title: Comic Book Noir
review: A dark movie in a typical comic book, a la Frank Miller style. Full of violence and sex. A memorable, noir movie. 3 stories set in the dark, violent sin city. The second time I'm watching it. And I'll watch it a third time.

title: Comic style drama
review: It was a great stylized action adventure film without a lot of substance in the writing. Character development was lacking. Otherwise an enjoyable watch

title: Sin City (2005) Review- Is It Still Worth It, 15 Years Later?
review:
Nearly 15 years have passed since the release of the Sin City film. In this lengthy review we will analyse the film, and answer the following questions: A). "Is it a good movie overall?" B). "Is it worth watching anyway?" And C). "Has it aged well?"... Let's Begin, without spoiling much.

The film consists of three major segments. It follows a non-linear storytelling style, which is almost reminiscent of Tarantino films. The first segment follows the story of Hartigan, a cop one day away from retirement, who saves a little girl from a perverted psychopath who happens to come from the state's most powerful family, and in return gets framed and falsely accused of numerous crimes he didn't commit. Eight years later he is released, and a mysterious figure hunts him and the now-young woman he once saved for unknown reasons. The second segment is pretty much the main story of this film. It follows the story of Marv, a hulking tough guy with some serious issues, who wakes up one night after sleeping with a gorgeous woman to find her lying next to him dead and himself instantly framed for the murder. In the middle of a large conspiracy, confused and angry, Marv starts killing his way to the truth. The third segment takes place after the previous two and follows the story of Dwight, a man who attempts to aid the working girls of Old Town in hiding the body of a cop they mistakenly killed, in order to avoid sparking a war between the girls and the police. But as it seems, there are more people involved as well. And now, the verdict.

1). Let's start with the story and script. As someone who has also read the graphic novels, I say this: The books are far superior to the film. But the film is an insanely loyal adaptation. The stories are gripping, interesting and the narration describing each character's thoughts is great. The dialogues are lifted almost word-for-word from the comics, and they are brilliant even though at times corny and due to the film's style the actors delivering them might feel bland or apathetic. 8/10 2). The Heroes. The main characters are not exactly heroic, except for Hartigan of course. Dwight is deep down a white knight but also a dirty criminal with questionable ethics, and a very troubled mind. Marv has some good inside him but he's mentally ill. Definitely. They all get fleshed out well, and we come to like each one in their own story. 9,5/10 3). The Villains. The villains in Sin City are weird. And mostly just crooked rich brats who screw over the protagonists. Some shine, some don't. The writing on Frank Miller's part is really good but it could've been slightly deeper. 7/10 4). The Visuals and the Directing. As far as directing goes, Robert Rodriguez and Frank Miller did a fantastic job. Pure genius. If the film is paused at any moment, it feels like a comic book panel. That's why the characters move and behave like they do. At times though it feels more cartoony than the comics. The visuals are great too, although based on today's standards some may seem outdated. The film isn't entirely black-and-white, as some scenes feature dim, desaturated colors, which I found to be in poor taste. What's nice though is that some things purposefully maintained colorful, like blood, or a red dress, etc etc. 8/10 -So let's answer the questions.- Q: Is it a good movie overall? A: "Good" is subjective. It's all taste, really. But it's really well made and stylized and the directing as well as the writing are okay if you like this type of film. Though the cartoony manner in which many things happen in the film, such as the action and the violence, may make it hard for the viewer to take the film seriously. Q: Is it worth watching anyway? A: If you're not easily brought down by dark and depressing themes, if you're not offended by certain abbreviations, nudity and profanity, and if you have a strong stomach, I definitely recommend checking it out at some point. Q: Has it aged well? A: Some moments will look laughably bad today, some others may feel like a really good cutscene from a PS3 game. But it's still watchable, and highly enjoyable. Today's standards are very low when it comes to anything other than visuals, and this film exceeds them.

8/10

title: Some Hyper Film Noir Mythology
review:
The Foundation: Anyone who studied cinema in any capacity had to watch some of Hollywood's classic Noir films and their French origins. They always packed a punch and dropped you into an alternate reality of deadly woman, intense protagonists and murder mysteries.

Sin City is a modern caricature of the aforementioned Noir tropes and an almost roided up version of all the classic elements. Taking three different stories and protagonists this movie follows the comics to an unprecedented amount of accuracy. The Graphic Noval is essentially used as the film's storyboard, adding camera movements only when appropriate and adapting Frank Miller's harsh and brutal world and art style with such attention to detail that is rarely seen in any modern Marvel movie.

Overview: If you can handle hilghy stylized violence, extremely intense dialogues and brutal action: Sin City delivers bone cracking punches, themes and pistol shots to the dick.

If Sin City was an object it be a highly ornamented, black coated Zippo lighter. A bit of an overkill on the classic silver models of the good old days. It was designed with the same functionality of the originals but is ordained with every sharpy motorcycle buckle and is used to light both cigarettes, gas tanks and humans.

Cast: No one was payed a lot of money in this production yet everyone delivers their A game.

Mickey Rourke was born to play Marv. The half tank half gladiator of the franchise. He gives Marv such depth of character that he makes you sympathize with this hulking, bleeding husk of a person.

Clive Owen's performance might seem to be the weakest of the bunch but I believe it had more to do with being in the middle ground story of the three. Some lines are just too cheesey to be taken seriously and I can't fault the actor for doing his best with the source material.

Bruce Willis gives his last good performance, meaning that Sin City was the last film I saw this guy act. Behind the scenes Bruce explained that a few minutes after seeing the test footage Rodriguez showed he was immediately asked to be apart of the film. It's obvious he enjoyed the role and his story is what ends the movie with a punch to the gut in what is the most powerful ending of the three stories. Ending on a bitter Noir note that couldn't be more appropriate.

Every other actor gives a solid performance and as always Rutger Hauer elevates any movie he's in if even for a few short scenes.

Soundtrack: Rodriguez worked alongside some talented people to compose a dark, harsh Noir atmosphere with a rusty Saxophone and Bass guitars, the soundtrack takes you into the black and white world of Sin City and let's you feel its roughness throughout.

Summary: This film was made before the comic book revolution and its interesting to think how much better this movie could have been received today after the success of Deadpool. I'm always attracted to films that don't feel formulaic. You'd be stressed to find a more loyal adaptation of a comic/graphic book or novel. This isn't Marvel or DC, this is something else and I only wish more movies like this existed. It's truly creative and celebrates it's source material to an impeccable degree.

title: Ok
review: I wouldn't say this film deserved a sequel. Most of the points go towards great costume, set design and editing. Beyond that the acting and storyline weren't compelling

title: unique style of the film
review: Unique pictures, together with the cool old town, as well as all kinds of bloody violence in the process of revenge, constitute a unique style of the film. The story is relatively independent but cleverly connected. Personally, I don't think the second story has much to do with the other two.

title: Great concept poorly executed
review: I really enjoyed the concept of this movie I was really exited to watch it but overall I think it was a bit disappointing in the end it could have been a lot better

title: A Dazzling but Uneven Display
review: 3 April 2005. This amazing looking film attempts to introduce graphic cartoon/novels into live action and does so very successfully along with an unfortunate Pulp Fiction interplay of various independent plots that is less than successful. This raw, intensely, graphic violent film replicates in great detail the actual feel and visceral experience of a adult film noire cartoon (the best to date, setting a new level of qualitative black and white retro film-making). This is a movie with male testosterone and male honor with a big, big heart. It explodes off the screen (not page) with a punch that hits to the core. However, one wonders how much more powerful the movie would have been if it had actually followed a linear comic book line instead of interspliced scenes. The movie successfully exploits the emotional buttons as well as the over-the-top rampage of devastation that is rarely allowed on the screen R-Rated through probably deletion of the most obscene scenes (with most of it directly suggested). This movie also is reminiscent of the physical mayhem in Clock-Work Orange. Seven out of Ten Stars - could have been a complete knockout, but it threw in a few too many punches.

title: A gem in terms of visuals
review:
In a city filled with corruption, we follow a couple of stories which present some impressive characters and their acts as they try to raise and overcome their condition in order to reach a higher purpose.

It's an unique movie which has a very interesting artistic direction. Everything is presented in a cartoonish or comic-book-ish black and white with a couple of colors like a stringent red or yellow being inserted from time to time for a different contrast. Visually speaking, this one looks spectacular. I really enjoyed and I also appreciate the way things have gone in this department.

In terms of plot, things aren't so spectacular. It's a great idea to present multiple sub-stories which might even intertwine at some point but I was left the feeling that it could have been a bit better. Its characters are good, quite well thought and presented, each with their own special traits. They do a good job in maintaining the suspense and thrill while also providing a good time through the exaggerated killings and fighting scenes in which they appear, but I can't quite escape the predictability and the overall feeling of superficiality. Everything gets sorted quite easy so you don't get feel something truly dramatic, especially when you tend to expect it to go in a way or another. You do get a couple of surprises along the way though, so it doesn't follow the same tone every single time, but still... Don't get me wrong, it's not bad; even far from it. I was just left a bit disappointed by this part of the film as it isn't on par with the visuals which were simply impressive.

The cast is a big plus for this movie, almost every single actor doing a very good job in impersonating its character, thus making them credible and even likable. The dialog is ok. Nothing groundbreaking but it's good enough to tie it all up. Another plus here would be the way each character presents its situation, its state and even the events which happened.

It's a movie which left me with some mixed feelings. It had a great presentation, a wonderful visual part, very well thought and implemented, a very good cast but with a plot which wasn't on par with the other parts. I know that you might be taken away by its action sequences, by its exaggerations or by its visuals, but for me the plot is by far the most important. Thus, you have to have an equally impressive plot in order to obtain a flawless movie. It a good plot, but far from impressive.

title: Sinful not to see
review:
Now this how you do a movie in comic style
The opposite of the hulks terrible effects
Even if you don't like the story you have to at least admire how the film looks
Cool action
Badass lines
What else do ya need

title: One of the best comic book movies of all time
review: Sin City is unique in every way. The stylish violence, unusual and unique characters, great performances by the main cast as well all of the supporting actors. The stories are interesting filled with violence, sex and mystery which surely guarantees a great time all under the direction of the Frank Miller.

title: Think you need to be a comic fan...
review: I honesty felt like this was a stylish film for its time with some (at the time) A-listers but did not keep me captivated all the way through. It seemed like the focus was eye candy without the substance. Still - not a bad watch.

review:
A different non linear crime thriller with massive screenplay
#worth watching

title: Stylish, stunning and an absolute treat.
review:
Nobody ever thought that Sin City, a graphic novel by Frank Miller could ever be adapted to the big screen. It was very stylishly done, often with very little in the frame, mostly black and white with color only being added to heighten certain things. So it was considered next to impossible to do. Until Robert Rodriguez filmed a short little scene showing how it could look and the effect was immediately nothing short of breathtaking.

The city is done in tones of black and grey with harsh angles and actors digitally inserted into it. In some cases the actors, though appearing together in the scene, actually filmed their scenes solo and were just composited together later. It makes for a really interesting look. But looks aside, how good is the movie itself?

It's very well done and told through the eyes, and the voiceovers, of the main actors. You have Bruce Willis as the hard boiled cop, framed for something he didn't do, to protect a young girl. You have Clive Owen as a man protecting his girlfriend from a crooked cop. And you have, who is arguably the best character in the movie. Mickey Rourke as Marv a tough as nails bruiser who's trying to solve a murder of a woman he loved. All three stories intertwine to a certain degree.

And since it was filmed in black and white, like the comic, color is only used when necessary. Like the character of Roarke Jr a.k.a the "Yellow (word that IMDB won't let me write but refers to somebody who's parents were never married)" who is yellow through and through. Or the stunningly blue eyes of Alexis Bledel's character Becky. But the blood and the the gore? It's pure white. So those that have an aversion to it usually aren't bothered by it.

The movie was a critical and box office success which eventually led to other movies being done in the same way. But "The Spirit" and more importantly the sequel "Sin City 2" just didn't have the magic that this movie did.

title: Darkness Superb
review:
Just paying my tribute here. Frank Miller & Robert Rodriguez did really achieve a masterpiece with Sin City. A top A cast, top visuals with some iconic scenes and a nice interwoven story.

Sin City is like 300 a real masterpiece for all time, but the successors to both movies (300: Rise of an Empire or respectively Sin City 2: A Dame to Kill For) were just okay for me. That's the sad news here.

title: Excellent - 9.5
review: Terrific acting, and excessively violent. A great Rodriguez/Miller film. A must see.

title: Very dark adult comic book with phenomenal visuals.
review: First and foremost, if it weren't for the visual effects "Sin City" would be nowhere; however, the visuals are absolutely gripping. The material itself is dark. Not like new moon dark--more like 2000 feet below the earth cave dark. Frank Miller frankly paints an absurdly evil world, and I that I think he actually has pretensions of making some sort of points about actual life, but this film is far too extreme, simple-minded, and cartoonish to constitute a significant contribution to the western philosophical canon.. No matter how extreme the violence, and it's pretty awfully extreme, it has minimal emotional impact--it's pretty much like you're watching a movie, so to speak. If someone accused Miller of "toxic masculinity", I wouldn't be standing up to defend him. All of the women are so hot, you'd scald yourself just brushing up against them, and all of the guys (both good and bad) work out all of their problems with extreme violence. Not really a happy place, although I do have to say an exceptionally stylish one. The plot ties together brilliantly as the film moves along well. If it could just have been edited down around another 20-30 minutes , I would have tossed it an extra star or two. Unfortunately the unrelenting bleakness just wound up overwhelming my tender.sensibilities

title: Aptly named
review:
Plot; Three tales crisscross in the hellish landscape of the titular town.

Though my initial visit to Sin City back in 2005 left me wanting, I've always felt compelled to revisit it thanks to its reputation as one of the all-time great comic/graphic novel film adaptations. What struck me this time were not the visuals--the film's calling card--but the pace. Though it runs a touch over 2hrs., it moves at a breathless clip. And by that I mean its narrative locomotion, as it's not action heavy. Oh there's a lot of violence, but it lacks anything really approaching a traditional Hollywood action scene. The aforementioned visuals are really immersive and director Robert Rodriguez and his team--like Zack Snyder w/his adaptation of Frank Miller's 300 a few years later--do a great job of bringing the graphic novel to life.

Of the three tales that make up the film, my favorite was the one focusing on Marv, played brilliantly by Mickey Rourke. His performance here is award-worthy and his tale is the most engaging. The middle story is fine, but suffers a bit by comparison. The third tale--which is a wrap around--ends things on a strong note, w/Bruce Willis giving one of the stronger performances of his career. If I had a criticism it would be that I think it would've worked better had the action and violence not been so stylized, though perhaps that's simply in keeping w/the book, which I haven't read.

Though I felt like I needed a shower after it was over, I did enjoy this return to Sin City and I leave w/a much greater appreciation for it this time around.

title: Graphic novel masterpiece.
review: The comic-book style, the stark framing, the dialogue, the hallucinatory design and strange mix of heartless gore and choked-up sentiment are all amazing. One of a kind. All the cast are amazing. Of the three storylines I preferred the Bruce Willis (Hartigan) story arc, but the best character for me was Mickey Rourke (Marv). Out of the ladies my favorite was Devon Aoki as Miho. Carla Gugino and Rosario Dawson and Jessica Alba all outstanding. Brilliant and unique movie.

title: Very different
review: Not your normal movie. Was it good? Yes, but not epic. If I never see it again, that's just fine. Is it worth a watch once? Yes

title: Stylized, visually stunning and extensively violent comic adaptation.
review:
7.5 out of 10 for clarification.

Sin City is the heavily stylized and largely successful adaptation of Frank Miller's comic series. It weaves together the profoundly violent tales of three protagonists seeking retribution in "Basin City". The core strength of Sin City lies in it's presentation. The black and white visuals, presence of comic art and distinct cinematography and editing create a gritty, visceral noir atmosphere. Sin City is an abundantly violent film, some of which is stylized and highly effective. Additionally, the film is bolstered by a non linear plot structure and monologues delivered by the protagonists. Leads Rourke, Willis and Owen deliver compelling performances that perfectly suit their tormented roles.

title: Loved it!
review: Long time noir genre and Frank Miller fan and this one really doesn't disappoint!

title: Comic book come to life
review: Brilliantly uses black and white, with hints of color to highlight certain aspects, much like the graphic novels it's based on. It's a neo-noir film with (not quite)superheroes.. in fact even heroes might be exaggerating, since there are no "Knights in shining armor" in this. There are however badass anti-heroes and a lot of sexy dames. This movie is ultra stylish, so even the most brutal acts of violence are beautiful to watch. It's probably the closest to a comic book literally coming to life on screen we're ever gonna get!

title: Unique
review:
Sin City can be summed up in one word, unique. It really is very unique. The cinematography and nature of it all is very different. It's based on a series of graphic novels. It's a film that's told in parts, it's not all one story, rather it's many different stories all wrapped up into one crazy film.

There are many different Hollywood stars that make up the cast here. The cast includes Bruce Willis, Clive Owen, Jessica Alba, Rosario Dawson, Brittany Murphy, Alexis Bledel, Mickey Rourke, Carla Gugino, Elijah Wood... and more. I can say that i really enjoyed the acting in this film, i was impressed by the strong performances given. The characters are all broken in some way, struggling with their own issues. This movies takes place in a city that has so many violent issues, and violent screwed up characters. The police force is mostly corrupt, and there are people that would rather kill you than look at you around every corner. It's definitely another world.

The visuals are all well done for sure, the film-noir look is cool and i enjoyed that style. The violence is appropriately graphic given the kinds of people that this film focuses on and the area it's set in. The writing is fine, I personally wasn't terribly impressed by it, it's really the acting and visuals that impressed me most. There are parts I enjoyed more than others. I would say overall that this film is good and it's well made, I just personally didn't love it like most do.

7/10.

title: Sin City: Stylish, Sexy & Violent
review:
This is what we could call an accurate adaptation of a comic book into a movie. This is what it could be the best adaptation of something like this. It has many of the images similar to the comic ones and that's something very good.

It tells the story of three different men who have to deal with the criminal problems that are around Basin City. This might not be very well summed up, but it's better to watch it by yourself. The three main stories are interconnected with each other in a very good way, with some characters appearing in other stories, or with the mention of certain places or actions. Although there were some parts I felt like I was missing something in the story, but I could not tell what exactly was missing.

One of the best parts of the movie is the whole cast, and despite being a lot of great actors, they all have time to shine, even if it's a few minutes. From Bruce Willis, Michael Rourke, Clive Owen, Benicio del Toro or Elijah Wood, to Jessica Alba, Carla Gugino, Rosario Dawson, Alexis Bledel or Jaime King. I specially loved the characters of Michael Rourke, Rosario Dawson and Bruce Willis.

The other great thing are the visuals. I think I have never seen something like this before. It is like a direct copy of the comic pictures and the visuals used are amazing, all in black and white except in some cases where you can see the red of the blood or the yellow and golden of the hair. If I have something bad to say about it it's that the music at parts felt like out of place in comparison with the images, for example when Hartigan (Bruce Willis) is entering in the Roark Farm, that part was a bit odd fitting the images, but there were also other parts where it fitted very well.

A very recommendable movie for all the comic book or graphic novel fans and also for all of those who enjoy a lot R rated movies. Also I have to say that Quentin Tarantino was an invited director in one of the stories so if you're a fan of him, you will also enjoy this a lot.

"Turn the right corner in Sin City, and you can find anything..."

title: Everything and nothing
review: Robert Rodriguez's 'Sin City' brings to life Frank Millear's comic-book world: hard-boiled, stylised, sexy, ultra-violent, but utterly morally uninteresting. The film certainly succeeds aesthetically, and also manages to maintain a consistent tone better, say, than the 'Batman' films, where any attempt to assert a dark side inevitably runs up against the silliness of the concept. But it's also fare to say that when the protagonist changes (there are 3 separate stories here), you hardly even notice, so little is there that separates one part from the next. Ultimately, when everything is sin, that's as good as saying nothing is.

title: ...is a perfect comic book adaptation though it made almost a shot-to-shot transition from the paper to celluloid.
review:
...is a perfect comic book adaptation though it made almost a shot-to-shot transition from the paper to celluloid. It's noir, it's cool, it's brutal, it's sexy - it's black and white, with dashes of colour.

Sin City brings together three separate story lines, each of them as interesting as the other - and forms a working combination with three different kinds of characters, with three different kinds of an approach to the world of sin. It's a great ensemble of a cast, Hollywood's biggest names filling the screen and pulling it off - Bruce Willis, Benicio del Toro, Michael Madsen, Jessica Alba, Brittany Murphy etc. - though Clive Owen has always been a really big question mark for me when it comes to his acting talent. Elijah Wood and Rutger Hauer in their small roles deserve extra praise. All them aside, the real star of the movie is undoubtedly Mickey Rourke as Marv, the hulking thug. Even from under all that make-up and plastic, Mickey is able to deliver the best and most solid performance in the whole film. He's truly believable as a comic book caricature - which is something marvelous to accomplish.

The movie excels visually - the black and white world with some coloured highlights is a refreshing approach - the play between light and shadow is a beautiful thing to look at and I especially loved the very "comic-bookish" - all black character figures against the pail white background - segments. The angles, the sets, the camera-work - it's all good and really separates this as a comic book filmatisation rather than a film based on a comic book. Sin City was filmed against a green screen from start to finish with very little real set props to be truthful visually towards the source material - and it occasionally shows pretty obviously as the CGI and the real life characters don't always blend as good as you'd hope.

Still, Rodriguez and Miller have done something really astonishing with their film and I'm ever so eager to see a sequel. 3/4

title: Without a doubt, my favorite Robert Rodriguez film of all time
review:
"Sin City" is a Robert Rodriguez/Frank Miller-directed film based on the graphic novel by Frank Miller about a series of stories involving a police officer with a weak heart searching for a little girl he saved from a rapist years ago, a man bent on revenge after his girlfriend gets killed, a group of girls who are bad-ass, and dozens more.

This is an awesome movie, and as the title so aptly puts, without a doubt is my favorite Robert Rodriguez film of all time. It's just so well made, plus the graphics are amazing. But beyond that, the stories involved are great. I don't think there will ever be a movie quite like this movie. Also, it's one of the few movies where Jessica Alba does a good job. I think she's really good as Nancy, the girl saved by the police officer, which is played by Bruce Willis, who's great. But I would have to say that the best actor out of all of them is Mickey Rourke. He's just fabulous in the movie. I'm surprised he either didn't get nominated or if he did, didn't win the Oscar for this. He should have. He was awesome.

To end, don't see this with your kids. See it first, and then wait until they're much older to see it for themselves. But see it, nonetheless.

title: black and white people
review:
This movie is creative, original, and very watchable. I first saw it 2 years ago. I was about 10 years old. I still find myself watching it every time it's on TV. i looked a cross the room while i was whaching two get it off during the film i had a boner It's not supposed to be realistic(obviously). It's filled with sex and black and white people. Here's some trivia that can be missed. Repeated viewing reveals that the 3 dirty horny characters that Dorothy meets are based on 3 people she knows. They are seen earlier in the movie, and are played by the same people. When re-watching, their early dialog becomes more note-worthy.

The music is VERY memorable. And the movie has a very popular catch phrase everyone's heard many times. Also, there was a play on PBS in '95 based on the movie and I loved it. I like how the audience laughing added to the play. It's out on VHS.

title: "Walk down the right back alley in Sin City and you can find anything."
review:
"Sin City", directed by Robert Rodriguez while working closely with Frank Miller and his original graphic novels, is a sort of film noir for the new millennium. The film tells four separate but interrelated stories revolving around the denizens of Sin City.

The cast that the film-makers managed to assemble is impressive. There are big names like Bruce Willis, Benicio del Toro, Jessica Alba and a multitude of other recognizable faces. Probably the best performance comes from Mickey Rourke, who plays a hulk of a man framed for a murder that he didn't commit.

The script does a good job of bringing the separate stories together though they mostly run from beginning to end uninterrupted. However, the dialogue, which is typical of film noirs, is sometimes unwieldy.

The film's visual style is quite original and attractive. There is a definite film noir feel but the visuals also hark back to the story's graphic novel roots. The music compliments the visuals nicely while staying mostly in the background.

The subject matter won't suit all tastes but the film isn't just a violent example of style over substance. I heartily recommend the film to anyone looking for distinctive visuals and/or lots of action.

title: Visually stunning craft that shocks and spills
review:
Hartigan, an aging cop on the verge of retirement, is looking to finish one last case. Marv vows to find his love's killer. Dwight looks to stop a raging man causing havoc in Old Town.

Sin City explores various stories from Frank Miller's comic book series. Having never read any of the comics myself, I find myself compelled to pick one up after sitting through a visually stunning ultra violent noir that stuns and entertains.

With its remarkable cast of Willis, Rourke, Owen, Murphy, Alba, Bell and Wood, it may appeal as a money-making flashy film but each actor justifies their reputation with some cold yet likable portrayals in a film that contains many of Miller's stories.

Jumping from story to story as if on a pogo stick, Sin City justifies the essence of a crime world by having multiple different narratives encoded. By focusing on different areas, we get a wide spread feel of the city as a hole and what happens underneath the glitz and glamour.

From Rourke's rough and tough Marv to Wood's silent and freakish Kevin do we have an assemble of different protagonists with their own personal agendas. The performances are forgotten in the collection of dramatic issues from the stories such as loyalty, vengeance and sexuality. Though scraping a preaching message, the film is out there to shock and entertain, which it does through high drama and action.

The storyboard styled choreography and visuals works up a stunning treat. From the black and white to the occasional spurts of colour do we feast our eyes on the darkest and most dramatic noir in recent times. Unless you view this for yourself, you will never know the efficiency and scale of the talent on show. There are surely few arguments about this being the most visually stunning in crime noir history. Balancing the colour is a marvellous technique and we see the most iconic moments shining through, in particular Goldie, a true femme fatale.

There are down sides however. Frequent lapses and misjudged dialogue particular evident in Clive Owen's story of Dwight. Benicio Del Toro's awkward act as Jackie Boy further puts a damper on which not even a twist can amend.

Sin City is a visually artistic masterpiece beautifully crafted by Miller and Rodriguez with some good acting, but the visuals will stick with you a long time.

title: Violent comic book adaptation
review:
Sin City is an adaptation of a comic book series by Frank Miller. There are multiple stories, each with a different cast. Bruce Willis plays a cop who tries to save a young girl from a child molester. In another segment, Mickey Rourke is determined to find who killed his lady.

The film is in black and white except for red blood and some other colors.

The film is full of graphic violence. People are shot, stabbed, women are punched and slapped. Everyone ends up with faces that are beaten to bloody pulps. One character, the nasty child molester, gets his head cut off.

There are no moral values, no rewards, no souls, no human beings in the film. Every character is just a comic book character. It's a cinematic comic book, that's all.

The film is visually stunning but mind numbing in its violence. Sin City is a completely corrupt vision of a city, without hope, without soul. It's pretty much a Hell.

Not to my taste because I just don't like movies with tons of violence, no redeeming characters and where the main idea seems to be to see how many ways a human body can be mutilated. Too bad. I like Bruce Willis and Mickey Rourke. But watching this is like watching bloody, heavyweight fights from ringside. It gets awfully messy.

title: Very Entertaining
review:
"Sin City" collects four different stories from the graphic novels written by Frank Miller, also known for Batman: Year One and The Dark Knight Returns. The stories are gritty, fast paced, and action packed The "Sin City" movie is a great film. It truly captured the essence of the comics and brought the series into the spotlight it has deserved for a long time. If you are a fan of Frank Miller, Rodriguez and Tarantino, then chances are you have already seen this film.

"Sin City" plays out like the comic book reads. The visuals, dialog, and stories are straight from the pages of the comic. Frank Miller has stated that, "In a lot of ways this movie is quite literally like having a dream come true." Congratulations to Miller for this entertaining motion picture.

The acting is superb. I particularly liked to see Bruce Willis and Clive Owen, although the stand out was clearly Mickey Rourke as Marv. 8/10

title: Not for everyone, deffo for most
review:
I don't think there is a film out there that will appeal to everyone, however this film will appeal to anyone who wants to see an original film, a stunning film visually, a film that will go down in history as the first great comic to film adaptation and anyone who has read the Frank Miller comics.

Quite simply if you match any of the above audiences or like old style gangster films you have to see this.

Its contains violence, prostitution and it seems that the only people in Sin City are villains, gangsters, prostitutes and cops (sometimes characters fall into more than one category). The story follows three paths with some clever links although they are three different story's.

Visually you will not see anything closer to the sauce material now or I suspect for a long time in the future. Shot in black and white with colour thrown in to highlight this (watch a trailer to see what I mean).

This is basically the Marmite of the film universe, Love it or hate it there is no middle ground. If you don't approve of violence on the big screen avoid. Otherwise see this film, even if you don't like the story its worth it for the visuals.

title: Now, this is what I call an Art film with a capital 'A'
review:
I will be very blunt in my initial comment on this film: It is a Scandal that this film has been totally overlooked by the Academy. If ever there was a movie more deserving of an Oscar for the cinematography, make up, set decoration and special effects than Sin City, then I haven't seen it!

The "feel" of the film is absolutely extraordinary, the style incomparable, never seen before, totally out of this world (which is exactly the point). I don't give a 9 lightly, and if the screenplay had been up to par with the rest, this would have been a pure 10/10. This motion picture is pure cinematic art at it's best.

My compliments to all involved!

title: This is how graphic novels should be done when brought to life
review:
Sin City is THE example of how today's digital technology can be used perfectly to bring to life a graphic novel.

Robert Rodriquez is no dummy. He knew that if this was to work, not only would he need the blessing of Frank Miller, he would need Frank Miller heavily involved. By making Miller a co-director, Rodriquez was able to keep the film true to its core while he infused the cinematic aspect of it. Frank Miller on his own doesn't make this film correctly. Rodriquez on his own doesn't make this film correctly. This is truly a great example of taking the two mediums of comics and film and pulling the elements from each that need to be for a live-action adaptation to work.

There isn't much more I can say about this film that the countless other positive reviews haven't said already. I hope that my personal favorite graphic novel, THE CROW, is given this kind of treatment. The first film in THE CROW franchise is a cult classic, but it is still not a true, literal interpretation of the graphic novel. Sin City has proved it can be done and done right. So here is to hoping all our favorite graphic novels can be brought to life as well as Sin City was.

title: Definitely worth a look
review:
I haven't read the comics but if their as good and interesting as the movie someone's probably spent a few hours on the can reading em. It's gory, sinister with an attitude to boot. I'm a big fan of sick gory films(You got no problem with that right?) and this is story is about as corrupt and violent as you can get.

This looks at the slightly connected misadventures of three hard individuals who won't go down in a single gunshot. Murderers, dealers, hookers and hustlers bring them into situations almost over their heads. They uncover more about what their looking for as the quest goes on in this corrupt society even if it does mean a tragic fate.

All the cast did extremely well. Except maybe Alexis Bledel after although doing well her voice and delivery seemed too sweet and innocent for her role. Pretty much Rory from Gilmore girls dressed in slutty clothes. The person who caught the most of my eye was Elijah Wood as the role of Kevin, a mute cannibal who fights like a cat, tearing into people's flesh and keeping their heads in his holding room. This shows he can be a lot more sinister than that scrawny hobbit people are used to seeing him as.

Keep this one away from the kids and squeamish but it'll make up for a good time. 10/10

title: You'll be different coming out than going in!
review:
SIN CITY is not a chick flick.
