Even the words spoken are straight from the book. This is by far the best film based off of a comic book/graphic novel yet! I've seen them all. This is totally up in the 10's with the like, Hellboy, Superman, Batman, Dick Tracy and Blade. This is not another Catwoman or Daredevil mush up with all new costumes. It's not a teaser like Spider-man (where he shoots webbing from his wrist) and it is certainly not an over-the-top rip of an artistic comic like Batman and Robin was. I've seen many films based on comics and there are a lot of them, look them up some time, but Sin City is the best.

title: It really doesn't get much better than this, folks
review:
I am a big fan of the comic and of the early Rodriguez film El Mariachi (which I thought was a better film than the bigger-budget Desperado), and watching this film was amazing. It isn't a movie of a comic book, it's a comic book on the movie screen.

Uncompromising, gritty, rough, brutal, hardcore: both Sin City the place and Sin City the movie are all these things and more. This film transcends not one but two mediums, bringing film-making as an art back into the public consciousness and, like American Splendor did last year, showing that comic books can be ART.

No tired re-hash of a Hollywood hit from yesteryear, Sin City is so fresh, so different, so goddamn exciting that I could scarcely stand to glance away. Frank Miller is an exceptionally talented artist whose visual acumen has fascinated me for years (since his Batman days), and Robert Rodriguez proves himself an equally formidable director, not just for conceiving how this film should be brought to the cinema, but for executing it so brilliantly.

A series of short stories, intertwined and criss-crossing pulp fictions, seemingly unrelated at first, until we discover, like the characters in the film, more and more details about each situation. Through excellent writing and choice of narrative structure, Miller and Rodriguez engage the viewer to become a detective as well, tracking leads, gathering information right alongside our protagonists, putting the pieces together with them. In the end, though, we are richer because we have more details and more questions, and our imaginations allow us to continue to explore the stories we have just seen after the projector stops. A good film, a good comic, all good art should engage the viewer's imagination, force them to fill in gaps, to think about what they are seeing, and Sin City certainly has that.

Amazing performances (Michael Madsen's terse, first-grader-reading-aloud delivery excepting), captivating images, and multiple intertwined cross-crossing story lines kept me entranced for more than 2 hours. I know that repeated viewings will bring more out of this film too; there is no way to have seen all the details in these compositions in one viewing.

My only dread would be the dilution of this work thru repetition. If sequels should occur, I hope that Mr. Miller and Mr. Rodriguez remain as demanding and uncompromising as Sin City itself, and that future works expand on the vision and possibilities which they have presented to us.

Good job, guys.

Bo

title: Worth $7 and 2 hours, but not much more
review:
I fully understand how fans of the movie can immediately jump to give the movie a 9 or 10 star rating. However, I'm a bit shocked that there isn't much of a voice on the other side of the ratings scale.

The movie was enjoyable. It was entertaining. In spending $7 for the ticket I am confident that I got my money's worth. While the movie is avant-garde, the translation from page to screen wasn't performed seamlessly. There are several points in the movie where the digital effects required to rend a 2D image into a 3D set distract the viewer, pulling them out of what is intended to be an immersive experience. A still-shot of any of these scenes would surely be awe-inspiring, but in motion it simply looks manufactured. This isn't a fatal flaw by any means, but any time a movie reminds you that you're watching a recording of actors in front of a blue-screen, instead of a view into an alternate reality, it serves to make the experience less rewarding. (For an example just think back to your viewing experience of Star Wars ep 1, or Lost in Space).

The acting in the movie is a shining point. For most of the scenes the actors were dropped onto an empty set, in front of a blue-screen, with no other actors to interact with. This movie truly served to show the depth of the actors chosen for this movie.

Anyhow, to wrap this up: the movie was good. It's worth the few bucks to see it in the theatre instead of on the small screen. But this movie is no "Wizard of Oz" that will change the face of Hollywood.

title: Good but not great...
review:
I liked this movie but Bruce Willis as usual sucked in it. This guy just can't act. It could have used a few more hot half nude women as well. :-) Visuals were great and not over done... some scenes showed separate elements however. Mickey Rourke was fantastic! On the other hand Brittany Murphy did not belong in this movie... she is the same character in every movie. Soundtrack and sound was poor... I expected a much better score than this. CLIVE OWEN shows why he will be an excellent Bond... I like this guy. Speaking of Bond... Benicio Del Toro was perfect as usual.

All in all a good movie to get lost in for a few hours.

title: good but not as good...
review:
For starters, I have been a Frank Miller fan since Daredevil and Dark Knight. I don't really think that Sin City is his best work but I always thought it would make a cool movie. with that out of the way, I enjoyed the film very much and give it (as a movie) 8 out of ten stars. i've always enjoyed films that transport you to another place by creating a universe unto itself. it reminds me of ERB novels of Tarzan when i read them as a child. but I digress. I'm a bit surprised that the acting was as good as it was. Mickey Rourke floored me as Marv and Benicio Del Toro as Jackie boy was equally as good. the problem with this is that the great acting exposed some of the weaker performances in the film such as Jessica Alba's Nancy: she was surely hot and FM has never really fleshed out her character, but she seemed flat. for the most part though, all the actors did what they could with the source material. the violence will probably turn some moviegoers off (even in todays desensitized society) and it's always more shocking to see a violent act then to read it, albeit in a graphic novel, but it is what it is. I look forward to the DVD and seeing each story in its entirety because the originals were so economically written that to cut anything is detrimental to the story as a whole. the visuals of the film were gorgeous of course and unlike anything we have seen on the screen before. color was only used only as an exclamation point, how Frank Miller intended. the score was simple and unobtrusive, ( I particularly liked the piano in That Yellow Bastard) it did not distract and only added to the bleak visuals. Robert Rodriguiez has accomplished what he set out to do: pay homage to Frank Miller and experiment with his craft therein turn the movie-making industry on its head.

done and done. congratulations to Robert and Frank for a job well done.

and there is one thing i've learned from this adaptation: no matter how faithful you are to the book, the book will still (and always) be better.

title: Interesting but repetitive
review:
Unlike many reviewers, I have never read any of Frank Miller's graphic novels--so I can't comment on the authentic look of the film. I can say that the film is visually stunning, particularly given that so much of what you see is digitally created. It is truly a work of art to behold.

I can also say that the characters are all uniformly interesting to watch. Not just the characters made up prosthetically, like Micky Rourke as Marv, or Elijah Wood as Kevin. Every major actor is playing a singularly interesting character, and the interaction between those characters is compelling to watch, just as compelling as the visuals.

But for me, the problem is that, both the characters and the look of the film, are at the service of essentially the same story, told three separate times.

Possible mild spoilers.

The stories are all about cruelty and retribution, with some form of redemption at the end. Each story plays out like an Old Testament tale, which is alright for the first hour or so. But after a while, all the over-the-top violence and histrionics begin to wear you down. By the second hour, the movie has become predictable, and that's as deadly, in a movie, as any shot through the head.

Critics keep referring to Sin City as a return to Film Noir.

But great film noir, like Out of the Past and The Big Sleep, have a lot of elements to it besides violence. Sex, for instance. With femme fatales, who the antihero and the audience don't know if they can trust--and that creates suspense.

There are numerous women in Sin City--in fact women are the catalyst for each of the stories. But there's not much suspense surrounding who these women are, and what they might be up to. And except for the prostitute gang, the women we meet in Sin City are all ladies in distress--hardly what I expected to find going in to the film.

In the end, the only suspense in Sin City is what new and bloody way someone can get his head bashed in.

I would certainly recommend seeing Sin City. It is dazzling to look at, even more so than Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow. I just wish that the story telling had kept up with the visual look of the film and the character creation.

title: Sometimes sticking too close to the source material hurts
review: I like comic books. I think they are beautiful pieces of art but where sticking to the book literally helps some stories i.e. LOTR (and even Peter Jackson new that some creative license was needed) the director of Sin City should have thought more about the possible audience for his film. I stories would have been good just in and of themselves without the naked women, endless violence and voice over. The characters were also interesting but if appealing to a wider audience is a consideration then sticking with the comic book violence and sex is a no, no. This film should as it stands if for seventeen year old boys who can't get real women and play hour after hour of ultra-violent video games. And since I'm not one of those I was disappointed.

title: Very nicely done! Thumb Up! Better than Kill Bill!
review:
I have watched Kill Bill (both I and II), and I was totally blown away by the gory violence and artistic style in Sin City.

It is absolutely filled with constant lustful desires and killing blood. Of course, like many other reviewers mentioned, this movie is violent to an extreme. However, it does come with a certain amount of humors, so you won't be stressed with seeing blood the whole time.

Certain physics in this movie are under question. For example, when Marv was hit by a car multiple times, he seems to be unharmed (not even a broken bones). Not to mentioned when he got shot so many times in the chest, ..and endured electrocution twice before being dead (or so we are made to believe). That's freaking unbelievable! My last concern was that it may be nice if they include a time line for the events happened in the movie. In fact, there is a 8+ years of time span within the movie (from the time Nancy was saved to the time she is saved again at age of 19), and if you aren't careful, you can get quite lost indeed until the very end. Perhaps, that was meant to be. Fortunately, it is not too hard for general movie goers to piece together all the puzzles.

Overrall, an excellent movie. If they do right on DVD, I may also get it too :)

title: worth thinking about
review:
I've never read the graphic novels, so I can't comment on how the film relates to them, except in the sense of disjunction--this film doesn't feel like it holds together, as it has no unified story. Thus, it can get long and, as it is on screen rather than on paper, it would have benefited from more continuity in story as well as in feeling.

What it has, however, is a unified sensation--morality, if such a word fits in this world. The fact that the movie begins and ends with an assassin killing (or about to kill) a woman who (certainly in one case and probably in the other) has broken the rules and betrayed her sisters and the code of the city is significant. In a world in which sin touches every person, no one emerging unscathed, the definitions of right and wrong, good and evil, may blur but exist nonetheless. You have your evil rapists, your soul- and flesh-eating monsters, and you have those who kill to revenge a wrong or to protect a way of life that guarantees some degree of freedom. The thing is that all of these people enjoy the killing; in this world, you have to or are part of that small group that doesn't fit and is targeted or desperate because of it. You have those that aren't a part of it or who don't enjoy the violence--you have Nancy and Becky, the first someone to protect as much as possible, the second someone who doesn't fit, seemingly more "normal" yet also the biggest femme fatale--the biggest simply because those around her would never think it of her--of the story.

The movie is unapologetically violent and explicit, but that's the context of this world: it isn't gratuitous, it's characterization--innocence does not exist. The little girl Hartigan tries to save grows into a stripper--still targeted because she's different--who is not as hard as many of those around her but is still tainted by this world--she grew up strong, and in this city, that means, among other things, taking some part in the events we see. Goldie, idolized by Marv, is one of the band of hookers who run part of town--she seeks help and comfort but is by no means pure. Even Alexis Bledel's character, whose eyes glow in a pure blue and who, despite her profession, exudes innocence, ends up being the one who betrays the code, a darker sin in this city, no matter the reason--do we forgive her betrayal, understanding her desire to get out of this world, or, because no one escapes, do we condemn her? The color added to the depiction of these last two characters is striking and important, for they are in some way different, for better or for worse, and both end up dead, also significant. Here, innocence is scarce, weak, false, or nonexistent, and that, for me, is the most interesting part of the film. In the contrast between A) the powerful, evil villains, B) the gun-toting hookers and the testosterone-charged heroes, and C) the tainted innocents of the film is the point.

I'm still working out what that point is, but the film speaks, nonetheless. It's worth seeing, but it is disturbing and shocking in its grit--there's no romanticized beauty here--or what little there is is tarnished--but there's much to see.

title: Back alley pot boiler!
review:
Damn, if SIN CITY doesn't look like SIN CITY! - the movie like the book that is. I haven't been as big a fan of Frank Miller's art as much as his writing, but I oddly hoped that the film would capture the look of the comics, and in that regard it triumphs. Marv and Bratigan are big and blocky, Shellie and Nancy are curvy and angular, and the city itself becomes a character, especially on those rain driven nights when a comic book splash page takes on new meaning in a driving rain storm.

And it's not just the black and white noir-ishness of the film; this movie's black and white POPS!, along with the surreal color splashes added for nuance and contrast. The eye goes where it must, whether the fire engine red of Goldie's dress or the sickening hue of "That Yellow Bastard".

Kudos to Director Robert Rodriguez for defying convention and resigning from the Director's Guild when threatened over Frank Miller's inclusion as Co-Director, and Quentin Tarantino's contribution as a guest director. Movie making can use more of this type of creativity. Ultimately quality speaks.

Every once in awhile a film comes along that breaks new ground and sets the bar for those that follow - SIN CITY is such a film, just as "Star Wars", "Aliens" and "Pulp Fiction" were in their respective genres. And for fans of comic books and graphic novels, this film will be THE one to top, and that won't be for a while, if ever. "Road to Perdition" was a successful transfer of story to screen, "Sin City" is a masterful transformation of the drawn and printed panel come to life. SEE IT!

Added bonus: Frank Miller as the priest hearing confession!!! That was so cool!

title: speechless
review: Ummm...I just saw it tonight, and to say I am disappointed is an understatement. I have read all the graphic novels, and when I saw the first preview a few months ago I nearly wet my pants. Maybe it was the anticipation, or maybe I went in with unreasonable expectations, but this flick blew me away with how incredibly horrible it was. Lets make a list: bad acting? check. repetitive scenes? check. long spells of mind-numbing boredom? of course. The worst part was the thing I was most looking forward to: the narration. After about a half-hour I was wishing Bruce, Mickey and Clive would shut up. Lastly, for some reason I didn't have a problem with it in the graphic novel, but in the movie every scene with the 11 year-old Nancy Callahan made me want to get up and leave the theater. I felt like I was watching kiddie-porn. Overall, this was probably the worst experience I have had at the movies since my sister made me watch Hairspray(it's not my fault, I was 10). All the fanboys out there may crucify me, but I call em like I see em.

title: Feels like a Comic,Works like a masterpiece
review: This movie is great It Feels like a comic so much its unreal,Like the first half an hour feels like pg9 of a sin city comic.As a teen I like the classic comic movies ex.Spiderman and X-men but watching sin city makes me wanna chuck a ninja star right into peter parker's buttocks.This is very hard movie to watch, but i would recommend it to anyone above 14.Very great acting from Brice Willis,Clive Olwen and nick stall.This movie sticks to the comic very well.Its amazing funny in some scenes (if u can handle the violence in them).Down sides to the movie:Britney Murphy's acting,All the winer ripping and all the winer shooting, anything that has to do with a man's penis getting blown away by a revolver really sickening(but funny).So overall this movie lives up to the rep 9/10

title: Don't be a Sinner... Go see that movie
review:
This movie is not a comic book adaptation... It's a comic book coming alive on the big screen. Unlike Spider-Man and X-Men, Sin City the movie make no compromise, if you like the comics books like i do, be assure that you'll be very satisfied by the way Rodriguez treat the original material. Everything is similar to the comics books but with one more more dimension. It's like seeing a the books coming alive before your eyes. Even if this movie got action, sex and violence, this is not just another action movie, but a real works of art like Natural Born Killer with a touch of Casablanca or a Touch of Evil.

Add to this great acting, great visual effect and many tragic destiny and you got a spontaneous classic.

Don't miss it... This is a cinematic experience like you've never seen before.

title: Go see "Sin City"
review:
Been waiting on this movie for over a year. Saw it twice today and I still don't know if it was worth the hype. Two shows, the 12:05 where only the junkies were there and 7:35 where the usual crowd was there to view their Friday movie. It was interesting seeing the two crowds. The followers went to the first show to see it as soon as possible and knew exactly what they were in for. They sat there silent watching, unlike the second group. First thing I saw when I walked into the cine the second time was a kid that couldn't have been more then 9 there with his father. I couldn't believe it, I was ready to say something to the father. They sat through the whole thing, I expected him to be dragged out by his father within minutes, but they stayed. Others left, this is a pretty disgusting movie we're talking about. Right around the ax scene people were dropping like flies.

Anyway, great movie. I was expecting more, yes. After all I've hyped it up I expected the next Star Wars. The visuals went from impressive to just plain cheap in seconds at times, but were good overall. I didn't like the order it was shown to us in. Sure, it had that Pulp Fiction thing going on with it's being out of sequence and Hartigan's story was great being sliced into two different parts of the movie, but the whole thing took away from Marv. Mickey Rourke was the man in this movie, but it was weakened by the other parts in the movie. He's got the first spot for his whole story right after two shorts right in the beginning, and then he's gone. He's back for a short time right near the end due to the sequence, but just barely. I think a lot of people there may have forgotten the whole segment due to The Big Fat Kill and That Yellow Bastard (who is VERY yellow by the way, especially when put put against other characters in black and white). That segment was amazing, enough to bring Rourke back to the top but it was rushed into the beginning and he was killed off as to pave the way to bigger and better parts of the movie (which are NOT bigger or better). It was a shame. Nothing was cooler then the very beginning. There was the whole "oh snap, we screwed up, let's fix it" segment and the touching cop/father figure segment with a creepy yellow dude (who wasn't accepted very well, the audience just didn't get it.). There's also two other short segments in which NOBODY but me got. I thought it would have been obvious, but I had to explain it to people. I won't spoil it, I'll just say that it was a brilliant twist and a great end to the movie. It's a love it or hate it kinda movie. I appreciate the style and direction of Miller, yet continue waiting and hoping for Rodriguez to impress me again. Tarantino's segment was no award winner either. I've always thought they have done other people's stories better then their own, but this was so close to their own that they blew it for me again.

Overall great movie. Goes right next to "Once Upon a Time in Mexico" in the "could have been better, should have been better" pile, but a great movie none-the-less. Don't let my ranting confuse you, go see it for your self. You'll probably like it. I'm just caught up in the "could have been better" zone.

title: Nostalgia and Leather
review:
I thought that I would be downcast upon leaving the theater, but the film empowered me; made me feel strong, manly. The fiancÃ©e appeared more fierce and beautiful than she did when I entered. The movie was packed with strong, sexy,vibrant, female characters. I have never been so attracted to women on screen, nor felt as capable of feats of endurance as I did upon exit of the theaters. Filmmakers who wish to portray their female leads as sexually attractive would do well to take a page from this screenplays and give their divas the fire and passion that such roles deserve. No Bond girl would have lasted a week in Basin City, that's for sure.

In many respects it really is a masterpiece. It will never be a Citizen Kane , but the homage that it renders is almost tearfully beautiful. But the thing that gets me is that folks over 45 didn't like it. The movie was shot to be nostalgic with the blue screen and all. Why didn't the old folks like it? Go figure.

title: Digital done well
review:
Sin City is one of the few movies you will ever experience that feels entirely and refreshingly different than everything else out there.

That being said, where your tastes run with it is purely subjective. It's easy to foresee that many watchers will dislike the flick; it's an oddity in a world of cinematic conformity. It's like the new kid in school and no one is quite sure how to feel about him. As for me, I think the new kid is pretty damn cool.

As the movie industry's second major attempt at an all-digital film, the quality far surpasses that of 'Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow.' So Sin City now throws to the forefront the possibility of stretching creative boundaries in cinema. All walls that have blocked in film's possibilities since its creation are now serving as fuel for digital fire. The possibilities seem limitless.

The entire visual experience of Sin City is mind-blowing. It really reads like a comic book. And while I admit that at first I wasn't at home in this new digital world, as the story unfolded (and Jessica Alba was oggled by the camera) I was completely drawn in. I started dwelling in the comic book, becoming part of it, in a way that only those blessed with the most vivid and powerful imaginations previously could.

As for the editing and pacing, at first I questioned their efficacy; but, once again, as I was learning to soak up this new visual treat, my opinion on these fronts was changing in tune. By the end, I had full faith in the directors' handling of the film. Robert Rodriguez, Quentin Tarantino, once again we must thank you for bringing something fresh and new to our world.

Let's just hope that their efforts kindle the creative flame burning inside of us and a new generation of courageous cinematic trailblazers has found itself the perfect tool for bringing to life, and to the audience, their most brilliant imaginations.

Digital done well.

title: Makes Kill Bill look like a PG movie
review:
We saw Sin City on its opening night. Our local paper gave it 4 stars. Good thing it's black & white (with touches of color), because it is a real gore fest! I kid you not...it makes Kill Bill look like a PG movie. Decapitations, severed limbs, mangled penises, buckets of blood, hatchets in the face, viciousness toward women (and a child), lots of nudity (okay, that part wasn't so bad!), cannibalism, pedophilia, a drooling yellow devil...shall I go on?

It's one of the worst--no, wait, it's THE most violent/gory film I've ever seen on the big screen. However, it's all done in a stylized comic-book way--the blood is white instead of black. Otherwise it would be too graphic and sickening.

Sin City had some dark humor. In one scene, a very tough guy character is being put to death in the electric chair. After his body convulses and smokes, he opens his eyes, spits out a mouthful of blood, and says "Is that all you pussies got?"

I'm not familiar Frank Miller or the Sin City series at all, though I love Tarantino's films. (Tarantino was given a guest director credit because he lent a hand in a few scenes. And you can tell which ones.) This movie is well-done and interesting for the kind of movie it is, and it is definitely the ultimate in pulp fiction if you're a fan of the genre.

title: Vicious in delivery, brilliant in execution. A great comic book flick.
review:
Just got back from this one. Easily one of the most faithful adaptations of the medium, right down to Frank Miller's visual style. Having picked up the odd Sin City comic here and there, everything's intact. And I'm not even a Frank Miller fan (outside of his work on Daredevil).

Great performances all around, especially from Mickey Rourke, who does a great turn as Marv (although the prosthetics make him look a bit like Hellboy). Benicio Del Toro, Bruce Willis, Clive Owen, et al are great as well.

Clearly, Robert Rodriguez "gets" it. Now, all I gotta do is break open the ole piggy bank, head to the comic book store, and pick up "That Yellow Bastard", "A Dame to Kill For", "The Big Fat Kill" and "Sin City".

title: Sin City is for everyone
review:
OK -- maybe not Grandma, but if you think this movie is not your thing  geez, you found my review  something got you interested! This movie has had me intrigued for ages - and I am pretty damn far from any "target demographic". I'm single, female, have a masters degree, don't tend to see violent films, have disliked most computer animation (other than Monsters Inc.) and LOVED this movie!

I only post to help those people decide who are on the fence about seeing Sin City. It is captivating, interesting, humorous, sexy and actually says some pretty awesome messages. The casting was flawless. The imagery never got old. Go sit back, and ENJOY the ride!

title: Brilliant..No Pulp fiction BUT Brilliant
review:
Ladies and gentle I've just watched Sin City and i think the movie is absolutely gorgeous. Id give it an 8/10, unlike Pulp Fiction which i had given 9/10! but i don't think you all would care about my grading. I really recommend this movie to everybody BUT not to those who cannot stand visceral violence in a movie. Yes it is violent, Yes it is fun BUT is it a must watch? for movie fans it is... for the people who enjoyed White Chicks and AVP please stay away from this movie.

Set in a nowhere metropolis, the film opens with a gaspingly beautiful image of a woman staring into the night. Dressed in a shimmering gown the color of newly spilled blood, she stands with her back to the camera, oblivious. That gives us time to register that this red is the only color in a landscape exclusively painted hot white, bottomless black and silvery gray. It also gives the narrator (Josh Hartnett) time to creep up on her.

"Sin City" unfolds in a permanent midnight with only an intermittent splash of color to brighten the dark. In this shadow-land, the men wear trench coats and chips on their shoulders, while the women wear next to nothing at all. Aesthetically speaking, the filmmakers have a thing for pneumatic breasts and bondage wear, and the women in "Sin City" are conceived along the same fetishistic lines.

Like "Pulp Fiction," which clearly influences its structure, "Sin City" turns on three tales lifted out of Mr. Miller's original.

Sin City" has been made with such scrupulous care and obvious love for its genre influences. Mr. Rodriguez put his own movie sense on hold, not even bothering with a real script. He didn't just try to make his "Sin City" look like a graphic novel: he tried to replicate the private experience of reading one too, slowly turned page after slowly turned page. The problem is, this is his private experience, not ours.

Enjoy this!! -Favin Wayans a.k.a paradox

title: Gorgeously filmed, Brutally violent
review: I can't say that this is the best film I have seen in my entire life but it does bring the comic book to the big screen in a spectacular manner. The screen shots alone make this movie worth seeing. This film requires some suspension of disbelief and as soon as you do that it jumps out of the screen and brings it to life. If your into comic books, even a little, you will like this movie. If you think their for geeks who play dungeons and dragons, save your money. Back to the actual look of the movie, the use of color in the film is deliberate and allows for the suspension of disbelief to continue which adds a tremendous element to the film. While the movie is in black and white, it helps to disguise the violence which happens every other second in the film. I am going to assume that the violence will be the biggest criticism of the film, and I can easily see why. I, however, would say that it truly describes the place of BaSIN City which is full of crime and evil people doing evil things and the heroes that try and make the world a better place, whether for others or them self I'll let you decide. This movie is groundbreaking in the way it was filmed and for the most part the story is intriguing and involving. I was a little disappointed with the flow of the three original stories being forced together in the film; I think they should have taken liberties from the comic books and blended the stories a bit more together. I enjoyed the film even though I didn't agree with a lot of it morally. It shows how corrupt things can become and how naive we are to react to it and blame those that may actually be in the right. Like every good comic, its good against evil, its just that everyone has blood on their hands in this movie.

title: Brutal, ultra-violent, GREAT!
review:
Rodriguez throws you into the pages of the SIN CITY novels and the movie is much the better for it. Not only does the look mirror the novel, but much of the writing seems to have been retained. While some lines are awkward when spoken, it adds to the abstract, stylized reality that is created on the screen. And once you've adapted to the style of the movie, it's easy to let the stories work their magic. Are these future noir? 21st century horrors? It doesn't matter what it's called. The ride is new and captivating.

Who's had anything good to say about Mickey Rourke's acting in decades? They will now, since he turns in the most stellar job in what is generally an exemplary ensemble. (I say generally, since some of the younger actors seem to miss the feel of the material, like contemporary singers trying to perform 50s torch songs.) Even under a nose and chin of make-up, Rourke gives a disturbing humanity to an unlovable man. Or is he? Bruce Willis seems to turn in his best work in ensembles (PULP FICTION, 12 MONKEYS come to mind immediately) and his work in SIN CITY is no exception. And Clive Owen proves yet again that he can animate whatever material he's given. I don't want to slight the film's women, but it is the men who dominate SIN CITY. And it is the story of the three protagonists and their love for women that is the story of SIN CITY.

title: Sneak preview last night!
review: Sin City - wow. I can't see how anyone could be disappointed by this movie, unless you're expecting to be handed money at the end or something. It transfers so well from graphic novel to the big screen - Frank Miller fans will be creaming their jeans. Comic fans all over the world: this is the big one. It makes the original Batman look like church. I have never seen a 'comic book' movie that has really transported me. This is a masterpiece. The cinematography is absolutely gorgeous, and it has to be seen in theatres to be appreciated - this is truly a big screen movie. I urge anyone who's even slightly interested in Sin City not to wait until video, this is easily one of the best movies I've seen in years - it has everything. The performances were outstanding, it was perfectly cast, the whole thing was perfect! We will definitely see it in theatres again. All I can say is: go, go GO!!!!!! It opens tomorrow, you have to see it!

title: Very Original
review: Got lucky and scored a free pass to a sneak preview of this Robert Rodriguez and Frank Miller collaboration. From the start, I knew it was going to be very interesting 'cinematicly'; shot mostly in a 'black and whiteized' color film, with some elements left as true color. The substantial use of voice overs to narrate the characters thoughts. All contributed to the 'feel' of the film. I was pleased with the results. For me it made the film take on a more'graphic novel' look than a typical action movie; which is what (I guess) they were going for. The story is set in Basin City, thus the title baSIN City. A play on words I enjoyed. Taken further you could make it Base Sin, and what is more base of a sin than murder, which is what the movie is about; murder, revenge and justice. The plot is weaved around 3 separate story lines, so be prepared. They don't flit from one to the other, but are shown mostly in total, then weakly tied together. The script is very Film Noir with a good dash of sarcastic edgy humor thrown in. The acting is solid, but no real standouts to me. I feel that was the way RR/FM wanted it. The F/X were fabulous. I loved the splashes of color used in spots standing out amongst the gray gritty city. Overall I found the movie an enjoyable and Original movie experience, one well worth seeing. 8/10

title: Stupid Movie, idem
review: This movie is complete stupid and unreasonable. And it only calls for violence. People smashing heads and cutting hands with a saw. The only reason this movie film exists is just because of the violence and to generate more violence. Even the duality between man and woman ends up disappearing. In the midst of so much unnecessary violence. An unnecessary film, perverted and ridiculous. At least, Jaime King has a beautiful face and beautiful cleavage. Seeing Jaime King is a unique pleasure, but to endure the poor performance of Mickey Rourke, with that unbearable face, that no one can stand, it is a nightmare. And actually, no actor in this joke of a movie does a good job, for the matter. The action scenes are even more ridiculous and extremely boring to watch. An experience that I do not want to go back to, and for that I can not recommend it.

title: Violent, crazy and brilliant. This is BaSIN City
review:
Sin City is a movie about three different people trapped in horrible corruption in the Basin City.

I didn't read the Frank Miller's stories before, so i didn't know too much about this movie. I decided to see this movie just because it was starring Bruce Willis, and i really liked the movies he is in. So i decided to watch it, and i don't regret of watching it, because i loved it.

I loved that the movie is black and white, and in some characters or special moments there are a few colors. It really looks awesome. The stories are well written and you end loving the characters, because it seems that they are immortals and they try so hard to save the people they care.

The movie is too violent, but even so the movie is brilliant and totally a masterpiece.

title: Makes Gotham City look like Munchkin Land ...
review:
Robert Rodriguez and Quentin Tarantino are of the same generation, but not the same range of talent, there's one element where Tarantino surpasses his friend : writing and storytelling, and in Hollywood, that means a lot. So at the time Rodriguez made himself famous with the 'Mexican' trilogy and the 'Spy kids' series, Tarantino was already a unanimously acclaimed director and the standard-bearer of a cinematic revolution that gave witty dialogs and random Pop Culture references their significances to weird intricate plots. And I must add with style and an appealing overdose of fun and violence.

Honestly, I'm not much a fan of the three last movies directed by Tarantino, I believe he got so wrapped up in his success that he never tried to get out of his comfort zone. However, I believe the "Kill Bill" series to be his last masterpiece, the pinnacle of the Tarantino touch, a vibrant, flamboyant and emotionally engaging, homage to the Martial Arts movies that influenced him. But the film had style too, and style was an area where Robert Rodriguez wasn't just comfortable but capable to outrank his gifted friend. So, it's just as in 2005, he came out with his own "Kill Bill", a no-less dazzling and hypnotic masterpiece named "Sin City", based on Frank Miller's graphic comic-book series. And that one of the best-looking movies of the 2000's never got nominated for Best Cinematography is as sinful as any of the sins in "Sin City".

Dark and gloomy, the titular setting would make Gotham City look like Munchkin land, it's over-the-top film-noir photography reminded me of these Photoshop effects where I playfully augmented the contrast to give an eerie look to the most banal image. Rodriguez, a man of his generation, understood the endless implications of computerized images : basically, you could make miracles with it. And that's what the movie is, a miracle. The black-and-white look like painted with China ink, and colors are highlighted every once in a while in the most visually affecting ways, blood is like red stains soiling the frame, the blonde hair of that Marv's sweetheart is mesmerizing, and sometimes, colors get you to more sickening reactions such as the guts of that gutless Yellow Bastard. Color is like a protagonist in the film, images serve the story as the story serves them, it's like the perfect symbiosis of the form and the content.

And with an extraordinary wizardry, Rodriguez edits the film to create another spellbinding symbiosis with the storytelling. I said Tarantino was superior in storytelling, but Rodriguez conceals his weakness by adapting the comics on-the-nose, straight-forwardly, an image speaking for thousand words but thousand-word monologues feeling like verbal caresses. Structure-wise, the film employs the same circular narrative that made "Pulp Fiction"'s reputation. In "Sin City", characters meet each other, you leave them someplace and find them again in another, they're always part of the same universe like different pieces of chess game that only at the end, reward your patience and give you the whole scope, through its bunch of crooked politicians, corrupt cops, and 'gold-hearted' prostitutes observing a fragile truce with the Police. With all the gangsters, priests, dancers, lawyers, killers and cannibals, "Sin City" is like the matrix of sex and violence in urban Pop Culture, where being good is the exception... no matter to which side of the Law one belongs.

Hell, what do you expect from such a title anyway? You have your share of Gothic sensuality, high-heels and G-strings, women are poetic sexiness in motion and men lustful and justice enforcers (the true justice), there's an odd mix of old-school characterization and modernity, and the whole movie is so dizzyingly good you never have time to analyze, it's a film to enjoy, to be entertained with. And it's a fun movie where you know all the actors had fun playing in it. In a way, "Sin City" is like Rodriguez' revenge on Tarantino, it's his own star-studded movie with Michael Madsen from "Reservoir Dogs", Bruce Willis from "Pulp Fiction" and a female casting instinct that has nothing to envy on Tarantino, from Rosario Dawson as a luscious dominatrix to the unforgettable Carla Gugino who makes quite an entrance in the film. But I must say Mickey Rourke makes the most durable impression, and I have the feeling that his come-back that pinnacled with "The Wrestler" started with "Sin City".

"Sin City" is a gem, one of the best films of the last decade, a masterpiece of Pop Culture, and Rodriguez' most mature and complete movie. He who asked his friend Tarantino to tell a joke in "Desperado" asked him to direct a part in "Sin City", it was the car scene between Clive Owen and Benicio Del Toro. I have less to say about that moment than this touching interaction between the two directors, there is something of Lucas and Coppola in them, Coppola was already an established director in 70's yet he always supported Lucas and encouraged him to push the envelope as best he could. In a way, "Sin City" is Rodriguez' "Star Wars".

title: UNREAL, perfect Graphic Novel feel
review:
WOW, possibly one of the best adaptations of a Graphic Novel I have ever watched! So excited to see where they take this, as there is a juicy story that has a lot of room for growth.

Mickey Rourke is such a classy actor. I have always admired his talents, but this role is so epic for him. I honestly do not believe anyone could have done it better.

It is a great role for Clive Owen, kind of upset they replaced him with Hawk in the latest film, but his character is such a powerhouse.

Brit Murphy nails her role too, and it was the last film I ever saw of hers. It acts as a great memorial for her career.

Rob Rod is such a visionary. I love his style, and I think it fits so perfectly in the realm of graphic novels. His big explosions and blood obsession makes it a giant film with so much action. Never a dull moment.

Nailed it! Go watch NOW

title: Sin City Review
review:
So there I was in the fall of '05, scoping out the DVD rentals at the old shoppette, looking for the next big thrill. I just happen to look up at the TV hanging on the ceiling to see them playing one of the new releases like they always do; I see Jackie boy and his gang getting cut up by deadly little Miho, spewing white blood everywhere. Don't know how these creeps get away with playing that stuff for all the public to see, kids and all, but it hit me from that moment onward that Sin City must be a hell of a show.

The film is literally black, white, and red all over: a smooth and breezy combo of extreme style and extreme violence. It's got all the works: car chases, shootouts, fist fights, knife fights, dancing ladies, and more. Everybody here has a score to settle, and they leave body trails miles long. There's so much blood, it's ridiculous. The sheer brutality makes it all a real whopper too. As much of a looker as the movie is, and with all its moxie, it's the stuff that comic book dreams are made of.

This picture takes after four of Frank Miller's original stories. The Customer Is Always Right is a short segment (originally test footage) that sets the tone at the beginning, and rounds things off at the end. The Hard Goodbye has always been my favorite: a real hard case about a down-out-of-his-luck fella avenging a dame's death, and the resulting rampage sure is gutsy. The Big Fat Kill is consistently thrilling doozy of a tale too, showing a guy doing everything it takes to stop war breaking out on the streets. That Yellow Bastard is split up at the beginning and end, and it is a fairly touching story about a double-crossed cop trying to protect a broad. All these stories play in the tropes of hard-boiled noir stories we all know and love: it's a world where cops are rotten, everybody with power is corrupt, criminals are noble anti-heroes, and they're all using brute force to worm their way out of exploitation and to find their own brand of justice. It's definitely amoral territory, but that's pretty much the point, and the movie handles the goods in all the right ways to make each story hit on all six.

Photography is solid. Editing has a few choppy parts, but a lot of it is precise and good. It's especially swell considering that most everything was shot on green-screens, and even the actors had to be spliced in together to make their scenes work. There are a lot of crazy lighting, coloring, and transition effects, most of which hold up, but there are times when it seems kinda cheap. The whole movie looks cartoony and processed, but as a moving comic book, it works great. All the players are ace. Writing can be blunt and choppy, but it helps the style. This production has some fine-looking sets, props, costumes. Most special effects hold up, especially considering that most of the movie is computer-animated. The music's not bad either.

Booze, babes, guns, cars, tough guys, blood...you find the right alley in Sin City, you can find anything. Recommended for mature audiences.

If you bag this on home video, you can either see this as one big cut with all the stories cut up precisely, or with each story separate with some good new scenes. Both ways work great in their own ways.

4.5/5 (Entertainment: Perfect | Stories: Very Good | Film: Good)

title: Original style
review: Based on the Frank Miller graphic novel series and directed mainly by Robert Rodriguez, this has 4 stories of Basin City; The Hard Goodbye, The Big Fat Kill, That Yellow Bastard and The Customer is Always Right. It's a highly stylized black and white visual with splashes of brilliant colors. It is completely unique and original. It fits the stories and the genre so well. 'Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow' tried something similar but that one doesn't have the edge. That one felt lifeless whereas this one is overflowing with power. The actors are all embodying the old hard-boiled noir style of acting. They are successful for the most part. Mickey Rourke is the best of them all. For some reason, he doesn't seem to be acting whereas everybody else are just pretending. He embodies his character so well that it doesn't even feel like he's acting.

title: Definitely the WORST movie I have ever suffered through
review: Oh this movie was so bad I don't know where to begin. Black and white? Really? Then there's the sadistic nature of everyone in it. The gore, the blood, that disgusting yellow guy; everything in this film is unpleasant and disturbing. I didn't even like the protagonist to be honest. Aside from what I said, the story didn't make any sense to me, and I still don't know how in the world I sat through all of it. I didn't think I would find a movie that was going to be worse than the "Scary movie" series, but this one tops that too in the list of the "WORST MOVIES OF ALL TIME." I really don't understand how it got such a high rating.

title: Studied Camp In Pulp Noir Setting
review: That's what it feels like watching this film. It's a tour-de-force in post modern smugness. The actors deliver lines as if in the worst Corman adaptation of a Chandler novel, and the whole enterprise seems like a mash-up of cultural anachronisms, a patchwork of Noir, John Woo and punk. People have told me the comic is like this, but that just means the source material is a lazy exercise in self-indulgent genre 'subversion'. "Get this, I can write like Raymond Chandler, but add gun-wielding punk prostitutes and mutants, that makes this art!" No, it makes it affected and tedious postmodern claptrap. The sort of thing a pretentious 17-year old English literature student considers an art film, or Tarantino an auteur.

title: Proves why fidelity to the source material is not always a good quality in movie adaptations
review:
If what you want is something relentlessly faithful to the source material, Sin City is THE movie for you. If what you want is a good film, Sin City is an amateurish mess.

Based on the comic books by Frank Miller and yes, most of them are comic books not graphic novels, this movie takes three Sin City tales and compresses them into one interwoven film. Mickey Rourke is Marv, a superhumanly tough thug out to avenge the death of a beautiful woman murdered next to him in bed. Bruce Willis is Hartigan, a superhumanly tough senior citizen cop out to protect a beautiful girl from the sick bastard who wants to kill her. Clive Owen is Dwight, a superhumanly tough guy hiding from his past and out to protect beautiful prostitutes from a rogue cop named Jack Rafferty (Benicio Del Toro) and the mob that wants to bring the women back into their control. If you're noticing a bit of similarity between those three stories, you're on the right track.

What's good -

Dwight having an imaginary conversation with a corpse in a car, Mickey Rourke as Marv and a topless Carla Gugino.

What's bad -

The dialog is painfully stilted and stifling. Words that burn the page when linked to a single image weigh the film down like lead when spoken by actors in real-time. It's like a Shakespeare play where the characters give these long speeches and the actors have to figure out what to do while they keep talking. But while the rhythm of the Bard's words gives the actors something to hang their performances on, the repetitive Spillane-speak of Sin City traps the actors amber.

Color is splashed haphazardly throughout the film, to the point that when you finally get to That Yellow Bastard...instead of being a disturbingly creepy image, he's just another theatrical effect. Maybe there was some design to the way color was used, but I can't detect it and it all just becomes distracting with usually no reason why something is in color or why it shifts from black-and-white to rainbow and back.

Cramming several Sin City stories together also highlights the sameness of the adolescent nihilism that runs through them. The one note that Miller played so beautifully in the books is pounded into your brain over and over again.

I call it an amateurish mess, even with the talent and skill of Rodriguez and Tarantino, because just as some comic creators today refuse to utilize the full capabilities of the word and picture, Sin City abandons or rejects some of the basic things a motion picture can do. Comic and Film are two different mediums and you cannot tell the same story in each in the exact same way.

It is very visually stylized, and if that's your thing it might make up for the storytelling weaknesses of the film. If not, you'll come away wondering what all the fuss is about.

I may be a little too hard on Sin City, the movie. It may be fine as an abnormally violent, visually indulgent crime picture. But because it is almost a literal translation, it ends up being nothing like the cinematic equivalent of Miller's brilliant work.

title: What was the fuss all about
review:
The film was OK, it was watch able, but I wouldn't watch it again. (I would recommend you hire it and not buy the DVD) At the start I though this was going to be a good film, good pace, good story line, but all that disappeared after the first 30 minutes.

*** Spoiler below *****

I was just glad when Bruce Willis finally shot himself so the film could end. (just to confirm the ended you spotted at least an hour ago) Again another film that could have taken us all on an unpredictable journey ended up following the normal predictability that just makes you want the film to end.

Just another comic book that fails to deliver a plot worth talking about, why do these films always seem to be so bad, we now had; Spawn, Xmen, fab4 and Dare Devil. This is by no means an endless list; they are just the one that spring to mind.

Only the Spiderman series and the first half the new Superman films have we had a decent comic book film, since the original 3 superman films. (I know there were 4, but the last one was bad too)

title: The thinking man's Pulp Fiction
review:
Sin City is one of the greatest films of the past decade. A pure adrenaline rush of action shot with a truly epic scope, it grabs you by the throat and never lets go. A bloody mosaic of revenge tales sharply focused by unforgettable characters, Sin City is quite simply a masterpiece.

Comics are being adapted for film all the time now. Some are excellent like Superman and Batman Begins. They embody the feel of a comic in ways never thought possible. Some are completely awful like Batman & Robin, mere mockeries of their source material. Sin City sets a whole new standard.

Based on the graphic novels by Frank Miller, Sin City is film-noir pulp, shot in black and white with flickers of colour creeping into the picture, almost like Pleasantville. Both films are similar because we have these one-dimensional characters struggling to break through to all three dimensions.

Another film I'm reminded of is Pulp Fiction. Both have a similar structure and individual stories that flow into another. But Sin City is far superior. There is a human face ever-present in each one of these tales. We get beneath their skin and learn in the corrupt world of Sin City, even crazed vigilantes have human souls.

Every frame of Sin City tells a story. There is so much here it could be a TV series. Although we only see three stories, by the end, we've learnt so much we feel like we've penetrated the darkest recesses of this city.

The film begins innocently enough with a three minute prologue that in a way is the most intriguing story for me. A beautiful woman in a red dress (and red lips), surrounded by black and white. Standing on a veranda to get some air from a party, she's joined by a smooth talker, who instinctively knows she's running from something. That in itself would make a great setup for a story. Unfortunately we never find out what she's running from, and neither does her companion, when he kills her.

That death scene is ironically one of Sin City's quieter moments. But it's interesting because even at this early stage, we know that every person in this city has something to hide. On to the next story, where Hartigan (Bruce Willis), one of the few decent cops left in this city is about to retire because of a heart problem.

Hartigan is searching for Nancy, a child kidnapped by Junior Roarke, the son of a powerful senator. He's already killed four children, but the law can't touch him because of his connections. Before Roarke has his wicked way with her, Hartigan catches up, and kills him. And then gets killed himself. For being the only decent cop, willing to do the right thing. That story would seem to be at an end. Only to be picked up later. Remember, in Sin City nothing is what it seems.

The next story is my favourite. Marv (brilliantly played by Mickey Rourke) is a sociopath with hidden layers. He spends the night with a hooker, Goldie. The film makes a point of this by illuminating her golden locks in stark contrast to the black and white of everything else. The next morning, Goldie is dead, and the police blame Marv for her murder.

Marv goes on the run, and journeys into the seedy corners and seamy underside of Sin City to find Goldie's killer, and avenge her. Marv has more than a passing resemblance to Hellboy, and it's great fun watching this tortured monster trying to reclaim his soul, even if it means committing murder to do it.

Throwing out wisecracks every five seconds, Mickey Rourke gives one of his best performances in years. His internal monologue allows us to get right inside Marv's psyche, easily enabling us to side with him on his vendetta. Special mention should also go to Elijah Wood in this segment as Goldie's killer, Kevin. Radiating a steely eyed coldness behind a pair of glasses and a thin smile, he makes a huge impression whenever he's around and does it without ever uttering a single word.

Marv's is quite a tragic tale. Taken by a hooker he hardly knew, he fell in love with somebody who probably only viewed it as a one night stand. And yet he was willing to give everything for her. Just because she showed an interest in him. Marv is such a complex character, he should get his own series.

The next story is the longest, and exposes the corruption that exists in this city. A battle between Irish radicals and weapon wielding whores on the streets. This initially didn't engage me as much as the others, but after a while it did. There are some marvellous action scenes, and a fine turn from the ever impressive Michael Clarke Duncan as the radicals ringleader. It's quite a virtuoso battle, like something out of a Viking novel.

Bruce Willis' tale picks up again, where he actually survived, but thanks to that same corrupt senator, gets wrongfully imprisoned for Nancy's abduction. Nancy and Hartigan strike up a friendship through letters, keeping him alive throughout his imprisonment. When he's released, he checks up on her, the only person left in his life who means anything to him.

Nancy is now a stripper (fetchingly played by Jessica Alba), sending the message that in Sin City, either you grow up fast, or you may not grow up at all. Hartigan has to save her again from the same abductor, who's now a grotesque creature called Yellow Bastard. A fierce battle ensues, with Hartigan making a noble sacrifice for Nancy.

I understand there are sequels in the pipeline. I can't wait. I want to learn more about the fascinating denizens of this city. This film is a breathtaking, stunning tapestry of events, beautifully realised, impeccably crafted, bringing to life the marvellous world of Sin City.

title: Sin City
review: Based on the graphic novel series by Frank Miller, he co-directs with Robert Rodriguez (Desperado, From Dusk Till Dawn), as well as guest direction from Quentin Tarantino (Pulp Fiction, Kill Bill) for one sequence, to bring his comic book creation to life. Basically the film sees three interlinked stories set in the dark and miserable ultra- violent metropolis town of Basin City, nicknamed "Sin City", specifically characters embroiled in all forms of crime, from corrupt cops, dangerous criminals and femme fatales. Aging police officer John Hartigan (Bruce Willis) stops serial child killer Roark Junior (Nick Stahl) from raping and killing his fourth known victim, eleven year old Nancy Callahan (Saw's Makenzie Vega), the police have been bribed by Junior's father Senator Roark (Tombstone's Powers Boothe) to cover up his crimes. Hartigan's corrupt partner Bob (Michael Madsen) told him to walk away, but he refused, Hartigan catches up to Roark Junior in a warehouse, despite his bad heart, he does get shot in the shoulder but Hartigan shoots off Junior's ear, hand and genitals, after that Bob has recovered and shoots Hartigan in the back, but sirens are heard approaching and Nancy is safe and sound, for now. Marv (Mickey Rourke) has a one-night stand with Goldie (Jaime King), but waking up finds her dead, he flees to avoid framing and explains to his lesbian parole officer Lucille (Spy Kids' Carla Gugino) he will avenge her death, through informants he finds out the Roark family murdered her, he goes to the family farm, only to be subdued by silent stalker and Goldie's killer Kevin (Elijah Wood), he wakes up in a basement with Lucille. She explains the killer is a cannibal and that Goldie was a prostitute, corrupt cops kill Lucille, while Marv kills the cops, apart from the leader who reveals Cardinal Patrick Henry Roark (Rutger Hauer) arranged Goldie's murder in Sin City's red-light district Marv convinces Goldie's identical twin sister Wendy (Jaime King) he is not the killer, she and him return to the farm where Marv kills Kevin, after hearing the cardinal's confession that he and Kevin ate prostitutes to "consume their souls" he kills the cardinal, but in the end Marv is captured by the cops and executed in the electric chair. Shellie (Brittany Murphy) is harassed by her abusive ex-boyfriend Jackie Boy (Benicio Del Toro) and his cronies, her current boyfriend Dwight McCarthy (Clive Owen) violently warns him to leave her alone, and he follows the thugs to Old Town to find them harassing young prostitute Becky (Alexis Bledel), prostitute leader Gail (Rosario Dawson) also witnesses the scene, so martial arts expert Miho (Devon Aoki) kills Jackie Boy and the gang. But then they find out he is "hero cop" Detective Lieutenant Jack Rafferty, if the cops find out he has been killed the truce between them and the prostitutes will end and the mob could wage war, Dwight goes to the tar pits to dispose of the bodies, a hired mercenary almost gets hold of Jackie Boy's severed head until it is retrieved, but Gail is kidnapped by mob enforcer Manute (Michael Clarke Duncan) who forces her to betray the prostitutes, but Dwight trades them the head for Gail's life, only to have the head stuffed with explosives, and the mercenaries are gunned down by the prostitutes. Hartigan has recovered in hospital, but Junior is in a coma, Nancy promises to write to write anonymous letters to him while he is framed and put in prison, this continues for eight years, but the letters stop and he receives a severed finger, so he confesses to the given crimes and gets parole, he searched for and finds adult Nancy Callahan (Jessica Alba) working at Kadie's Bar as an exotic dancer. Hartigan realises however he was set up, the Yellow Bastard, who is actually Junior (Nick Stahl), deformed due to years of regenerative surgery, attacks and takes Nancy to the family farm, but Hartigan catches up, fakes a heart attack, and gets the chance to kill Junior, with Nancy safe he knows that Senator Roark will continue hunting them, so to ensure her safety Hartigan kills himself, justifying it as a "fair trade". Also starring Josh Hartnett as The Man, Marley Shelton as The Customer, Arie Verveen as Murphy, Frank Miller as Priest, Insomnia's Nicky Katt as Stuka, Tommy Flanagan as Brian and Rick Gomez as Klump. Willis is indeed poignant as the disgraced cop who will do anything to protect the girl, Owen is good as the tough private eye, Del Toro is suitably dark humoured, Alba is sexy as the victim dancer, but it is indeed Rourke who steals the show as the soft-hearted ex-con out to kill his sweetheart's killers. The film does have cheesy dialogue and one or two small repetitive moments, but with great chase and gun filled sequences, accompanied with high bloody violence, it doesn't matter, but what really makes this film really stand out is the sensational colour, like an authentic comic book, filmed in black and white it's the splashes of bright colours, especially in the violent and sexy scenes, overall it is a great neo-noir action thriller. Bruce Willis was number 35 on The 100 Greatest Movie Stars. Very good!

title: Black and White, it's Dynamite
review:
Sin City, a film noir spectacular, created by the one and only Frank Miller (responsible for some of the greatest Batman stories ever told) was, by far 2005's best film. It was stylish, intense, funny, action packed, but most importantly, a spectacular film.

Right from the start you know you're not in for a normal one hour and thirty minute run-of- the-mill movie. It grabs you by the collar of your trench coat and pulls you into its tales of sexy dames, killers with hearts of gold and ultra-violence.

The violence, and boy, is there a lot, isn't to much to handle, thanks to the MPAA forcing Robert Rodriguez to cut out some blood, is perfectly executed. It matches panel for panel the genius comic that Miller created and wrote. It never gets to be to much to handle, and most importantly you care deeply for the characters by the time the movies done with.

The acting was stellar, with Mickey Rourke and Clive Owen giving the performances of their careers. Rourke especially as the big lug known simply as Marv.

All in all, the film was a great success. I loved every minute of it. Definitely a must-see for anyone who's a fan of the graphic novels.

title: Top 5 best movies
review:
Three words: Oh my God!!! I've never seen a movie like this.... The concept of shooting a black & white movie with some fades of color is brilliant. I cannot compare this movie to any other movie, but it is definitely in my movie top 5 which also holds Pulp Fiction. But I cannot say if its better, because it's a total different movie.

Bruce Willis finally plays a great role again and also Clive Owen has definitely made his breakthrough now. It's even cool to see 'hobbit' Elijah Wood as a stone cold killer and Benicio Del Toro in a very cool role. Also cool is Rutger Hauer in a major movie again.

But the star of the movie is of course Mickey Rourke. He has the coolest character with sharp one liners. Cool to see him back! The women all act very very good.. A break through for Jessica Alba.

It's almost impossible to think that the entire movie was shot on a green screen.

It is going to be a long time before I'm gonna see a movie as good as this one and it's also been a long time.

title: An award winning masterpiece
review: Sin City is a graphic and fascinating tale of human minds when confronted with kindness and love; the old ways of unquestionable dedication to individuals that have been saved by unconditional love. Each character, despite their anger and violence, had a sense of morality that doesn't openly exist in the modern world. This film showed humanity in people with the world in its worst possible state, whilst also showing pure evil in others. The plot, although interconnected, managed to portray each story individually well. Consequently, the experience of the story and characters is rewarding in itself. Then came the direction. Robert Rodriguez is an excellent director but in addition to the story, he managed to shoot a masterpiece totally in green screen. Quentin Tarantino added an aspect that completed the masterpiece and Frank Miller provided characters that will never really be forgotten. In conclusion, Sin City can intrinsically be described as drinking absolute vodka in a Jaguar X8 with your soul mate, on the way to a six month vacation in the Caribbean.

title: Long Overdue... and Well Worth the Wait
review:
Over time I've come to abandon hope of a movie being made based on material originally from a comic book or graphic novel that was not only faithful to the source material, but actually conveyed the same atmosphere and feeling as the original. Sin City has changed that.

This is what happens when Hollywood bypasses its default settings and allows true creative minds to do their thing. It's by far the best new movie I've seen in the last couple of years. The casting was spot-on. Every frame of action is a work of art in itself, following Frank Miller's tales of two-time losers and sultry dames -- virtually panel for panel from the original artwork -- giving the viewer a visual treat not to be found elsewhere.

I first read the Sin City stories when they were published in the 1990s. Dwight, Gail, good IL' Marv and Miho -- deadly little Miho -- became like old and memorable pals. I found myself repeating bits and pieces of dialogue from those pages years down the line, often forgetting where I'd first picked them up. In short, the series was and is by far one of my all-time favorites in the underrated art form. And I couldn't be happier that now, finally, a film has come along that does it justice.

Ten out of ten. I give Sin City my highest possible recommendation. See it in the theater.

title: Great Comic Movie!
review:
Sin City was a great comic, and thus, a great movie. It isn't a realistic drama nor is it another Kill Bill type action fest. Instead, its an odd mixture of 50's noir; hard boiled cops (Hartigan) and tough guys (Marv) along with a host of other typical noir characters fight for their women in a city full of corruption and sin. Its a merger of old school noir and modern day action, and what a mixture it is. The cinematography is superb, with some really striking imagery (white silhouettes instead of regular black ones is one of the easiest examples of this stylistic approach).

All in all, its an excellent tribute to the comic, which itself is a great tribute to the noir genre of film.

title: Simply Awesome
review: I love violent movies. They rock. And with this film, you get plenty. You get hacked off hands, heads, and cannibalism. It is simply brilliant. And as an avid reader of the Sin City comics, I am proud of the work they put into it to make a righteous film worth calling the best graphic comic film ever! If you were a fan of Pulp Fiction, or the Desperado series, this film is the only equal out there that you can find. It is just as brilliant, there is a wry wit to the dialogue, and the stars aren't ridiculous- they are their characters- not actors playing themselves, playing their role. There aren't any witty lines for Willis, they are all served cold, and powerfully. If ever a action packed r-rated film with animation were to win an Oscar it'd be this one.

title: Frank Miller should write more for movies!
review:
This movie gives a great boost to Miller fans everywhere! It's writing like this that makes Frank Miller an Icon in the comic book industry. The only thing better than the dialog was the color. B&W with accents of color where needed! How great is that?

If you haven't ever read any of Miller's works, I suggest to pick-up some of the graphic novels and read them cover-to-cover. You won't regret it.

From Batman to Daredevil, Frank Miller has brought some of the greatest stories of superhero legends ever told. If they had just used his Year One writing for the Batman movies, they would've been even better.

title: This Movie is a masterpiece of post modern noir
review:
After I saw this movie I knew not what I have seen but I know that I loved it then. I searched through out my old collection of 50's noir and after watching, some fav titles of mine. I have to say this movie is a rebirth of that genre. But done in fantastical world called Basin City, what made me fall in love with. This film is how they take the comic book genre or should I say graphic novel, making a whole new genre that is neo-noir now. I've heard and read how most people have focused on. The gore and violence in this film but what they do not understand is. That the violence the gore is the brush they chose to use to paint this beautiful work of art.

Everything about this from the direction down to the design and look are brilliant. I enjoyed how the actors became there characters and can you talk about a better cast. I loved how they used this voice over like They did in old noir to give a look into. The depths of the person soul, I especially loved the Dwight character he seemed the most tormented. When the corpse start talking to him was genius to show he was not at all in the right state of mind. This movie works on some many levels though I must say this movie is not so much for the children it very adult but very amazing 10 out 10.

title: Perfect
review:
Let me cut straight to the point. Sin City was by far one of the best movies that I have ever had the privilege of watching.

From minute one of this masterpiece, you can give up reality and surrender everything to this movie. The action is non-stop, as is the violence and the gore, and just when you think things are going to calm down... BAM!!! Miller and Rodriguez kick you square in the nuts with an economy sized boot of action to make sure you're not going to forget this movie experience. I won't even mention what the plot's awesomeness could do to you because that's far to graphic for this review.

Now, on to the characters. I will say that casting half of Hollywood has been the downfall for many movies, but Sin City takes that concept and double-barrel-shotgun-blasts it right out the window. The performances were solid. Mickey Rourke as Marv = HARDCORE!!! Jessica Alba alone could have made this movie sexy, but let me say that the other women in this movie did a good job contributing to Sin City's, dare I say... Sinfulness. Willis and Owen were also outstanding. These two guys bring the pain to the umpteenth level. Finally, Elijah Wood... Wow... so Elijah's character, Kevin, was like taking Charlie Brown, Wolverine, and Hannibal Lector and rolling them into a nice neat little psychopath. True bad-asses. Every single one of them.

"I'm still trying to put my face back together because Sin City rocked my face off so much."

Sin City is, for lack of a better word, Perfect...

title: It'd be a Sin to miss out on this film, which is without a doubt the most faithful comic adaptation of all time.
review:
Based on three of Frank Miller's Sin City graphic novels, Robert Rodriguez has co-directed the film with Miller himself to create the most loyal comic adaptation ever seen on screen. The film opens with the first portion of the story, That Yellow Bastard, which stars Bruce Willis, Jessica Alba and Nick Stahl. Willis is a detective named Hardigan tracking down a pervert who has kidnapped a little girl named Nancy (Alba plays the older Nancy).

One of the things I was really looking forward to was Powers Boothe and Michael Madsen. Two of my favorite actors, and I haven't seen them in role that fit them for a while. And I was not disappointed. Boothe owned the role of the slimy Governor Rourk. He fits the role. He gives a real darkness to the character. As for Madsen, he IS his role as Willis's "partner" Bob. He also gives a mysterious part to the role I can't quite put my finger on. But it's there.

He rescues her from the deranged son of Sin City's senator, Roark, Jr. (Nick Stahl). The story continues at the end with Nancy all grown up and sexy and the senator's son a little more yellow. The second story is The Hard Goodbye and follows the adventures of Marv, appropriately played by Mickey Rourke. Marv is a tough street fighter who's just had the night of his life with a beautiful woman named Goldie (Jaime King). He wakes up the next day to find her lying dead next to him. Marv unleashes a brutal quest for revenge, killing or reassembling anyone who gets in his way. Co-starring is Elijah Wood, Rutger Hauer and Powers Boothe.

Finally, The Big Fat Kill stars Clive Owen as Dwight, a P.I. trying to keep things clean in a dirty city. The cops are corrupt and have a deal with the hookers who live in Old Town  basically don't cause trouble and we'll turn a blind eye to what you do. When a cop winds up dead at the hands of the ladies of the night, the "something" is about to hit the fan. Co-starring are Rosario Dawson, Benicio Del Toro, Brittany Murphy and Michael Clarke Duncan. That's about as much info as I can give about these stories without spoiling the fun.

I absolutely love how the film opens. That one scene and all it's brilliant dialog more or less spells out what is yet to come. The film is 18A for a reason. It is incredibly brutal. For example, I'd never once thought I'd describe killings in a movie being more than one castration. You can expect blood to fly, heads to roll, limbs to be severed and pretty much everything else you can expect.

Mickey Rourke gives a brilliant performance as Marv. His whole scene I felt uncomfortable. It was an incredibly brutal scene, that involves an equally creepy Elijah Wood. I'll get to that later. Throughout the scene you can really understand why Marv is seeking revenge for his one night stand. He really was in love. He never had that before. Rourke really hit the nail on the head with this one. Elijah Wood gives his best performance ever, which is a non-speaking role, as the cannibalistic Kevin. A deeply disturbed man.

Bruce Willis gives yet another great performance. But who steals the show in the Willis saga is Jessica Alba just because, well you know. She's too sexy. But anywho. The reason why the movie is the greatest comic book movie ever made is because it looks and acts exactly like the comic book. The characters look and act exactly the way they were in the books. I imagine if you look at the comics and watched the movie, I wouldn't know the difference. It's just as brutal as the books, and it's brilliant use of colors and lack there of is even better.

I don't care what anyone says, this IS the best comic book movie ever. I respect their opinions of course, but it'll be difficult to find one that has the look and feel of the actually comic. That's what a comic book movie is supposed to be. And Sin City is all that, and so much more. Any fan of the comic, as I am, will NOT be disappointed. And it'll make fans out of it. As with many of my friends. This movie is a movie I will not soon forget.

*****/*****

title: Not what you'd expect from the commercials
review:
After watching "the making of..." and late night interviews with some of the actors on TV, I thought I knew what I was expecting when watching this flick. A "cool" black and white film shot on green screen, stunning effects, angles galore, and an dark story line. Oh yea...and Jessica Alba looking mighty foxy.

The intro was interesting but the rest of the movie left me bored and shaking my head. At one point, there came a scene which resulted in several people in the audience laughing and saying "You gotta be kiddin" and "That's crazy"...etc. If I wasn't one of those people who stick to the "Silence is Golden" rule, I would have shouted the same utterings.

This movie, although very creative and full of eye-candy, is just too dark, sinister and gory for the average crowd. The violence (oh, the violence) is rampant. I don't think the people in our theater were expecting this much blood and guts. And what's with the talking Pez Head??? (inside joke) My wife was freaking out. She turned to me and said "Wake me up when Bruce Willis comes back on". She got a good hour of sleep until he returned.

On a positive note, I truly liked Micky Rourke's return to cinema as Marv. I was thrilled to see a good guy turn into "bad" good guy. He was ruthless...and to the point.
