He didn't let crap get in his way and his lines were priceless. They could have written a 2 hour movie called "Marv" and I would have loved it. Wish we could all have heroes like him.

The effects are pretty cool and it feels like the comic novel comes to life. However, the scenes and dialog are pretty sappy and you too might find yourself talking back to the screen with "WHAT THE HELL WAS THAT???!!!". Viewer beware.

title: One Helluva Guy Movie
review: I went to this movie without any expectations except for stylized action. I walked out with my jaw dropped, and my heart still beating from the adrenaline. Sin City is one rough, dirtied up place. It's got hookers, dirty cops, crooks around every corner, bad politicians, even cannibals. Everybody shoots first and asks questions later. What else could a guy ask for? I would like to say that Clive Owen and Mickey Rourke did an especially awesome job. While this movie is as close to perfect as it gets, nothing is perfect. It's kinda hard to believe that Bruce Willis is close to his seventies. Also, I would've liked more background on Josh Hartnett's character. And my last complaint is that everyone has the same tough guy voice. Except maybe Clive Owen. It just gets confusing, because everybody's voice is the same, and they often have you reading the characters minds. Oh, and one more teeny little thing, they could have told us with a little less confusion when we change stories and time lines. But that's as far as the complaints go. This movie has three different stories, which tie up loosely at the end. Each story is intriguing, but what'll really blow you away is the visuals. I think that Robert Rodriguez made a smart move leaving the Directors Guild for this movie. The little splashes of color are the perfect touch. But man, this movie's got blood, gore, action, bullets, punch outs, boobs (lots of boobs, don't take your girlfriend to this one) and kick ass driving scenes. What more could a guy ask for?

title: Masterpiece
review:
Films based on comic books (aka graphic novels) are often a hit or miss situation. There have been some great hits: Spider-Man, Batman, X-Men...and some notorious misses: The Punisher, Daredevil. Sin City, based off of Frank Miller's series of graphic novels, is not just a hit, it is without a doubt the best film adaptation of a comic ever. The story (or actually 4 different stories that are loosely connected by their shared setting) is captivating from the very start, filled with indomitable heroes, sympathetic anti-heroes, despicable villains, and one down right freaky Elijah Wood. The casting for this film employs a long list a stars and "little" stars which, to my pleasant surprise, emboldens an already spectacular film. Visually, the film is so sleek, so unconventional, so comic bookish it is down right beautiful. You feel like you are actually inside the graphic novel and almost forget that this is a live-action film. More films should be done in black and white (with a little bit of spot-coloring for intensity).

Bewarned, Sin City is not for the faint of heart. The film is filled with lots and lots of violence: a broken bone here, a decapitated head here, a dismembered victim here, an impaled head here, a guy punching another's face to a bloody pulp here...you get the idea. But, despite this, the violence is not "gratuitous" but completely necessary for the film. There are also nudity in this film along with one sex scene. The language for the most part is imperceivable, you are so engulfed by the story and the violence that the language just doesn't register. The film also deals with issues that are completely not appropriate for young kids: cannibalism, vengeance by any means necessary (see the explanation on violence), molesting serial killers, and torture to name a few.

The film is rated R for the above reasons mention and that warning should be heeded.

A masterpiece through and through, an instant classic.

title: Toto, I don't think we're in Kansas anymore
review:
Or perhaps that should read, "Frodo, I don't think we're in the Shire anymore," considering how one of our all-time favorite hobbits mutates into an insatiable, head-collecting cannibalistic psycho in Frank Miller's Sin City, without even blinking an eye (literally).

He's only one of the many deranged lunatics we get to spend quality time with in the dark, courtesy of Robert Rodriguez's undeniably faithful film version of Miller's intense and brutal graphic novels. With a screenplay by Miller himself and co-directed by him (with a guest-director credit to Tarantino - what would Sin City be without his contribution, I ask you!?), we get to take a trip the likes of which we've never taken in a movie theatre before, and hopefully we'll never have to take again, but that's just my opinion.

Don't get me wrong, the film is a stupendous achievement, visually - if you've ever read any of the Sin City graphic novels, you'll recognize the place immediately from the very first shot: beautiful, bleak, barren, brutal - all the good 'b' words. And the stories weave together brilliantly, there's no question: the film works on a plot level too. The performances couldn't be any better either, particularly Mickey Rourke's portrayal of Marv: covered in band-aids, brandishing bucketloads of bile, with a prosthetic profile which looks like a combination of Kirk Douglas and Roy Scheider, this is most definitely the role he was born to play.

And you want babes? There's plenty of babes, most of 'em decked out in bondage gear to beat the band, and they're just as hell-bent on kickin' major butt as their male counterparts, make no mistake. Sounds really swingin' so far, huh? But remember, this is a Rodriguez/Tarentino joint, so of course it's gotta be more than just tastefully violent, it's gotta be yer basic beyond-the-levels-of-human-endurance affair, with broken bodies, half-eaten bodies, Pez-dispensered heads and severed heads galore, and this is just in the first hour. The person I saw it with had her eyes closed nearly the entire time, but that still couldn't shield her from the carnage, because, this, being a Rodriguez/Tarantino joint, remember, has to also include the characters' graphic verbal rehash of the violence: what had just happened to the victim, what it felt like when it happened, and what was going to happen next. So if you're especially squeamish, bring ear plugs to the theatre as well as your eye mask.

When I was watching the film, I couldn't help thinking how much fun making this movie had to have been, especially for Frank Miller, to finally get to see his vision brought so lovingly to life, and this got me through some of the most bombastically brutal sequences. Don't get me wrong again, Sin City is not an incoherent exercise in excessively over-the-top self indulgence (a la From Dusk Til Dawn). It's worth seeing, especially if you could sneak an extremely large flask into the theatre with you (which I kept wishing we had done).

title: pure, genius direction
review:
A lot of other people have adapted millers character but watching SIN CITY is watching his amazing creation, SIN CITY come to life, and to commend the excellent editing , story telling, acting etc , i would just say that this is direction at its best. A PURE, GENIUS direction.

If you really wanna enjoy the movie for what it is and if you haven't read the SIN CITY comics, see the movie , then read the 7 books and then see it again , you will be blown away by it.

Watching the movie without reading the comics, i guess would still be fun if you enjoyed once upon a time in Mexico, kill bill , reservoir dogs and of course pulp fiction and others of this genre.

i give it a 8/10 for what it is .. an excellent transformation of a nice comic.

title: Despite Miller/Rodriguez/Taratino anti-Religious Paranoia, pretty good
review:
I awaited this movie for months, and despite the fact that the directors paint religious people with a broad, negative brush, it more or less delivers.

I liked the creativity of the occasional color splashed against the back and white, tweaking the traditional motif of most film noir movies being completely aesthetically black and white. Sin City revives a genre that is dying on the vine.

I also think that the dialog is some of the best of its kind. It's descriptive yet staccato enough to stay cool, which is the ultimate demand of a film noir film.

The violence is not for everyone. It in fact is over the top, primarily in the Tarantino directed sequences (you'll know when).

Religious people do not commit acts of such brutality that are perpetrated in this film. If the character who killed so many people were gay or of some other social minority, many people would take to the streets in protest.

I will overlook the fact that a groups was painted with such a broad brush in favor of me being a comic book fan who has waited a long time to see this movie. Recommended with great reservation.

title: A Great Landmark in Cinema History
review:
I saw Sin City on opening night at my local theater. I was expecting something good and entertaining, but I my expectations were blown out of the water by this beautifully constructed, magnificently written, and awesomely acted piece of art.

First, I must talk about Robert Rodriguez. The man is not afraid to push boundaries and break rules, which has payed off well every time. This is, in my opinion, his best film, and I've seen them all. The directing here is next to flawless. Every frame of this film looks great. He can get his actors to do things you wouldn't expect from them. This is most obvious in Elijah Wood's role as Kevin. He is flat-out creepy as the cannibalistic Christian. Rodriguez's best film to date, and I'm praying for a sequel.

Next, the writing. Brilliant. Thats all I can say. Miller knows what he's doing when it comes to this. The characters are all well developed, the plots are new and unpredictable, and the violence isn't there for the sake of violence, it actually has something to do with the storyline. 2 thumbs up to Miller for this great story.

Finally, the acting. Every actor looks like his or her counterpart in the graphic novels. They are all brilliant, Miller and Rodriguez really lucked getting all these great actors. I must say I was blown away by DelToro, as always. He is so hate-able yet lovable as the corrupt cop Jackie-Boy. His speech in the car with Dwight is hilariously well done with the shifting voices. Rourke is does a bang-up, and I mean bang-up, job as Marv, the hardcore fighter out for revenge of his one true love. Jessica Alba doesn't disappoint either, which I was expecting. But I must say, my favorite here was Alexis Bledel. She is so convincing as a teenage whore who loves her mother. She is the most believable of all the actors here, and I can see her career flourishing in the near future. Hats-off to all on board here, you did a great job.

This is truly a comic book come to life. The dialog is laughable sometimes, but you must give them credit for staying so true to the films origins. The only word i can use to describe this movie is...fun. It is really just a joy to watch these actors and directors having such a great time making such a great movie. As an aspiring film-maker, movies like this are the reason I want to make films. It pushes the boundaries of what has been done before, and sets the bar mighty high for the next comic book-turned-film.

9 out of 10 stars here.

title: Amazingly dark and creative
review:
Sin City is the ultimate film noir. Perpetual night and dark alleyways and bars serve as the setting for 3 stories that cross each other only slightly, each portraying flawed heroes brutally fighting the darkest characters of Sin City.

Dialogue is quick-witted, flippant, coarse. Voice-over narration creates a mood not unlike the hardboiled detective story. Combine that with creative artistic touches of color and a very comic-booky look, and you have Sin City.

Or not quite. There is also the harsh violence and frequent nudity . . . Though the trailers may mislead one into thinking this is a straightforward action film, it is a far deeper and darker and more disturbing film. And that is to its credit. At the same time, the violence is cleverly masked in many parts to make it bearable, even humorous.

Kudos to Rodriguez for making this film. It is definitely a unique movie experience

title: Great
review: Sin City was very well done. The whole 3 directors doesn't pull away from the story at all. The way everything is done with color it awesome. Only one draw back was that it was a little slow, but that could have been watching it at 1 in the morning. The story pattern isn't the traditional style (beginning, middle, end) it is more of mixed but makes sense. I was disappointed with the ending, but it is based off a comic and those don't tend to offer answers. All of the actors did a great job, but it's a comic so don't think that they stick around for a long time. You have to know how to stick with several stories at once, if not you will be lost. Oh, and it is a hard R, nudity and very graphic killings and such, it was great.

title: Everything a buff could want.
review:
"By Jove! I've never seen anything so unreal in my life. And earth struck me as something great and invincible, like evil or truth, waiting patiently for the passing away of this fantastic invasion." Joseph Conrad's Marlow in Heart of Darkness

For the comic book geeks who can't warm up to Spiderman 2 and Hellboy film adaptations because they're dated and lack high art, Frank Miller's Sin City has some of the highest artwork ever with characters straight out of Miller's dark, post-modern noirish magazines. The film is broken up into the morbid adventures of three very tough guys in the fictional Basin City and a bevy of scantily clad femme fatales as deadly as the guys. Against a backdrop of a perfectly CGI'd city, this film has everything a buff could want except sophisticated plot, never a demand when artwork dominates. Sin City abounds, however, in themes of honor, lust and redemption, the stuff of hard-boiled film noir.

Of the three heroes in three stories, Mickey Rourke as Marv is the most memorable, made up like Hellboy, just as impervious to pain as that bad boy, and tender to his women, albeit they are super efficient at prostitution or assassination, depending on the need. The impressive Bruce Willis is Frank Hartigan, ex-cop on his last day before retirement, looking after the welfare of an 11-year old girl, who just happens to be an attractive grown up 19 when he is released from jail. Don't ask; it's complicated but comprehensible when you view the film. For the women, Rosario Dawson as Gail the hooker Valkyrie is unbeatably tough and gorgeous, and just as dangerous as the men for those traits.

The black and white of film noir, which accentuates the broad conflict between good and evil, is splashed with bits of color, especially red blood, and yellow, for that matter. The heroes are about as flawed as a Bogart detective on a bad day, and the women as voluptuous as an R rating will allow before it turns to NC-17. Although the three minimalist plots seem to revolve around some type of revenge, the important element is the evocation of an underworld unremittingly evil, just short of a true hell on earth. Because this is Frank Miller's comic book world, men are riddled with bullet holes but often recover to find revenge another day.

Rourke's confrontation with a powerful bishop and his murderous son is a tribute to Miller's vision of a flawed universe, where evil is unchecked and churches are often at the center of corruption. Sounds like today to me.

title: Biggest Piece
review: Fantastic special effects and camera work really done well on that end. On the other end though this movie is the biggest piece of gynocetric trash I've seen to date. It's also way to politically correct for a bunch of people who live in an evil dark awful town. Everyone in this movie is bad yet there concerned about some hookers getting killed even though frame after frame after frame men are being slaughtered and nobody is saying a darn thing. Pretty soon if all the men get slaughtered the hookers aren't going to have much of a business left, but I bet none of you thought of that and then what are the hookers going to do all stand out in the cold and rain wondering what happened? (Probably) This film is total trash. I saw it when it first came out on video back in 2005-2006 didn't even make it the whole way through.

title: Worst movie I've EVER watched. Period.
review:
Yes IMDb correctly assigns the rating as "Awful" when I give it a single star. In fact, come to think of it, even awful is an understatement.

Honestly I know this film is regarded as a cult classic and dozens of people recommended this movie to me. Which is precisely the reason why I went out and bought a rather expensive DVD to watch this movie. My reaction? Well it was "Oh what style, huh...what nonsense is that?". Pretty much the same throughout the movie.

The story is harebrained as one could ever be and this is the second Robert Rodriguiez movie I've watched after death-proof (which was the worst movie I'd ever watched until I watched Sin City) and you can't make a mistake twice. There is just ridiculous blood and gore, stupid dialogs and acting that'd put a b-grade movie to shame. This chap seems to have a knack of turning out cult classics which are nothing but plain loads of nonsense.

I know not many people would write such a critical review of this movie and I don't really bother writing review on IMDb but this movie is really so bad and I'm so mad at myself for wasting my money that I felt inspired to come to IMDb and write a frank and honest review. Just because everyone else likes it does not mean its good. Think McDonalds, for example.

If you haven't watched this movie, you've saved a precious couple of hours of your life - take a walk, smell the roses, enjoy the fresh air. Stay far away from this nonsense.

title: Great Del Toro, bad Clive Owen, often laughable
review: There is one strong acting performance in this film, but this is within also the unintentionally hilarious episode, the third, with the women. Benicio del Toro's acting is detailed while no-one else's is. Clive Owen has to spout some unintentionally hilarious dialog while failing to live down his innate Britishness, while makes him ridiculous. He doesn't carry off the dialog. He lets the side down. The women are super-funny, framed as they are by some dodgy writing. Alexis Bledel from Gilmore Girls is even worse, badly miscast. The first episode is Bruce Willis in an extremely weak waste of time of a section. Bruce doesn't really fit here either, seeming so old and powerless - the actor playing the part, not only the part itself. The next section has Mickey Rourke in a part that is very little more than superhero special effects. Far, far better than this is the film Watchmen, also using graphic novel as its source.

title: A lousy yet entertaining movie
review: For anyone who has actually read sin city graphic novels it would appeal to them,however anyone who actually likes good movies I will urge you to move on. When a movie is so bad that I simply leave the theater I can easily say it wasn't good. The movie is divided up into sub stories each on liking into the other. This formula is fine and adds a unique quality to films. Except when the movie is a rotting pile of trash as in Sin City's case. The dialog in the movie seems to be more cheesy then anything with characters constantly talking to themselves. It almost makes it seem like your watching a parody of other old style movies. Violence and Sex are the two main ingredients to this movie, and sadly nothing else. no character is really memorable or likable. Honestly I was hoping and A-bomb would go off and just kill everyone. However the cheese factor plays well in it since nothing can be taken seriously its a good movie to watch with friends and joke about. I do also have to give points for the creative use of comic book black and white, plus some red occasionally.

title: Lost in translation...
review: SIN CITY (unfortunately) points up one of the major flaws with most comic books: while the writing may seem new and dynamic to regular readers of comic books (who- trust me- put up with unbelievably bad writing), it simply doesn't hold up when fleshed out. (HELLBOY is another case in point: purty pitchers, but an unvarying storyline that always ends with Mr. Boy pounding his supernatcherl adversaries into dust. Creator Mike Mignola has recently taken to lifting ideas from the late Manly Wade Wellman's Silver John the Baladeer stories and, most recent of all, "borrowing" a storyline from the teleseries ANGEL. None of it makes HELLBOY any more readable, or the movies worth watching.) Frank Miller, mistaken for God by many of the aforementioned famished fanboys because he took that bastion of Law and Order, Batman, and tried to make him out to be some kind of Outsider (when, in fact, Batman is "by the book" to the core), did a decent enough job with SIN CITY (the comic versions), but the whole thing falls flat on the Big Screen. The reason is all too obvious: the writing. Visually on a par with most video games, it just doesn't hold up where it needs it most.

title: Beautiful movie with a bit disturbing graphic violence
review:
I have not read the comics Sin City (I did pay a visit to library immediately after the movie), but I must admit, this was one of the greatest comic book adaptations I have ever seen. When I think of X-Men, which was great, or Spiderman, even though they are very unrealistic, they look so much more real life than does Sin City. Sin City really looked like a comic book made into a real movie with real actors. It had such a tremendous feeling of the comic, with people jumping off houses and landing on their feet, cars running over people who still survive. All this amazing comic stuff is in there.

Not to mention how visually beautiful the movie was. Not only did it have these adorable babes, but the whole world was visually amazing. I loved the use of black&white, with small splashes of colour here and there. Or having a whole person coloured when everything else was b&w. Wonderful way of making the viewer notice the difference between twins for example I just loved those blue eyes of Becky(?) and red shoes of Dwight! I must admit that even though everything was very much cartoon violence, there were some parts that were pretty disturbing to me. I have some problems in seeing people cut to pieces that way... even the bad guys. BUT that did not bother me so much that it would have interfered my enjoyment of the movie as a whole! I really loved the hero characters: Marv, Dwight and Hartigan. Such great guys with their own dark deep secrets. All wishing to do good in their lives and ready to sacrifice themselves for someone they love. But merciless for the people who do bad for their loved ones. Just love that.

The babes were absolutely amazing. The girls of the Old Town were marvellous. Miho with her samurai sword was beautiful, as was their leader Gail, and they were able to take care of themselves these girls, they were not just some brainless chicks. Goldie was really an angel, as was little Nancy.

All in all I loved this movie. And I'm gonna see it again. And buy the DVD.

title: The future of comic conversions...finally
review:
Very rarely do I feel compelled to submit my humble opinions on this website (mainly because I find the anally-retentive, obsessive nature of most posters quite taxing). However, Frank Miller's Sin City has rekindled a passion and respect for "multiplex " movies that I had long thought extinguished. For too long Hollywood has churned out rehashed, derivative, production-line mediocrity, with many studios simply seeking money and putting the art firmly in the back seat. To see a film such as this, a film so blindingly fresh, makes me believe there might still be hope.

As an earnest fan of graphic novels and a former film student I have waited in vain for a faithful, unrestrained comic conversion. After numerous disappointments it's finally happened. Despite not being a particular fan of all of Miller's books I have read some of the Sin City novels and found them quite enjoyable. However, I think that the film surpasses it's comic incarnation in some ways. This leads me to comment on some other reviewer's opinions that the film is "style over substance". As with any adaptation, the end product can only be representative of the source material. The nature of graphic novels (and comics in general) is very stylised, particularly the violence. Arguably the style IS the substance in that medium. Many people have complained of the excessive brutality in the film. I think this misses the point. I have a strong stomach and admittedly I also found myself feeling a bit bothered by the mindlessness of the characters actions at times. Yet, I found this worked in it's favour and only made the film stronger. After all, isn't violence supposed to be abhorrent and repulsive?

The film's characters and plot threads might not be particularly original. This doesn't matter. It displays it's reference points boldly on it's sleeve. One man's cliché is another mans archetype. This film's freshness comes from the performances and, most obviously, it's striking visual approach. This must be one of the first times I have actually forgotten that I am looking at CGI. No mean feat considering this film is almost entirely green screen. Instead of the usual "hey, look how clever we are...here's Jar Jar Binks" approach, the synergy between foreground and background is almost seamless. This is how CGI should be used, to accentuate themes and events, not replace them.

The stellar cast put in admirable performances, most notably Mickey Rourke. This is perhaps his best film since Angel Heart. He sinks his teeth into the role with gusto, much like John Travolta did in Pulp Fiction. It's strange how many actors need to drift into near obscurity before they pull out all the stops. It seems to give them a hunger and poignancy that might otherwise be lacking. Let's just hope the shouts of "comeback" don't go to his head! Elsewhere Bruce Willis earns respect as his usual brooding self. Clive Owen was perhaps miscast but is still menacing and very watchable. Benicio Del Toro is as sleazy and majestic as always. Elijah Wood was suitably eerie, without actually uttering anything (perhaps for the best ) and Nick Stahl was equally repellent as The Yellow Bastard. As for the female characters, some people have complained of misogynistic representation. I can see their point but at the same time would ask them to remember the context these characters are in. I would also argue that the female characters are some of the most powerful in the film. In particular Rosario Dawson whose character commands every scene she is in and Devon Aoki who slaughters more people than almost anyone else in the film. If the film is to be considered a homage to Film Noir, I defy anyone to show me an example in that genre where the "broads" and "dames" are this empowered or don't just swoon helplessly at the leading man.

This really is Miller's vision realised, faithfully and uncompromised. It is exactly the kind of bold audacity and artistic integrity, shown here by Robert Rodriguez and Frank Miller himself, that Hollywood has sorely lacked in recent times. This film is not meant for your average, blockbuster-consuming, movie goer However, why should films try to cater for everyone? After all, most true film fans have favourite genres and tend to stick to them and defend them vehemently. Many films try to appeal to all tastes and usually end up appealing to none. By aiming for such a specific demographic the films creators have shown guts and given a big middle finger to an otherwise played out and stale studio system. Even if you don't like this film you have to respect that

title: Captivating, but...
review:
Sin City is everything it's supposed to be. It's faithful to the original material, near-flawless in the execution, violent, visually engaging, and innovative. The latest definition of cool since Pulp Fiction. I thoroughly enjoyed it.

However ..

You can't blame anyone (male or female) for despising the movie. It's probably one of the most misogynist films ever made. With one exception, every female character is either a hooker or a stripper, and with no exceptions they all rely on a man to get them out of trouble. Jessica Alba tried to defend the movie in the press by saying she thought all the female characters were "empowered". I guess you could see it that way if you considered "whores with guns instead of pimps" to be empowerment.

The problem, if one insists on seeing it that way, is the source material. Comic books are one of the last American bastions of chauvinism (along with Tom Clancy novels). Whether you're talking comics or graphic novels, the authors are almost exclusively male, and the intended audience is as well. Women  whether they are heroines, villains, or damsels-in-distress  are there to be provocative and sell copies, and that's about it. Granted Frank Miller has transcended and redefined the genre in many ways, but even he stuck to this standard with Sin City.

Some would accuse the detractors from failing to "look past" the violence, chauvinism, and titillation to see the movie's real themes, but there's a fair question of whether the movie is really about these things or just using them to tell the story. In the end they are inseparable, because these stories can't be told any other way. And if someone can do without these stories being told at all, you have to respect that.

As I guy, I would still recommend this movie. It's supposed to show you some dark places.

title: I think I liked it
review: To start, I don't really watch a lot of television, or go to that many movies. I'm a movie renter, skip the commercials. In the 2 hours max that I sit in front of a television per week, I stumbled across the trailer for Sin City. It looked pretty action packed and full of energy, so I thought I'd give it a go at the real theatre. I agree with the previous poster about the artistic talent (both actors and presentation) making this movie different, but the straight up killing is what I enjoyed. Granted, nowadays pretty much all movies have killing in them. That or sex. And yes, this movie has both. It's the way that the kills happen that makes this movie stick out. Or is it the way the women are dressed as they blast bullets into bad guys with no regrets? Or is that part of the way the kills happen? Perhaps it's the way the kills seem so un-un-real? And yes, I meant un-un-real. On one hand, death happens very easily and fast. On the other, death is only an illusion. Perhaps it's about sex then, there were quite a few topless women throughout this movie. No, No, it's about the killing. The fact that it does capture the \ comic book / \ cartoonish / \ fantasy / mood only gets you wanting more. Or does it grasp you into the mindsets of the killers' confusion that quirks your brain to want to know what happens next simply for the fact of satisfying your innate sense to hunt?

title: Great adaptation
review:
If there is anything that must be applauded about this movie, it's two major things: The cinematography and the accuracy to the comics.

When I heard about this movie, I immediately hunted down copies of Hard Goodbye and Yellow Bastard. I loved the stories, and when I saw the movie, it was like deja vu. Certain scenes look EXACTLY like the comic, and most others are relatively close. Plus, Clive Owen really looks like Dwight, (I know that because I got A Dame to Kill For,too) Another thing that makes this movie stand out is that it doesn't wuss out. If it happens in the comic, it happens in the movie, no matter how gory or racy. There are two notable exceptions, but they are understandable. One because it would be pornographic if it was in, the other because Jessica Alba won't show her boobs. But that doesn't stop the movie from being the greatest adaptation of a comic to a movie I've seen (and I have seen the Spiderman movies)

I dare say that this movie should win an award for Best Adaptation.

title: Sin City, magnificent...
review: Having never read any of Frank Miller's Sin City comics before, I can't say I truly appreciated the adaptation that Frank Miller's Sin City movie is. Instead I'm forced to appreciate it on all the other great efforts put into this movie. Sin City is a new kind of magic, not the normal movie magic we're so used to. This is a magic that could only come from a graphic novel... or "comic book" if you're looking for the juvenile term. This is a whole new level of live action comic. Rodriguez and Miller didn't film this movie they painted it. Alexis Bledel's beautiful blue eyes, the white blood leaking out of Hartigan, The yellow slime oozing out of the Yellow Bastard. This is a masterpiece of cinematography. The structure and storytelling of it is akin to Pulp Fiction, only Pulp Fiction is much more tame by comparison. A short opening followed by three different yet slightly intertwined stories; Heartigan, Marv, and Dwight and followed by an ending that brings the film about in full circle in a way that I can only compare to Honey Bunny and Pumpkin's destiny with Jules and Vincent in the diner in Pulp. But this is no Pulp Fiction. Better or worse? No, just different. While Pulp Fiction stood out with it's amazing dialog, Sin City's spark comes from what is not said. Unlike any other comic adaptation I've seen, this film takes you inside the characters minds, it doesn't even deserve to be called voice over (or what some would say is a cheap and lazy way to move along narrative in a screenplay). The use of thought in comics is never questioned, and I'm glad Rodriguez and Miller didn't exclude it from the film for what the industry thinks of it. Instead they use it in the only way it should be used, the way Kaufman used it in Adaptation, to take us inside the minds of each character and help us understand them. We may not agree with them, we may not identify with them, but we understand them more than any dialog could help us to. Sin City is a rare thing. See it.

title: You have to see it To Believe It!!!
review:
"Sin City" is the greatest comic book adaptation of all time. Nevermind 'Spider-Man 2', which is the best SUPERHERO movie ever, But NOT the best COMIC BOOK film ever.

Directed by Robert Rodriguez ('Desperado', 'El Mariachi'), Frank Miller himself (author of 'Sin City' and 'Batman: The Dark Knight Returns'), and featuring a special guest directing job by Quentin Tarantino ('Pulp Fiction' , 'Kill Bill'), 'Sin City' tells three tales (four if you think about it). The stories are 'The Hard Goodbye', 'The Big Fat Kill', and 'That Yellow Bastard'. The cast is spectacular in this film with Mickey Rourke having the biggest impact. There is little humor in the film but what little there is, is very amusing actually. Without giving it away, one of the funniest parts is with Marv (M. Rourke) driving the car and questioning a thug in a very...um...unusual way. "I don't know about you, but i'm having a blast." he says. 'The Hard Goodbye' tells the tale of Marv who falls in love with a hooker named Goldie (Jamie King) who went to Marv for protection. He wakes up to find her murdered while they were both sleeping. He then goes on a rampage of revenge and boy, does he find it. He comes across a cannibalistic mute named Kevin who is utterly shocking. Without speaking a word, this boy will give you nightmares. This is all that will be shed about 'The Hard Goodbye'.

'The Big Fat Kill' revolves around Dwight McCarthy (Clive Owen) who is a Private Detective and goes to track down his current girlfriend's ex, Jackie Boy (Benicio Del Toro) who is ruthlessly brutal physically and verbally to Shellie (Brittany Murphy - '8 Mile'), Dwight's new girl. He ends up getting himself in a scenario that endangers the trust in Sin City between the cops, the mob and the prostitutes (who are the only 'innocent and decent' people in the town). He happens to get in trouble when he accidentally kills Benicio Del Toro and fights with himself mentally to figure out if Jackie Boy's decapitated head is talking on its own or just a figment of his imagination. These scenes are highly entertaining! Also features the characters of Becky (Alexis Bledel - TV's 'Gilmore Girls'), Gail (Rosario Dawson - 'Alexander'), and Miho (Devon Aoki - '2Fast 2Furious') in unforgettable roles.

The last story, in my opinion is the best because the characters in the film are all one dimensional yet they are pulled off perfectly. There is not enough time in each story to develop each character so don't look for any. But, in 'That Yellow Bastard', John Hartigan (played perfectly by Bruce Willis, who can play these kinds of roles in his sleep) is a retiring cop out to save one more girl, Nancy Callahan (Jessica Alba - 'Honey') from the clutches of the Senator's pedophilia son, Junior (Nick Stahl - HBO's 'Carnivale', 'Terminator 3'). Hartigan saves her but not before being betrayed by his partner, Bob (Michael Madsen - 'Reservoir Dogs', 'Kill Bill') and soon he is set up and sentenced to 8 years in prison after the system frames him for kidnapping and 3 other crimes that Junior has done. 8 Years pass and Hartigan goes to check on Nancy and finds that she is now 'grown up and filled out'. Quick note: Jessica Alba is SOOOOO MUCH FUN to watch. When the DVD comes out her dancing scenes will be played in slow-mo. Hartigan finds that Junior is now the deformed Yellow Bastard out for revenge. I cannot give out the entire details because this is meant to make you want to see it, not tell you what happens.

Starring: Bruce Willis (Die Hard), Mickey Rourke (Man On Fire), Clive Owen (Closer), Benicio Del Toro (Traffic) in the main roles. Also featuring Josh Hartnett (whose best scene is near the closing), Jessica-I-can-get-you-hot-as-a-DRESSED-Stripper-Alba, Brittany Murphy, Rosario Dawson, Alexis Bledel, Michael Clarke Duncan (Big boy from 'Armageddon' & 'Green Mile'), Michael Madsen, Carla Gugino (who is naked most of the time thankfully), Jamie King (same with her too), Devon Aoki, Rutget Hauer (finally in something NOT straight to video), Powers Booth, Nick Stahl and Mr. Frodo Baggins himself, Elijah Wood as Kevin 'The Cannibal'.

Reminder: 'Sin City' is NOT for the faint of heart!!! This is the bloodiest film i've ever seen with the exception of 'The Passion' and has enough splatter action that would make the D-Day sequence of 'Saving Private Ryan' seem like child's play. Armed to the teeth with decapitations, dismemberment, cannibalism, shootouts giving exit wounds the size of watermelons on the victims, Car crashes, Explosions, Naked gorgeous women (though it's not consistent, just in small parts), a bad ass Private Eye, A determined street fighter and an aging cop with a bum ticker you can't help to accept as a third Grandfather that some of the little girls would have a crush on.

But, With visuals that make you wish for more movies in this style, Robert Rodriguez, Frank Miller, and Quentin Tarantino have crafted a film noir that is so utterly spectacular, you have to see it to believe it.

title: All I can say is Wow!
review:
Wow to everything! I can't decide if Frank Miller is a genius, a madman, or both! Robert Rodriguez's adaptation of such a stunning graphic novel was nothing less than stellar given what he was to work with: some of the most technologically advanced graphic software in the movie industry. The use of green screen in this movie was done so tastefully yet so dastardly enough to bring the seedy underworld of Sin City to life. The noir-esque setting mixed with a barrage of cars from Ferraris to 50's T-birds and weapons ranging from "Dirty Harry" -like Smith and Westons to modern Uzi brings together such a world never displayed on film before. The tone is somewhat to the feel of, say, "Pulp Fiction" while the the brutality being somewhere on the lines of "The Passion" or "Dawn of the Dead" (for that matter, any modern zombie movie) with the gushing blood, dismemberment, and brutal torture. This movie is for those who enjoy great art and skill, but also who enjoy the occasional severed head or a lady of the night "going to work" so to speak.

Those who are fans of Tarintino movies or some of the more gory zombie movies may find some of the more brutal violence mildly yet darkly funny, as I did, and as the violence was meant. Those with weak stomachs, virgin eyes, and strong outward morals and views on censorship, please PROCEED WITH CAUTION.

Great movie for all of those mature enough to see it.

title: Definitely worthwhile
review: It's unusual to see a movie in black and white with occasional color, not unlike "Pleasentville". The movie is a pleasant retreat back to the old 'noire' stories and movies of decades past, but in more of a modern setting. You don't have to be a huge fan of the Frank Miller original stories to enjoy the movie, but admittedly it doesn't hurt. It truly is like finding a totally different world to lose yourself in. As the rating says, you need to prepare yourself for several different levels of violence, but, the black and white appearance of the movie allows for it by cutting down unneeded sensationalism's's of 'blood for the sake of blood.' The stories are good, and the acting of the ensemble very good. People who go to the movie to see 'Frodo', for example, will have a big surprise coming. This role is an excellent counterpoint to the Ring movies for Elijah Wood.He may not have to worry as much about typecasting after this. Overall, not best picture material, but, as it should be, simply enjoyable.It's difficult to find movies to compare this to, without going back to the old Alan Ladd movies of the thirties or so, and even then, what happens in this story couldn't be done then.

title: A Sin it was even made
review: This is a disgustingly wretched pieces of violence-porn filth. These "movies" always make me wonder: how did it ever get funded? And how did it ever get filmed? The only thing this needed to be totally in the sewer is zombies! I found it nauseating. If anything it only serves to illustrate the kind of degenerate and politically corrupt climate now being implemented by the Looter & Liar in Chief. Hollywood continues its revolting degenerate spiral to the bottom. Not even worth a five minute look, unless you have the kind of sick twisted soul who like this kind of violence-porn. Save your time, save your money, and don't even bother.

title: Terrible.
review: Someone spent $40000000 on this pile of absolute bull? No wonder there are starving people in Africa when people chose to waste money on bull like this. What was the money spent on? Certainly wasn't script writing. Or on sets. I am guessing it was all on getting some half good actors in there? Who can tell. I was expecting a good film and i was disappointed to say the least. If you haven't watched it yet, i wouldn't bother. The only real reason i can see for anyone to watch it would be because of the mostly naked women with guns, but even they're not worth the time i spent watching it. It's all a bit too f**ked up for my liking.. Guy falls in love with young girl he saves.. People getting shot in the head and living? And in terms of how it looks, the graphics are awful. It makes the whole thing even worse. I appreciate it is meant to look like a comic, but i feel they failed. Anyway, that's my opinion. I had to ramble on because it has to be over ten lines long. Have a nice day :)

title: The most overrated movie of this decade
review:
I was impressed by the publicity this movie was having so I sad to myself this has to be something.

First of all I don't read comics, I watch movies and I must say this is one of the most stooped movies I ever saw. I still don't know what genre it is. The dialogs are very stooped, to quote Bruce Willis's character, Hartigan, "An old man dies. A young girl lives" which sounds something you invent on the toilet. For me, this line, characterizes the whole movie.

Also 50% of the movie its about women in bikini", To make it more interesting they are prostitutes with guns that control a part of the city (If that doesn't sound stooped I don't know what does). Nudity is everywhere.

I really suggest people to satisfy themselves before watching the movie because it seems that some people see Jessica Alba's but and they think the whole movie is great, as a man I have to admit the movie has very nice nude scenes but it takes more than that for a such a overrated movie.

There are some characters that make you want to shoot yourself like that played by Elijah Wood (what the hell is up with that thing and what's its purpose), many characters and other stuff" (I didn't know how to put it) look like they don't belong in this movie (what's with Michael J. Anderson's character, that plastic surgery, why is so important in the movie that he looks like a clown, cant he just have some scars on his face or something). And I don't know who got the idea that people want to see dick's getting shoot but whatever, we can all say that's original. I like to say

I'm not the critic type, I usually go with the flow" but when it came to Sin City I had to say something (I still can't believe how overrated it is).

Seems they're making a sequel, let hope for the best (nooot...).

title: Raise your expectations
review:
Oh.

My.

F**king.

God.

It's the Frank Miller books. Amped. Without distortion of its honest spirit, of his stark visuals, or of the hard choices an even harder city imposes on its citizens.

Like any great film noir, appearances are deceiving, and part of the story. Despite having read the graphic novels, the story, the look, the performances, the score surprised me. From the opening to the end. Without a break. The art direction, the makeup, the cinematography, the performances, even the wardrobes were all of a seamless whole. And everything, all the elements, work together. Sin City is commitment like a knife in the eye: quick, sharp, deadly and you can't do anything about it even when you see it coming.

Sin City is visceral. It calls for thought too. Its social commentary is all tacit, where you don't notice it, fodder for meditations on the meaning of corruption, self-sufficiency, perversion, responsibility, friendship, love, torture, revenge, and defining yourself by your actions. Nothing a bullet won't cure.

I crawled out of the theater stunned, mumbling "OMFG." Fellow Sinners staggered into the lobby, shocked. I'm not going to the movies for a while. Sin City leaves them stale, pale, limp, and bland. Who knows when I'll get the metalic taste of blood out of my mouth.

OMFG.

title: Some People Just don't get it
review: This is a fantasy also pegged as a fictional city, I would use the word fantasy. Noir films of old depicted real life events in a swish pastry shop way. This film does not. The lives and events are fictional more fanatical really. No real outstanding performances except Mickey Rouke, Excellent job. You have to be a fan of this type of underground comic to really get the point or meaning of what is being portrayed. That is if there really is one. Just like music sometimes it is just entertainment. Other comics like Faust and Razor have violent disturbing visualizations of an exaggerated truth. Again take what ever meaning you want from it, this type film is truly a love it or leave it type of art form. It may opens doors (hopefully) for more gritty capturing stories that go beneath the shelf. Lets face it the next Spiderman or Superman for that matter would never go to these depths. R rated either for the bucks are with the kiddies. Thats why comics like this aren't much understood. But the righteous indignant right will hate it and blame it for countless things wrong with society. But how can they do that when it takes real life horror to exaggerate a fictitious story like this from. Remember the comics code, big brother etc. Read the paper and see the news at night, it's not film that makes people go off. This is escapist entertainment people!

title: So ridiculously typical.
review:
The art style and film-making are truly a masterpiece. The story itself is dull, lame, predictable, cliché, and in the end 100% forgettable.

I'll start with the action. To be blunt, there is hardly any at all. When the action happens it is lame and uninspired. It reminded me of dumbed down action scenes from Spider-Man, but even that is too much of a complement. Most of the film is nothing but people walking around and talking about things that make no difference.

So, with all the talking scenes and characterization scenes you'd expect the plot to be, you know, at least a plot. Oh, how wrong that assumption is. There is no plot. The mini stories that somehow are kind of a plot mixed together are generally boring, and entirely cliché. You've seen these mini stories on cartoons before.

But it doesn't even have the same level of fun, original cartoony feel. It's more like a bad cartoonlike Tom and Jerrythat has grown up but never matured. It just feels . . . awkward and boring. Like a 40-year-old man doing something like a 5-year-old. It's just lame.

This style of mature cartoony-fantasy has been NAILED in video games like Killer 7, which hone the originality and innocence of cartoons, but mix it with mean-spirited ultra-violence. Movies like Kill Bill also get it down. But Sin City simply doesn't know how to do that in a way that isn't boring and cliché.

But, as I said, it's truly a masterpiece in style. Too bad that style wasn't used for something original and cliché-defining, instead of a lame Spider-Man wannabe with some dumbed-down blood to make it seem action packed when I've seen more action watching people walk by my back yard.

. . . and I wish I was joking.

1/10

title: Sexist Crap
review: Oh, My Gosh! Raping, Killing, Whipping, cut-off hands, arms and other body-parts... so far, it sounds like one of those movies German society seduces me to be sick to watch and even like, just as "Last House on the Left"... But for some Reason this time, Everyone seems to like "Sin City" but me. OK, it's black-white with some co lours... how artistically. OK, Soundtrack and Scoring fits. OK, big names in the cast... ...but that's all. The rest is nothing but senseless violence, perversion, tortures, killings, tapings... absolutely no storyline, no logic, no message!! Hey Folks, if you dig Crap like this, then why do Joel M. Reeds "Bloodsucking Freaks" get so bad votes? It's just as "artistically"...

title: Wow
review:
If I could give this dreck a negative 10, I would. "This is the film they were trying to make when they made Sky Captain." I've heard this, or similar statements over and over in the press and on the web.

Let me see: Both are digital movies. Only the actors and some of the props are "real." But where SK created fully realized, DAYLIGHT worlds, SC is all dark and virtually black and white.

SK is from an original idea by its director. SC is (from all accounts) a shot by shot remake of a comic book. (Yeah, I know, comic books are freakin' art now.) SK provided a sense of wonder and amazement. SC provides cheap thrills and waves of disgust. Not that there's anything wrong with that.

SK had fun, subtle sexual chemistry between one guy and two disparate women. SC had men who are violent (and proud of it in most cases) and women who are tits, attitude, and foul mouths. The entire time I forced myself to sit through this crass, low-class, crud I could only think: This is the wet dream of all the puny, pasty-souled, weak-willed little men of the world. Men who want a big gun and a big powerful way to make up for their tiny truth, in other words, its defenders.

SK did it first. SC did it wrong, from they hyper-red lipstick to the uber violence and prejudice (misogyny and homophobia runs roughshod) SK had a first time director showing the world his deepest fantasy. SC, a "Quentin Tarantino" dithered with Rodriguez low-budget horror show. If this is Frank Miller's deepest fantasy, then I want to be warned if he's in the state.

All you defenders, you defend this mess. This is one man's opinion. It is too bad I didn't see this at the press screening, I might have been able to warn others.

Sin City is not better than Sky Captain. SK has all kinds of faults. But it is not ever going to be as bad (or faux hip) as this.

title: Wow
review: I saw this movie the day it came out on Friday afternoon and when it was over I did not want to leave. There is absolutely no other movie that can be placed in the same sentence as Sin City. I saw this movie with my girlfriend and even she thought it was a great movie. It was spectacular. I never thought that I would ever become more a part of a movie before. The camera, the lighting, the special effects, and the comic book feel was unreal. I never paid more attention to any story in a move before. This movie will change you perspective on how to look at movies from now on. This is at the top of the film pedestal and I don't see it being topped in the near future. I give it two thumbs up for every aspect, acting, directing, sound and filmaking.

title: Ultra-Noir
review:
There are all sorts of prosiac, film studious ways of describing FRANK MILLER'S SIN CITY. But the best way to describe it is that it takes film making to a new level, especially for graphic novels/comic books.

In a word, SIN CITY rocks. Unapologetic, in your face, makes you want it bad rocks.

The scene compositions, the dramatic lighting, the high contract adjustments to simulate the look and feel of the original graphics novels proves that Rodriguez is a master of film. He also assembled a stellar cast, and used them all to the best possible advantage. It's impossible to single anyone out, because then all the actors and their performances would have to be listed.

Rodriguez and Miller, co-directors, did an amazing job. If you aren't already aware, Rodriguez resigned from the Director's Guild to do this, as he felt Miller had to be co-director. He also won over Miller by producing the opening sequence to show him his vision of SIN CITY.

The Guerilla film-making mentality of Rodriguez, who scored, shot, edited, and more, as well as co-directing, proves yet again that while it may take cajones to do it yourself, it pays off in the end.

FRANK MILLER'S SIN CITY is a must see, pay prime money, and get the DVD

title: Pulp Fiction + Dick Tracy.= Sweet!
review:
Three chilling and intriguing tales of unlikely bad ass heroes in a seedy underworld interweave themselves throughout a great film. Much style is to be seen as the creative tale involves a huge cast of well known actors (including a wonderful performance by Bruce Willis) tons of gore, dark humor, a botched body disposal and lots of plot twists that are hard to swallow but too cool not to want to.

Wasn't Pulp Fiction great?

OK it wasn't a PF ripoff though. While there are many similarities at a glance, Frank Miller's and Robert Rodrigez's (and apparently some guest direction from Quentin Tarantino) Sin City was all about the style. A Highly stylized nod to film noir with some really cool everything else tossed in. The women were all hot, The violence was pleasantly excessive, the "heroes" were all cool as hell, and the villains were Villains!!! Guys this is not a date movie. Limb's will fly blood will gush and Miller seems to have a thing for.... You know what I'll save that surprise for anyone who wants to watch it. Just prepare to cringe. The writing was a bit lacking but it made up for it in the brilliant way it set up its moods. If you liked Kill Bill vol 1 then you'll love it.

That was one MESSED UP HOBBIT.

title: Absolutely Brilliant
review:
As someone who has not seen the comic taking my first steps in to the world of Sin City was a mixture of excitement and curiosity. I had no idea what the plot was going to be coming into the film, and I was more than exceedingly surprised. The art and direction was beautiful and executed with equal amounts of subtlety and extravagance. Plot, character development, art, design, cinematography were all top notch and superb. If you are looking for a good story and don't shy away from some (or a lot) of graphic violence then an adventure through the rough streets of Sin City is one you cannot miss.

But, a word of caution some comic book fanatics may be a little irked with a few elements of the execution. Do not let this dissuade you from enjoying one of the most creative and artistic films I have seen in a long time. Action, suspense, love, hate it has it all.

I gave this movie a 10/10.

title: ugly
review:
First things first : this film is extraordinarily violent, without there being any sane reason whatsoever for it to be so. It can safely be classified as comic-book gore porn. While watching it, there were at least a dozen occasions when I wanted to hit the 'eject' button on my DVD player ; the only thing that kept me going was simply that I wanted to get it over with.

Is this what art has come to in this age ? Were the filmmakers so desensitized that they went to these levels of harrowing cruelty to titillate their audience ? And just why is this film so chock full of celebrities for roles that a C-List actor would avoid ? Elijah Wood plays something like the ultimate misogynist-cum-cannibal......eh ? That being done with, Sin City is still highly remarkable for its novel and sophisticated filming style. The film was shot on a digital backlot, first in color, which was then converted to high-grade black-and-white, and then desaturated to give it a high contrast. Colour is added in interesting places, like all the girls' eyes, lips, hair, apparel.....you get the point. Oh yeah, and the barrels and barrels of fake blood used here was accentuated to a deep dark red. I also liked how they used CGI only as and when necessary, so the film looks like a cross between a very real and a completely fictional world.

Maybe the film's only true saving grace is that unlike Pulp Fiction and Kill Bill, it doesn't even try passing off as high art ; the film is perfectly aware of itself as being simply low-brow violence for violence's sake, and nothing more. Let me tell you that if you haven't seen this film, save yourself the trouble, you're not missing much. Give your time to something more worthy of it. This film isn't half as clever or funny as it would like to be, and just because a film goes into places with violence that other films don't DOES NOT make it revolutionary or original. It doesn't even matter that Rodriguez supposedly "stayed true" to the source material, since the "source" in question is jarringly stupid to begin with. This film will most certainly appeal to rapists and women beaters, so if you liked this hunk of sado junk, well......

A friend of mine called Sin City "misogynistic crap". She's perfectly right. Armond White of the NY Press called Oldboy a "virtuosic stupid movie". Now THAT is clever, and funny too, and what's more, that phrase is even more true for Sin City.

title: Some say this movie is dark. No, night is dark, this is darn right bleak!
review: Some say this movie is dark. No, night is dark, this is darn right bleak! Now I like the cast and the whole film noir look to it or as they call it today Neo Noir. But there are several things that I can't get around, things that I can't suspend my disbelief over. The days of beating a false confession out of someone died a long, long time ago. In this day and age, even if Internal Affairs was also in the Cardinal's back pocket. There's still the Press and the FBI. Besides that, if he's killed in the electric chair, then how can he be narrating the story? What he's telling God his story. Then there's the Senator in the Bruce Willis story, how can he do that? When the President, the most powerful politician in the world can't get away with a simple break in or banging a chubby intern? He can't! He'd never get away with hiding a pedophile Progeny. There's also the grim look at the Church, this is way to dark for me. I look for some ray of hope in my movies. THE NOOSE!

title: Did anyone else notice?
review: How Marve never seemed to die even though he got badly hurt more than 10 times. He just seemed to keep on going and going. He didn't even die up until he got put in the chair the second time around. And he seemed to be a very tough and troubled character. He also seemed to know just about everyone in the film. It got to the point where you didn't even know how he knew all these different people. He was obsessed with trying to find the murderer of Goldie. Which gave no reason as to why she was with him in the first place. She was way to pretty for his ass anyways. In the end I would say he was a very bad character to place in this good movie.

title: Exactly what I was hoping for. A beautifully literal translation from the page.
review:
Some scenes will make you forget you are looking at live action because of the perfect integration of high contrast art. This film is perfectly cast. I couldn't imagine anyone but Mickey Rourke playing Marv and Bruce Willis playing Hartigan. Brittany Murphy gives an over the top performance as Shellie, which really made the film noir experience for me. When I first heard about the casting, I was upset that they chose Jessica Alba to play Nancy, due to Jessica's "no nudity" clause in her contract. But she managed to pull it off. Rosario Dawson has never been hotter. Another perfect fit.

That's all I care to say without spoiling any of the film. See it immediately.

title: Wow
review: I went to a preview of Sin City last night, and I was extremely impressed. The cinematography, effects, and editing were all fantastic, and it was as close to watching a graphic novel on screen as any "comic book" movie that has come out. (The Hulk came close.) Rodriguez' use of color is amazing, and there are enough big-name actors in here to keep you saying "I know that guy!" for the whole movie. It is a dark film, and has all the gore and skin that the graphic novels have, so be careful if you don't like such things. But, if you do like them, and you want a well-put-together movie with good acting and a great story, go see this one.

title: Holy F***ing S***
review: For the record, let me say that i was not sure of IMDb's censorship policy, so i did them a favor. If seeing the uncensored words above would have offended you, don't see this movie. This movie is a beautiful adaptation of Frank Miller's masterfully written graphic novels. This movie borrows plots from "The Hard Goodbye", "The Big Fat Kill", and "That Yellow Bastard". Unfortunately, number 2 in the Sin City series, "A Dame to Kill For" was excluded, at the price of leaving Dwight's character vague, but the movie still owns unbelievable amounts of ass. In short, a man gets hand-castrated, another gets his arms and legs sawed off before getting eaten by a wolf, and still another gets shot repeatedly before shooting a man in the balls and saving an 11 year old girl. Words cannot aptly describe how much this movie owns, so I'll give up and tell you to go see this movie. Now.

title: Very cartoonish looking
review: I love the minimal use of color. The acting is good. The black and white really adds to the gritty tone. However, the fighting scenes look very cartoonish and unrealistic. Some of the practical effects look cheap as well. I'm giving it a 7/10 because the story is amazing, but it's a little rough aesthetically.

title: Pure hype
review: A bad movie is a bad movie even when it's bad on purpose.

title: Sin City, a fantastic Miller's concept, near Masterpiece!!!
review:
According mostly reviwers they love or hate it, watching this picture on 2007 as great reader of comic books on my teenager years I found it a upper class production from Robert Rodriguez, with a little help of Tarantino, Rodriguez tried persuade Frank Miller by any means, but the slippery master of comics finally had accepted watch a demo, he likes it and gave his endorsement if Mickey Rooney could be Marv, Rodriguez agree and also got a robust casting including Bruce Willis, Jessica Alba, Benicio Del Toro, Michael Madsen and Clive Owen and a dozen extensive casting, the movie has three segments, being the first one too short and just finished on the close ending, however all them are linked altogether, the stylized format on Frank Miller's concept was stringently ensured, the dark atmosphere follow the Noir genre, the picture has his own dynamic intrinsic on comic, each single scene has a meaning, the character are extremely colorful, even the most minors ones, but the highlight are quite sure the gorgeous and sexy girls wearing those exciting tight clothes, engaged on a wise screenplay it flow easy, I won't give a highest grade due it was made on blue screen and excessive CGI, it was a unexcusable sinfulness to me, therwise I will against my own principles, absolutely near masterpiece!!

Resume:

First watch: 2007 / How many: 2 / Source: DVD / Rating: 9

title: Know Thyself, and Stay True
review:
One important aspect of any media that keeps coming up for me as of late, and appears to be somewhat overlooked, is the ability for a film, TV show or book to know itself. That is to say, they should understand the type of media they are trying to produce and stay faithful to that, not get bogged down in unnecessary cliche and exposition, and use every aesthetic and storytelling tool to realize the premise they started with. The ability to stay true to oneself is up there with dialogue and visuals in terms of its importance in creating a believable and impactful film. There's a reason that everyone from early morning children's cartoons to Lady Gaga tells you to just be yourself. One film that does this exceptionally well is Sin City.

In one respect, Sin City starts with some advantages in this way. To begin with, it is an adaptation of an exceptional graphic novel. The film needed only to stay faithful to the original and it was bound to be something special, and that is exactly what they did, keeping the stunningly contrasting aesthetics and largely including the dialogue. Graphic novels have had a great ability to keep this authenticity. They can take the neo-noir visuals and translate them well onto the big screen in order to keep that feeling of turning pages and viewing something real but not too real. V For Vendetta (2005) and 300 (2006) are some of the best examples of this. The colors and the landscapes are not quite realistic, and the fighting is almost believable. They are clearly comic books in the form of film. Scott Pilgrim vs. the World (2010) has very literal moments of comic visuals, and the fight scenes make no excuses, they are wild and crazy just as we would expect. Sin City captures both of these concepts beautifully. The colorful blood, the ridiculous fighting, the wonderfully overacted dialogue all remind the audience that they are watching a comic book. There are moments to make you say "What the hell!" enough for five films.

This is in contrast to comic book adaptations, which are significantly more malleable. Take the Marvel universe. Surely, there are wonderful and revolutionary films, but they take many forms. Ant Man (2015) is a comedy film. The Avengers series is epic sci-fi fantasy. And the Daredevil series on Netflix is a gritty crime drama. This is the advantage of having a huge amount of source material and an extensive canon to work with. You can pick and choose pieces to fit as you need them. Graphic novels are generally a lot more limited, and their ability to stay truthful to the source material is incredibly important in creating something that both new audiences and die-hard fans of the work will appreciate.

The second advantage was having Robert Rodriguez as the director and Quentin Tarantino making a guest appearance. Rodriguez has an excellent ability to keep a film true to its intentions, even if the film itself is not particularly amazing. His later projects after Sin City show this pretty nicely. Planet Terror (2007) is a masterpiece of camp and gross-out horror. It is cartoonish and sarcastic without making any excuse to become realistic or heartfelt. Machete (2010) is a non-stop highlight reel of carnage. Just like the "fake" trailer that inspired it, it was ridiculous and amazing. Spy Kids (2001) and Spy Kids 2 (2002), which are altogether mediocre films, should have had no staying power whatsoever. Yet the film's names still resonate with many and the thumb people and guy with four heads still give me nightmares, at least. Somehow the success of these films was enough even to convince a studio to make a fourth installment ten years later.

Sin City stays aware of itself from top to bottom, and from start to finish. The musical accompaniment is perfectly noir. Every actor has bought into the concept as so each character, no matter how minor, plays an important role in making the world (un)believable. The sets are clearly built in some studio, but it doesn't matter. We know that behind the walls is just some wooden paneling holding everything together, just like we know that a book is bound together by glue and threads, but it doesn't stop us from being totally engrossed. Many films fail to maintain this truthfulness, and that brings them from great movies to something simply good or acceptable. Take, for example, nearly any major Disney Studios release from the last ten to twenty years. The Disney execs are so intent on keeping films inside of a basic and successful formula that they lose their sense of authenticity. They have to shoehorn in romance, rebellion, an evil villain and the hero's journey into any film whether it fits or not, because that is what the audiences want. These movies will always be successful, that's Disney's power, but they rarely get discussed in top lists during the years in review.

Sequels also especially fall into this trap because they stray too far from what they originally intended. Perhaps there is a change in directors, producers or writers, but even when they stay the same this can happen. Take IT (2017) and IT: Chapter Two (2019). What made the original so terrifying was its portrayal of the monster and the feeling of helplessness that was inspired in every audience member. Thirty minutes into the second film, though, this feeling is lost. IT is no longer omnipotent or villainous. He is more mischievous and manipulative. These traits would be okay if the whole construct of this universe didn't hinge on the monstrosity of the villain. IT: Chapter Two has none of the authenticity, and therefore none of the power of the first film.

Sin City is a fantastic film in its own right, but it is a lesson too. A lesson on how to take a concept and run with it for two hours to the very apex of that idea. Perhaps some artists are worried about taking something too far. Well, I say not far enough. Push it to the extreme and see what happens. Let your characters become caricatures if the framework is already a caricature of reality. No one will blame you for making something silly and weird if it makes them think. The feeling of Sin City resonated in my mind for years even before I rewatched it recently. This is not because it stuck to a formula and made some generically marketable, but because it took the truth of itself to the very extreme that it could and made something so cartoonish it became a lifelike work of art.

title: Truly miserable & unenjoyable
review: I remember going along to this premiere whilst away on vacation and it ruined our evening. A friend has spoken glowingly about it, but right from the outset it was a truly depressing & uninspiring experience. Avoid watching this garbage if you prefer not to feel like a piece of your soul was lost on the moment you watched it.

title: Unbelievable and amazing
review: Got to see this years ago and just got a chance to rewatch it. This film created a color grading approach that many film schools now teach. Even though it was already done before with Speilberg "Schindler's List" the red dress little girl. Regardless the comic feel, amazing story and cast made this film amazing.

title: Sin City
review:
How to describe "Sin City" - Twenty-First Century film noire with a splash of red thrown in, fantasy combined with comic book violence and sadism? Somewhat disjointed, especially if you haven't read the associated graphic novel. On the other hand, perhaps the viewer is not meant to read much or anything into it.

This one is strictly for devotees of the genre. At around two hours it is also heavy for the uninitiated. Its saving grace, if it can be said to have one, is a half-decent soundtrack.

title: I couldn't disagree more
review:
New York Magazine (Vulture) Ken Tucker
¨visually stunning. Sin City has grit to spare and a thrilling undercurrent of morality.¨
Time Richard Corliss
¨Sin City is brazenly, thrillingly alive.¨
ReelViews James Berardinelli
¨The most visually inventive comic book adaptation to make its way to a movie screen.¨
Dallas Observer Robert Wilonsky
¨Rodriguez clearly assumes Sin City to be his "Pulp Fiction," his rambling portmanteau--a blending of disparate tales to form a complete, overwhelming epic.¨

title: I don't get why people liked it!
review:
It's visually cool because of the selective colour and some experimental lighting techniques... yes but so what!!!

It's weak and disgusting almost in all of the other aspects!

Sometimes people overreact about new stuff which is illogical...

5/10

title: Super interesting visually
review: As a movie it's garbage as an artistic piece it's very interesting and cool but is just an amalgamation of random stories

title: Stylish, a comic book brought to life
review:
In this stylized adaptation of the comic book, Sin City features an all-star cast in over-the-top roles glorifying sex and violence. It's all supposed to be tongue-in-cheek, so be prepared for that type of acting and filmmaking style when you rent it. It's a black and white film with filters and saturations designed to make it look like the drawn pages of a glossy comic book. Occasionally, there are bursts of color, like red blood, that once again bring up the comic book feeling. Visually, if you're a comic book aficionado, you'll probably be in love with this movie.

I'm not, so with the excessive violence and gratuitous sexual themes, I didn't fall in love with this movie. Obviously, in a comic book, it's a necessity for one of the female characters to be a stripper, but to me, most movies that feature strippers film the scenes in an exploitive manner. The movie is segmented into vignettes, and each vignette has an extraordinary amount of violence so that at the end of the movie, you're surprised anyone's left alive to inhabit the city. But if you want to see Bruce Willis, Jessica Alba, Rosario Dawson, Mickey Rourke, Elijah Wood, Benicio del Toro, Michael Clarke Duncan, Clive Owen, Brittany Murphy, Michael Madsen, Josh Hartnett, Marley Shelton, and Alexis Bledel all together in a very stylized movie, you might like it. Watch the preview first, though, so you know what you're getting into.

DLM Warning: If you suffer from vertigo or dizzy spells, like my mom does, this movie will not be your friend. This is a stylized movie, and there are swirling camera movements and canted angles that it will make you sick. In other words, "Don't Look, Mom!"

Kiddy Warning: Obviously, you have control over your own children. However, due to adult violence and sexual content, I wouldn't let my kids watch it.

title: The worse film.
review:
This a peculiar movie with a different plot but for being so different you would expect to get involved in it and be stunned all the time. However, the film is boring and actually I couldn't finish it. 
A lot of facts made this film the worst that I have ever seen before, including the fact the film is without colours, a flat performance that doesn't help, without mentioning that the story is really weird.
It isn't a easy film to see, and if you are not a fan of comics... it could be worse. 
I cant recommend it, even if you are bored and trying to watch something different preferably leave this option out.

title: Visually interesting and gritty but uneven and a bit overbearing.
review: Stylish and visually inventive, this graphic novel adaptation uses more CGI than it does colour - digitally creating a monochrome world and inserting our hard-boiled heroes into it. 'Sin CIty (2005)' is usually entertaining, if uneven, and unconventionally 'vibrant', as close to page-perfect as possible for better or worse. Yet for all it's flair, the sickly ham-fisted dialogue and clumsy knock-off noir narration overflows like bile, despite the fact that its tongue is allegedly planted firmly in its cheek. The vignette style makes for some stories that work better than others, but an overall disjointed feel that doesn't necessarily feed into the combined aesthetic. Not bad, but not great either. 6/10

title: Masterpiece.
review: As much as drawing comics is a piece of art, that much the same stands for this movie. I was never much into comics, but this made me love them. The visuals, the colour blend, the acting, the actors, the story rotations... just beautiful

title: Make it all black instead of black and white and it doesn't make a difference.
review:
If you take the movie as a terrible low-budget comedy, you might not get bored to death. But this is not low-budget, this is not a comedy and this is, apparently, not terrible.

The first chapter(The Yellow Bastard) was quite alright, then it all just got boring, tedious. All the chapters were like "the main (anti)hero has to kill somebody and it will probably end badly for him". But the final act was absolutely terrible. The killing scenes were comical(perhaps because of the black and white setting), I could not take it seriously for a minute.

Positives:The acting and the soundtrack.

With all the great actors in the movie, this film was a tremendous disappointment for me. 20 minutes after it ended, I cannot really recall much of the film.

title: A must see just for its style.
review: This movie enters in the typical description of "style over substance". But what a style! the story is nothing over the top, but anyway, visually speaking its outstanding, specially if you consider that it was done in 2005, more than 10 years ago. Yeah, it have it's flaws and its very predictable but I think overall it is an acceptable film.

title: Sin City (2005)
review:
I've been meaning to rewatch this film for quite some time. I'm a massive fan of Robert Rodriguez's Planet Terror. The Grindhouse films that came out a few years ago was one of the greatest theater experiences I had. I recall being slightly disappointed with Sin City: A Dame to Kill For although it was still decent. After rewatching the film I feel just about the same about the first film; its a wonderful visual experience and wholly engaging.

The film is based on Frank Miller's graphic novel and tells the tale of a few select characters. Themes of revenge and putting out crime are strong in this film.
