Shellie, however is with Dwight (Clive Owen), who will not accept Jackie Boy's attempts to get closer to his girl.

title: A macabre masterpiece.
review: The real enemies aren't the terrorists or the dictators of foreign countries; they are the clergymen and politicians of society. The law and the Word are what hold back every-day people from achieving greatness and these groups are willing to do whatever it takes to sate their lusts, desires and grudges. Mickey Rouke plays a sneering, cold-blooded murderer who has us cheering for him from the first bullet that rips through a priest's brain. His use of a hacksaw and rubber tubing is grand and horrible fun. He is cruel, malicious and a joy to watch even as he fries. A refreshing change in today's terribly upbeat films.

title: Awesome movie!!!
review:
I must have dropped off the map for a while as I heard very little of this movie when it was out in theaters, anyway when it came out on DVD I rented it and wow was I surprised. It's totally badass, a guy guy movie to say the least. Great story with tons of Violence, Filled with beautiful woman with some good nude T&A scenes, and a likable cast of professional actors. I will be in the theaters for Sin City 2 for sure.

What amazed me most about this movie was the amount of violence they were able to show, I think it goes back to my blood theory, meaning that the more red blood they show, the harder it is for them to get the R rating (meaning to harsh for R). So this movie is filmed similar to Sky Captain in that most of the backgrounds are CGI while the characters are real. However the movie is filmed or converted I should say to mainly black and white, but color is added in certain situations for certain things, just to shake things up. In doing this they accomplished a few things. It kept a sort of 1920's kind of feel to the movie, yet it also made it scarier in a way which was good. Plus the big factor is that they could show a guy getting shot up or beat to hell in very graphic ways, but the blood would be in black in white or some other color than red in certain scenes, IMO this enabled them to get away with showing some graphic scenes and yet keep the R rating.

This movie blew me away from start to finish as I was intrigued and glued to my seat the whole time. It goes without saying that this is a hardcore action movie, so for those who don't like action or violence in heavy amounts, take a pass on this one. However for those who thrive off heavy action / gory movies like me, then this will be a treat for you! The movie is very comic book like containing heroes & villains who are all badass in their own way and who can take and dish out quite a bit of punishment. And yet it didn't come out trashy like 90% of all the marvel comic movies that come out. A real tribute to comic book like movies and action / gore movies If you haven't seen it yet and like Action / horror / thriller movies, rent it ASAP as it is awesome

title: Wow to first comic adaptation for not being an utter bulls*it
review:
I don't want to sound overly zealous or anything but still I'd like to express my loathing of comic adaptations that were created in past few years, including Xmen, Daredevil, Hulk, Fantastic4, Spiderman and whatnot. For most of them I only had to endure a trailer or a commented review on TV though...

And though I'm not a comic book fan, I know that Sin City differs from other comic franchises. It's black-and-white, it's ultimately dark, it has its own black humor and overall style.

Reluctantly I went to see Sin City on tape. The first scene suggested that the style from the paper version would be preserved. Subsequent credits indicated that Frank Miller had much to say and decide during the production. And next... from start to end one hell of a satisfying ride.

The flick has a noir style that is near to perfect. That may be the case of other comic adaptations as well (just cut "noir") but Sin City is supported even by the characters. Almost every single one of them has a believable personality - acting was surprisingly good for me.

Next thing is a fine combination of reckless violence and humor. It goes so well together in Sin City. I won't spoil anything though because I believe this movie deserves to be seen even if you are not into comic books in general.

Just go and watch deadly little Kevin and deadly little Miho, to name the few, in action.

title: If there was a box of crime clichés, it would be called sin city...
review:
50 years ago this film might have followed a trend set by hardened American cop characters created to feed the masses with the story of the criminal element. But today this movie is in a league of its own, its been half a century since we have seen a good, rugged, hard movie showing the dark and sleazy world of organised crime and its antagonists, the hard as nails cops, 2 days from retirement as per usual.

It has everything down to perfection, you cant go one minute without hearing a corny line from a cop, a mouthy threat from a crook, or a snappy comeback from a walking juggernaut, being insulted by small time hit men. Hartigan is everything a cop should be, he is retiring, 30 years on the force, wife, kids, partner of so many years, and so many criminals locked away to his name, and hes fishing for his last trout on the streets of basin city.

Marv is a classic rendition of the streetwise bare fist extraordinaire tank of a being, who strolls the streets, knowing he owns the place. The cops cant touch him and the crooks cant scratch him, and he knows the weakness of every situation he gets into....he also takes two shots of 50,000 volts to die successfully.

If there was a box that contained every single crime story cliché in history, it would be called sin city, and thats why its great.

We've heard it all before and seen it all before, but now we get to do both in style, with a star filled cinematic epic to bring film noir to the next generation.

title: From Comic to Screen.
review: An explosive Pulp Fiction style action movie featuring a magnificent cast including Bruce Willis, Clive Owen and Mickey Rourke in this screen version of the graphic novels created by Frank Miller. There are 3 stories about Hartigan, Dwight and Marv and how these characters are driven to revenge and war. All of the characters in this movie are significant in their own way and this movie mixes violence and humour. With brilliant and talented directors Quentin Tarantino and Robert Rodriguez this is a bit of a change when it comes to special effects and action sequences. This movie also features talent such as Elijah Wood, Michael Clarke Duncan, Michael Madsen, Rutger Hauer and Benicio Del Toro. This would have to be one of the funniest action movies of all time.

title: "A Darkness Is Here in the Nursery"
review:
There were feeble screen adaptations of comic books. There were quite ingenious ones, like, for example, Tim Burton's "Batman" movies. "Sin City" sticks somewhere in the middle. Unfortunately, with its nose definitely towards the option number one. There is a refrain in the movie declaring: "In this City you can find anything". Actually, it' s quite opposite to the truth - not a lot, in fact. And the main weakness here seems to be an obviously incongruous combination of the movie's sheer gruesomeness and its utterly superficial attitude.

The latter manifests itself in almost every element. The plot situations are insignificant. Had the characters happened to have at least some dimension they could have been considered cardboard. As it is they are transparent. While justified in a way - since the material derives from comic books, all this shallowness could have made a fit for another Rodriguez's endeavour in the area of entertainment for kids or some half-comedy like his "From Dusk Till Dawn". But it's hardly appropriate in the movie where every next minute someone dies having previously vomited a gallon of his own blood.

Some performances do not improve the situation either. Nancy Callahan, who is quite convincing in her incarnation as a child, instantly ceases to be so as soon as is transformed into her grown-up Jessica Alba version. Apparently, it's a full-time job to conjure a spark of something genuine out of this cute but totally inexpressive and utterly phoney, especially as it comes to anything sex related, starlet. It partially saves the day for her, but hardly for the viewer, that she happens to be accompanied most of the time by another unabashed paragon of creativity and invention - soon to become an Officer of the Order of Arts and Letters Mr. Willis. Who is customarily delivering his two and a half expressions of a badass with a heart of gold we have already seen on a zillion previous occasions. Other performances are pretty decent, including Mickey Rourke as Marv, who through a few pounds of make-up delivers another brick into his welcome comeback, and Elijah Wood as a sinister unblinking man-eater. But the actors are unable to drag the movie by themselves.

So, as a result, all this Rodriguez/Miller collaboration's infernal playground with all its pretentious "darkness" happens to be suspended in the void - in the wake of its unfortunate players. But if the creators didn't forget to supplement their performers with a CGI background, they have completely missed all the opportunities to add any substance to their work in all other respects. And in the end the viewer is left with just a series of visual attractions the degree of attractiveness of which is sometimes controversial.

In general, I would just say that to stick to such a superficial approach while making a movie for adult audiences is not good enough - of course, if we are not in the realm of pure visuals meant exclusively for such audiences, but it wasn't the case here, was it? Oh, yeah, talking about dirty pretty things - special thanks to Carla Gugino. Her nonchalant moonlit walk brings the only definite touch of allurement to this not highly compelling construction. I saw another review on this title summarized: "An overrated movie, nobody will remember in a year". In a year? Dude, you're being way too generous. Of course, apart from its inevitable sequel.

title: Absolutely amazing!
review:
Sin City, i believe, is one of the top three movies ever, for me. Stunning, amazing, awesome and so on.. all those words are not enough to describe how great this movie is. But, of course, it is always a matter of taste.

Since I've read many great comments on the content of this movie i will not really go into the story, but simply share my opinion.

Sin City is an extremely violent movie, the story is extremely dark and moody and so is the filming. AND it is truly original. It is also like a fountain of great actors.. every single actor is doing a great job and contributes extremely well to the movie. In fact Sin City was so violent, dark and had so catchy, moody dialog that i almost laughed all the film trough.. it was so extreme in all ways, yet so incredibly good that i could not hold myself from laughing.. strange feeling.. adrenaline kicking, exaggerating, arousing..

This is a must.

title: One the best later comic book films
review:
It's way better than Spiderman, X-Men, Batman (although Michael Keaton did a decent job), etc. comic-book or graphic novels - (Kill Bill was based on "The Bride" and Pulp Fiction was loosely based on "Battle Royale"). Kill Bill and Pulp Fiction are better films, but to me they seem based on chop-socky Asian or samurai (many of these are outstanding, much better than Pulp Fiction and Kill Bill).

One thing I like about Sin City is the European sense of timing - it takes its time developing a story - I wish it was longer. By far the most enjoyable story was Marv and Goldie, it was more personal than the other stories. Jaime King (Goldie/Wendy) and Mickey Rourke were so good and they connected, unlike Bruce Willis and Jessica Alba or Slive Owen and Rosario Dawson and Brittany Murphy. I really like the evil characters, like Bernicio Del Toro, Nick Stahl, Elijah Wood, Rutger Hauer, Powers Booth, and Michael Madsen.

Granted, the dialogue was kind of stilted - but hey, it's not Shakespeare, Tom Stoppard, Sam Shepherd, David Mamet, etc. But the dialogue echoes the film noir classics in the Thirties, Forties, and Fifties.

The set design and the whole look of this film was great - it rivals Berlin (Terry Gilliam), Metropolis (Fritz Lang silent), Battleship Potemkin and Aleksandr Nevsky (Eisenstein), The Godfather I and II (Scorsese), La Femme Nikita (Luc Besson), etc.

title: Visually Astounding
review:
I expected Sin City to be great before anyone even knew what it was. The movie contains three separate stories and one 5 minute one done by the master himself, Frank Miller. Not only does this film feature an amazing cast some of witch are, the master of action, Bruce Willis, The new babe, Jessica Alba, the hard ass, Mickey Rourke, and the Hobbit, Elijah Wood, but it also features two of my favorite directors and the masters of blood and gore Robert Rodriguez and Quentin Tarantino, and Frank Miller just making sure no one screws with his baby.

The one thing in this picture that stands out the most is background. We have all seen Schindler's List and have seen the transition of color in black and white. But you will never experience it like you do in the film. The movie is black and white but almost not black and white. Filming the entire film on a green board and punching in the background later, Rodriguez uses the troublemaker studios to make a back round that is completely computer generated and yet somehow makes it look as tho it is a page from frank miller's graphic novels. Perfecting this caption, unlike sky caption did, Rodriguez also uses color to express certain parts of the movie. a happy moment and somehow color sneaks into the background. A cop tailing a car and the red and blue lights flash inside the car. He truly perfects this unique aspect in this film.

The movie starts in the segment "the Hard Goodbye" The First in the Frank Miller's Sin City series. It is a interesting story of revenge and...well...just sick people. Mickey Rourke Makes his comeback in this movie playing a hard ass gladiator out to get 'em. His performance is truly astounding and hilarious at parts. This segment is my personal favorite in this film.

The second segment is called "the Big Fat Kill". This stars Clive Owen ,Benicio Del Toro ,and Brittany Murphy in a plot that involves obviously killing and hookers(every mans dream). It features some interesting plot twists (tho some are quite predictable). The acting in this part is sort of corny and over dramatic with a little bad dialog (tho i'm sure intensional). HOWEVER before i get you thinking badly it probably has the best story out of the three. This is my least favorite out of the three.

The final Segment is "That Yellow Bastard". This segment stars Bruce Willis, Jessica Alba, and Nick Stahl. Now this story on the other hand has great acting by all and good dialog. The story is a great romance tho a little strange of a romance. Very bloody (what a surprise ;)).

Overall this is the best movie i have ever seen visually and probably the most bloody. With many twist and turns and the unique three stories this movie was great but could have been astounding if it weren't for the acting and dialog. I know it was done that way on purpose but i still think that the actors could have done better with the exception of Mickey Rourke. But if Frank Miller ever reads this... i love you man, you are truly my hero and one of the best story writers in my book but man...don't take this personally and you REALLY need to in prove on your dilate. Love you man peace out...

title: Perfect
review:
I must admit that I know, or knew rather, very little about the story or history of Frank Miller and his series of comic book novels - and maybe that is why I enjoyed this movie so much. Although, this is still a different type of situation where one who was a big fan of the stories might be seriously critical of every little detail of the comic book turned movie. I don't believe anyone who considers themselves truly knowledgeable about Miller's work can say that this was not represented well on the big screen. I'm now intrigued to go back and check out some of his work.

That aside, as far as it being a movie and a work of art, I would give this movie high marks in both categories. For it being a movie, it was nice to see something so different as far as the approach to making it go. Also, having such an incredible cast makes it all the more intriguing. I don't see anyone else having portrayed any of these characters any better than the cast that was hired to do so.

title: A Bad Film
review: This film is really depressing - How can you take so many good actors and so much time spent editing to such a unique style yet generate something that is boring. I'm going to write off the apparently bad acting as an attempt at being consistent with the style of the novels. This film consists of a series of short stories that vaguely interlink, some better than others. The story featuring bruce willis is unfortunately boring and really slams him as an actor. The story to follow that is quite exciting and the next one isn't too bad although i zoned out during the middle. Then it returns to the willis boredom-fest - at this point i walked out on the movie (and I usually really feel a need to finish a movie i go to see). This sort of anime-style cartoony film noir stuff is tough going and the movie is pretty gory, which is a good thing and saves the movie for short periods, an obvious influence of Tarantino. The style is an obvious copy of shindlers list and an attempt to put the batman & general marvel style comics to the screen. Overall - an incredibly over-rated movie thats worth a watch if you're doing so for free but the film wont be remembered in a years time.

title: Amazing atmosphere,,Excellent movie
review:
It has really been a long time since i saw such a good movie! All stories are excellent connected, and the feeling of sin city was simply there..! The film caused me and my buddies an addiction for the rest of the night, while driving in the streets...

Atmosphere, was amazing, the colors of the movie, Absolutely great, The characters where nice, and the "old town" was perfect, and i guess Miho, was Tarantino's magic hand in the movie...

Again, a great movie,, and if there was no comic behind, then i would surely compare it with Pulp fiction, and most probably i would give a higher rate than Pulp...Which was till yesterday my absolute perfection..

title: Comics Sense !!
review:
Stylish !! OK understood that it is a needed attribute for all good quality films, now. But Over Stylish shall be the estimation for any audience who haven't read the Frank Miller's Comic Book.

This Film at visuals is just like or little better than "Dick Tracy". Of course it has altogether different taste. Sin City is that Evil Violent City in which dwells the small town with exotic women prostitutes & mobsters. Our Characters & Heroes are sort of Hidden Natural Born killers and probably the only one who retain some respect for their own gorgeous women.

Sin City covers the fabulous touch of a fast-paced Story shot in Black & White & with a Comic style of outlook governed by good special effects & art direction. Each story has a hero out to protect the women from evil villains or avenging some kind of atrocities made on women.

But the film makers never considered that a Hollywood production is a venture for global distribution. Not even one percent of the global audience must've read the comic book. And what happens is the Hero gets shot with a machine gun and he lives. He is shot again & again, but he lives. He is shot on the chest with more than 10 bullets but he lives!!! The Hero jumps from the 4th or the 5th floor on the ground & he lives !! Why didn't the film makers make a Carton then. The Film is definitely not made for children as Sin City series of comic books are only for Adult reading. Then out of how many Hollywood movie goer adults are immature enough to relish this sort of comic fantasy on screen? The Movie then gets a touch from Kill Bill sort of sword action sequences which are of course scene stealers & greatly executed. Quinten Tarantino must have just added a value out of this comic sense of mess.

The film's best part was the Babes. The hot & the hottest babes. Jessica Alba, Rosario Dawson, Devon Aoki, Jaime King & others sets the screen on fire. The touch of romance between these hot babes & their counter part heroes is splendid.

Full marks to Cinematography. Mickey Rourke is excellent & deserves applaud for his great act. Finally the Film only belongs to Bruce Willis. Just after when the 2 prime story ends & we thought that we shall not see Willis again, comes the continuation of the 3rd story. Bruce Willis' screen presence saves us from all sort of disappointments.

title: A visual feast
review:
...whose content may cause indigestion.

This is a must-see for cinematography fans, unique (as far as I know) because it successfully attempts to replicate the look and emotional feel of a graphic novel/comic. Rendered in high-contrast black and white with splashes of vivid color (here bright red lips, there a vivid blue eye, and for the last third, here a sickeningly yellow villain), every shot is highly designed and stylized. I couldn't take my eyes off of this film.

Though I wanted to! Sin City is not for the faint of heart, as it is one of the most graphically violent films you'll ever see, tempered only by the dark humor inherent in something so extreme. It doesn't surprise me that Quentin Tarantino was involved in this, because it has that over-the-top, ultra-gory, did-they-actually-just-show-that element (severed heads, anyone?)

That goes for the acting, too: Just about everyone does a fine job --Mickey Rourke in particular. Their voice-overs and on-screen performances expertly render that Film Noir tone, with just the right balance of earnestness and irony. Also, Elijah Wood and Alexis Bledel succeed in their attempts to change their "nice" image.

As a woman, I have to mention that this film (and presumably the graphic novels on which it's based) adhere strictly to gender stereotypes. All the men are tough and testosterone-charged, and all the women are whores, or whores with hearts of gold. There is one noble "dyke" who nevertheless parades around gratuitously naked. But I could forgive this, because the characters are really just archetypes in service of the multi-part plot.

If you get the DVD, it's worth checking out the "making of" feature -- interesting to see how they actually shot it.

title: Great? Possibly. Fun? Not so much...
review:
SIN CITY gets a good solid 8/10 from me. It's a huge, over-the-top miasma of gore and sex (though mostly gore, really). And no film has so faithfully rendered the feel of a comic book.

Visually, the film is utterly brilliant. Mostly black and white, with odd (and frequently disturbing) splotches of color bring a compelling look to a story that relies on film noir conventions mostly without irony.

There are some unfortunate weaknesses to this film, though. The unremitting grimness of the various characters gets a little wearisome by the halfway point. The rich, heavy atmosphere that Robert Rodriguez has constructed here gets a little TOO heavy at times. Constructed as a series of loosely-related subplots, some stories are better than others. The middle of this film is taken up with a subplot (featuring Benicio Del Toro and Clive Owen) that was probably intended to provide some comic relief, and really just kind of goes off the rails. And, I'm sorry to say, Jessica Alba turns out to be sorely miscast when the story finally turns its attention to her.

But where SIN CITY DOES work, it works remarkably well. The story of man-monster Marv and his attempt to avenge the death of his beloved Goldie is compelling, even moving. Is it over the top? Sure, but so is opera. And Mickey Rourke's Marv is probably the best, most convincing character in the film. And the story of Bruce Willis' Hartigan and his attempt to save an 11 year old girl from a sadistic rapist works, mostly.

This is not a fun movie. Women are (badly) mistreated, though I'll say it's in the service of the story. The violence is pervasive, graphic, and at times disgustingly original. Part of what I admire about SIN CITY is Robert Rodriguiz' commitment to bring to the screen such a lurid, politically incorrect story in these times of resurging conservatism.

title: awesome movie
review: You have to watch this movie.I am not a comic book fan, so I had no idea what to expect before watching. I rented it because of all of the stars who appear in it and I had read the reviews which were all good. This movie was awesome. Its not like watching a movie at all. There is a lot of gory scenes, but they are done so creatively, you don't really get grossed out. The stories are woven together and unfold slowly, so you can take it all in.I enjoyed all of the actors. My favorite was definitely Mickey Rourke. He was great. I'm a huge Bruce Willis fan, and I think Clive Davis is HOT! Elijah Woods does a very good job as a weird-o killer. There's a lot of other actors you will enjoy too. The women are good, but it seems that the men make the movie what it is. There is one woman, and I forget her name, that is the coolest woman in the movie. She never says a word throughout the whole movie, but you will know who I'm talking about as soon as you watch it. She has a great part! I didn't care much for Alexis Bledel in her part. I can't see her as a prostitute and to me she didn't sell her part. Sorry. I won't name all of the names, but it is definitely packed with stars! Let me say, after renting it, I will buy my own copy for sure.

title: Wow!
review:
I don't say "Wow" about a movie very often. But I was particularly blown away by this movie. I'm a fan of the director and literally every bit of this incredible cast. And what a cast it is! Robert Rodriguez put together an incredible piece of art. I'm not a comic book reader and had never heard of Sin City, but I am a fan of great film making. From the writing, to the score, to the acting and straightforward and appropriately cheesy dialogue - this movie kept me fully engrossed for its entirety. A real escape into a brilliantly-created world of kick-ass film noir.

On a bit of a side note, I laughed hysterically when Benicio Del Toro used his teeth to pry the fingers from his gun... don't want to ruin anything for anyone, but it was unbelievably and original storytelling.

Give this movie a chance, you'll be glad you did.

title: This film and Land of College Prophets are in the same vein.
review: Sin city is an amazing tale. It is as valid to me as any Shakespeare play or any critically acclaimed film that I have seen. To me the character Marv stands out as the most amazing performance of he year and if people don't see the high art and amazing leap in film-making in this motion picture then I believe the public to truly be daft. It is simply the best film this year in every way.I saw a sneak peek in NY at this other flick called The Land of College Prophets. The Land of College Prophets is coming out pretty soon through York Entertainment. It has the same comic book vibe. It's fight scenes are just as cool and elaborate but these guys made it for like 1/100th the cost.I used to think Rodriguez was the king of Bang for the buck but he's gonna have to move over cause this film is really amazing in a dark comic book way yet cost less than Rodrigues spent on his catering. Sin City rules though!!

title: Oh my, what a surprise
review: I must say that this movie went beyond what i expected and by far.... I am sure it will find its way into the fame of pulp fiction....its a must see for those who like the darker side...worth the watch. I found myself arguing with my wife as to who won best actor in this movie. She felt Mickey Rouke won...while I felt Bruce Willis took the show. The Movie brought back the trills i found in both Pulp Fiction as well as Resiviour Dogs, with more twists and turns than i can count, done with a skill that allowed me to see a few coming,,but boy did i miss the big ones...simply put, one smart movie. I hope that they plan to follow with a Sin City II, I do not usually go for sequels, yet for this I would more be happy to follow the storyline further.

title: I can't tell enough people about this film....
review:
I had never heard of Frank Miller before this film....I honestly only wanted to see it because of Robert Rodriguez (and anything with Tarantino attached to it for that matter).

You don't have to be a comic book fan to understand or appreciate this movie. The characters jump right off the screen...the stories (told in Pulp Fictionesque order) draw you in and don't let go.

I loved that this was filmed in a completely CGI world, it lends to the feel of how a comic book story should be told on the big screen.

Truly unique platform, outstanding direction, music, acting (except that I think Madsen was a bit lacking, but that could've been intentional), story telling and action sequences that I applauded every time.

Not for the kiddies..but definitely a seductive and stunning indulgence for everyone else.

title: Definitiely one of my top 10
review:
I have to say I love this movie. It was interesting, fast paced and had everything you would expect from a comic book!! The attempts in the past fail to capture what Sin City has done so well. It has taken everything I loved about comics and brought it to life in a movie.

The cinematography was superb. The use of animation added to the movie, which I think other movies in recent times, such as Fantastic Four, Hulk and the Star Wars movies seemed to over use.

The disjointed storyline is true to the comic!! I loved it. The stories flowed independently and then nicely meshed at the end.

The action scenes, while graphic, were not over done. It was not gore. It was hard action, but none of the blood bath scenes that disgust your girlfriend. Hehe.

The characters were complex. In a relatively short space of time, the characters were developed in such a way as to provide the viewer with a brilliant insight into how and why the characters would act and react.

I loved this movie. I failed to find anything I didn't like about it. I was riveted by it for the full length and was begging to watch it again!!

title: An incredible feat in film-making
review:
"Sin City" is, without question, one of the finest achievements in cinematic art in recent times. It stays completely faithful to the original graphic novels without sacrificing cinematic effect. In an era when "comic-book flicks" are becoming the big summer movie blockbusters and it seems all one must do is make the film and it rakes in the cash, we have a movie that's impact is deeper than great special effects and the Good v.s. Evil archetype.

Granted, said special effects are amazingly effective. Though grand and exaggerated, it feels real. At no point do you find yourself saying "Okay, that's just too much, there is no way that happens". After watching overly-elaborate light saber duels in "Revenge of the Sith" and lackluster action sequences from "Fantastic Four", the simple yet brilliant action sequences in "Sin City" are very refreshing.

And the characters, my god. Though the narrative is strikingly eloquent throughout, each character uses it differently. For instance, Marv (Played BRILLIANTLY by Mickey Rourke) uses the narrative in such a way it makes you forget that your are watching a sadistic slayer of men who seems to value human life no more than a piece of garbage rather than the brooding, good-hearted giant you find yourself rooting for, in essence, Marv is everything the dark parts of us wish we could be. In contrast, Clive Owen's Dwight uses the narrative to paint a brilliant picture of the under workings of of the dark parts of the world. You feel every insane, high tension spark that Dwight feels.

The criticisms one hears of "Sin City" are mostly the same you would hear about "Pulp Fiction" or any other Tarentino film, namely abrasive violence and monotonous characters, to which I would reply with a firm: WHAT?! Granted, I will not deny that Sin City is a violent film. It is a very violent film, but the stylistic manner in which most of it is portrayed, one only flinches at the more horribly violent ideas and the truly gory portions of the film are few and far between. Indeed, Sin City is victimized by the same hysteria that labeled "Pulp Fiction" and "Texas Chainsaw Massacre" as terribly violent and gory films, despite minimal blood and on-scene mutilation. Much of the gore is implied, though the violence is on full display. In the case of the "character monotony", I would argue that this is film about "seedy" characters, and as such, we characterize all of them as the same. Between Marv's Confused Psycho, Dwight's Collected Murdering Meddler, and Hartigan's Straight Arrow Cop who understands that in that city, the straight and narrow path often leads to failure, we see a collage of dark characters who are most different in where they are similar: They all see violence as necessary, but each of them uses it from a different perspective.

In the end, "Sin City" will have its fans and its detractors, as do many of the Quote-unquote "Cult" hits such as "Resevoir Dogs" and "Pulp Fiction", but one cannot deny that "Sin City" uses the lack of restraint of violence only to paint a greater picture with the beautiful narrative, stunning imagery, and beautiful noir atmosphere that makes "Sin City" stand out among the great cult films of our time.

Walk down the right back alley in Sin City, and you can find anything...

title: "Tell anybody the truth and they're dead!"
review: Robert Rodriguez is an ambitious filmmaker. He's done an old west trilogy, he's done 3-D kids movies, but his crowning achievement thus far is Sin City. Not just story wise, but visually and technically, Sin City is a triumph. The glossy, rich look that this movie possesses is something to behold. The use of black and white gives depth to the story and lush look that will not doubt be copied in the future. Most of Sin City was done in front of green screens with the backgrounds added later, much like Sky Captain was, and the transition to finished product is wonderful to see. Based on the graphic novels, as in illustrated comic books but could also apply to the very adult content of the stories, by Frank Miller, Sin City translates three of Miller's stories into the film, held loosely together by a running storyline. The stories pretty much follow a standard formula: an unlikely hero gets in disturbing trouble and they have to fight their way out of it. Greed and power are overlying themes throughout Sin City, often ending with violent results. Bruce Willis plays a detective with a bum ticker, Jessica Alba plays a stripper, Rosario Dawson plays a commando hooker, Brittany Murphy plays a waitress, Mickey Rourke plays an ex-con who is on a mission for survival, Clive Owen and Benecio Del Toro play opposite each other for one storyline, and Elijah Wood plays the most disturbing character in the movie, the mute Kevin. This is only a partial list, it's a fun game to watch Sin City and try to figure out where you've seen each actor on the screen before. Rodriguez shares the directing credits with Frank Miller, as the movie takes it visual style straight from his books, and Quentin Tarantino, who directed one scene. The movie bogs down in it's length, as three of Miller's stories are condensed into this two hour movie. This lead to some confusion on which character was which and why they were doing the things they were doing. The movie would have benefited from disposing of one of the three stories and saving it for the inevitable sequel. The stunning visuals however overcomes any qualms I had with the plot. The violent nature of the movie will detract some viewers, and that's OK. This movie was not made with the casual viewer in mind. Sin City is best viewed when the viewer is prepared for horrifying violence and beautiful black and white photography.

title: A visual and aural masterpiece!!!
review:
Amazing visuals! The high contrast b&w with bits of color used in all the right places made this film a real treat to look at. The voice-over's were also amazing. Especially the voice of Marv played by Mickey Rourke. You need a sub-woofer to get the full effect of Marv!! The special effects spectacular! The exaggerated sound effects during the fight scenes were startling. If you didn't see this film in the theater or even if you did, I highly recommend experiencing it on a big screen TV capable of 480p or better and a DTS receiver complete with surround speakers and a sub-woofer with lots of watts.

I thoroughly enjoyed this film. It brought the pages of Frank Miller's graphic novels to life in the most spectacular way. I've never seen specials effects like this, ever. Of all graphic novels turned movie, this is by far the best to date in my opinion. I totally agree with the directors that Mickey Rourke seemed to be born for this part. It's hard to imagine anyone else playing the part of Marv. He is one bad M.F.!! I can't wait to see the sequels scheduled for 2006 & 2008.

If you enjoy this genre, it's THE must see of all of the must see films. It's truly a masterpiece.

title: WOW this one was over the top great job by the whole crew
review: This is what movie making should be, bold with passion, Micky Rourke was born to be Marv, a real old school bad ass. I am so glad that Miller resisted the temptation of letting just anyone with a ton of dough do his baby. The whole movie displays a real commitment, one of the best uses of black and white with color highlights. They really created a surrealistic world of super macho men and vivacious ballsy woman, wow I really liked the woman, everyone of them were beautiful and had great dialog, the experience was like living in the comic book world of Frank Miller and he wrote you into the movie, like a fly on the wall. True art, the violence might offend some but everyone in the cast really got into the spirit, over the top, bold, and they took a lot of risks. Which no doubt cost them a lot of main stream movie goers. But I predict will becoming a true cult classic, the dark side of the big city in any country. From LA to Moscow this will speak to those who have been in a dark alley at night. Or had to back out of a pool hall with cue stick in their hand. I loved it. I hope you will tool

title: sin city RULES
review:
This is the perfect example of how to make a comic book into a movie.

Robert Rodriguez did the right thing when he involved Frank Miller and Quentin Tarantino. I hope to see more like this in the future:)

The fact that all the actors involved were so enthusiastic about being involved and the care taken in the settings and color and so on really makes this a totally fascination and spellbinding movie. It may be filled with gratuitous violence but its all within the context of the story ,so its not all that bad.

I HIGHLY recommend this movie to ANYONE who loves comics and just plain bad ass fun movies!

title: good adaptation of graphic novels
review:
SIN CITY

Frank Miller holding the credits for the story and co-direction for the movie actually is graphic novel ( a rather more honored term for comic books ) writer since past 20 years or so. His novels portray characters in black and white with some splashes of color on the paper. The movie SIN CITY is actually an adaptation of three of such novels/comic book by Miller , namely "The Hard Goodbye" Marv-Mickey Rourkey and Goldie's-Jamie King story, "The Big Fat Kill" ,Dwight-Clive Owen and other ladies, and "That Yellow Bastard", Hardigan-Bruce Willis and Nancy's-Jessica Alba story).

the movie has just brought together these three stories together , all three having no relevance with each other only for the BAR scene where three heroes of the three separate stories come to have a drink . Marv comes there to have a drink after he runs from the police, hardigan comes there in search of Nancy and Dwight is there just to have a drink n meet Shelly . otherwise the movie goes separately for the three stories.

however in these stories each hero has a severe problem and he has to fight both his personal problem and attain his objective of killing others. in case of Bruce Willis , it was his heart , which pounds and pains when he is in excitement or whenever he has a rush of adrenalin in his veins. he has to overcome his age problem and fight with the fat yellow bastard. Marv or mickey Rourke has a problem with reality , he sometimes fails to understand whether whatever happening with him is real or it is just his dream, he can't make decision whether he should kill people or not because he is not able to judge if the reason for which he is killing people is genuine or just dream generated , if its not real then his acts will eventually make him a psycho killer going and killing people for no good reason . he fights his problem and tries to overcome them throughout the movie . Clive oven / Dwight on the other hand has a grotesque feeling that he can talk to corpses , what actually happens is he is so afraid of dead bodies that he himself talks to himself , a case of portraying himself as a talking corpse.

The entertainment ability of the movie lies in the direction and screenplay of the movie , how it has been adapted from a B/W paper work to a 32mm projection material. If you might have noticed,throughout the movie no object in the background is in the motion , its only the characters and the objects they are involved with , not even a single leaf moves in the whole movie . this is because the whole movie was done indoor and the background implanted using the technology after wards. the movie has been directed so that it seems it is an adaptation of a comic book , the action used in the movie is cartoon style , people flying on explosions or car hits etc. the whole movie has been kept B/W and only some object have been shown in color just it is in the case with the comic book.

the whole movie is cold,violent,raw,rough and grotesque, the way nowadays US guys enjoy the entertainment to be. a proof of the fact is huge number of fans of the movies like PULP FICTION, NATURAL BORN KILLERS, KILL BILL etc. this new revolution in the movie making can be attributed to Tarantino , whose PULP FICTION came to be a great hit in US.he was invited as a guest director in the movie as well , where he directed the scene where Goldie's sister rushes the car over Marv.

direction and screenplay wise movie is good . people seem to enjoy such movies nowadays , its ranking of 91 on IMDb says a lot about that.

title: Inked Characters Walk and Talk
review:
Sin City is simply incredible! Stylish, sexy, and sleek (as well as a few other words that start with the letter 's'), Sin City is the movie that Kill Bill wishes it had been.

Fans of Frank Miller will be pleased to know that this entire movie is an almost EXACT, scene-for-scene and word-for-word reproduction of three of the Sin City graphic novels.

The acting was amazing, even some of the actors I don't normally like did very good jobs.

It was, obviously, a comic-book placed up on the big screen, with everything that entails. If you expect 'realistic' violence, look elsewhere. Of course, that's part of the humor. Marv, in particular, is very funny.

title: Not At All Bad
review:
I have never read Frank Miller's comics, so I came into this with an open mind .. a clean slate. The look and feel of the film was excellent, and the stories were more than gritty.

That being said, there was one thing I found rather annoying.

Major (if trivial) Spoiler: The film had a lot of voice-over narration, and the narrators, in two cases, died on screen. Admittedly, there's nothing wrong in doing this in a literary device that has been used for ages in books and short stories, but it seemed to me a bit out of place in the film context.

Probably the highpoint of the stories was the Marv story, with a vengeance tale that just kept going. It's something of a pity that Marv's ultimate vengeance was displayed indirectly.

This is not a film for everyone. But it's rather good for some.

title: Splendid adaption - but disturbing brutality
review:
You can't blame a movie for being close to the original, can you? Having read most of the Sin City comic books just recently, I sometimes thought that some of the most disturbing portrayals of extreme violence and bloodshed should have been left out in the movie. It is something different if you have a black and white panel in a comic book or if you have moving pictures which make the experience much more alive.

Still, apart from the blood and gore criticism, the film is a very exact rendition of what the comics are about. Harldy ever has any form of book been transferred to the big screen in such an unbiased form - certainly due to Frank Miller being the co-director of the movie.

The movie is fast-paced, the characters are strong and the visual adaption of the comic is breath taking. If you close your eyes during some of the most violent scenes, you have a perfect example of a comic book movie here.

Still, I thought that some of the elements left out in the Hardigan storyline were diminishing the personal drama the character is going through. Maybe it would have been better to show these elements - scenes in which Hardigan talks to his wife or is confronted with Senator Roark in court - and to leave out one or two severed limbs instead?

title: A beautifully filmed and written, overall dark film
review:
Sin City is yet another comic book turned film. But instead of Sin City being another cheesy comic book film where the superhero saves the girl from the clutches of an evil monster, the film is made into something I've never seen before in a comic book film. A visual masterpiece which is overall one of the darkest films I've ever seen, literally.

Sin City follows the stories of three separate people living in the futuristic city of Basin City. Hartigan (Bruce Willis) is an ex-cop falsely accused of child molestation and sentenced to spend of a life of shame in solitary confinement. After being released, his only goal now is to protect young Nancy Callahan (Jessica Alba) from the dark past both her and himself share. Marv (Mickey Rourke)is one of the ugliest people in the city but after having the night of his life, everything is about to change.

Marv's lover and only friend, Goldie, is murdered by a superb assassin, Marv will stop at nothing to kill the man who murdered his love. And Dwight (Clive Owen) is the boyfriend of young waitress Shellie (Brittany Murphy) who is being harassed and abused by her ex-boyfriend. Dwight enacts revenge but realizes to late what may just set off a war between the cops of New Town and the prostitutes of Old Town.

The three stories intermingle a bit and are all narrated by the three lead characters. The cast presented is one of the best I've ever seen and each actor is able to bring their own character to life. The story does not drag once as the film expands two hours. Some scenes are a bit nauseating and others, heart-touching.

The film is almost entirely in black and white except for some beautifully shot scenes using colors to emphasize emotion and/ or personality. This is one of the most stunning films I've ever seen. It's bold, it's fresh, and above all else, dark.

Sin City. Starring: Clive Owen, Bruce Willis, Mickey Rourke, Benicio Del Toro, Elijah Wood, and Rosario Dawson.

5 out of 5 Stars.

title: Thoroughly Enjoyable
review:
Sin City is a very cool movie. There is no way to describe it as anything other than cool. While not being on par with such movies as Apocolyse Now, it was a thoroughly enjoyable experience watching this movie. I wish I had seen it in theaters, as the movie included shots that could have been grand on the big screen.

The movie follows four stories, which are shocking, brutal, nubile, gory, and humorous. My personal favorite is the story of Marv, who seeks revenge after his love Goldie is murdered. Marv(Mickey Rourke) is a tough, ugly bruiser who can take quite a beating. It is well acted, and the shots come straight out of a comic book. The other stories are equally good, with an old cop(Bruce Willis), prostitutes galore, and a smelly yellow bastard.

Also starring Elijah Wood as a creepy serial killer, Benicio del Toro as a jerk who thinks he's the boyfriend of a seedy waitress, played by Brittany Murphy, and Clive Owen as Dwight, a murderer with a new face. They all do superb acting jobs.

My final score: 10/10 for enjoyability.

title: Sin City
review:
I thought about Sin City a bit...and realized how chauvinistic it is. All three male characters' motives are to save some damsels in distress--Willis saves Alba, Owen saves the Old Town girls, and Rourke saves(helps) Wendy. Even the seemingly strong female character needs rescuing(Rosario Dawson). The only exception to this is Miho, the Japanese assassin, but she's not the brains behind the operation; Clive Owen is. Other than that, I think the movie's concept is OK--in a city choke-full of sin, the good guys divert their energy into saving their perception of goodness--which is women, apparently.

Of course, the intended audience of the movie are 20-something males, and the movie/comic book plays to feed their interests of violence, underdogs, and women. So I can't say I expect anything else in the contents. But I wouldn't want it any other way. The product came out well.

Another thing--the format of the movie is more along the lines of a comic book, rather than a movie. Due to that, the pacing of the movie was a bit lagging.

But the awesomeness of the way the comic book visuals were translated into film blows away most of the doubts I have about this movie. It is absolutely gorgeous. The black and white, with red splashes and shocks of yellow are so striking, so well-shot, that I can't say enough good things about it.

A couple of other highlights of the film--the soundtrack was quite unique. It went well with the movie. Also, Elijah Wood is beautifully creepy as the cannibal version of Charlie Brown.

Sin City is not flawless--but the originality with which this film was produced and directed just lifts this film high above most other films I'm seeing these days.

title: Rodriguez defines coolness new !!
review: First I have to say that Sin City was my most wanted ever since the first teaser appeared. I was so inspired by this mixture of a real movie and comic that I watched every single trailer or whatever I could get ;). So finally the movie released and I could find out if my expectations would be fulfilled. First I have to say that it's a very violent movie and in some scenes a bit to explicit, even for me. However, this was known from reviews before and so you could avoid going in the movie if you don't like such stuff. Another thing which was known was the unusual comic-style. In one word: AMAZING. It fits perfectly to this evil city and the dark characters. Also the colored patches where perfectly made so that they fit in the movie. The movie itself contains three parts from which all have different characters. First is Marv, the coolest character ever in a movie. He doesn't know what pain means and so he does everything to get revenge for his dead girlfriend Goldie. That leaves a track of devastation and corpses behind. Next one is Dwight. He helps the "girls" of Sin City to hush up a murder which endangers the armistice between them and the police. The last one is Hartigan, a retired cop who tries to save a girl from a psycho. Every episode is a masterpiece for itself. They are all darkly and every character shows his bad sides, so nobody has a white waistcoat in the end. It's not about heroes but about people who fight for their conviction.

title: A comic book, not a movie
review:
I really like the movie, but it is a comic book. That is not a bad thing, and it has been brilliantly done. But it is not a movie.

Remember when The Superman Movie came out? "you'll believe a man can fly". That's the premise of a movie, movement/action/sound. The action in SIN CITY is mostly a transition from the comic book panels. Brilliantly done, but it is not a separate vision from the comic book, it is a reproduction of the comic book.

Those that have called this the best comic to movie venture ever are correct, if you want a complete remake of the comic. But shouldn't a movie be something different? Shouldn't film take advantage of its medium over that of a comic book?

The editing in SIN CITY is exceptional, but only in recreating the feel and experience of reading the comic. This then again, is not a bad thing, and I really enjoyed the movie, but it was not a different experience from the Comic. The characters did look like actual humans rather than the comic figures they are, and the casting and look of them was great.

The action though, the essential element a movie has over other medium, seemed to be the challenge to the film makers. How to transpose the still life frame of a comic to the thousands of frames of perceptually continuous movement of a movie? Well, they did it.

Even the most intense actions films had a deliberate stop and go edit to them that created a nearly seamless transition of moving from panel to panel in a graphic comic book. The movie is unique in its success in creating this effect and from a technical achievement deserves accolades.

But for me, the attraction of comics to film is to see a different representation of the characters, plot, genre and theme of the comics, while taking advantage of the medium. This is the same reason comic readers enjoy reading comics written and drawn by different people.

Each keeps the source material, but add a personal view into the soul of the characters and their world. The movies of Spiderman (especially #2) and Batman Begins have done this best, while Unbreakable did it from a completely different perspective (building tension though pacing-a film technique). These movies bring the characters and their world to film and let us experience them in a film, not as a panel by panel remake of an existing comic.

Enjoy the movie for what it is. A good movie brilliantly recreating an exceptional comic book. Not a great film using source material from another medium.

title: Six words for you "Awsome"
review:
I found this movie to be one of my favorites of 2005 no wait that doesn't quite give it justice, how about one of my favorites EVER! This movie has a storyline that just keeps you in, with lots of great action scenes to keep you at the edge of your seat. I just can't wait until the next movies come out so i can indulge in Miller and Rodriguez's tasty eye candy again. The visuals in this movie are so beautiful, every shot looks as though it is a beautiful artwork. I absolutely fell in love with the unique style that the directors brought to it which made it much more thrilling to watch.

I liked all the characters as well, all with their own missions and values and were on average acted well by cast members. I thought Mickey Rourke did a brilliant job of Marv. which made that segment of story highly enjoyable. Having never read Frank Millers graphic novels gave me nothing to compare the movie to, to look at possible faults but it certainly had made me feel bad for not having read the graphic novels yet, which i will begin to do quite soon.

So I highly recommend this film, and say to those who have not yet seen it, what are you waiting for get out there and watch it now!

title: A film noir for a whole new generation
review:
While Robert Rodriguez' work has not been much of an art form really, Sin City stands out not only as his best film to date, but also the must-see of 2005 and the most rebel commercial release since Quentin Tarantino's Pulp Fiction. This is truly the most faithful transcription of a graphic novel to the big screen.

Now, Rodriguez was really lucky to have the creator of the original material on-board for the project, Frank Miller, credited also as a Director (which had Roodriguez signed out of the Director's Guild of America) because it definitively would not have been the film it is without him. The cast is amazing, and also resemble the comic cast of characters incredibly well, with Mickey Rourke taking the silver screen by storm, and Benicio del Toro, Bruce Willis, and Clive Owen performing incredibly good. Also is worth noting Elijah Wood, really well directed and in a role that will take that Frodo character out of your head.

As you probably know, the movie is comprised out of three Sin City comic books: The Hard Goodbye (1), The Big fat kill (3) and That Yellow Bastard (4) with little bit of A Dame to Kill For (2). If you have read the comics, you'll be amazed of how it translated so faithfully to the screen. If you haven't you'll want to read them as soon as you finish the movie. According to the director, there's a Special Edition coming in December/05 that has some really neat stuff, including all three stories separated and viewable as individual pieces. So you should check it out. This movie is not only worth watching: it's gonna influence cinema in ways Rodriguez never imagined. Once you go to Sin City, you'll never want to leave.

title: I will never look at Elijah wood the same again...
review:
I was so sickened and disgusted by his character... especially that quote "even after i had cut of his arms and legs he still stared at me with that same sick smile on his face". Good thing it was in black & white. I think they should have made the movie clearer. Other than that it was okay. Like the color effects, for eyes and hair.

-rock peas on my head but don't call me a pea head. Bees on my head but don't call me a bee head. Bruce Lee's on my head but don't call me a Lee head. Now please excuse me, I gots to get my tree fed. You wear name brands and I make my own clothing. I hang out with an apple who loves self-loathing. "I hate myself."

Pancake on my face makes me extra happy. I like shampoo bottles that sit on my lappy. Cause it's my show you can't tell me what to do. When life hands me lemons I make beef stew.

So yo I gotta go, it's time for me to rock it. I put baloney in my left pocket. Smear some cream cheese in my gold locket . Cause it's my show I'm Andy Milonakis. It's my show I'm Shmandy Shmila-Shmakis. It's my show I'm Andy Milonakis.

title: Very Good Action/Drama Movie
review: Sin City I thought was a pretty good action flick. It had awesome cinema-tics and the cast was amazingly well known. I normally don't like the kind of movies that jump back and forth but this is an exception like Pulp Fiction or Kill . However there were some pretty weird and gross scenes in it like the part when Miho chopped all the gangsters into chop liver. But the best part was when Benecio Del Toro, after being cut up, starts to talk to Dwight while driving the old car. But the reason I don't give it a 10 is because of the Goldie story, I was a little confused on some parts there. But overall, I think I'd buy this one. But if you're a little confused if you want to see it, just rent it and see what you think.

title: First and last stories - Leitmotif
review:
Not having read the comics I don't know what may be otherwise well known, but here goes: What is the meaning of the first and final segments? The hit-man has no other bearing in the movie. He seems to be another story that will/might be developed in a sequel. Or...

All the stories (including first and last) carry one leitmotif: Roark. There are time/place coincidences in the three main stories (Hartigan goes to find Nancy in the same bar where Marv is, When Marv arrives to at the house where Kevin is, he hears someone hitting someone else in the top floor: that later turns out to be Roark Jr. lashing Nancy, etc). But in the first and last stories, there is no such coincidence. What seems to connect them to the other three is the underlying evil in Sin City. As a Senator/Cardinal/Degenerate, Roark is the personification of that evil power in Sin City and (probably) also whoever hired the assassin both times.

Do the comics clear this up or do they also have -on purpose- loose ends like this one?

title: A masterpiece
review:
It's the best film based in a comic i've ever seen.......with that better than good photography and those assume actors,better directors and don't forget Quentin Tarantino......Frank Millers masterpiece of comics,sin city has reached to the big screen as it is in the paper,one of the best comics ever and the best based on comic film.Chapeau for Robert Rodriguez and Frank Miller as directors,the reappeared Mickey Roore,and the old wolf Bruce Willis and all that team of actors...... But i really liked over all,that comic photography,with those strong colors over light and dark.....really good,Frank Miller's Sin City is a masterpiece.

Koma

title: This is one great movie but it is definitely not for children.
review:
This is one of the best movies I have EVER seen. It's gritty look and unrelenting brutality make this a movie to remember. But this is one extremely violent movie and it is not recommended for any one under the age of seventeen.

Even though this is one of the greatest comic-book movies ever made you have to take it with a grain of salt because certain characters are continually subjected to various forms of violence throughout the entire film.

Despite its dark and brooding atmosphere Sin City takes it's rightful place next to Batman as being one of the greatest comic-book movies ever made.

title: A different way to tell classic stories
review:
Not being a big fan of anything shot in Black and White, the fact that I was interested in seeing a movie with only splashes of color told me I would enjoy it. Where do I start? Well, having a sick sense of humor meant I was laughing in the most inappropriate places.

Devon Aoki and Elijah Wood were outstanding considering neither spoke a single word throughout the film as Miho and Kevin respectively. Most of Mickey Rourke's acting had to be done through his eyes due to the amount of makeup he had on, that impressed me considering I'm not a big Mickey Rourke fan. Clive Owen, Bruce Willis and Rosario Dawson always rock in what ever roles they take on. In Rosario Dawson case though, it was treat to see her as tough as nails Gail. Benicio Del Toro, what can I say. He makes being a thug look real appealing.

Jessica Alba however, was a disappointment. She looked bored in most scenes she appeared in and even when she smiled, it looked like a strain. Unless you go to see her swaying around in her underwear, I suggest to find some other part of the movie to enjoy.

As a whole, it was thoroughly enjoyable.

title: Great movie
review:
This is the only movie in the 21st century that deserve an "R" rated.Most of the other movies are rated are but should be 14A.

The only thing I don't like about this movie is the color.Black/white movie was between the first film ever made and the 1950's, but now we are in the 21st century this movie should've been in color and it would've made the blood stand out more.The only reason why I gave it a 9 out of 10 is because of the color.

Still, even if it is in black/white it is still a very good movie.This is in my top best movie of the 21st century until now and I can't believe it only made 50million$ at the box office, it should've made at least 75 million$ at the box office.

If you haven't seen this movie yet i suggest you go see it now.It's a good movie.

title: wow!
review:
Absolutely, undeniably fantastic! The best film I have seen for a long time. Get ready for a fast paced, phenomenally original experience! Beautifully presented and brilliantly acted, it truly is a gem amongst comic book adaptations and films in general. It is a release that I could watch over and over again and never cease to be amazed!

Don't doubt Bruce Willis' ability to be separate from the expectations we have built up of him over the years, although his part easily bears comparison to that of "Die Hard" (and the generic rehashes that have regularly followed ever since), it is taken to another level.

That said, Willis' part is far from the best amongst all involved, every character (including the somewhat comical, yet frightening, part of Elijah Wood) is played most fabulously.

title: Pretty, Badass, and Pretty Badass
review: This movie is great, to put it short. If you liked Pulp Fiction or Kill Bill, this is an immediate recommendation. Like Pulp Fiction, it has three different slightly intertwining stories. Also like Pulp Fiction, it is told in an out of whack chronology. The acting is excellent. Clive Owen, Jamie King, Bruce Willis, and Brittany Murphy are very good. Benicio Del Toro and Rosario Dawson are excellent. But Mickey Rourke OWNS this movies. Let me tell you how much he owns this movie. He is in one third of the movie, and he OWNS it. Jessica Alba and Alexis Bledel are there only for pretty faces, which is made up for by the former actors. Finally, Elijah Wood does well and does a complete turn around from Frodo to the creepy caniballistic Kevin. Very quotable, and a great movie for the ages.

title: Amazingly Sick!
review:
Ever since the previews came out,(Dec?) i wanted to see this movie. I finally saw it and have to say I'm amazed. The way Rodriguez took the book and made it into a movie is incredible. Its not like a adaptation, it IS the book. The three stories are all connected by many different things in Basin City. Marv ( Mickey Rourke) has a one-night stand with a beautiful girl named Goldie, (Jaime King) whom which he falls for. After she is murdered, he goes on a rampage to find a culprit. Dwight (Clive Owen) kills an undercover cop and breaks a balance between cops and hookers. And Hartigan (Bruce Willis) is imprisoned for a crime he didn't actually commit. So after he gets out, he tries to find a "little" girl he has to protect.

With its unique art direction and an all star cast, this movie ROCKS! 9/10

title: Coolest!
review:
This movie freaked me out!!! I have never seen anything like this. Filmed in a very different way. And that the movie is mostly in black and white, which probably is a idea which Mr Tarantino came up with.Tthe actors/actress is very good. Bruce Willis, who I'm usually not a big fan of does his best role ever. Jessica Alba, what more can u say then: DAMN!!!! Mickey Rourke, hard to find a cooler dude. Elijah Wood, who doesn't say a word in the movie is excellent. If you haven't seen Sin City, you better do that fast or else you gonna miss something incredible. Peace out.

M to the N - Orta

title: Outstanding
review:
I initially didn't think I was going to like this. I knew it was a series of fairly unconnected stories, and the first two seemed to occupy about five minutes each. I thought the whole movie would carry on that way, and if so it would have been a disjointed mess. Fortunately it settles down quickly - and later on it returns to the little bits and develops them fully to boot.

Overall, I loved it. It's got a very weird visual style, over the top characters, gritty as all hell plots. Don't look for heroes in this movie - there are none. Sin City is a place where everybody gouges everybody else every chance they get, because it's the only way you get even a slim chance to stay alive. If there was a real city like this, no sane person would go within a hundred miles of it - but it's the kind of place that sucks people in and traps them there even as it breaks them down.

It all falls apart if you stop to think about it, but you don't stop to think about it so that's not a problem. Best film I've seen in ages.

title: best movie of the past 3 years, and few will see it
review:
Which is fine by me, this is a free country, and all those who miss this movie, that's their business not mine.

But if you've seen Bruce Willis when he was good (the old T.V. show moonlighting, or "Nothing in Common," or "Pulp Fiction") or Mickey Rourke (when he was good? check out Spun; he's been putting in Oscar caliber work for the past 10 years but no one has noticed), or are a comic book hipster geek who has been waiting 20 years for Frank Miller's work to finally get a fair shot, then, well.

I don't want to say anything specific, but if you are the last person who loves movies for the artistry and the shock you can not dismiss when a movie is both horrible and true, who has yet to see this movie, then rejoice because I envy your seeing this movie for the first time.

But enough of me babbling, just take it from a class A movie freak who watches a thousand movies a year: I've seen three thousand movies before this and five hundred after, many of which were good, but all of which I'd forget before "Sin City."

title: What a Film
review:
This is the most visually stunning piece of Sinema (see what i did there) I have seen in a long while. I had never read the graphic novels before but now I have and they are so well represented by Rodriguez and Co.

Rourke is superb as Marv and i am now as i write this looking for the poster to put in my room although the one i want is about Â£12 aaahh. The three stories are every bit as brilliant as the three tales in Pulp Fiction and i say this with the biggest respect to Pulp as it is my favourite film of all time. A film that is not to be missed, fans of the original novels will not be disappointed and since Sin City 2 will be on the way soon i think that we are going to see more of the same which in my opinion isn't bad at all. If you haven't seen this film it's OK as it is now out on DVD, although i am disappointed with the extras available on it hopefully there will be another with lots of extras.

If the world was a better place then it would get a couple of Oscar nominations but it won't. The Academy is just sad

title: Sins have never looked so cool
review:
Okay, I think we have a winner! In the past, we've a great deal of comic based films which have generally followed a familiar formula: Hero saves city from bad monstrous freak. Though I have generally enjoyed most entries into this genre, I have to say that few have really tried to push the boundaries of cinema.

With Sin City, based on Frank Miller's graphic novel's, we have given something stylistically different to anything before it, a dark as anything 50's world were nothing is right, and the 'heroes' are always severely flawed in some way.

I personally loved everything about it. The look of the film, almost entirely made up in digital, creates an atmosphere unlike anything you will see in other films. The dialog, though certainly not 'mainstream', offers a great throwback to another time when one-liner's and narrative's were king. The characters, many of whom you will love, would be despicable in another world, but here they are as unique as the world miller has created, and are made to be cared about.

Despite some claims that it moves at lightning pace, there are times when it is slow up a bit. It cannot be understated that the film is incredibly gruesome in parts as well, though not overly gratuitous in it's attack on the senses. However, if your after something that's a little different for a change and can handle the gore, then check it out!!! You won't be disappointed.

title: Totally Redefines Film
review:
Really, this film isn't just excellent due to the stories, the acting, the cinematography, the soundtrack - no one thing is more amazing than any other. But together all those incredible elements combine to make a film like none we've seen before. The sheer calibre of these actors (Count how many names you know!) sets you up for a good movie, the look of the shots, the ambiance and the feel of the storyline is amazing. I need more superlatives. Just watch it and you'll see what I mean.

I was expecting something a lot less thought out and clever, a lot more pulp than true fiction, but the three episodes contained in the movie all show what I'd call a twisted and gripping reality. The actions and morals of the characters are stylised - this is a fictitious world - but they still relate back to the stories we all relate to. I think that sums this movie up: an action packed, stylistic masterpiece that knows its bounds and exploits them perfectly.

title: Wow
review: This has to be one of the best movie's I have every seen. Period. I have been counting down the days until it's released on DVD. If you like movies, at all, YOU MUST SEE THIS. NOW. I saw it two times. I didn't respect Jessica Alba as an actress until I saw her in this movie. Bruce Willis does great in this movie. I was surprised at how great the plot was. I kept wanting more. The acting is superb, the stories are unique, and it was a great change from the teen comedy crap the movie industry churns out these days. Please, keep bringing us surprises like this! If every movie based on a comic book was like this, I would be broke from all the movies I go to.

title: Extremely violent, but a true comic-turned-movie, very original and stylish
review:
What can i write that hasn't been written before already? This movie rocks! Forget Spiderman and Batman, this is what a comic-turned-movie should look like. It's kind of like the visual style of "Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow" and the violent plot and fast pace of "Kill Bill", with a 3 part story like "Pulp Fiction" or "Go".

Violence plays a very big part in "Sin City". There's stabbing, shooting, decapitations, the electric chair, castration, gang-style executions.. it's all in there so don't say i didn't warn you. But it's all so raw, so gruesome and so way over-the-top, that it actually becomes funny again.

Recommended, provided you are willing to see the violence for the mockery that it is.

title: Best movie of the decade
review:
Having following this movie for 1 year, from the time I saw it announced on the internet that they are in the process of making a movie called Sin City and later seeing the trailers, there was a very large chance (more than 99% chance in fact) that I could be disappointed with this movie. The fact that is was not disappointed at all shows how amazing this move was.

It lived not only up to my really high expectations, but so far passed it I was left in aw of how good that movie was.

The camera effects capture the comic book feeling where as other comic based movies fail. I love the way most of the filming is in black and white but only a woman's red dress is in colour. The gore leaves you shocked and your mouth open, probably one of the goriest movie ever. The acting is spectacular showing the highest talent of the all star cast. There are many story lines through out the movie however they are all strong and predominant even with all the gore.

If I could leave you with a few words... See this movie!

title: Disturbingly good
review: Sin City-Home to hookers, crooked cops, average Joe's, ex-SEALS, street fighters, hot women, and cold drinks. This movie centers on three Sin City yarns: the story of Marv, a street fighter on a brutal rampage, trying to find the killer of a hooker he slept with one night; the story of Dwight, a killer with a new face and a mysterious past, who attempts to save the hookers of old town; and that of Hartigan, one of the last honest cops in Sin City. The movie is mostly in black and white, with the occasional splash of color, i.e., someone's eyes, or blood, or a car. the movie is heavy on violence, gore, and a bit of nudity. The actors are scarily similar to the characters in the comics, and over-all, this is the most faithful comic book movie ever, and one of the best movies this year!

title: "A New Hope" In Film-making; This Generation's "Star Wars"
review:
When one does this sort of thing, it won't go unnoticed. Sin City is the 21st century's "Star Wars", using the best of, surprisingly, off the shelf software, and digital video, to recreate Frank Miller's drawings in his amazing Sin City graphic novel collection.

I don't think this movie would be possible if we were still in the "dark age" (as Robert Rodriguez calls it) of film, and negative cutting. This film was done so fast and quickly with digital everything: editing, score, set building, and many other things that expand a 50ft (if even that) green screen to a huge city. Though one of the main attractions of this masterpiece is it's digital process, the three stories (excluding "The Customer is Always Right) are, if not disturbing, excellent and humorous. There is a scent of Tarantino in this, yes, he did direct a scene in this, but the words from the comics, and things that happen, are very Tarantino.

Why are we attracted to the darkness of life? Murder; crime, sex...we are attracted to it because these things happen in real life. Though it may be very fantasized, a prostitute that sleeps with a muscle builder could be killed by a cannibal. We love these stories because they are real without scaring us that they can happen to us...we love them because they can do this to us.

All in all, however you look at it, Sin City is a breakthrough not just in film-making, but in storytelling and style. See this immediately; fall in love with every character, whether they be good or bad; applaud how the actors act (which is very well); and be amazed at how it is directed, and how it looks. Be ready for one of the best films ever created. Be ready for Sin City.

title: Sinfully delightful
review: One of the most shocking, and most intense, thrilling shocker movies, ever made, Sin City does it all, with it's action, and noir like stories in the fictional city, which is full of crime, murder, scandal, prostitutes, corrupt officials, politicians, gun toting, sword wielding women, and a lot of other depraved sickos, and you get to hear each person's side of the story, of the situations of what's on and what's happening in Basin City, especially what's happening in the outskirts of the city, especially the one in the farm, which seems to reminisce the murders of Ed Gynne, and Elijah Wood's character was kick ass! Each scene features black in white, mixed with color in some scenes, with red in the cars, and the blood, though some of the blood is white, perhaps for legal reasons, and also in one of the segments, there is color, and the cars also get different colors. Robert Rodriguez did such a good job in making this adaption onto the big screen, with the help of Quentin Tarantion of Kill Bill/Pulp Fiction/Reservoir Dogs fame! I must admit, this surpasses both Kill Bill and Pulp Fiction in terms of plot, and action. Recommended to all who enjoy Rodriguez's films and action films, especially violent ones, and to the fans of the original comics, and I heard there is a sequel in the works, and I feel overwhelmed with joy, hoping it will be as good.

title: how wrong was i?
review:
wow!!! firstly i had a real high expectation for this film being that members of my family were huge sin city fans. spent many days checking the cast details and which stories they would include. three things struck a chord.... mickey Rourke as Marv, the former boxer wasn't exactly my first choice as Marv, especially after his role in once upon a time in Mexico(stupid dog).
