Elijah wood as Kevin, i just couldn't see past the hobbit, shallow i know. but i still remember the faculty. his speciality is nerdy! lastly the point that the film would be made mostly cgi, now i'm a fan of special effects as much as the next person but too much makes films look like a Sega genesis game. streets of rage instead of sin city.

many of you reading this think I'm now bashing the film but what I'm trying to say is that i was so....WRONG!!!! Mickey Rourke is MARV!!!! without a doubt there is no person on this Earth that could have done a better job. Elijah wood was just creepy and good on him, the noir effect on his glasses was divine. and finally the cgi aspect was astounding. Robert did a great job, one for frank miller and his fans to be proud of. in case you haven't seen it, I'm recommending it to all, comic book fans, actions fans...everyone!!!!

title: Off to Frank Miller's world
review: I saw this piece yesterday at the cinema, and I have to make clear to everyone that I have never been especially into comics by Frank Miller. I guess I have never really give it a fair chance. Anyhow, the piece totally stunned me. I love that the movie is generally in B&W except for some Technicoloreffects, and that really puts a neat "comic feel" to it. I guess the editors captured the feeling of being exposed to a comic, as the whole piece really did feel like a comic, at times reminding me of the movie scenes in the PC game "Max Payne". I think that the story is told in a superb way, and the actors (impressive cast!) don't really surprise us, as we already now what these actors are capable of. See this today, you won't regret it! 8/10!

title: Very cool movie and if you don't mind a bit of violence a must see.
review: Sin city is gritty, dark and well dark. You have to be a certain type of person to like this sledgehammer (Using the term literally) of a film. It uses a huge amount of film nior but pulls it off very well. Don't be discouraged by the black and white as you will not even notice it after a while plus it adds to the flavour of the film. Basicaly this movie is an incredibly violent but very cool digitalised comic strip. The three plot lines had good story lines and crunched and splattered at a break neck speed that maintained my attention with ease. Good acting jobs from all the cast with a host of well known and very suitable choices for the main characters. I highly recommend this movie with its extreme (but stylish) gore and excellent portrayal of a city that is too true to its name. Go see it! But ahh don't eat lunch before hand.

title: A Class Act
review:
Having never read any of the comics, and indeed never being a comic fan, i must confess I really enjoyed this film. Simply reading the cast list, reading the American reviews (i live in Australia it only came out in mid July) and eventually seeing the previews I expected I would like the film, but probably not to the extent i did.

From start to finish, the way the film is shot, a black and white film with certain part coloured is very effective. The cast all shine in their individual roles. All star cast often seem to fall flat but this is one example where it's really come off well. They'll be pressed to find a cast as good as this for Sin City 2. Certainly a highlight for many is seeing Elijah Wood in a role so completely different from Frodo Baggins of Lord of the Rings.

As you would expect from anything that Rodriguez does, and any that Tarrentino has anything to do with, it's a very violent film. Due to the black and white filming, some scenes that are extremely violent or gory are made watchable. I appreciated this. It's not so bad that people will be really turned off by it (people who watch films of this genre that is) and yet it's still extremely cool action.

One thing that really impressed me was the dialog. There was no swearing basically the entire film. This is so hard to find now day. It seems if you want to make a kick ass film with lots of action and violence people won't appreciate it unless it's full of the 'f' word. That really frustrates me and is probably my biggest criticism of Tarrentino who's work I still really like. So this was very refreshing.

Overall, it's a fantastic film, I've seen in twice in a week and i'm sure i'd still enjoy it if I saw it again. If you know anything of the director, you'll expect there'll be lots of violence and lots of women parading around in little clothing. If you don't want to see that, then don't watch this film. Simple. Don't watch it then come complaining about all that stuff. For most of us who have enough interest to come to this page, I'm confident this film will exceed your expectations.

title: A gut churning spectacle
review:
Sin City was an awe inspiring cinematic event. Never have I see such an effective meld of story, acting, genre and film in one delicious package. For me there were no stand out performances as all the cast seemed to melt into their roles and the dark scenery behind them......though saying that Mickey Rourke and Rosario Dawson were excellent (I gotta stop pratting on) It is interesting to note that some of the cast who were in the same scenes together actually didn't film them together and never met.

In the old clichÃ© 'if you are going to see one movie this year....this should be the one!'

title: Blood, guns and fun
review: A black-and-white, ultra-violent film based on a comic book, directed by Robert Rodriguez, Frank Miller (the creator of the comics) and a special guest director Quentin Tarantino. It has to be cool! And it is. I was so happy after seeing "Sin City" that I decided to make a list of things I liked about this film: 1. The dialog is brilliant; 2. Although the characters say clever things almost without a break (and during the breaks we can enjoy their interesting thoughts), the action never stops either. There is always a good chance for a bullet, a car or a maniac to appear; 3. The laws of physics are the same as in comics - the cars take curves and make jumps wickedly; 4. Blood fountains appear to the places where used to be a leg or an arm - just like in "Kill Bill"; 5. Like in "Schindler's List", some things are in colour: the red dress of a woman in the opening scene, the yellow face of Yellow Bastard etc; 6. Some characters never talk but they have other good qualities as shooting arrows or throwing swastika blades to kill people, or cannibalism; 7. The characters are shot, their arms and legs are ripped off, they are ran over by car, punched with hard fists... but they stay alive and fight back for a long time before dying; 8. All the bad guys get punished. Hard; 9. There is always night in Sin City; 10. It's hard to find a character in the film who is normal; 11. Elijah Wood plays a quiet boy who has long nails and cool sunglasses and who eats people. Slightly different from Frodo of "The Lord of the Rings"... 12. Michael Clarke Duncan plays a cop who tries to waste the prostitutes; 13. The prostitutes are pretty. They also use wicked weapons to protect themselves against the cops who try to waste them... 14. Josh Hartnett from the "masterpieces" "Pearl Harbour" and "40 Days and 40 Nights" plays in this film. And this time he's a bad guy; 15. Tarantino directed a scene where a man with his throat cut talks... There are many more good things about this film. Rodriguez has given us "Desperado" and "From Dusk Till Dawn", Tarantino "Reservoir Dogs" and "Pulp Fiction". "Sin City" is a new gift from them, Frank Miller and a punch of great actors. We should thank them all...

title: Ball Busting
review:
This is the film that i had been waiting for. Rarely has there ever been a film where i was knocked out of my seat from the ball busting attitude of a film. Right from the first second of film I felt i would leave a happy person. The heavy black and white cinematography, the intense colour work, the awesome acting from everyone, every bit of this is flawless in my eyes.

Many have said this is sexiest against women, but the whole time the women were on I thought i wouldn't want to mess with them. This is really empowering for the women. As they said, the women are the law, and you wouldn't want to cross them; especially Miho.

All the guys are tough and forceful. Marv going on a relentless massacre for a woman he loved is the best tragic love story i have every seen in film. But all the stories are tragic love stories in one way.

A thought about the violence in Sin City. If this was in colour, the violence would have been so much more disturbing. Though this is a violent movie, it is very stylized; so the impact is dulled down that your not always registering the violence.

In all, this is Robert Rodriguez's best work. This film will never date and be as strong in 20 to 50 years time.

title: If murderous mutilation with an art-house twist is your thing then this is the movie for you
review: Upon viewing this movie I have to say it left me totally baffled. Why is pointless excessive violence so popular?? This movie does not answer, but rather prompts such questions. I am not a fan of violence. I cant see the point in glorifying humans doing ugly things to each other. Prior to checking out this movie I did not realise that Tarantino had a guest spot, otherwise even the opportunity to see Josh in action would not have enticed me into the theatre to sit through multiple depictions of (in my opinion) seemingly endless and senseless butchery. I could appreciate the clever visual design and artistic styling of the movie - and lariat wielding Jessica is stunning, but Frodo "How could you?"

title: Fantastic!
review:
Robert Rodriguez doesn't seem to know the word moderation. His movies over the past ten years or so have either consisted of children's flicks like the Spy Kids series or violent bloodfests like the Marachi saga. The idea of an 'M' rated movie seems abhorrent.

Which brings us nicely to his latest venture- an adaptation of Frank Miller's graphic novel series Sin City.

This is not a movie for everybody's taste; and although the MA15+ may suggest that already, I find it hard to believe that this got away with a softer rating than Kill Bill Vol. 1 after what some of the characters go through. This is not the sort of cartoonesque violence that made Kill Bill so wild and stylish, rather Rodriguez, Miller and Tarantino ( as a 'guest director' ) show a much more darker and grittier world of violence that is dominated in black in white, with only the odd emphasis of colour.

The plot is actually 3 stories- all loosely connected with one another. Bruce Willis stars in the first one as Hartigan- a cop whose early retirement plans are cut short due to a combination of his own obsessions with justice and his partner Bob ( Michael Madsen ); only to find his obsession later on all grown up in the form of Jessica Alba and his nemesis still alive in the form of what can only be described as something seen to be believed. Mickey Rourke in the second story plays Marv- a convict who is determined to get to the bottom of who killed a hooker that spent the night with him. This perhaps sees one of the most interesting performances of the movie in the form of Elijah Wood, who after Frodo Baggins, plays Kevin- a cannibalistic stalker. Finally ( as if two wasn't enough ) there's Dwight ( Clive Owen ) who attempts to help protect the 'sisters' of Old Town led by Gale ( Rosario Dawson ) from the mob and bent cops.

All the cast of Sin City really come to the fore, with Owen and Willis in particular standing out and making the gritty neo-30's gangster dialog come to life. The environment is fantastic and one can only applaud Rodriguez for the time he has taken to recreate the atmosphere of Miller's novels.

As I said before, Sin City is not for everyone- but if you can handle violence ( and I mean violence ) then this is a movie not to be missed.

title: Brilliantly done.
review:
Sin City is a movie that manages to awe everyone in the room. The way that they did it in black and white with small touches of color is very artistic. Visually, the movie, with digital animation in black and white shows that Frank Miller the original creator of the Sin City comics/Graphic Novels is a pure genius. What these people did with a movie, this man did with ink and paper. It has been said that the graphic novels of Sin City were the story boards for the actual movie. Every camera angle/shot in the movie is good, and done in a very artistically done way. Judging by the movie has been done you don't know who to give more credit to, the director, Robert Rodriguez who is a genius in his own respect, or to the co-director/ graphic novel writer, Frank Miller who I have already stated is a genius.

(Spoilers) The story lines in this movie also make me think that Frank Miller is a genius. He has the story line of Marv, a tough man that has had his one true love killed while he slept right next to her. Marv seeks the men that killed her, and had her ordered killed. The second Story line involves a man named Hartigan who protects a young 11 year old that is going to be raped by a pedophile who just so happens to be the son of the governor that has very high power. That being and with a corrupt police department he can do just about anything that he wishes. In that Hartigan goes to jail falsely for eight years, and when he gets out he searches out the now 19 year old girl to protect her from that very same man that attempted raping her eight years ago. A third story line appears with a man named Dwight who has affairs with a woman, finds out that she has a man around that beats her. Dwight attempts killing the woman beater who is a good cop gone bad, and then the rest of his story is covering up for the murder. (End Spoilers)

The movies violence is not always in good taste but it is very amazingly well done. The violence begins five minutes in and doesn't let up for the entire movie. There are things like Gun Shots, dismemberment's of the body, decapitations which I suppose would fall under the previous category, there is also a very large amount of explosions that make the film even more violent. The nudity which has been said to be very bad, is actually rather mild. The nudity usually takes place in a dark area and is barely visible. This is not to say that you should let a child view these scenes, much less the movie.

The All star cast is a reason to see it alone. Bruce Willis, Mickey Rourke, Jessica Alba, Benitio Del Toro, Elijah Wood, Clive Owen, Brittany Murphy, Michael Madsen, Josh Hartnett, Jaime King, and Nick Stahl all deliver amazing performances in this AMAZING movie.

title: Comic Book meets Pulp Fiction
review:
I went with two typically critical friends into Sin City tonight. It wasn't our first choice, and the eventual decision on seeing the film was more on the fact we could get decent seats (went to one of the few places in Sydney with allocated seating).

What a ride! It took a while for the movie to warm up, but once it hit the first peak it stayed there for much of the film. If you didn't mind the blood and guts from films like Pulp Fiction and the Kill Bill series, then you'll be able to sit watching this without squirming. There's a lot of violence in this film! The film is in black and white, but the addition of colour for blood, tears and the like is essential in order to draw your attention to certain things (this becomes even more important near the end when certain characters are completely coloured). A very enjoyable film! 9/10

title: Everyone ought to see!!
review: This, I believe, will be the start of a new trend, a new vision in Hollywood. The stories are reflected to the audience in a very professional and original way and none part of the puzzle remains missing when the two hours of excellence comes to an end. I don't want to be seem as a wise .ss and I should confess that for the details I have to watch the film again, and may be again, but I can say it by heart that Sin City is worth watching for, worth spending your money for. I do not want to go in details of the film ( I am not yet sure if I got them all or not:), also there is no need to mention the cast, but I shall say that I've already started to wait for Sin City 2. Enjoy it...

title: bits i can't tie together
review: I've never read any of the comics and only saw this film the other day, but I was wondering if anyone could answer some questions for me... first of all, why did Hartigan's partner (madsen) shoot him as he was saving the young Nancy? was it just as pay back for him just punching him, or was he corrupt and therefore answering to the roarke dynasty? and secondly, I'm sure you'll all think I'm being really stupid here, but is josh hartnett's character Dwight before he had his face changed? and if so does he have it changed back to kill Becky??? or is he just a hit-man, and if that's so, who is the girl he kills in the first scene- an escaped prostitute, or is that scene just used so we know what is about to happen in the final scene? Thanks

title: This is a comic book
review:
This is the art of the graphic novel put to film. There is nothing more that can or ever should be said about this movie. This movie must be watched.

Unlike this film that strips the graphic novel to the barest of components and transports us into a new world of what is left, IMDb requires more text than should be spent on a review. With this in mind, I must repeat:

"This movie must be watched."

"This movie must be watched."

"This movie must be watched."

"This movie must be watched."

title: Such a magnificent movie... all simply great and the best I've watched this year yet.
review:
It isn't that often I go out from the cinema with such a satisfying feeling for having watched such a great movie. This is surely one of the very few movies that has given me the credit to have such glorious and satisfying feeling. Probably the best movie I've watched this year and the year isn't ended yet.

This movie is casted of surely almost all actors you know or recognize either their faces or names - names such like Mickey Rourke, Rutger Hauer, Nick Stahl, Clive Owen, Bruce Willis, Alexis Bledel, Jessica Alba, Elijah Wood, Josh Hartnett, Michael Madsen and a few more. This movie is parted by a few histories that is tied to each other and make new ways to new stories and new mysteries. The first story is a young charming man (Josh Hartnett) who kills an unbeknown st woman who believes he loves her (it's how he gets to kill his victims). The second story is about Hartigan (Bruce Willis) who is the only last good cop left in the sin city. He is fixed by the mind of finding Nancy Callahan, 11, who is kidnapped by the town's senator's son (Nick Stahl) who later turns to be the yellow and disgusting man. He arrives in time, killing his assistants and, to last, shooting the ear and the cock off the kidnapper, saving the pretty and very scared girl. But he is betrayed by his friend, another cop, and is shot a few times. He finds himself waking up in the hospital, accused for having killed the other six girls and kidnapped this pretty girl Nancy who he actually saved. He gets into prison and eight years later, he is prepared for revenge. The third is about Marv (Mickey Rourke) who has a glorious night with Goldie, but finds her murdered besides him on the morning, making him looking for the murderer who did this, at any cost. It becomes a thrilling hunt that may finish a few lives, making a way to the person who is behind everything, the villain you never would ever imagine... or dream about. Also, another story is about Dwight (Clive Owen), who comes to the Old Town where the whores have their own laws and their own business. He is there for a business - because of Jackie (Benicio del toro) who has been with his last whore (Brittany Murphy). It turns about to be that the girls make the task of stopping him themselves - but what they don't know was that he was a cop, making the resting between the whores and the cops turning into a war... if not they are stopping it before it is too late.

Sin City is no usual movie. The visual effects are very unlike the others you've seen - it's all based on comic book-like, making it feel that you are the audience behind the events into a comic book, when it actually is a movie you are watching. It feels real, so real, that you just keep your eyes on the movie, afraid of missing anything meaningful, anything interesting or anything great and magnificent, or afraid of missing any special character. The movie is all black and white except from the eyes that are colored (either blue, green, brown or whatever), the yellow man (Nick Stahl), the Goldie hairs of Goldie and a red dress. Blood can turn to be red sometimes.

It is filmed in a real action way, a way that make this movie real, thrilling and bloody. I have never liked action movies that much before, but I really really like this movie, despite all violent scenes... it is despite everything a fine story of violence, fighting for your people against all others, finding your loving one, making murder for revenging your loving one's death, truth and corrupts. It is more bizarre than the reality but it is such a well-done movie gathered by all great actors into one and same movie and all great visual effects. The story ain't stupid either, and the characters are very different and cool.

I enjoyed this movie fully, never being bored or missing anything even a second... Couldn't practically blink... was completely obsessed.

title: About as good as a movie can get - remarkable
review: My sons, whose opinions I value, told me to see this and not to wait for the DVD. They were right. This is remarkable film making. Totally engrossing, visually stunning. If you can see it in a theater, do. If it's too late, see it on DVD on a big screen in a dark room. A cast dense with famous actors has created a series of images and moods which is perhaps unique in film history. While that seems a hyperbolic statement, I have never seen anything like this. The effect is so vivid that when you walk out of the theater you are still there, on mythic streets looking for mythic characters. Enjoy it, but be careful going home - you may have the urge to drive foolishly.

title: Mmmm, very weird - but watchable
review:
This is good. It's tough to believe some of the actors never met each other even though their in scenes together.

Right, we'll talk about the cast 1st. Benicio Del Toro - wasted. Could have made so much more of this guy. I liked the scenes where he's "dead", their very surreal. Bruce Willis - very good, comes across a bit too "Die Hard" in certain scenes (I think the director should have told him to act, not pretend to be in another Die Hard Film). I still found escaping from the noose a bit difficult to believe though. Nick Stahl - Damn, I had to look up to see where I remembered him from - Terminator 3! He was pretty average, nothing to write home about. Even as the Yellow Guy he was difficult to watch. Micheal Madsen - I figure he was doing this for Quentin Tarentino as he barely appears at all, and the scenes he IS in he loses to Bruce Willis every time. Michael Clarke Duncan - I will apologize for mistaking this guy for Ving Rhames every time I see him. I think he played his role well but didn't really have very much to do in the film at all. Mickey Rourke - unrecognizable but brilliant. Took this role and ran with it, totally made it his. Sheer bliss to watch every frame he's in. Rutger Hauer - hardly appears but makes nothing of his role. I think it's time he quit the business, he seems to have lost his edge. Elijah Wood - badly cast, totally unable to play a psycho killer. And I still keep thinking he's damn Tobey Macguire from Spiderman, that I WON'T apologize for. Clive Owen - OK, 1stly I'd better make it very clear I AM actually related to Clive (he's my step-cousin) but I won't let that relationship cloud my judgment. This role is excellent, and Clive acts his damn socks and shoes off. I think this kind of role shows he CAN be the next James Bond if they wish to choose him (please do, I really want to be related to James Bond!) Clive doesn't have be American to prove himself as he shows here, he does the hard character acting, the gritty tension, the love interest, the slightly bad and mad to know talking to a corpse person. He covers the whole board and not once did I doubt him. I was shouting internally "NO!" when the tar just seemed to happily wash off him in the rain though.

Right, the female cast. Apart from Rosario Dawson, the women were generally rubbish. Rosario as Gail was excellent, a very tough yet street savvy lady, able to hold her own in any situation. I don't really know Jessica Alba or Brittany Murphy (whose voice sounded familiar then I found out she was Luanne in King of the Hill.) and quite frankly from their performances in this film I don't want to know any more about them.

The film is weird, it's more like watching cut scenes from a computer game, It reminded me a lot of Max Payne and XIII. If you like film noir, or comic book style films then I think you will enjoy this. I'd say to the comic book crowd hold off for the DVD which is bound to have boat loads of extras. Oh, and can someone cast the girl playing Miho in a bigger role very soon. She cast one of the rays of hope into an otherwise (apart from Rosario Dawson) bloody awful female cast. Not everyone is going to like this film, some people may not even be able to sit in the cinema through the whole film, they might get bored. Wait for the DVD then and watch the whole thing, it IS worth the effort. I didn't really understand the sequence at the end with the girl and Doctor in the elevator but maybe I wasn't supposed to.

The film certainly has too many traces of Quentin Tarentino's director style and they don't improve the film or make it any more watchable. Oh, and Quentin? There are more actors than Madsen and Willis about you know, try casting some new faces we don't know.

title: Would have liked the strands in an alternative order...
review:
Would have liked the strands in an alternative order...with the last strand 'THAT YELLOW B'STARD' as the second story. Ameros Perros got it right, Sin City got it wrong...

I found that the second strand in Ameros Perros dipped the pace and was slightly boring compared to the explosive opening of the film...even so, the ending was so brilliant you just thought wey-hey! what was that film? I've just got to go and watch that again. However exiting Frank Miller's Sin City after the 'THAT YELLOW B'STARD' strand had slightly bored me..the feeling that there should be something so much more after the wonders of the first two strands and the performances by Clive Owen and Mickey Rourke

title: The Marv sequences were awesome the rest of the film a let down
review:
firstly I'm only vaguely familiar with Frank Miller's work and therefore not a fan waiting to see his comic's made into a film.

I loved the first 30-40 minutes focusing on Marv, a great big lovable brute of a man, it was quite breathtaking, hard, fast, mean etc and superbly acted by Rourke. Ther rest of the film that followed just felt like a bit of a let down, to be honest, and the third story was the weakest of all so buy the end I was feeling rather disappointed.

I know that the director was trying to be faithful to the the comics, and tell each story as they appeared in them but it made the film rather disjointed. If the 3 narratives could somehow have been more intertwined or even linked this would have made for a better film.

Visually stunning and probably the best ever attempt to turn a comic into a film, yet there were some rather leaden moments.

More camera angles and classier editing, (think Pechinpah, think the Wild Bunch) would have made this an amazing film instead of just a pretty damn good one

title: A New Classic
review:
Based on 3 of the several graphic novels in the Sin City series, the first titled "The Hard Goodbye"(Sin City). This tells the story of a tough-as-nails (almost literally) street fighter named Marv (Mickey Rourke) and the only girl who ever loved him, Goldie (Jaime King). While he sleeps, she is murdered. He then goes on a rampage throughout the city and vows to find her killer and get the ultimate revenge.

The second book, "Those Yellow Bastards" follows a retiring cop named Hartigan (Bruce Willis) who trails a sadist (Nick Stahl) who has kidnapped an 11 year old girl named Nancy Callahan. The sadist just happens to be the son of a senator (Powers Boothe). Hartigan is set up by his partner, Bob (Michael Madsen), and years later searches for little Nancy Callahan (Jessica Alba) and tries to protect her once again.

The third and final story, "The Big Fat Kill," follows a group of prostitutes (Rosario Dawson, Devon Aoki, Alexis Bledel, etc.) and their protector, Dwight (Clive Owen) as they go after a cop with violent tendencies (Benicio Del Toro).

'Sin City' is the most stylish and visually stunning film I have ever seen. Every image, every turn around the corner in Sin City is another work of art from the creator of the graphic novels, Frank Miller. About 90% of the movie is in black and white, with exceptions to colors thrown in there such as the color of a woman's eyes, the red or yellow of a person's blood, or the red of a woman's dress. The blood in the movie is white, but at other times can be as red as ever. This film's style doesn't really scream Robert Rodriguez or Quentin Tarantino, it all comes from Miller. If you read the novels, you would know that scene for scene, word for word, this film is spot-on. Tarantino is a special guest director because he directed only one scene in the movie (the scene where Del Toro and Owen are in the car, and Del Toro has a gun stuck in his head). The whole film was shot in front of a green screen and looks highly realistic. The characters actually interact with the set other than work around it like they did with Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow.

Bruce Willis, one of the most underrated actors out there gives another great performance as Hartigan,the last good cop in Basin City. Clive Owen plays Dwight perfectly, and what can I even say about Mickey Rourke as Marv? He was born for this role. He got every step, every word, every movement of Marv down. The narration by the three characters, as well as Josh Hartnett provides a lot to the story and is done very well. Benicio Del Toro plays his role slightly over-the-top, but is loving every minute of it, and so is the audience.

This movie is very violent. The only thing that was toned down from the graphic novels was the nudity. But all the violence, they kept. The film is ferociously funny, and really keeps the ball rolling. Some of the scenes were funnier than films that were actually comedies. 'Sin City' is a classic example of film noir, and one of the greatest too. It goes through all three stories and is very fast paced. The film starts and finishes with Josh Hartnett's hit-man love story, which, I thought was a great way to end a great movie. It's definitely not for everyone, but it's definitely worth a try.

title: Pure Perfection!
review: Before I begin, let me explain my rating system: 1 - Not worth seeing for free, 2 - Worth seeing for free, 3 - Worth paying to see, 4 - Worth paying to see again, 5 - Worth buying. When I first saw this movie, I was not prepared for it. I have never read a Sin City comic, but I knew all about Frank Miller. While I was watching this, there were some parts that were almost shocking (for me) and I thought "this is really dark. No, this is Frank Miller." I had no idea that Sin City was like that. I have to buy the graphic novels now. This movie was FANTASTIC. A comic book movie could not have been done better. I applaud Robert Rodriguez for his efforts, and for standing his ground with the DGA (he got kicked out...again!) I give this movie a 5/5.

title: The best movie i've ever seen
review:
I went to see it thinking it could turn out to be either very good or bad, after what i've heard about it.

I was amazed. I was dumbstruck. I was in love. Excellent cinematography, bedazzling performances (Micket Rourke is great!!), insanely well written script, sick humor (tasty blood - yum yum)!!

From the baas cop to the ugly beast over the dirty whores to the sexy stripper. Sin city is evil, cruel, rips off your flesh. You feel like you're starring in the movie.

Almost too good to be a movie. What more can you ask for?? Not much!!

Can't wait 'till the DVD comes out!!!

title: Sin City's fresh air
review: As most people that have looked forward to going to see this film, i was ready for this breath of fresh air, but upon getting into the cinema i was uncontrollably drawn into this world. One reason for this is the score. Not realising how much it complimented the film until the last story, its presence was just beneath the screen, but potent enough to carry the story. Another reason is the notion to digitally shoot the film in black and white-instead of grey and white, and this film would have been banned (and not as good) if it had been in colour. Although having the easy to grasp plot lines similar to that of Kill Bill volume 1, it still manages to make the viewer watch for any word or movement that could change the story all that more. Choosing 3 stories was a great idea on Rodriquez's's part, as it means that nothing gets boring, and u get an instant idea that this city really does not have a good side (or a day time). One of the most enjoyable revelations looking back is that there were no good guys, not one of them could honestly say they were fighting for the forces of good, yet your always happy when they get their way. Sin City is not a disappointment like most films of its calibre.

title: I thought i reviewed this Gem.. Well I am gonna fix that..
review: Saw this 2 months ago, on my B-day. What a great present. I read all the graphic novels (I think everyone who razz's this movie should do). Having frank Miller doing most of the work, makes this the closest movie adaptation of a comic, the only fault is missing certain parts of the comic, but honestly they were not really needed. Mickey was A-1 choice for Marv, he WAS Marv. Holy cow, magnificent. And Willis was great as Hartigan ( had him down to as well). This is one movie I will Have to get on DVD. I love the whole b&W world, with just the tastes of red, yellow and blue. Magnificent. A must see on DVD if you haven't seen yet. I can not wait for the next installment.

title: Basin City Lives through Sin CIty
review:
The first thing I would like to say is that a goddamn love this movie it's so fresh, original and sexy it completely blew me away. With me been a huge fan of the graphic novels I went in the cinema with a cringe hoping that Rodriguez didn't ruin one of the greatest graphic novels ever, even with Frank Miller co-directing.

But wow, the dialogue is word for word and even the frames are exactly like the comic, even when you go down to little things like lighting and sound. The actors are all chosen perfectly for the film especially, Elijah Wood as Kevin and Bruce Willis as Hartigan, which both shocked me in their performances even though Elijah doesn't say a word in the whole film. The perfect actor cast in this film and who is the heart of the graphic novels is Marv played by Mickey Rouke he surprised me the most because he portrays the character perfectly to the last plaster.

The movie has everything, love, hate, revenge, death, war and some bad-ass action and fighting beautiful brought to life for the screen.

The Three stories the film portrays are The Big Fat Kill, That Yellow Bastard and The Hard Goodbyue which are some interesting stories but can't wait to see if they do Familt Values and A Dame to Kill for.

The world is truly believable even though it is all green screen which makes the movie one of the greatest CGI movies of all time. So, to leave you with a summary it is the best adapted comic book adaptation even better than X-men. The characters are fully rounded and the performances mesmerising. Rodriguez has gained the respect of me and hopefully of you as one of the most imaginative directors in today's cinema.

P.S -- Go see this movie if you don't your dumb.

J.T McGrath

title: A dark, twisted & sick story... I love it!
review:
What a refreshingly good movie. With all the junk we've had to wade through lately it was a relief to finally see an original production with good acting!

The best thing about this movie is the way that it is filmed - it is just so effective and I'm sure it will set a new trend in the way comics are brought to the big screen.

Warning: it can be quite graphic at times but it's so extreme that it is actually quite compelling to watch even if you're a bit squeamish. BTW, Mickey Rourke really steals the show in this one - his acting is awesome.

So if you like extreme gore, action comics, Tarantino-type movies or prostitutes with guns, then go watch this movie! Enjoy!

title: Thoughts on Sin City
review: I thought this movie was an absolute work of art. The black and white gave it an awesome feel and feel that if it was in color it would have taken away from the awesomeness of the film. I saw nothing wrong with the movie at all...not to mention Jessica Alba is smokin. The story was kick a** and the acting was superb. I feel that everyone played their character the way they should have and it was amazing to watch. I do not know many movies that can be so awesome in all aspects from writing to directing to acting. I love Sin City. If for whatever reason you have not seen this movie yet drop what you are doing and go see it right now, trust me it is worth your time.

title: Truly cool
review:
Sin city.

What can a man say? what can anyone say.? I really liked this movie. Sure it was violent but then again this adds to the film and the very essence of the story. This is a SIN CITY for crying out loud, nothing about it is meant to be nice so if you don't like violence don't watch.

When i finished i tried and tried to think of a REALLY bad actor or actress in the movie. Yes it was a 'feast for the eyes' a 'truly masterful visionary piece if mise en scene' bla bla. It entertained me. The city where the sun never shine intrigued me, it kept me interested. So what if the violence is over the top (Marv getting hit THREE times by a car) Who cares? It interested me. Seeing Elijah Wood as a non-hobbity monster cannibal who, may i add, dodges what? Three gun shots with lightning speed! and near on annihilate the mountain that is Marv made me think, 'MAN! Don't fu...i mean, don't mess with hobbits Sauron, now look what you did to him'

A few days before i went to see a movie called ONG BAK. That was really brilliant action so it kind of deadened my senses to the short fight scenes in THIS movie but standing alone from what i saw previously Sin City was brilliant and if you can allow yourself to live like these characters for the Two and an odd minutes it lasts then you will feel the sin seep in.

title: Amazing
review:
Now this had me very gripped from start to finish and i can't believe how enthralled i have become with Frank Miller. Due to the impact of the film I have recently purchased 5 of the "Sin City" books and i can't say that any of them have dropped below standard. I have now seen Sin City 6 times and it still does not bore me, to do this is an absolute treat.

There is not a bad comment I can make: excellent direction from both Rodriguez and Tarantino: excellent cast that could not have been bettered and finally an excellent portrayal of the graphic novels. I was already an avid supporter of Taratino and I even did an English A Level project on his work. His Del Toro and Owen scene was outstanding bringing new heights to the direction. The cast were fantastic and I believe they truly surpassed themselves.

title: Escape To Another Place
review: The strength and power of this movie lie in it's depiction of unreality. A comic book world is perfectly created here along with a comic book atmosphere. Everything here is mega-cool, melodramatic and ultra violent, all with the safe distance of fantasy. The men are blatantly macho with only the evil characters being unnecessarily rough, lacking in a moral motive for their actions. The women are sharp of tongue, tough as nails and sexy as hell! The intermittent use of colour that is used to emphasise or draw attention to something also works well and gives Sin City one of the most original styles seen on screen. Three stories are told here and while they don't really have much to do with each other, bar their setting in Sin City, the movie still fits together. It's probably a little over-long but generally it rolls along well and there's a good few laughs, even if half of them are at some poor stool getting his posterior royally kicked. Well worth seeing but just short of perfect!

title: A Night Time City Full of Gulity Pleasures & the Choice Between Revenge & Redemption
review:
Sin City is a night time city full of guilty pleasures where the people are torn between revenge and redemption. Based off the graphic novels by Frank Miller, Sin City is the best movie I've seen all year, and is the only one that really sticks to the graphic novels. I say graphic novels because there is a difference between graphic novels and comic books. Graphic novels are aimed toward adults, as Sin City should be, comics toward children.

How many of you saw Kill Bill: Volume 1? Do you remember the scene where The Bride is fighting in Japan and the screen suddenly went black and white? That was because Quentin Tarantino was told that the scene was too bloody and it would either have to go to black and white or to be cut altogether. He opted for black and white. If Sin City hadn't been intentionally done in black and white, it would have been forced to be. There is great violence in this movie. People are getting shot or killed with knives and swords or pipes. But it is all, almost, done with a good purpose. You may be startled but you think, "Hey, the guy deserved it." This movie is really three of the graphic novels out into one movie. The Hard Goodbye, The Big Fat Kill, and That Yellow Bastard. These three graphic novels all take place in the fictional town of Basin City, also called Sin City, where you don't know if the cops are clean or dirty, where women walk the streets, the bad guys are as high up as a United States Senator, and where danger is around every corner and there is no place to hide.

The Hard Goodbye tells the tale of Marv. Marv who has never known real love in his entire life until Goldie. Marv only knows Goldie for one night when she is murdered while he sleeps right next to her. It becomes Marv's goal to find Goldie's murderer and make him pay.

The Big Fat Kill is a story about Dwight. Dwight makes his original appearance in book 2, A Dame to Kill For, which is really just background information for book 3. Dwight goes to the part of Sin City known as Old Towne. Old Towne is run by the street walkers, the leader of which was romantically linked to Dwight, and the women have a perilous truce with the police. The girls keep that part in order and keep out the mob, but when something goes horribly wrong and a messy body gets discovered, it's up to Dwight to protect his friends, even if it means killing a whole lot of people.

That Yellow Basard is the account of an aging cop named Hartigan who is an hour away from retiring when he gets a call that an 11-year-old girl has been kidnapped by a lunatic; a loose end that Hartigan hadn't tied up.

All these stories are in the movie and are very clear to follow. They hardly ever overlap. What makes these stories really come to life is the color. The majority of the movie is in black and white. But every now and then you'll see a splash of color. In the opening scene, you see a woman standing on a balcony. Her surroundings are completely black and white, but her dress is a vibrant red. As are her lips. And when her eyes are mentioned, they light up green then fade back to black and white. It is the little surprises of color that makes you not want to take your eyes from the screen. The dialog is just as amazing.

When the characters actually talk or when you hear their thoughts, it is like watching an old 40's movie. One of my favorite lines is right at the beginning and it goes, "The silencer makes a whisper of the gunshot." Nobody talks like that anymore and it makes the movie that much more exciting. The dialog is just so old fashioned that it makes you remember the days of tommy guns and Dick Tracy. A character named Bob is talking to Hartigan and he says, "You're pushing 60, and you've got a bum ticker." It almost makes you giggle, if it weren't for what happens next, but we won't go into that.

This is one of the most gifted casts I've ever seen in one movie. You have Bruce Willis, Clive Owen, Mickey Rourke, Jamie King, Carla Gugino, Jessica Alba, Nick Stahl, Josh Hartnett, Elijah Wood, Benicio Del Toro, Michael Clark Duncan, Rosario Dawson, Michael Madsen, Brittany Murphy, and Alexis Bledel. Not to mention Robert Rodriguez directing with the writer Frank Miller, and Quentin Tarantino directing a scene. This movie is just There are almost no words describing it. You just have to go see it for yourselves. You have to. Your life will not be complete unless you go and see Sin City. I mean it. Now. Go find a car! "A hardtop, with a decent engine, and make sure it's got a big trunk."

title: Just seen it and it rocks!!!
review: Its encouraging to see the directors are allowed to have the courage of their convictions and see through something that they believe in fair play to miramax for letting it happen! Although Rodriguez has some balls, that movie had me wincing and chuckling in the same breath! After seeing many of Rodriguez's movie over the last few years I did have my doubts that he would manage to fulfill such ambition or more so that he had the talent to create something so bold! I must applaud him because that has to be the best comic book to film adaptation I have ever seen! Anybody have any ideas of what's to come next in the sequels is there to be be more marv?

title: Nothing much to say .. just a good movie!
review:
Finally something refreshing again from the USA...

I haven't read the comics before i saw the movie, but must say it was a great movie which was different from the standard stuff coming out of the USA lately.

I think it was also good to see the hand of Quentin Tarantino in this movie, but not sure if i do Robert Rodriguez any shortcomings since i can not remember seeing any movie of him before.

Certainly worth a visit this one, BUT if you don't like violence or 'Noir' style movies i would not recommend this one.

One other thing about this movie is the use of CG. I wonder which is CG because i had the feeling sometimes CG was used but couldn't say for sure. My best guess are the old cars, but they could also be real cars.

title: Comic book adaptation come good
review:
POTENTIAL VERY MINOR SPOILERS The first real comic book adaptation I had the privilege of viewing was the original brilliantly campy Batman ... Adam West with his lawful haircut wore underpants over his tights, zapped, biffed and socked his way out of being boiled alive in giant teacups and treated Robin like he was a little kid. And it really was fantastic!!! Those pows and thwacks may have been a tad crude, but added to those trips up Gotham's skyline and the ridiculous sets and eccentric villains Batman made for an entertaining 25-odd minutes of loose comic book adaptation.

But this is 2005. We've seen varying degrees of success in region of adapting comics since 1966. The earlier Batman's set the bar too high for more recent efforts to reach (eagerly awaiting Batman Begins); Dick Tracy definitely showed some promise and the recent Spiderman's and X-Men (to a lesser extent) movies showed what could really be done by combining modern day technology with genuinely interesting story telling.

First off and most obviously Sin City's striking and innovative use of colour and technology sets it apart from most other films you are likely to have the pleasure to see. In an interview I heard Clive Owen (and he himself knowingly admitted it clichéd) that this is something that is totally new; and the man is right. This film noirish effort is filmed in black and white ... there are no grey areas ... the spilling of scarlet blood or the flash of blue eyes is the closest you'll get to the relief of colour. The scene in which Bruce Willis' character is about to close in on Roark Jr. and he is standing by a massive farm door, particularly struck me, in that it look as if a frame from the comic had been drawn into the film. Another interesting touch is the use of silhouette frames at key points in the film.

Sadly I myself haven't yet read any of Frank Miller's Sin City comics but the inclusion of the author as a co-director (as well as reports I've heard) suggests the film is particularly loyal to the original story lines. Tarantino manages to muscle his way into Miller's vision and is a 'special guest' director for one scene.

The performances of those occupying the corrupt hell hole that this Basin City are very solid to say the least. Mickey Rourke is particularly forcefully as 'psychokiller' Marv, while Alba and Willis stand strong in their story about a weathered cop stabbed in the back for protecting an innocent young girl. Elijah Wood gives an unnerving and totally silent performance as the demented Kevin, a young cannibal. The violence although totally over the top (this is a comic book after all where men can take up to 5 shots and survive) is unrelentingly brutal; scenes involves the male genitalia are very gruesome and had me wincing for a minute. The film itself aside from its obvious quite brilliant and striking presentation is an unrelenting testosterone rush from start to finish. It runs like a film noir with the main characters narrating as woman with near perfect features seem to either end up dead or in the arms of some vengeful do-gooder (or longing for those arms). This is surely reflected in the female cast; as big a fan as I am of Brittany Murphy the prospect of playing a scantily clothed stripper or soon to be dead hooker may not have appealed A-list actresses. I think I must have been joined by have the cinema when a slow sweeping shot of Alba borough an unwitting smile to my face! Sin City is definitely an innovative piece of work from the visual artistic perspective; add to this some quite gripping story lines and you've got something that sees the progress of comic book adaptation in cinema take another step forward.

title: Originality not seen for some time
review: this film is a must see movie, i fail to see who this film wouldn't appeal to. solid acting, great story, original style, truly a classic in the coming years! Robert Rodriguez has created a fully encapsulating environment with his rich visuals creating a real life animated comic book. i would have loved to have seen all the marvel films done in similar styles, I'm sure this would have added to their considerable poor showings in most reviews, the shear quality of the visual adaptation of Frank Millers original story is fantastic. the acting from Elijah Wood, Rosario Dawson (Who is finally breaking through into bigger films, which is far overdue(Awesome actress)) plays the sexy and powerful character of Gail brilliantly, and Mickey Rouke shines as the larger than life Marv. the sequels, pencilled in for 2006 and 08 if they continue with this style will be superb, can't wait to hear more in the future months.need i say more, roll on 2006 and make sure you don't miss this! SEE IT!

title: "There's nothing like having your friends turn up with a whole lot o' guns".
review:
Set in a city where there's no good  just degrees of bad, worse and evil. Where all the men have square jaws, muscles and unstable personality disorders. Where the women are all sexy and dangerous (and invariably wearing very little). Sin City brings to life that seedy underworld forever hinted at in films but never carried off with such enviable style and talent. The exaggerated personalities of every character  all of which have purpose and a place of their own in the film, adds to the spectacle of such aesthetic magnitude that you'll have difficulty taking it all in.

This film is, in short, an instant cult hit. It has the makings of any truly crazy, violent and stylish film  beautiful hookers, twisted cops, cannibals, torture, and some tough thugs who just won't die! You need to see it to believe it, you need to live with the characters in their world and absorb yourself in the atmosphere in the cinema. Go see it  to believe that films this good really do exist. If there is a God  he's sitting up there wearing a black trench coat, listening to Rob Zombie, surrounded by the Dames of Sin City and creating films that are about as subtle as a sledgehammer.

title: A cartoon movie, for good and for bad
review:
I was persuaded to go see the movie because of its good reviews. I expected to be entertained with an action-filled plot.

There was lots of action, lots of blood, lots of stupid cartoonish clichés, ala violence is the only solution to injustice, the ever so corrupt authorities, there is only one purpose with women (and it is not to clean the house or cook), and so on. But there was little plot. The stories are simply too obvious. I found the movie boring, down-right stupid in its wrecked portray of the extremely fictional Basin City, and also a bit disgusting.

I guess the movie is just like the cartons of Frank Miller. If you like those, go see the movie, you will probably enjoy it. The special effects are extraordinary, and the movie feels very much like a live cartoon.

If you, like me, never really enjoyed the Batman movies, I recommend you stay away. Its just too far out.

title: A good Neo Noir... it's been a while.
review:
Although those of you in the States have has Sin City floating around since April, Europe just saw this adaptation of Frank Miller's gritty comic book series hit cinema screens last week. A long awaited film, was it worth it? For starters, it's NOT Film Noir, I'm not gonna go through what makes a film, Film Noir, just know that Sin City is not Film Noir, it is in fact more accurate to call it Neo Noir. That being said, it mimics what made old Film Noir classics like Double Indemnity closely, with a bit more violence, cursing and of course naked women.

What it presents us with is a unique style of film that really you should go and see just for that, it's unique visuals make it worth while. Unfortunately that's it's weakness. Rodriguez was so caught up in transferring Miller's comic to life he left the characters as flat as they were on the pages. With little to no character development you'll either hate the characters or love them.

The script didn't let down, it followed the noir style closely, fast talking and each story narrated by the main character is a typical "detective" way. Again this is a thing you're either going to love or hate. So if you're a fan of Film/Neo Noir then you're going to walk away from Sin City with a little more than enjoyment than most people will.

So, a film you should go and see for the style of it if for nothing else, but worthwhile all in all.

title: I really enjoyed it
review:
I walked into this film not expecting a great deal. Thought it would be another Kill Bill that was all style and no substance. A film that with so many actors vying for decent screen time would dilute a story into a glorified pantomime.

What a great surprise so see a film that is refreshingly adult, cool to look at and has involving stories. I wasn't sure how I would get on with the high contrast comic book look to the film but it actually works. The fact that they set the world, its physics, what does and doesn't work from the beginning means that you have a control for your intelligence to lock onto. For instance someone might get shot 10 times and still be alive which although preposterous to begin with seems normal once you become involved with the film. It also sticks to these guidelines so you don't a get a normal fight one minute and then another where the confines of gravity seem to have been forgotten the next.

It's so good to see a film that isn't afraid to be squarely aimed at adults. Women have sex but then are not unrealistically scrambling for the covers to hide their nakedness, the revenge motives are played through to their natural conclusion without characters going soft and the blood is liberally applied to blows and injuries.

Mickey Rourke is sensational. I never used to like him as he was quite arrogant in his early days but falling on hard times and forced to do 'straight to video' b movies seemed to provide him with some humility and allows me to appreciate his craft even more. His story is the best of the three. Bruce Willis is also on top form and the rest of the cast deliver very good performances. Clive Owen was a little weak, I don't rate him as that accomplished an actor and for me it showed. But this couldn't dampen the creative flair, the depth of story or sheer brutality of the action. There is plenty of female flesh on show (most of it very nice), a smattering of humour where needed, generous amounts of violence delivered with gusto and crunching sound effects and a good score.

Overall I was very impressed. An enjoyable film that was great to look at as well as being involving and rewarding to watch.

title: Top Stuff!
review: I have just left the cinema. I feel a wide range of emotions. All of these emotions, however, are positive. What a film! The best way to describe this film is a black & white meeting between Batman and all Quentin Tarantino films. The way the film is delivered, you really get the feeling that it stays true to the comic book. Most of the graphics are very cartoony and some of the violence is occasionally over-the-top, which is what makes you feel like you're watching a very, very violent comic book come to life. There is an unreal amount of blood. However, the blood doesn't always come out on the screen as red which, in a way, adds to the disturbance. The acting in the film isn't the finest, but it doesn't need to be. The directing is superb and overall I left the cinema feeling like I had witnessed a new era in film.

title: Rightful heir to Dobermann
review:
It was a grey day when I snapped open the lid on my laptop. After chugging back the day's first cup of joe I violently ripped open my pack of cigarettes and popped one in my hard, cruel mouth. The broad upstairs could wait, I had to review Sin City, and fast While surefire hit Sin City is full of hard men and 'easy on the eye' women, it is an ultra-violent world beyond Raymond Chandler-Humphrey Bogart's Fifties era of gumshoes and handguns.

It's mainly black and white spiced up by the occasional inspired flash of colour with the result that every frame of film is an instant slice of breathtaking art.

Sin City, based on the acclaimed comic by Frank Miller, is easily one of the best-looking films of the year but it packs several unexpected punches that will leave you staggering out of the cinema wanting more.

Unlike other comic book adaptations, the film isn't centred on just one character, giving us their background, life and loves, their mum's maiden name, etcera.

For once it makes more sense to have little or no clue as to what is going on. It's enough simply to have these fantastic, ridiculous creations on screen courtesy of Miller and co-director Rodriguez who 'shot and cut' and also scored the film's music.

Set in Basin City, part of Sin City 700 feet below ground level, the film starts off with Hartigan (Willis) on his last day on the job as a cop - ready to go out in a blaze of glory.

With his partner Bob (Madsen) Hartigan tracks down the whereabouts of a little girl, Nancy Callahan (Alba), who has been abducted.

A lone good man in a bad town, Hartigan battles against forced more twisted and powerful than him, coming up against a powerful senator (Boothe, best known for Walter Hill's Southern Comfort) and his son (Stahl).

Meanwhile Marv (Rourke) is wondering who could have killed beautiful blonde Goldie (Jaime King) who lies next to him in bed.

Marv, an indestructible killing machine, has an iron- shaped flat top hairdo and a Kirk Douglas-modelled nose and chin taken to an extreme.

This already odd-looking hoodlum with a hefty heart rounds off his look by appropiating other men's leather coats and having little white plasters all over the cuts on his body from jumping from cars or windows.

The lovable maniac is as determined as Hartigan to uncover the reason for Goldie's death and he starts to make people talk  he calls it "killing my way to the truth" - until a trail leads to Cardinal Roark (Hauer) and creepy killer Kevin (Wood).

All good things come in threes and Clive Owen's Dwight shows up, cut from the same saintly-cum-sinister cloth as Hartigan and Marv.

While Dwight isn't as riveting as his fellow vigilantes he does introduce us to the ladies of Old Town, the prostitutes who patrol their patch.

His old girlfriend Gail (Dawson) joins forces with Dwight when Jackie-Boy (Del Toro) disturbs the peace in Old Town and a whole lot more blood is shed in the name of glorious entertainment.

All this and Irish terrorists, ridiculous quiffs, fantastic lines, a bald Nazi, gold balls for eyes and the scariest silent martial artist cannibal you will have seen.

Sin City is released in a digital print which makes all the dirt and sleaze stand out magnificently and even lets film fans focus on the oddly quivering lips of Josh Hartnett at one point.

Along with Hartnett at the bottom of the talent barrel, Brittany Murphy and Madsen are as crummy as ever but Rourke and Del Toro cancel them out the second they're on screen and the casting as a whole is just right.

A sequel has been announced but, for now, feast your eyes on the rightful heir to A Clockwork Orange, Dobermann and Pulp Fiction. A monstrously good time.

title: no fluffy clouds
review:
If you like graphic novels, larger than life characters, women wearing very little clothing and lots and lots of violence then this is the movie for you.

It's the sort of film the teenage lads at my partners school will absolutely love.

It is incredibly stylish, all black and white except for a few splashes of well chosen colour. I'm a big movie goer and I think it's a must see film ... Although after the first hour or so I'd had just about enough of the violence and wanted to go to a place where there were fluffy clouds, furry bunnies and lots of pink.

title: wow!!!!!
review:
There isn't much to say about this film, because it's so good, that many people have commented it. Although it seems a bit pointless to share my opinion withe the others, I'll do it anyway. Why?

Well, Sin City is one of the best film I've watched (and I've done several times already). Great cast, fantastic atmosphere, quite a plot for a "badass movie". The film is divided into 4 parts - but the 1st and 4th are about the same man, Frank Hartigan (Bruce Willis), who is a hero cop. Standard plot, but nicely done.

The second part is story about revenge. Marv (Mickey Rourke) wants to kill the bastards that assassinated his new girlfriend, Goldie. In my opinion that's the best part of the movie. Rourke plays really tough guy, whose devotion to a girl he's spent only a single night with, is moving. Even bad asses have some feelings!!

The 3rd part is also great. The plot may sound a bit funny, because the main problem is to defend... the whore town!! Clive Owen's performance is great - he is calm but ruthless and Benizio del Toro was even better. You just have to watch it! All of the actors were fantastic, just like the girls, who were beautiful, charming and sometimes mysterious. I only disliked the fact that 99% of them where prostitutes!!!!

Those of film-maniacs who watched "Payback" with Mel Gibson and "Last Man Standing" with Bruce Willis and Christopher Walken have probably spotted that the main character not only acts, but he also "comments" everything and tells the whole story to the watchers. That's really cool effect. The same thing was in "Sin City". Rourke, Willis and Owen are doing outstanding job, their comments are full of emotions (especially anger),passion; the actors are really engaged in all their actions and I really appreciate this. It seems quite obvious that they enjoyed their roles. Pity that the film is about 1:48 long, because if it was longer, we could enjoy more of the characters.

I hope that Mickey Rourke has started a "new era" in his acting career because "Man On fire" (2004) and "Sin city" (2005) are excellent movies and in my opinion we may expect more of Rourke at his best in the future!

Anyway, watch Sin City, because if you don't, you'll miss a great production.............

title: Five Word Review: Beautiful, shocking, witty, sexy, sleazy.
review:
Sin City (2005) Directed by Robert Rodriguez and Frank Miller

So the start of the summer blockbusters is upon us and the season opens with this very bold and exciting movie, Sin City. You've seen the trailers maybe even read the "graphic novels" (that's comics!) that the film is based on but does this visual treat hold up for 2 hours and 8.50 of your hard earn cash? With some critics calling it the new Pulp Fiction (in part due the input of 'Quest Director' Quentin Tarantino), a bar that high is going to be hard to clear but Sin City does it with style and then some.

Based on three graphic novels in the Sin City series by Frank Miller, the film plays out in three separate chapters much like the Pulp Fiction it has been compared to. Each segment is narrated by its central character, Marv (Mickey Rourke), Dwight (Clive Owen) and Hartigan (Bruce Willis), following their story through Basin City (knock off the 'Ba' and what do you get?) as they encounter revenge, violence, sex, drugs, love and hate. Following the film's time line can be tricky on first viewing, however the film will hold up to multiply viewing and a re-watch will prove enjoyable and possibly rewarding as you connect all the characters together to form a much broader picture of Sin City. A violent and unsettling place, Sin City does not shy away from any form of body inflicting damage. Fists, teeth, knives, cars, dogs, razor wire, sledgehammers and rubber tubing are all put to good use in order to torture and kill. Sin City has more than earned its 18's cert and probably would not have passed the Censors where the film not shot in black and white.

And its the black and white "graphic novel" look may very well catch most viewers off guard. Shot in a digital back lot all the actors performed in front of blue screen with all the background added later. While this original look, broken throughout the film only by select and significant splashes of colour, is at first a shock and then a pleasure to watch its impact is soon lost within the first 20mins of viewing. This is however no great loss as the film's great ensemble cast quickly picks up the film and carries it beautifully to the end. A great comeback for Mickey Rourke, and with Bruce Willis only being Bruce Willis for one quick line ("Wait here for me to come back, I'll keep you safe." Very Die Hard!). Notable supporting roles include Brittany Murphy, looks great and proves that her 8 Mile performance wasn't just a once off, and Josh Hartnett for brief but excellent opening and closing of the film.

Overall Sin City is a sick pleasure to watch. A film that must hold the record for "most male genitalia" dismembered, it is bold, inventive, witty and in your face. Director Robert Rodriguez has taken his source material, of which he is a big fan, directly translated it to the screen and created a film that has pleased fans of the comic and is also accessible to the movie watching public. Co-directed with Sin City creator Frank Miller, a 'Guest Director' spot filled by Tarantino and a cast that will make "top 10 ensemble cast" lists for years to come it seems Sin City is set to be an instant hit. Sin City is bold, creative film-making but perhaps not for everyone. With Sin City 2 and 3 due in 2007/2008 is longevity in the public eye is assured but if Sin City will go down in the books, as a classic is a matter only time will tell. Go see it. Go see it again. Then put it on your DVD's to buy list. And let's leave at that for the moment.

Overall: Sin City shocks, titillates and teases. Funny, bloody and visually stunning, it proves itself one the best comic book adaptations of recent times. Even with such a great cast it will still remain to be seen if Sin City can outdo summer heavy hitters such as War of the World, Mr. And Mrs. Smith and Land of the Dead.

Five Word Review: Beautiful, shocking, witty, sexy, sleazy.

title: Oh yes!
review:
Now i may be being a little over excited with the 10/10 but it says excellent next to it and the film was excellent so i feel justified.

Firstly, you have to take this film with a pinch of salt, not only is this film the best film out this year so far but it is also one of the funniest. People say "it's horrific images and it horrifies me that people enjoy them". It's not real! and that's the thing you need to remember he, this film is so violent (i don' think there is a swear word and there's some nudity and it still has a 18 certificate) its funny! The scene where the deformed phsyco-path Marv is driving along whilst grinding a man face into the road is hilarious, it's so ludicrous you can't take it to seriously! As for the effects, well that's genius too! it is the ultimate graphic novel adaptation. Even the rain looks like real comic book rain! I could ramble on about it but allot of the reviews do so i'll just leave you with, u may love it or u may hate it, there probably isn't a half way view. but everyone should watch this film at least once.

title: Flawlessly good.
review:
WOOOOOOOOOOOOWWWW!!! i sat behind a couple who decided to go on a date to see an action packed film, yet at every point when there was violence and believe me there was plenty- ultra violence, they jumped and shrieked. this summarises the film - an extremely harrowing taste of backstreet life in Sin city. Remarkably, the influence of Tarantino can clearly be seen even tho he spent only one day on shoot. So when i'm asked whether or not it was a good film or not, i am unable to express its brilliance. Gritty, Stylish, Gory (weak men steer clear- you'll see!) and an unforgettable cast make this the best film of the decade so far.

Great to see Rourke and Willis back on top form too.

Rob.

title: Dark, Shocking, Intense, and Wonderful
review: Truly the best movie I've seen in years. I had no idea what to expect when I went to see this flick and was very pleasantly surprised. The dark comic book dialog and cinematography is captivating. They weren't afraid to go heavy on blatant comic style violence and sexuality which added much to the feel of the movie. The black and white with color highlights was a very nice touch as well. I haven't been this impressed by the uniqueness and intensity of a movie since Pulp Fiction. It's the kind of movie that makes you react out loud without even knowing that you're doing it. I found myself exclaiming "holy sh#t!" and other various explatives in the theater at several scenes throughout the movie which is out of character for me. Well I don't want to give anything away about the movie so I'll stop at this, you get the idea - this movie gets my highest recommendation. If you don't love this movie, you have no taste.

title: All in Black and white. And some red. Plus a bit of yellow.
review:
From start to finish you are in BaSin City. No explanations, no updates, just the facts. Everything revolves around bringing a recognisable yet outlandish comic noir world to screen - the effects are completely slave to this one master. The format is Pulp Fiction, the violence is Reservoir Dogs, the action is From Dusk Till Dawn. The result is in some ways more satisfying than all of these.

The performances are pitch perfect. The only slightly bum note is Clive Owen, who has a little difficulty with his performance. He doesn't have the background or depth to really pull his character off - too many Brit flicks have tainted his ability to act. Everyone else knows the territory and come off the page without effort.

So pull on your mac, get into your hard top and get some action in Basin City.

title: Masterful and stylish: Modern cinema at it's best.
review:
SIN CITY (2005)

Sin City is a bit like Pulp Fiction fused with Kill Bill and tumbled around for a bit in a comic book universe. It's incredibly stylish for one: it's all in black and white and filmed in a way so that it even feels like you're reading Frank Miller's original graphic novels. Of course, the main question is...

...do they match up to the comics? The answer is yes, definitely. In fact, I may even go as far to say that the movie is better (although some may not agree). Frank's work has always had a different edge to it, and the film captivates that edge to it's peak and broadens our view on the hellish (and masterful) Basin City.

Of course, it's not without it's flaws. A few here and there, but nothing to get too worked up about. I will say though; for somebody who hasn't read the novels, it's a little hard to follow first time through. The acting is superb, especially from Bruce Willis and the beautiful Jessica Alba. Their relationship on-screen seems heartfelt and "meant." The other actors don't sink either: everyone who appears in this movie(and there's a lot, I tell you) puts forth a memorable and well-orientated performance.

Overall, Sin City is probably the greatest comic book to screen adaptation of all time. It's fast, cool, slick and holds true to it's purpose. This will forever remain as one of those "cult" classics that people remember for years to come. Exceptional. (10/10)

title: Miss it at your peril!
review:
Sin City won't be for everyone, no doubt about it. Its far to different to be appreciated by the masses, but if its on your wavelength, prepare to be thrilled!

When the film begins it takes a while to get used to the radical style of film-making on show here, but its not long before you become immersed in the fantastic fantasy noir world that Rodriguez and Miller have created. Never before has a graphic novel been so faithfully and lovingly put on screen, you may find yourself wondering as i did, why can't all comic book movies be made like this?

Visually, Sin City is quite simply awesome. Gorgeous black and white splattered with moments of devastating colour. The action is jaw droppingly executed and is hideously violent with lashings of black humour, witness the scene where the hero has a conversation with a dude who was dispatched in the scene before!

As for the cast, well, what a line up! Its true Mickey Rourke steals the film as Marv, but the rest of the cast are well up to the job, even Clive Owen gives a good performance! And wait till you see Elijah Wood's terrifying incarnation!

Films like this come along all to rarely. Something that dares to be different, and doing it so amazingly well. With the way women are portrayed in the film some may argue its just a male wet fantasy, and they're probably right, but thats all the film is, a fantasy, not to be taken seriously.

But do yourself a favor and visit Sin City. The best time to be had in the cinema this year so far. Cooler than cool!

title: Extraordinary
review: This is by far Rodriguez's best work so far, how he managed to put in all the stories together, of course with the help of Miller, nonetheless this is a great film no matter what people say. To those who are saying that it is to violent, to much sex content, let me say this, that is what our world is coming to so deal with it. This could very well be the future of a major city even a country such as Cuba, note the similarities such as technology, situation and other things like that. However if you 2 dimensional critics get out of your little boxes, you would see that this film is great in its artistic style as well. The camera angles, the effects, the acting every thing is superb. I do not consider this a perfect film, but I do rank it a 10 out of 10, and I do believe future film makers will want to see this film and take many of its contents to use in their own films. I recently read Rodriguez and Miller are already planning what will be Sin City 2 and I cannot wait to see that one and I am sure it will be something artistic as well as innovative.

title: Most stylish film ever?
review: Frank Miller's Sin City is probably one of the best films I've seen this year. In fact probably longer than that. From the offset, the use of colour is perfect. It is filmed to perfection. Many have compared the style of this film to that of Pulp Fiction but I disagree. The only similarity with this other masterpiece is that it moves from story to story. This film depicts three stories in the nightmare that is Sin City. The cast are perfect for their roles, even Elijah Wood surprisingly making a great villain. Having not read the books that this film is based on, the stories themselves are fairly good. However the main drawback of this film is that I didn't feel as attached to the characters as I would have hoped considering what happens. I think this may be to do with the style in which it has been filmed. This will surely be the judge of the film rather than the stories themselves. The use of the colour in particular the contrast between black and white is spectacularly clever and still appropriate. The style of this is consistent from the opening scene to the end credits. This film is well worth a watch. The unique concept that Frank Miller has put across in this film mixed with the cinematography and the cast makes this an amazing film. However, I'm not so sure Sin City 2 or 3 will live up to this.

title: Fantastic!!! Best film I have seen in ages
review: I knew this film would be fantastic just from seeing the list of actors who were going to be in it, and having Robert Rodriguez as director, but nothing could have prepared me for what I have just seen!!! Normally when you expect so much from a film, you end up being disappointed because it rarely, if ever lives up to your expectations, but this one most definitely did! You rarely get to see so many legendary actors all in one film....Benecio Del Toro, Micky Rourke, Bruce Willis, Ellijah Woods, Clive Owen, Rosario Dawson...even some actors who I have never been a fan of in the past, but everyone did an amazing job, and if there were only 2 hours left of my life, I can't think of many better ways to spend them!!! It was great to see an action film with a proper plot line for a change...and an original one at that!!!

title: All I can say is excellent.
review:
This adaptation of Frank Miller's graphic novels completely blew me away when I saw it. I never read any of the comics but the film is a true must-see. An all star cast including Bruce Willis, Mickey Rourke, Clive Owen and many more give excellent performances as the various inhabitants of the vile Basin City.

The stories are not pleasant, but then again it wouldn't be so compelling if they were.
