It's also fun to contemplate which scene Quentin Tarantino directed.

The use of the early, more jumping scenes was ingenious ahead of three longer narratives for initiating the style for people so that certain visuals, cartoonish laws of gravity, glorious costumery, etc didn't distract you in the main sections.

It is also one of those that begs to be seen over and over. It grabs you and doesn't let go almost making it impossible to take everything in. I can't wait to see it again, and own the DVD.

I think it is a film once seen never forgotten and even those who don't appreciate the style I am sure will see its place in history as  groundbreaking new artistry.

I applaud all involved and hope Rodriguez continues to make films this visceral and exciting in the future.

title: Gorgeous Film
review:
With "Sin City," I didn't know anything about it. A friend of mine who's obsessed with Elijah Wood wanted to go see it. I told her I'd go see it with her, but I had no opinion about it either way. Then I saw a preview. Realized I *had* to go see this film, if no other reason than the beautiful cinematography. Well, I finally saw it. I loved this film.

The cinematography was even more amazing than I thought it was going to be. I loved the use of the black-and-white. We just don't see enough of those anymore, and for a genre like film noir, black-and-white works well. However, it was taken a step further by the use of color in certain places, like Goldie's hair color, Dwight's car, the blood on Marv's face. These heightened the surrealness of the movie, along with the almost cartoonish look, like the first time Kevin's on the screen or Marv's bandages. This movie is stellar example of awesome cinematography! But that's not the only great thing...the music was perfect. Within the first minute or so of the opening credits, I knew I had to buy the soundtrack. The music perfectly accentuated the movie, which is what good scores are supposed to do.

I thought the acting in this movie was incredible. All of the actors did a great job in connecting with one another for each scene they were in. It wasn't so far over the top that it got annoying. One small thing was the way all the guys had that gruff, smoking-for-their-lives way of talking, but since that's common in film noir, it worked. Also, the voice-overs could be annoying for some. They didn't bother me, since I realized those, too, are common in film noir, and there were three different stories in this film.

The fight scenes were cool. I really liked watching Marv fight. While they're a little over-the-top, I was okay with it.

All in all, I just loved this film. I thought it was supremely awesome, and I'm planning on buying it once it's out.

title: Promise made, Promise kept
review: Sin City is one of my most expected movies in this year. I've read the Comics and after seeing the film I couldn't find much difference between the film and the Comics. The Colors, the Camera-settings, all is taken straightly from the Comics! Only one or two scenes were dropped in the film, but that doesn't matter! Sin City has gratefully reached the goal of making, and holding up this dark (and violent) Sin City-atmosphere, by using the b/w-Style (with some colors in it) and filling in this hammer of a Soundtrack! Apart from that, the cast couldn't be chosen better, all the Characters seem to be copied right out of the Comics. And at least to confirm: This really is the best and similar-est Comic-adaption I've seen! Finally I can say: This is Robert Rodriguez' best film ever made!

title: Gritty, Dark, Violent, and Amazing!
review: I'll admit that going into this film I had no idea what I was about to see. I had never read or even see a copy of the books but I had heard excellent word of mouth about the film and opted to see it. I was surprised. This film blew me away. The action and the story were amazing. The characters were portrayed to perfection and you really begin to like them, whether or not you agree with what they are doing. The violence is great but it sets the mood for the story. The film has to be one of the better movie to come out of Hollywood in the past 10 years. It was great and I recommend it to anyone who loves a good action movie with a good storyline.

title: good individual stories but ...
review:
I finally got to watch Sin City last weekend. Let me tell you. i was so excited. The movie posters and trailers really hyped me up with the cell shading style of the movie. Rodriguez and Miller has seamlessly blended the art of comic shaded style imagery with live action perfectly. The CG backdrop was awesome! So awesome that it made Jude Law's Sky Captain flick looked like child's play. However, as much as i loved the well crafted images and narrative story telling, i was shunned by the fact that it tells three stories one after another.

The most striking thing that you see in this movie is the dark sense of the movie. Rodriguez and Miller cleverly mixed dark colors like Black and White and Grey with just a few notable bright colors like the bright gold color of Goldie's hair or the bright yellow for Yellow Bastard. The individual noir style script for each stories is so well written that it blends well with the dark ambiance of the Sin City feel. Add to that the comic style shading and camera pans, and you got yourself a true unique cinema masterpiece.

On the down side, (now, I do realize that this is a retelling of 3 different books) and don't get me wrong either, it is a film that consist of three different stories. Each story was so well made that it kept you to the edge to your seat each time. But, hey i am a writer my self and my believe is that you need just one really good climax to a good movie and it is for a good reason. I was so excited on the first chapter about Marv but then it ends so quickly and suddenly it moved to another different story about Dwight and after that we are taken back in time for the Hartigan story and we get to see Marv again putting up a cameo in a bar. Each story moves too fast for me to feel any empathy for each character and as a story ends you find yourself trying to sympathize with a set of different characters. In my opinion Marv's story was the best and unfortunately it was the first story in the film. I am not saying that the two other stories were bad but it fell short of my expectation and to my dismay it got me disinterested.

In the end, i will have to commend Robert Rodriguez for pulling such an ambitious project. It is the most impressive comic stylized movie i've seen so far. Although i won't be back to watch it in the theater again, i will be sure to pick up a DVD copy. Like i said I love the first chapter but i'll skip the last two.

title: A certified hit
review: To be honest I went to see Sin City almost completely in the dark on what to expect... I did a little research into the comics on line but there is only so much you can get that way. If you go to this movie expecting to see campy or tongue in cheek stuff like some comic book to screen adaptations give us you will probably be disappointed and even shocked by the dark vision that unfolds on screen. There is no hero in tights here to save everyone from the evil villain. No one in Sin City is an innocent but the anti-heroes we watch administering their own brand of justice provide some of the best action and drama I've seen on screen in a while. The film integrates black and white live action with a touch of animation and hits home on every level. Its one surprise after another right to the very end (if you haven't read the graphic novels) and I enjoyed every twist and turn

title: Sin City a grand tour de force of violence and mayhem..and great viewing.
review:
I should preface that I love film moire and this genre. So, when I saw it the other day I was really struck by Mickey Roarke's performance. He played one mean s.o.b. and when he promised toughness, he delivered with style. If ever a movie role was specifically geared for an individual Marv = Mickey Roarke were born to play each other. The movie, itself, was fast paced and action packed. There were some nice performances turned in by Bruce Willis, Rosario Dawson, Michael Madsen, Brittany Murphy, Benedicio del Toro, Nick Stahl and Jessica Alba...who is one sensual young woman.

The story involves a couple cops trying to stop a serial child rapist and murderer, who happens to be the Senator's son. The Senator is brother of the real crime lord of Sin City...the Catholic bishop who has his fingers and tongue on all things evil in Sin City. This crime lord..literally, is played by the venerable Rutger Hauer whose pet friend is the mute Elijah Wood...Frodo freaks out in this movie and plays this bizarre, mute killer that cooks his victims and shares his meals with Rutger...

There is definitely a battle between evil and eviler in this movie. The protagonists all have their flaws but they all have character and all take turns shining in this unusual movie.

I gave it a strong 8 stars and definitely worth seeing but NOT with the little kiddies or the squeamish...enjoy

title: Beautiful
review: I have to admit, when I first saw the poster of Jessica Alba about 5 months ago I wasn't as excited about this movie as the teenage guys working at the movie theater. Curiosity is the reason I went to see it. I must say this movie was beautiful-not the violence in it, but the brilliant splashes of color and interesting dialog. From the moment the movie began, I couldn't take my eyes away from the screen. The music made my heart pound as well as the random silhouettes throughout the movie. A few parts made my stomach turn, but overall I think that I did pretty well for 20 year old Fine Art Major. I recommend this movie to anyone but my parents! This movie took my breath away and left me quoting characters like Hartigan and Dwight. Give it a chance, I feel it's worth the money and time.

title: Natural Black & White Killers
review:
For Joe Schmo Viewer: Boy, this is silly, nonsensically violent (numerous people are borderline invincible), and hilarious in a grim way. It is also the best eye candy anyone who likes black and white images could ever dream of. If you don't like random religious bashing, seeing what has to be hundreds of people dying, mild cop bashing, and a few bits of female nudity, I recommend this heartily. (I can't wait to see it again, personally) For Noir Nerds: This movie is clearly modeled after INDIANA JONES: it's nostalgic, it shows the traditional Hollywood feature of having many disposable characters, which is a shame. Rodrigeuz and Tarantino did much better with El Mariachi and Pulp Fiction/Reservoir Dogs: those are smaller, more intimate stories with characters you connect with a bit more. Here, villains are set up only sothat they can be taken down in short order by sexy "heros/anitheros" who defy deaths better than Batman.

Still... well, damn it, I LIKE LOOKING AT IT! Even if the sound was off, this would be an enjoyable movie for me. A non-pc one to be sure, but enjoyable as hell. (Despite all the "nudity" stuff you hear, there's no full frontal stuff, which rendered the whole thing in my mind to be no worse than a trip to the beach.) I don't really think the movie degrades women any worse than Disney nonsense which portrays them as being obsessed with material goods or shallow as Satan: at least the women here have goals in life you can get behind.

There was some great lost potential here: too much time is spent showing the heros flashing their guns and such things: a lot better would have to show the politics behind their framings a bit better, or the female psychology of being sexually abused (as happens constantly) This movie has too much testosterone, I think that summarizes its problems.

Plus, what the hell was with the swastika? I recommend it to nerds, people who like black and white, horny teenagers, dirty old men, and people who fastforward to the good parts of anything.

title: Booze, Broads, and Bullets easily sum up the beauty of Sin City
review:
Sin City deserves a ten for it's look alone. It did what Sky Captain was supposed to do and made Digital Filming look better than anything ever seen by movie-goers. But, despite its visual beauty, Sin City's highest point comes from the one thing that is really on the set, the actors.

Without a doubt, the Best Acting all year goes to Mickey Rourke, who is brutish, tormented, and insane, and makes it look so damn good. He portrayed Marv better than Jamie Foxx portrayed Ray. Bruce Willis, while not the perfect look for Hartigan, but earns his acting chops after the dismal yet extremely different Whole Ten Yards character. Clive Owen was truly marvelous as Dwight and showed great versatility by dropping his heavy British accent. But however good the good guys are, you know it's cooler to be a bad ass bad guy. Elijah Wood will scare you to hell and back (pun intended) with his beyond creepy smile and stare. Nick Stahl is great as always as the crazed pedophile we all know and love, and Benicio Del Toro, whose character is drunk in every scene he is in, highlights the baddie section with another mind-blowing performance that blows the barrel right off the gun.

Robert Rodriguez has nearly kissed his chance of an Oscar goodbye after he quit the D.G.A. to do this film with Frank Miller, and all who see this piece of art should thank him for the sacrifice he made to bring us this truly remarkable film.

title: Don't be fooled by hype and surface.
review:
A great style study, wonderful techniques, serious effort by many artists (even by many stylistically challenged actors) but ultimately empty film. See it, be very entertained (or offended), and leave forgetting it. Unfortunately so much of our cultural life is empty or lacking that many will be fooled merely by 'hipness' and style. It may be instructive to compare this to the excellent Spiderman 2, the failed Daredevil, the first Batman, etc...

I don't mind studies in style and often very much enjoy them as I did this film. But especially in our cultural desert and already demeaning society and Bush-league cruel world, I mind that it is given so much weight and meaning when it has none or merely has such celebration of cynical, superficial, negative, sometimes cruel perspectives.

title: Great visual appeal, but lacks story
review:
This movie has more hype than it merits. First the positives. The cinematography was amazing. The black and white with the splashes of color were great, and the green screen effects were cool. The display of neon-white blood was innovative. The women were beautiful (although the girl I went with commented on how the movie's vixens created a gender bias.)

HOWEVER, the movie lacked a real story line. The story of Sin City was actually three stories that somewhat overlapped. The stories alone, as a thirty minute episode, would have been cool, but they could not succeed all together. They were too similar. At one point, I thought that it was possible that Willis's character would end up being Marv. In reality, it was just a typical role that a few of the characters shared.

At no point was a surprised or shocked by a plot twist. There was potential to really tie the three main characters together, but it never happened.

I left the theater impressed by visuals, but disappointed overall by the movie as a whole.

title: Great Pulp Entertainment
review:
Just saw this movie yesterday and I must say it's one of the best movies I've ever seen. The way it's done (I'm sure you all know about the B&W with bits of color) was done more selectively then I thought it'd be. I really marveled at how they used color in some scenes. It was brilliant. The three stories were all very compelling and well done. The acting was a bit cheesy but that makes the movie better because it's supposed to be. It's one of those movies that, as you're watching it, you're aware you're viewing something special. I can't wait to buy this on DVD.

Oh and as for the Rating: It's got a lot of breasts in the beginning, a few shots of sex, barely any profanity and a ton of violence and blood. It's done like "Kill Bill" though so the blood is usually in white making it not so nasty.

title: Enthralling Pulpy Noirish Comic Picture Show
review:
I was never a fan of comic books, and an even lesser fan of comic book movies. With "Sin City" (oddly probably the most faithful comic book movie ever in that it adapts film to a comic book level instead of adapting a comic book to film), however, I was completely entranced. I credit the aesthetics. Whether it's the stark black and white cinematography (speckled with bright color in all the right places), or the antiquated and noirish set designs, or the clever and amusing use of make-up (especially for Mickey Rourke's lovable thug "Marv"), or the over-abundance of gorgeous women beautifully photographed in all stages of dress and undress, there is always something to look at here. And it was my busy eyes that got me totally caught up in this beguiling world of violence, sex, revenge, dames, shady heroes, corrupt cops, slimy politicians, good-hearted whores, and more castrations and beheadings than any other film in history created by Frank Miller and Robert Rodriguez (a director who knows not the mantra of a good editor that I never really cared for).

Ultimately, with its roundabout episodic plot line reminiscent of "Pulp Fiction", the stories really amount to nothing much, but that's just fine because the blazingly original visuals give your mind more than enough to chew on. While you may not think much about the plot or characters, you'll never forget the images, and this is the true testament of a good film. Yes, a great film would have an enthralling story, too, but when it comes to the lowest base of story-telling represented by comic books and their filmed counterparts, you're not going to get any better than "Sin City." Bravo, they've made every comic book film that has come before it and every one that will undoubtedly and unfortunately come after it, a moot point.

title: Graphic Violence, Nudity, Sex, and Blood. Dude I'm in!
review: Sin City is one of the coolest movies I've seen in the last few years and although not perfect it holds up with Reservoir Dogs, Kill Bill, and even Pulp Fiction on violence and coolness. The film involves three stories, first about a man after revenge because a hooker named named Goldie gave him the night of his life is killed sleeping right next to him is killed, number 2 is about a man who goes after a bad dude but the dude ends up being a cop and unfortunately he finds this out after he kills him so they go on a pretty crazy ride to try and hide the body, and the third about a cop blamed for a crime against a little girl that a senator's son actually committed so he goes to jail and after 8 years he confesses falser to the crime and goes on parole while on parole he finds the little girl is tracked by the senators son almost killed by the son twice and has to save the girls life again. Mickey Rourke gives the best performance of the three lead actors Mickey, Bruce Willis, and Clive Owen. Mickey is certainly in the most violent of all of the stories. In his story you see a man get eaten by his own dog after having his legs and arms chopped off, a bunch of guys get cut up with an Axe, a lot of shooting and people getting shot, the main character get his face beaten to a pulp twice, and many other scenes of torcher one involving a mans face being ripped off on the pavement of the street, oh yeah and did I mention the electrocution chair scene and the sex scene and the other scene where you see the mom from spy kids prance around nude. Clive Owen's story I thought was the best, and the most intense but the least realistic. Most of the blood in this chapter is white due to the fact that if it was red this movie would've been a no brainer NC-17. You see a few decapitations and partial decapitations, many dismemberment's, a lot of shooting including head shots, many deaths by stabbing and a lot of arrows are shot bye the deadliest character in the movie named Miho. Bruce Willis' story is the darkest of them all. To explain how I described this story earlier in a more formal fashion I will tell you it once more in a clearer way. Bruce Willis plays a clean cop who saves a little girl named Nancy and shoots the man who kidnapped her (the senators son) arm off, penis off, and ear off. But in the process he is shot 10 or more times by the son and by his own partner. He is sent to jail and the little girl writes him once a week for 8 years. But one day he doesn't get a letter. He doesn't get any letters for 2 months until he gets a letter with a finger in it. He confesses to get out of jail to know for sure what happened to Nancy. He finds her as a stripper at a bar but he is tracked by the senators son who is now yellow which is explained in the film. The son kidnaps Nancy again and attempts to hang Willis. Willis breaks free and goes to save Nancy. The story unfolds violently and at the end grossly. In this story you see a few stabbings many shootings, a man gets his you know what shot and ripped off (real nasty), and a man is almost hung and there are a few scenes of people getting beat up badly. Sin City overall is awesome and very very violent in many ways. Its fun to see with friends but don't see it on a date. Peace Out Antichessclub5423

title: You'll either love it or hate it, and I loved it
review:
This is a love it or hate it type movie. If you have a strong hatred towards comic books or can't take strong violence, this movie is not for you. If you don't fall into either of those categories then by all means, see this movie! First, let's look at the obvious factor that made it great, the way it was filmed. The black and white with splashes of colour looked absolutely amazing and had me in awe. The acting was absolutely phenomenal as well, but that is to be expected with such a great cast. This film was also very original which is hard to find these days.

Now let's look at what has been the main criticism towards the film, the violence. Honestly, if by now you're seeing this movie and our posting on this board afterwards then you've probably seen the other reviews saying how violent it is. It shouldn't come as surprise to anyone who reads the reviews here just how violent it is. So take this review as one of the many warnings, IF YOU CAN'T STOMACH EXTREMELY GRAPHIC CONTENT, THEN BY ALL MEANS, AVOID THIS FILM. If you can however stomach it then this is a must see. That being said however, a lot of the violence is styalized and does not look real.

If you want to see your everyday summer movie then this is not what you're looking for. But if you want to see something original and all out spectacular, then don't waste another second. Leave your computer now and go to the movie theatre.

title: Too much or not enough?
review: I was very excited when I heard a movie written by one of the greats was going to be created. The movie in my opinion was very well written with one exception: there were too many story lines in one movie. It started with the story of one character and then developed into at least three more stories with the people the first character came into contact with in the first story. An interesting concept, however, it made the movie a little hard to follow. I did not understand the movie completely until my awed mind sorted through all the facts about an hour after I was already out of the movie theater. Other than that the cinematic views and storyline were superb. This is definitely a movie to watch again.

title: Overall great movie. For people a little off in the head :)
review: This film was shot perfectly. The story line was that of a comic,if you didn't like it your just not twisted enough from the news media. The story of over whelming evil crushing the life out of the city, and a handful of near unrelated events starts to break this crushing fist. This is a comic book people, okay graphic novel for the hard liners, but research your movies before going to see them. This is an ADULT film. It is rated R for a good reason. If you are offended easily DO NOT see this film. If you are a typical callous American, you will throughly enjoy this film. One thing you must understand about this movie is that every character in this film, was or is insane to some degree or another. You would simply have to be to live in a fictional city as repulsive as this.

title: Quite Simply... Awesome
review:
Where do I begin? Being a big fan of the comic-to-screen genre of movie, I couldn't wait to see this - and I certainly wasn't disappointed.

Take the better bits of flicks like Creepshow, The Maltese Falcon and Casablanca, combine it with the viscera and energy of Pulp Fiction, throw in some sensational performances (notably by Mickey Rourke and Elijah Wood), dowse heavily with simply stunning special effects, crank up the tension and atmospherics to eleven - and you have before you the beautiful-ugly that is Sin City.

Don't be put off by the fact that this movie is in black & white, or that it lends itself to the film-noir genre - its fast, furious and bloody good fun.

Quite simply... awesome. Expect to see this nominated for a couple of Oscars at next years Award Ceremony. Certainly the best movie I've seen so far this year, and arguably one of the finest movies ever made - and I don't sling praise like that around readily. Make a date, and go spend a couple of hours with Marv and the boys - you wont regret it.

9.3 out of 10

title: THIS is how to make a "stylistic" film!
review:
I was not incredibly enthusiastic about seeing "Sin City". Lately there have been so many horrible films based solely around art direction ("Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow" is the first one that comes to mind). Plot, characters, drama, tension, excitement, humor; all of these become lost when a film is based around a "look". Even some of those vaunted "film noir" films of the past ... well, frankly they suck. Bad acting, lame plots. I never saw what the interest was in them. They may have been fine for their time, but now they are just patently uninteresting.

I was very pleasantly surprised to see that "Sin City" is not one of those films.

This film has excitement; it has tension; it has very interesting characters; it has funny dialogue at times. In short, this is a fun (but violent) trip through a graphic novel.

Benicio Del Torro is an absolute hoot. Elijah Wood is an amazingly believable (and creepy) assassin. Bruce Willis is great ballsy cop on the edge of retirement. And the women! Wow, are they hot! I've always been big on Rosario Dawson, but ... wow! So many cast members are excellent in their roles, and they play it over-the-top like the characters they portray.

This is not a film for the kiddies, it is very violent, even gory at times. So it's clearly not for everyone. But if you like watching movies with a very dark edge, this is for you.

This is also a film based on 3-4 different story lines (like Pulp Fiction). Not everyone likes that, either, so if you like linear storytelling this isn't for you.

I do have to take off a few points here and there. Clive Owen's performance was pretty lackluster. And the edits between the various stories were too short, it ended up not flowing too well together at times.

But overall a good flick. 9 out of 10.

Barky

title: outstanding
review: I thoroughly enjoyed the movie. There were great one-liners, funny shooting scenes, good action scenes, hot women, and bad guys you love to hate. I left the theater with a renewed sense of hope for Hollywood movies. One of my favorite lines was "...like a palsy victim performing brain surgery with a pipe wrench." I haven't read the graphic novel yet, but want to now. Micky Rourke played my favorite character Marv. He had the best action scenes. Elijah Wood was the most disturbing. Good thing he likes wolves! Jessica Alba is drop dead gorgeous. Quinton Tarantino is a guest director so if you have seen his movies and love 'em...you will not be disappointed by this movie either.

title: Very in-your-face action!!
review: By far, this is probably one of the best movies I have seen since "Gladiator" because even the smallest aspect of this movie is incredible. The characters really pull you in and make you truly involved with the movie. When I watched this movie a week and a day after it came out, I regret not seeing it on opening night! This movie is absolutely incredible. I am a huge fan of the film-noir style films and the darker sides of life and all of the characters electrified the movie, even the smallest roles (ie: Elijah Wood's "Kevin" character. I still have nightmares about that guy!). I find myself talking to my friends who have seen this movie and say, "Which story was your favorite?!" and most say that it is either Marv or Hartigan's story. Personally, I find Hartigan's story more personal and in-depth. It was sad how after saving Nancy, he had to spend 8 years in jail and ruin his reputation in order to protect her. I was happy to see that they reunited and defeated Yellow Bastard (who was absolutely DISTURBING! Bravo Nick Stahl!). I love Bruce's soliloquy's (spelling?) and how he would always encourage himself to fight on despite his age and heart condition. Definite courage to be admired. If such a thing were possible, every character should deserve an Oscar for that movie! I suggest that everyone sees this movie as soon as possible! After reading this, get some buddies together and hit this movie up! I guarantee you will not be disappointed! :)

title: Sin City is utterly amazing
review:
"Walk down the right back alley in Sin City and you can find anything." These are the brick-breaking words that kick off The Hard Goodbye, the first of three dark tales that make up Sin City, the latest outing from legendary director Robert Rodriguez, based upon the graphic novels by Frank Miller, who also serves as co-director. What is truly remarkable about this quote, though, is what the audience finds. Amidst the shadowy underworld of crooked cops, vigilante hookers and twisted murderers where Sin City takes place, a great film can be found, one that is visually astonishing, brazenly acted, gloriously directed and totally original.

The film, which combines three of Miller's books (The Hard Goodbye, The Big Fat Kill and That Yellow Bastard), is actually an elaborate conglomeration of multiple stories, all about one story. Through the eyes of several extraordinary characters, ranging from the innocent and tormented to the deranged and sadistic, the audience is plunged into a seamy world where the bad go badder and the good go bad-ass.

The three stories follow three disparate men, each on a quest for retribution, redemption, or a little bit of both. Marv (Mickey Rourke), a hulking lug of a guy with a short temper and an even shorter attention span, is on the run from the law after being framed for the murder of Goldie (Jaime King), a beautiful prostitute he falls in love with after one night. Dwight (Clive Owen), a reformed killer with everything to prove and even more to lose, is on a mission to save the sultry and sexy girls of Old Town, Sin City's hooker point, particularly his ex-flame, Gail (Rosario Dawson), from Manute (Michael Clarke Duncan), a ruthless and evil dictator, after an incident with a sex-craved maniac named Jackie Boy (Benicio Del Toro) sparks an all-out war. John Hartigan (Bruce Willis), a seasoned cop, beaten down by a bum ticker and thoughts of retirement, is hot on the trail of Junior (Nick Stahl), a fluorescent-colored freak-show of a pedophile, who is out to get revenge on Hartigan by murdering Nancy Callahan (Jessica Alba), a girl Hartigan saved from Junior eight years earlier. The film also features a short segment entitled The Customer is Always Right, featuring Josh Hartnett and Marley Shelton.

What is utterly outstanding about the film itself is its absolute devotion to its source material. Rodriguez has not so much created an adaptation of Frank Miller's bookssuch as Sam Raimi has done with Spider Man and Guillermo Del Toro has done with Hellboybut has fashioned a literal translation: What you see in the comics is what you see on the screen. Each and every panel in the book serves as a storyboard for each and every frame in the film. Even the coloring of the booksa desolate landscape of black and white that is enhanced with light patches of color here and thereis accurately displayed, from the emerald blue eyes of Alexis Bledel's stunning Becky, to the grimy yellow skin of Nick Stahl's "Yellow Bastard", as well as the gallons of red blood that pump out of the characters at, seemingly, every moment of the film. It is a huge undertaking that, at first, seems gimmicky, but quickly surpasses the "Ooh-ah" factor and lures the audience into a story that is equally fascinating and compelling. In order to achieve this feat, Rodriguez shot the entire movie against green-screen with only the actors in the foreground, which allowed him to add the props, backgrounds and color effects in post-production. This all-the-more enhances the dramatic and emotional aspects of the books, because it allows the performances and Miller's gripping narrative to come first. All-in-all, this is film noir at its gritty and gory best.

Of the three main performances, Clive Owen's is the most resounding. His portrayal of an honest man with a shady past, desperately struggling to reclaim his existence by doing the right thing, rings true for anyone who has ever tried to fight back. Mickey Rourke gives a bravura performanceand makes a well-deserved comebackas Marv, and is able to bring an inner turmoil that inspires sympathy and remorse to an otherwise big and bad lout of a character. Bruce Willis turns in another knockout performance as Hartigan, a man who battles whatever evil lurks about and wrestles to make the neighborhood a better place, despite the fact that his body is telling him to turn in and clock out. The lovely ladies of Sin City also give impressive performances. Jessica Alba becomes the graceful and child-like epitome of every man's dream as Nancy. Rosario Dawson makes Gail a tough-as-nails force to be reckoned with, finally shaking the role of "the girlfriend". Though her role as Goldie is short-lived, Jaime King gives the audience a lasting impression as a woman trying desperately to find love and re-birth in the face of her occupation (Watch for the moment where she is reunited with Marv in the form of her twin sisterit's enough to bring tears to your eyes).

It is easy for the audience to wonder what the point of Sin City is. Is it purely for them to watch in wide-eyed amazement at the look of something that has never been seen before? Is it merely for them to be drawn into a seedy world that could possibly serve as a model for modern society? Or perhaps it is simply to exist as the greatest comic-book-turned-movie ever made. The point is this: There is no justice without sin. Through Sin City and its inhabitants, the audience is forced to confront their own demons and face their worst fears of vice, lust and loneliness. It is a point that scars with brutal poignancy and resonates with raw veracity. Despite the roughness and the violence, Sin City is a righteous film, and it wouldn't have it any other way.

title: Nasty violence, with a 'cool' look
review:
Robert Rodriguez's 'Sin City' (for which he gives graphic novelist Mark Miller co-director credit) is a beautiful, stylish, and ingenious adaptation, but even for a filmed comic book it's violent to the point of being brain-dead. One thinks longingly of the pleasing teenage romantic darkness of that brooding revenge fantasy, 'The Crow,' both Alex Proyas' version and Tim Pope's sequel. There's revenge in both, but 'Sin City's' revenge is so heavily laced with confused morality that it gives no satisfaction. If you want ingenious ultra-violence, try Kubrick's 'Clockwork Orange', where the violence is saved up and released so that it has a shocking elegance and a punch. If you want teenage adventure with the same look (at a time when such techniques seemed fresh and new) -- stylized black and white with touches of color -- try Coppola's 'Rumble Fish.' Despite its nice look and its heavy overproduction using all the latest technical tricks, Sin City pales in comparison with all these.

In fact the only movies 'Sin City' stands up well against, ultimately, are Rodriguez's other ones. This is his most complex and probably his best effort: here, he has bolstered his usually thin content by slavishly following Miller's cartoon books and linking up three of them so we've got a little cluster of characters and stories, although whether the stories are really interwoven or just stuck together is sometimes hard to say. Little is discernably added to the stories by Rodriguez; at times he follows dialogue and image as if the books were his storyboards. The effect is of a waxworks rather than a new permutation.

A comic book/graphic novel is one thing and a movie is another. This distinction seems to be more and more lost. But on the one hand, you can have an effect like the Superman, Batman, or Spiderman movies, where the cartoon images are fleshed out with (at best) good, live actors and special effects. On the other hand, you have a movie that becomes a comic strip, like Richard Linklater's marvelous, twittering, 'Waking Life.' Any imaginative animation may have this quality, though digital animation, with its glossy roundness, loses the pleasing flatness of real cartoons, which are hollow and two dimensional, and either made out of black lines or filled in with flat Ben Day dot color. ('Waking Life' has the quality of hand drawing in every frame, because Bob Sabiston designed all the images that way.) 'Sin City' exists in neither world but rather in some Neverland where the actors are made to seem unreal with prosthetics and costumes and CGI but the drawn quality also has been lost.

Part of the "fun" of the rather joyless horror fest that Sin City becomes when fleshed out as a movie, as opposed to the stylized and stylish black and white images of Miller's books, with their dry, artificial quality (in the books, there's plenty of white; in the movie, the prevailing color is a gloppy gray, characteristic of a very different kind of comic book drawing), is spotting the various well known actors. Typically, Bruce Willis (Hartigan) looks just like Bruce Willis (has he ever donned any disguise other than a small hairpiece?). Clive Owen as Dwight looks like Clive Owen too, only more handsome, and also sadly more ordinary without his English accent. It may take you a while to recognize Benicio del Toro in the very evil Jackie Boy, and he hardly has the lazy, teasing speech mannerisms of del Toro: but is that an improvement? Are these actors making comic book characters larger than life, or are they just disappearing into them? Unlike these is the Yellow Bastard, the final evil manifestation of the evil politician's depraved son (played by Nick Stahl, who always looks sallow and nasty), because he looks like the Golem--an animatron with a yellow head. Perhaps the only actor who really rises to the occasion is Mickey Rourke, who's no stranger to deep cover as an actor and whose pugilistically battered face has been completely made over.

But what are all these people doing? I'd really rather not say, if you don't mind. Probably when I was twelve I would have loved this movie. One of my favorite things to watch in movies back then was torture, smashed thumbs, eyes gouged out, bodies broken on the rack: I loved all that, because it meant nothing to me; it wasn't real. Now I know that this kind of stuff really happens all the time, and I don't want to see it. But this is a movie for boys, because here, again, as for me at twelve, none of it means anything; none of it is real. There's some pain over a little girl who is threatened with nastiness, but for the rest whether a guy has a hammer in his back or a knife sticking out of his brow matters not at all.

The girls are the best part, for sure. They're as tough and macho as the guys, and a lot better looking. But whether a whore in skimpy leather packing heat is an example of woman's liberation is not something worth debating. Cool? Yes, very cool, if you're fifteen, or forty-five going on twelve.

As has been pointed out, Rodriguez's literal reconstitution of these graphic novels is hardly as original as the graphic novels themselves, despite the technical innovations, and those novels themselves had less originality than the film noir they grew out of. The images of 'Sin City' remain striking and often beautiful, but I think there are in fact certain key elements in Miller's drawings that Rodriguez has failed to capture. He has used too many closeups and not enough of those wonderful distant, sharply angular images so typical of comic book vision. Did those themselves grow out of the work of people like Greg Toland, Orson Welles' cameraman for 'Citizen Kane'? Probably.

title: Pointless movie.
review:
Sin City the movie stayed aesthetically true to Sin City the comic book. It makes a great comic book, but it made a pretty bad movie.

You realise that Sin City should never have been a movie when you think of the millions of dollars that would've been poured into a movie like this. It's like spending a million bucks on paints to recreate in exact detail the view of your wall with the Picasso painting on it. The movie was a big parody of film noir movies.

Maybe they should pour all that money into an original movie.

I'm being told by this site that I can't post this review until I add a few more lines, so I will warn anyone that is squeamish and plans on seeing this movie, or letting their friends drag them to it.. this movie is not for the squeamish. And, to restate what I just said up there...just read the comic book.

title: if you haven't seen it yet and you have a Y chromosome get off ure lazy...
review: Must i say more... What do you go to the movies for? If its a good time, see this movie. If its for seein some violence and guns, watch this movie. If its for seein some gorgeous women scantily (if that) clad, see this movie. If you ever found any reason to go to a movie, see this movie. The point I'm getting at is that this is the single most testosterone inducing, eye widening, bloody, gory, beautiful, artistic production bestowed upon a previously pathetically boring wasteland we call the movie theatre. I've seen it once, I'm going back soon, why don't u join me. I must say it pays homage to a Frank Miller comic the way only... well Frank Miller could. This is a movie i guarantee will have u talking for days and at least let u forget about your dull event less life for a little while; while u see everything that doesn't happen in real life but sometimes u wish really did. Some of you might be turned off by the blood and the boobs but this is America, entertainment is blood and boobs, so get off ure high horse and come watch Sin City with me. Mickey Rourke played Marv to the tee and actually made me stand up and cheer a couple times, this movie is that good. Jessica Alba is scintillating. The story is good, believe it or not there's more than the bullets. You will not find more to love in a movie. When you come back to rate this movie its gonna be a 10. And when u loved this movie tell ure friends and give a shout out for how much u loved marv cuz i know u will.

title: excellent movie! cool hero's, tough quotes, comic book stylized look.
review:
great comic book feel to live action. may have even used comic books as story board when filming. they spent some bucks in post production here. love the use of color. not too heavy on the 'Tarentino' style of story telling. the stories seem to nicely overlap in the same general time line.

i only go to the theater and pay for movies which require the big screen and i might consider going back to see this one again.

were a few scenes that lost me when characters are introduced as being human but show superhero abilities. still not many gaps in this one even if your as picky. gave it a ten when i walked out of the theater but bumped it down to a 9 after some thought and discussion.

title: kept changing from cool, to boring, to cool, to boring throughout
review:
i heard from many people it was good and many people it was GREAT. When I saw it, i was amazed at the visuals, but the story just kept on going. I had fun about the first one-fourth of the movie, but then it just got old and boring. The characters were unique, but the plot was just weird. They were looking for a guys head! Than, there was a whole different story after it. The two stories had nothing to do with each other. They were just put together to make the movie longer, I think. I liked how they made some colors stand out though. The overall movie was well-made, but i think it got good, and then boring, and then good, and then again boring. By almost the end of the movie, i wanted it to end because it was the same over and over again. The violence is excellent, but there is no real point to the whole thing.

Word of advice, the girls and the nakedness is the best part. The only thing i hated that they didn't have Jessica Alba naked, but had all the other girls naked. I think she was by far the hottest out of all of them. Whats up with that? I WANT HER NAKED!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Right now. I want her NAKED and i want HER ON ME!!!!! That would make me love the movie so much more. he he

title: 'Sin City' is brutal, violent, gritty, and a lot of fun
review: Sin City (2005) Bruce Willis, Mickey Rourke, Clive Owen, Jessica Alba, Rosario Dawson, Jamie King, Brittany Murphy, Benicio Del Toro, Nick Stahl, Elijah Wood, Michael Clarke Duncan, Michael Madsen, Josh Hartnett, D: Frank Miller, Robert Rodriguez, Quentin Tarantino ("special guest director"). Gritty, violent, visually sensational comic-book film noir, based on Frank Miller's graphic novels, is set in the corrupt, crime-infested Sin City, full of thugs, dirty cops, bloodthirsty killers, and sleazy prostitutes. Film has a collection of interweaving stories: a burly brute (Rourke) on a mission to avenge the death of his love; an ex-photographer (Owen) who kills a cop with a gang of prostitutes and must cover it up; and a soon-to-be-retiring cop (Willis) who tries protecting the girl he once rescued. Virtuoso visual style (black-and-white with only splashes of color) feels overly self-indulgent at first, then overtaken by terrific energy from graphic violence, an array of hard-working talent, and crackling humor. Given a hard R-rating for a reason! 123 min., rated R. *** Â½

title: A living comic book ... spectacular.
review:
It's certainly true that lately we've been bombarded with many big-budget Hollywood adaptations of comic book movies, and that many of them have been bad. The problem wasn't necessarily with the movies themselves, but with their lack of originality. They all go for the same dark, Gothic Batman-esquire style, which, appealing as it may be, frankly just gets a little boring. We've been waiting a long time for someone to bring us something truly original in this genre ... and here it is.

"Sin City" tells three different stories, all of which take place on the same night, and all of which are connected by at least one character and common themes. It's dark and it's bloody and, to be honest, a bit silly, but all in all it's a great work of fantasy. The actors relish both in their character's originality and in Frank Miller's gritty, ingenious dialogue. Plain and simple, this movie is a mini-masterpiece.

Very good performances all around from stars Clive Owen, Bruce Willis and Elijah Wood (an unusual role for Elijah, but he pulls it off extremely well). The standout performance, however, comes from Mickey Rourke as "Marv". He's probably the least well-known of all the main cast members, but this may well change after this. All of the supporting roles are filled out extremely well also ... Benicio Del Toro, Nick Stahl and Rutger Hauer in particular give memorable, if short, turns as their various characters.

After seeing Sin City you're left with the impression that you've just watched a computer generated animation rather than a movie, such is the visual feel of it. It is truly a direct translation of the comic book, and something which has never been done before. The only comparison I can come up with is a computer game -- "Max Payne", which itself is done in the style of a comic book, and like Sin City it mixes film noir with a Gothic horror style. This is, without a doubt, the finest comic book movie I have ever seen.

This movie deserves to be a hit. It deserves to have sequels. Anything else, would be a travesty. An injustice. A sin.

title: Sadism masquerading as art
review: Rodriguez has reached the nadir of his career with this sadistic, sophomoric trash. The only thing interesting about it is the black-and-white cinematography, similar to that of last year's "Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow." After two hours of non-stop, over-the-top, cartoon-like violence, I felt dirty leaving the theater. I'm not familiar with the graphic novel genre, other than the Tom Hanks film "The Road to Perdition." That film had real characters and genuine interactions between them. The violence was necessary to the telling of the story, unlike this film where the violence is the story. This piece of junk has no redeeming qualities. Avoid it!

title: cinema-comics
review:
i've never been a huge fan of the comics, and never read frank miller's work... but this picture was absolutely incredible to watch. stylistically, the black and white presentation with minimal color added worked well-- and i'm assuming this is how miller pens (or penned) his work. i look for moving-going experiences that give me something new... something i've never seen.

this movie fit that bill.

the plot-lines are pretty fundamental... and very violent in a comic-book sort of way... but the experience is visual-- and for that alone, it's worth the trip.

title: Wicked Good Fun...
review: In my humble opinion, Frank Miller's Sin City (2005) is Robert Rodriguez at his best. I was immediately reminded of such singular gems as Stanley Kubrick's A Clockwork Orange (1971), Michael Almereyda's Nadja (1994), Nick Taylor's A Clown in Babylon (1999). With rock solid performances by Bruce Willis and Mickey Rourke, amazing photography and editing by Mr. R., and some bloody amazing looking young ladies, this black & white with a splash of color "comic book" come to life kept me on the edge of my seat from beginning to end. The only weak link for me was the over the top hooker machine gunner sequence which completely broke the flow and got me biting my nails. Fortunately, it was followed by a revisit to the "Willis" character, and literally ended with a bang. Great Job!

title: It's a REALLY good movie, but I didn't like it.
review:
>>They call it "Sin City". Maybe that's why I didn't like it.

In all truthfulness, it was a REALLY good movie. No use in doubting that. It was a REALLY good movie, and yet...

...I didn't like it.

Apart from being just a little too long, by the time we reached the half-point of the film, I was already sick of it. Yes, it's called "Sin City" and there is a reason why it's called "Sin City", with all the violence and brutality and sleaziness helping the film live up to its name--its title, but the fact of the matter is, they exhausted all those entities, along with others, to the core.

In the first hour, I was amazed by Sin City. Its luminescent, lucid, at times blazing, grades of black and white. Its piercing action and racy dialogue. The unexpected outbursts of red, yellow, green, and blue. The characters you find yourself enchanted with, the characters you rush to hate and hesitate to love. All this, the first hour gave me.

But then, the film ran on....and on. They exhausted their use of violence, gore, and brutality. It really did make me kinda sick. There were parts at which I felt like gagging. Too MUCH gore. Too MUCH brutality. "Sin City" <--no lie. Maybe I should of expected all that "sin", but really, they exhausted this word, too. Many characters got the sh*t beat out of em. Likewise, this film got the sh*t beat out of it. By gore, by brutes, by sleazy, twisted men, who made me feel like screaming. I sat, writhing in my seat, finding no other solution to my fuming awkwardness.

They threw the blood at us, and it became annoying. An overly excessive use of gore. I can take it in moderation, hell, I can take a lot. SIN is not just gore. Makes you wonder if they realize that. GORE is a product of sin, but it is not its equivalent. Once again, this film is REALLY good. But I didn't like it.

title: Great on so many levels, yet if falls short
review:
I am a huge fan of Miller's comics and really dislike Rodriguez's films. The hype surrounding this movie was huge and as of today the movie is in IMDb top 100. But at the same time, so are Kill Bill and Kill Bill 2, two movies that I disliked with passion. So I didn't really know what to expect from Sin City. Unfortunately I walked out of Sin City with mixed reviews.

First the good The attention to detail that went to transferring the comic book into movie is amazing. Backgrounds look exactly the same as they do in the comics, and to give the movie another dimension, many features, such as rain and scenes that show characters all white against black background, have comic book look to it. This movie take the technology introduced in Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow to a whole new level. Mickey Rourke is amazing as tough-as-nail Marv. Perfectly cast, perfectly played out part. Elijah Wood creates perfect Kevin. I get the chills while reading the comic every time Kevin shows up. Movie is no different. Devon Aoki and Rosario Dawson do excellent job as well.

The bad So many actors are not suited for their roles. Bruce Willis does not suit almost 70 year old Hartigan. Clive Owen, Benicio Del Toro, Jessica Alba, Brittany Murphy, Joshua Hartnett all are playing parts not suited for them. The inner monologue that each character work brilliantly in the comic, but for some reason looks ridiculous in the movie. Each character thinks as if they are all read Wall Street Journal and watch private eye flicks from 40's. Sometimes the end result is simply laughable. The scene when Clive Owen is being pulled out from the lake by Devon Aoki is a perfect example of that. Finally, when characters do talk, it is always as if the words are being forced out of them, always ending with a big sigh.

Overall, I don't think the movie deserves to be in the top 250 of all time, let alone top 100. It is solid, but not great, and definitely not deserving all the hype it got so far.

title: I thought it was going to be STUPID. I was mistaken.
review:
Okay I had seen the trailer, but I hadn't read any of Frank Miller's stories. Having an anti-Bruce Willis bend, I wasn't inclined to see this movie anyway. (No doubt his ego demanded they put all that hair on his normally bald dome.) Very few movies can get along only on Black-And-White, and this is one of them. The spot color works very well. It is so dramatic, it only adds to the comic book feel.

It is extremely violent so I wouldn't take along the kids. Too cheap to get a babysitter? Then don't go! Some parts have nudity and some are so over-the-top, you just sit and laugh.

The way you see the characters and stories overlap reminds you of Tarantino's "Pulp Fiction." All of a sudden you realize the movie doesn't follow one time line.

See it. It's not one of the greatest movies ever, but it is entertaining and different.

title: An Honest Objective Review
review:
I thought that Sin City was a decent noir film, but nowhere near as good as the hype would indicate. Seems like the same audience that loved Kill Bill is falling over Sin City. Violence for the sake of violence. Is there any kind of commentary either Rodriguez or Tarantino are making about violence through the evisceration-a-second action? In the case of both, I don't think they let their work become too intellectual. It's like they put the violence in a pill for you to swallow and you absorb it and dump it a few hours later, end of story. Films like these don't really stick with me because they are a more concerned with reaching the pinnacle of style and being cool.

Mickey Rourke had the most sincere performance stand out from the muddle. Perhaps it is because Rourke starred in one of the greatest noir films of all time, Angel Heart. He didn't have to reach very far, which is not to say he is dialing in his performance, but he excels in the genre. Clive Owen, Rutger Hauer, Rosario Dawson and Benicio Del Toro were the second tier. Everyone else falls somewhere below for the following qualities: posing like a filmed storyboard, acting like an over-directed stand-in with lines, or simply failing to rise above the material, which is not that great to begin with. Classic film noir with a lot of shock value and a slick new film look.

The look is most certainly unique. No doubt that many people will imitate its style in the coming years in a variety of media; print ads, commercial spots, other noir-type films, TV shows, etc.

I suppose if there is any positive to come out of Sin City, it's that murdering a religious figure or corrupt Father through a confessional is the proper radical response to some of the unethical religious intervention in the current political landscape.

title: "Walk down the right back alley in Sin City, and you can find anything... "
review:
Usually I'm not a fan of movies that are ripped from the comics because in my opinion they never do the original characters, story lines or art/artists any justice. But this time around I thought it may be different, with Robert Rodriguez on board as director along with Frank Miller (the man behind Sin City), himself. I was kind of excited about this one from the get-go especially with Quentin Tarantino having a guest directive spot , but thought maybe I'm just getting my hopes up.. Anyway, I got to see the movie on Friday night. I am a fan of the original graphic novels, the art is just so gritty and beautiful, completely black and white (no shades of gray) with splashes of color on distinctive characters and tangibles.

Let me tell you, it's worth it to go see this movie, I really enjoyed it, although it might not be someone's particular taste who isn't into the Dick Tracy meets Gotham City sort of thing. If you can stand the tacky and satirical old-school film noir movie narrative (akin to the writing of Frank Miller's novels), it really turns out to be a must-see.

The cinematography is really what stood out the most for me, it was amazing and as close as you could possibly get to the actual art in the original novels. It was just beautifully and AWESOMELY done. But then again how could I expect anything less with the 3 creative geniuses I mentioned above at hand? I can die happy now.

title: Its Sinful 2 miss SinCity
review:
When i first went to SinCity is had mixed feelings. While everything was unique and well done, i just had difficulty with so much black and white cinematography. On reflect, however the b&w does not take away from the film at all. The only way they could do this movie and no received an NC-17 rating was to do b&w with color edited killing scenes. Great number of star cameos, very much in the true Terrantino style (although he is only a guest director). Overall, this movie leaves you feeling satisfied.

I don't think this is for every one though. Lots of violence and brutality. As always, Bruce Willis gives an excellent performance (he doesn't get enough credit due to some poor action movie choices). Wanted more Alba and Murphy.

Only problem...didn't like the fact is was 4 separate stories with very weak linkages. I know its probably written like that, but it kind of takes the climax away leaving and return the main story, with the independent stories of Owen, Murphy, and others.

title: Didn't Kevin look a lot like Harry Potter?
review:
I really liked this movie, but was a little bit surprised by all the gore.

My wife and I argued about who was playing Kevin because he looked exactly like Harry Potter.

She thought it was Daniel Radcliffe, and his shirt seemed to have a zig-zag or lightning bolt on it too.

When I saw the credits, it said Elijah Wood.... I just thought it was strange to make the character look like Harry Potter. Same glasses too.

Anybody else make this mistake in identifying him?

Hey how many more lines do I have to write? 5 Hey how many more lines do I have to write? 4 Hey how many more lines do I have to write? 3 Hey how many more lines do I have to write? 2 Hey how many more lines do I have to write? 1 Finally!!!!

title: Fantastic
review:
I must say, I am very impressed by this film. I do not read comic books, and I've never read the graphic novels for Sin City. This film has certainly made me curious.

The visual style is stunning, the romantic themes are endearing, the action is edge of your seat, and the characters are jaw-dropping awesome. I can't figure out why there is so much trashing by critics. What do you guys like??? Why do you even watch movies??? It's obvious that they miss the point on many great films, because SC grips you all the way and every five minutes it gives a moment where you just want to shout "DAMN, That was cool!!!!" The cast is top notch, the stories are excellent. Are there any flaws? None that got to me. It was a very satisfying experience.

To watch Marv, Hartigan, and Dwight in action is like watching Greek heroes from Mythology take on insurmountable tasks. It's Perseus vs the Medusa, Theseus vs the Minotaur, Jason traveling the world to get the Golden Fleece. These are ordinary men thrown into impossible situations, fighting the good fight for the sake of a woman they love. Each of them reaches a low point that spells their doom, but just as they are about to give up and die, they find within themselves the ability to go on, and not just cheat death in that moment, but to overcome defeat in ways they never dreamed possible.

This is all sounding dramatic, perhaps too dramatic, but these are the kind of moments that turn ordinary characters like Dwight, Marv and Hartigan into legends of epic mythological proportions, like Frodo or Luke Skywalker, Van Helsing or Hamlet, Odeysseus or Moses, etc.

Oddly enough, it's a very pro-Feminist movie. The women are very much empowered, and the good guys are very courteous to them, almost chivalric. It's refreshing to see a film that combines noir themes with outdated notions like chivalry. The film, despite its level of violence, is not crude. The dialogues and behaviors are from a bygone era in an age where TV And films try to shock us. There's a difference between "Shock value" and being "Jaw-Dropping". This movie balances all those details.

I highly recommend Sin City. It just kicks ass on many levels. Ignore critics. They don't get it, and they never will.

title: Just the way it should be
review:
This movie was amazing it really stayed with the comic, something that i didn't think they could pull off...and now for a little warning. This movie is called SIN CITY not the happy elf movie not Disney jerks you off, this is Gory sick stuff thats in your face the whole time. most women will not like this movie; however, if you want to get rid of the wife for a night and see something really great this would be the thing to see. The style of the movie really pulls you in from the start then they push you from story to story the whole time keeping you on the edge of your seat, so get a soda kick back and enjoy Frank Millers Sin City.

P.S. If you take your kids to something like this you should be shot in the face over and over, hell we may even just let Marv deal with you

title: Minor Quibbles
review:
First thing's first: Good movie. Very, very good movie. But not great. Let me be clear, I saw this movie on opening weekend with four friends, two of them HUGE and well-versed fans of the graphic novels, and a third who had just read them the week before. Among them, they had zero complaints. So maybe I'm splitting hairs. You tell me--

First, and most obvious to me, was the fact that no actor ever stood more than 10 feet away from the camera. In close-ups, this isn't a problem, but in every group shot or wide shot, the actors were ALWAYS in the foreground, and never spaced very far apart, depth-wise. After 20 minutes, I could start to see where the green screen hung on the back wall. Not literally, of course, but I had a pretty good idea. In the "Big Fat Kill" sequence, when the cops chase Jackie-Boy's gang into Old Town, there are four or five hookers who show up to watch... they're ALL in the foreground, on the same corner, just extras who walk in and flash their g-strings at the camera. To me, that's the most obvious example, but again, I could be nitpicking.

Second, there was no dramatic arc. Zero. The graphic novels felt real, because with a hundred still-shots making up a book, your brain fills in the rest. With a motion picture, in this case, filling in the rest FOR me, I didn't find it as affecting. A character dies, a character is injured, beaten, kissed, I felt nothing. In the books it was real, because Frank Miller's incredible artwork evoked the emotion he was going for in any individual frame: fear, terror, revulsion, lust. In the movie, with a familiar face filling in, the actors LOOK like their characters, but they don't INHABIT them. The best way around that, of course, is to cast no-names, but I understand it's tough to market a movie like that. So there we are.

Beyond that, I still have to say I enjoyed the movie. The visuals were stunning, both Miller's original work, and Rodriguez's interpretation of it to turn it into a real place. I just missed the character, which isn't usually present in an action movie anyway, but, y'know, it was in the books, so... maybe it's just me. 8/10.

title: slick, stylistic
review:
The movie is well produced and edited. While directed by several directors, the feel is still fluid without giving up the flavor of each. Holds true to the comic and doesn't really compromise. Some of the violence is a bit graphic so better to keep the under 14 crowd away. Definitely worth the trip to the theater.

Outstanding performance from Mickey R. Acting through all the makeup, he was still able to emote well. Perfect vehicle for Bruce and if you can get past the ick factor of the "relationship" you'll see one of his better efforts.

The old town sub plot is a bit strained and is the weakest part of the movie which contributes to the less than perfect 10 rating I dished. The usage of silhouettes and the comic-like use of shadow and light (especially during the graphically violent scenes) is used to superb effect.

title: Living By Its Name
review:
I've never read any of the comic books, but I thought this movie was a pretty damn good movie. Robert Rodriguez did a fantastic job of transforming this comic book into a movie. Of course, having the creator (Frank Miller) co-direct helps a lot too. To me, it was a fine visual display of work. The black and white w/colors at time made the movie to me. This was better than anything like Pleasantville (Good Movie) or Sky Captain (Yuck!). The way the colors were used were perfectly done and blended well on screen.

The dialogue, while cheesy, was pretty entertaining. There were some memorable quotes, especially from Mickey Rourke's character Marv. However, I think a few of the characters were almost too excruciating to watch. Primarily Michael Madsen (Bob) and Brittany Murphy (Shellie). Michael Madsen plays Bruce Willis's (Hartigan) partner in the movie and the delivery and tone was too bad, almost porno-bad. This wasn't a very good way to pretty much start the movie/storyline. But I've liked Michael Madsen in the majority of the things he has done so I'll give him a break. Brittany Murphy on the other hand just didn't get the job done. I've never really liked Brittany Murphy in anything and her acting in this is horrendous.

However, the good outshine the bad. Mickey Rourke stole the show in my opinion. Marv was an awesome character and I don't think anyone could have done the job better than Rourke. This guy was big, mean, and ugly with superhuman strength. Do not screw with this guy. Rourke is out for revenge throughout the film and he is fighting a good cause for the most part. Clive Owen also performed very well as Dwight. I was impressed. Bruce Willis did his thing. Jessica Alba wasn't in the film as much as I thought she would be, but still played her role well. Elijah Wood is another character I'd like to comment on. He plays a Cannibal-like character named Kevin. I know most people are used to him as Frodo but I thought he did an excellent job playing a freaky mute-like character. Finally, Devon Aoki was fantastic at playing Miho, she kicked major ass in this.

The three story lines are pretty well told but they aren't that impressive to me. Hartigan fights for an eleven year old named Nancy from getting raped by a psychopath known as Rourk Jr./Yellow Bastard played by Nick Stahl. Marv seeks revenge for a hooker's death and will go to hell and back to find out who did it. Dwight seems to be a mellow guy who is a pretty damn good killer if provoked. But I don't think he likes to kill people unless they deserve it. He is in this to help the hookers stay to their normal lifestyle and prevent a war from happening. My question is why are all of these three stories intertwined. I think there is a connection between the main characters that is very subtle, but it is hinted at in the Dwight/Shellie conversation.

A final thing I'd like to comment on is the violence and the nudity. There is a lot of violence, I won't lie. This isn't for the faint of heart or little kids. That's why it's Rated R. To me, there isn't that much nudity in it. Yes, there's hookers wearing slutty clothing, but they're not nude or anything. There's only about three nude scenes that I can recall. This movie is called Sin City and it lives by its name. From what I've heard from the comic book fans, It also stays true to where it came from and I respect that a lot, not that many comic book movies can say the same thing. I give this movie an 8/10 for its great visual display, good acting, average story lines, great action/violence, and overall balls this movie had and lost. Walk down the right back alley in Sin City, and you can find anything...especially a movie that will not disappoint.

title: Question
review: Anybody know which scene Tarantino directed? Have my theories. My friend thinks it's the old town battle. That could be. I'm thinking maybe the car crash scene in the snow. But does anybody know for certain? I thought the movie was incredible. I feel better as a filmmaker for having seen it. I was back and forth on Rodriquez. Loved Mariachi, so so on his other stuff. Thrilled he's back and with a vengeance. So there. Maybe that'll fill my ten lines they're demanding. Can't wait to see the next series. Nope. Guess not. Here we go again. As far as the "gratuitous" violence I've read about on the other pages, I think that thinking is hogwash. It's a comic book for god sake. Settle down. And violence towards women? Violence towards everyone. Chill. I think maybe the gals in Old Town would probably disagree with you that they're being underrepresented. I think they came off kick-ass and just fine.

title: Comic book as storyboards. GREAT !! That's even better. REWRITE!! That's fantastic....
review:
This is truly a movie for a fan of Frank Miller. It is simply and purely, the motion version of Sin City. This is also not to say that this movie is incomprehensible to a lay person. There is something for everyone, but this movie is specifically for the fan.

Sin City is a collection of comic mini-series (about 8, with some one-shots) published by Dark Horse Comics in the late 1980' and early 1990's. Sin City is comparable to Las Vegas, but Vegas of the fifties and sixties. It is less glitz and a lot more grit. The comics are almost completely drawn in chiaroscuro (black and white) and are very angular. There is very little detail to the characters. Blood is usually a white glob. There is some color, however. Some of the characters eyes, hair, or clothes sometimes get the Ted Turner treatment (but the rest usually is still black or white). The stories are also not treated linearly. They jump around and various characters throughout the stories intermingle ("everyone knows everyone kind of place", by reputation or otherwise). Sin City has it all : hookers, crooks, snitches, crooked cops and priests, dirty politicians, lawyers, gamblers, strippers, drunks, drug addicts, assassins, and regular Joes.

Rodriguez and Miller (who both have the directing credits) did an amazing job of copying and pasting from comic book into flesh and blood. This movie captures all the elements of the comic. First of all, the movie looks like the comic (not quite black and white, but definitely filtered). The city is dark, dingy and grimy. You can almost taste the 4 day old, tobacco laced coffee. It tastes like toast with a nice layer of dirt on top.

The majority of the story takes place around 3 of the mini-series (Sin City, The Big Fat Kill and That Yellow Bastard; there is also a little bit from The Babe Wore Red). The cast is also a who's-who's of the Hollywood heavyweights. Just about everyone in Hollywood signed up to do this picture.

Sin City is the original mini-series, which tells the story of a brute named Marv, who wakes up with a dead girl next to him. He's got to find out what happened. The Big Fat Kill is about a guy named Dwight who gets into a situation at his girlfriend's house, when her drunk old boyfriend shows up. That Yellow Bastard is the story of a tough, untouchable, old cop named Hartigan. Hartigan's final case (before retirement) has him looking for a child rapist/murderer.

It would have been nice if they introduced us with A Dame to Kill For instead of The Big Fat Kill. That way we would have gotten more background on Dwight. Even though the characters have a past and history, that isn't important. The comic books follow a film noir plan. The assumption here is that we don't get all the information on the characters. We have to accept them for what they are showing and piece together their past from their interactions. Its a detective novel wrapped up in an action thriller. The dialog is typical of what one would find in a film noir classic (think Bogart, but not quite as good, with some swearing - also lots of internal monologuing in a trench coat). I can forgive most of the dialog because it is suppose to be a little hokey. That is, what I thought was the weakest part of the entire movie. The rest is just marvelous. Some of the stories started up a little slow, but as soon as we got mid way into it, the action would kick in. This is a visually stunning looking movie. Thats the movie's (and the comic's) strength. It pulls you into the world. The action is fast and furious. At times it is staccato (jumps from kill to kill in a faced past motion - we don't linger on a kill) and at others its is quite over the top (i.e. - the end of The Big Fat Kill). I highly recommend this film for fans of film.

title: if you don't like this movie, you don't like movies...period
review:
absolutely one of the most brilliant films ever made. groundbreaking. awe inspiring. brilliant and amazing and a work of genius. hands down spectacular. i wont even bother explaining why.

one comment...if you are one of those folks who complains about violence, two questions...why did you see the movie? it is the very definition of "comic book violence". you had to know this going in. it is rated r. what more warning do you have to have? to complain about this particular film's violence is roughly akin to complaining about its stylized look for not being realistic. this is so over the top, and intentionally so, that no one in their right mind could ever or would ever mistake this as a real attitude towards violence or even a roughly accurate depiction thereof.

if you cant take violence, you should not see violent movies. it is your fault, not the movies, that you couldn't take it.

i have heard other such nonsense about its "degradation of women" and other rather PC concerns...look folks...it is a COMIC BOOK!!!! at what point do we stop judging every piece of entertainment as if it is a documentary style examination of everyday life in America and simply let it be what it is...

this is one of the single most brilliant uses of the cinematic form since the invention of celluloid and the discovery of persistence of vision, and beyond that, a damned entertaining movie. if this one didn't work for you, give it up. you don't like movies.

title: One of the greatest films ever
review:
In my humble opinion, Sin City was one of the best movies I have ever seen. No... never mind. It was hands down the best movie I've ever seen. This movie was ART in the truest sense. This was not a great movie because it appealed to everyone. This was a great movie because it accomplished what it set out to do. Bring a comic to life. It just had that feel, and maintained it throughout the whole movie. The dialog, the cinematography, the use of coloring... It was brilliant. Robert Rodriguez does not disappoint.

My only complaint about the movie is the hordes of ignorant people you will inevitably watch it with. It is just downright disheartening to watch something great with nearly everyone else laughing like idiots at every single part of the movie, especially at parts not even close to funny. Watch the movie KNOWING it is a comic. Then you'll see it as it was meant to be seen.

title: Expectations....
review: Funny that I really really liked this movie, but as far as expectations, it was summed up by a review I read a couple of days ago. The fellow said that it didn't blow away his expectations, but that it met them right on. I agree. This movie didn't roll me over like fight club did, but felt like a comfortable pair of gloves. Scratched an itch. Really gave me just what I was looking for. And Marv is the toughest sunofabitch (except Chopper, maybe :) This movie basically boils down to the strength of the comic, 100%. The direction was really good, but it really lets the actual comic do all the talking. What do you all think?

title: Sin City is Great and Mickey Rourke deserves an Oscar
review: Waiting for a Mickey Rourke comeback of astounding magnitude? Mickey doesn't just play Marv, he becomes Marv, and his performance is riveting. This film makes no mistakes throughout and is perfectly paced. I have seen it TWICE since Friday. TWICE. And I will buy it to own it on DVD. There are a few people here who seem not to like it, but judging by audience reaction in 2 different cities 200 miles apart--first time a college crowd in San Luis Obispo and second a crowd of industry professionals in Burbank, CA, both groups reacted with enthusiasm, laughter, shock, and surprise at all the right moments. It's the character of Marv who gets you to understand it's OK to laugh through the exaggerated violence.
