If you want to see something new and refreshing plop down your money for this cinematic work of art. Rodriguez transports you to a place that is dark and corrupt. It's not just cinematography that grabs you. The acting is first rate too. Bruce Willis does an excellent job as a good cop. Another excellent performance is by Clive Owen. If you are not familiar with Clive Owen, go see him in the Mike Nichol's film "Closer". He is an incredible actor with range. He should be the next James Bond. He is cool man, real cool. Benicio Del Toro and Brittany Murphy's performances were amazing too.

One thing I need to point out. This film is not for everyone. Some people are not going to like it. These are the people in the audience that didn't get it when I saw it. The violence is over the top so in a way it is rather comical. However, some women will find the movie offensive so guys, I don't know if this would be a good date flick. Some are going to find it more offensive than entertaining. It's your call. I just know what I like and I really dug it.

title: See this movie now...
review: A delight, both to listen to and to watch. A true homage to Frank Miller's original books, Sin City weaves together stories that we are both repulsed by and attracted to; these characters, though raw and hard-boiled they may be, have souls among the ghosts that populate Basin City. What we have is Frank Miller's classic tragedy of good vs. evil; though no bad man goes unpunished in SIn City, no good man does either. Our heroes, namely Marv and Hartigan, are martyrs for justice. Though not beyond using ultra-violent, unconstitutional interrogation methods, we know that these are the "good guys." SIn City presents a series of stories that Americans can relate to in the post 9-11 world; good people dying to dispense justice.

title: what's black and white and red/yellow all over? well what the hell do you think?
review:
May contain spoilers. see for yourself.

Sin City. full of black and white. splashes of color. strip bars. strippers. crooks. cops. crooked cops. revenge. vengeance and gore. oh yea it's gory as hell. Sin City follows three characters over the time of basically one night or so. with exception of Willis and Rourke.

Sin City is amazing to look at, and wonderful to sit through. though it is gory and bloody, the acting and story lines plus characters waters it all down. the cast is wonderful and amazing. the story: the first full story we dive into is the story of a crook and thug that basically can't be killed. he is a Big for-headed, big mouthed, but love-able kinda guy. Marv,(Micky Rourke) we hear his over voice and from the start we wanna know more about him. we see him make love to Goldy, then a cannibal messed up serial killer( Elijah Wood) walks in and shoots her dead, which throws Marv into a world of hurt. cops then storm in on the dead broad and Marv and he realizes he's been set up, so now he goes on a killing spree on search for Goldies killer and the person who set him up. this story is known to Frank Miller fans as "Sin City." Marv runs into unforgettable characters, like a stripper who is actually Goldies twin sister. and a parole officer that lets him drug up and kill. Rourke is wonderful to watch. and Elijah is terrifying.

the next story that we come to look into , is known to Miller fans as " The big Fat Kill" it follows a photographer, Dwight ( Clive Owen) who loves his women. by day he hangs with a blonde little stripper ( Brittany Murphey) and at night he stalks "OLD TOWN" with a hot little Uzi token diva ( Rosario Dawsen.) we follow him when he tries to avenge the hurt a scummy cop , Jacky Boy ( Benecio Del Toro), Puts on the little blonde stripper. and when he follows Jacky Boy to "Old Town" and the strippers, who run the town, put some hurt on Jacky Boy it's up to Dwight to get rid of the bodies, but instead gets framed for a murder by the chief of police in Basin City who thinks Jacky Boy died for being loyal. the gold eye brute of a chief ( Micheal Clark Duncan) then puts out a hunt on Dwight and a certain head that Dwight is carrying. and when The Uzi Diva is kidnapped the story ends with a bang. Dwight encounters bad guys of his own, including Jackie Boy, and Irish phsycoes that love killing. Mentioning form this story goes to a great performance by Clive Owen, Brittany Murphy, Dawson. and good directing by Miller and QT.

The last and final story, actually starts the movie off, with a soon to be retired cop, Hartigan ( Bruce Willis)who saves a young girl ( Jessica Alba) from the rapist ,Junior ( Nick Stahl.) but he doesn't make it very far, and instead gets shot up and incarcerated for raping the young girl who falls in love with the corrupt cop for saving her life, because she knows the Truth but no one will listen. we then shoot to 8 years later, when Hartigan goes ona search for this young woman who is now a erotic stripper, and on his look he is being stocked by "The Yellow Bastard" (who is also played by Nick Stahl.) and through finding himself, Hartigan seduces the young girl(Alba) without knowing it, and he falls in love only to find himself defeated in the end. Great characters are involved in this story as in the rest. Bruuce Willis is great, and Nick Stahl is creepy and very lovable as an evil jerk.

The characters and stories are just toppings on the cake. the stuffing lies with the way the stories intertwine, the direction(which is outstanding and brilliant) and the artistic view the directors took to make this outstanding movie. This is the best Comic to Movie, movie ever. Frank Millers characters and drawings come alive on screen with the help of director , Robert Rodreguez. Robert, not only brings the liveliness to his filming and imagery that he does with how he wants the characters to be. each actor kind of just molds into their character and you don't believe your watching actors on the screen. unlike other comic movies, who take the characters and make new story lines to fit "real-life" this movie doesn't take a realistic point of view at all!

It is gory and may make you wanna puke in some shots. but the gore is not distasteful and the really gory stuff is done off screen. Rodreguez, Miller, Rourke, Owen, Willis my hat is off to you. you made a brilliant comic book into a wonderful delightful movie. 10/10

title: what a movie
review:
The books are comparable to the movie. Some actual shots in the movie are the same as panels from the comic. That is why Rodriguez(the director) had Frank as co-director . The movie is very bloody and leans a little more towards realistic violence even though the violence can get sickening. In comparison to the anime movies Hokuto No Ken and Akira, not that much blood is spilled. There are more certain realistic consequences in the film even though certain sequences probably couldn't/wouldn't/shouldn't be done in real life.

I didn't read all of "That Yellow Bastard" before the movie, but then the first part of the movie follows the first part of that graphic novel directly.

I found the movie so good, I am planning to rent it when it gets released on DVD.

title: Amazing work of art!
review: I got the very last tickets to see this movie at my local theater, and it was packed. My expectations were high, and i wasn't the least disappointed. It was really great and very "comic" like ( unlike the other comic-to-movie adaptation's which have failed badly ). Yes, there is lots of violence and gore, so leave the kids behind. Since, the comics were release long back and well accepted, character development was very very strong. Every character stands out, just where they ought to and stay with you even after the film is over. *********May contain spoilers**************** Loved characters with no dialogues, miyo and junior ( elijah wood has done a great job, with the fight scenes, miyo reminded me of kill bill ). *********end spoilers************************ Overall a great movie, watch it on the big screen to experience the "clean-cut" feel of the movie. I was glad the movie is not in full color, with the amount of splatter, i am sure you will agree with me. Great flick, sure to become a classic.

title: Great but over-rated
review:
Sin City is indeed a watchable, and for the most part highly entertaining film. Did it live up to its hype (I mean, I've been anticipating this for almost 6 mos)?

Not so much.

It starts great, with the segment introducing Bruce Wiliis' character, and sets the tone for yet more of the super-stylized ultra violence that we've come to relish in Rodriguez's films.

(And when big Quinty is listed as a 'special guest director', you just know there's gonna be a whole lotta genital-mutilatin', limb-choppin fury. You know, for the kids...)

The story line featuring Mickey Rourke as Marv is great, a good story well told. Then the film hits a big fat lag.

They could have trimmed twenty minutes out of this and had a real good, tightly connected series of vignettes that really would have sent me home loving it and wanting more.

Don't get me wrong, I love del Toro's work, but the whole hooker-sequence-with-lotsa-misogeny, and little killer Miho (or whatever the hell her name was) just went on and oooonnnnnnn.

I know I'm not into a piece when I find myself looking at my watch to see how much longer it could drag out, ya know what I'm saying?

Plus, you know, I'm getting tired of the flying Chinese superchicks that are all the rage among the Tarantino-esque set for the last three years.

Ditto for the d'enouement, with Bruce Willis confronting the yellow guy whose appearance turned the whole thing into a lame-ass Star Trek-era makeup retread. And whose whole dialog and raison d'etre have been done so many times.

Pity, too, as I was SO hyped after the first couple of stories.

Bottom line: Sin City is alright, but only alright. You wont regret it if you wait for the DVD release, but it is worth a look at some point. Heaps of style (albeit derivative of a lot of other recent movies, most notably Sky Captain and a lot of great Asian cinema like Casshern)

Its a better than average film, and I love Rodriguez's work. It just ain't no Once Upon a Time in Mexico.

title: Bold and Mesmerizing! By Far the Best Comic Book Film Adaptation Ever Made!
review:
Sin City has to be one of the most inventive films I have ever gazed my eyes upon. The minute it starts, it reels you into a world full of blood, mayhem, sex, black-and-white imagery and a hell of a lot of cigarette smoking. Along with being the most inventive and cool film of the year so far, it is also the best. Based on the provocative graphic novels by Frank Miller(also the film's co-writer/co-director), Sin City is so full of life you will probably have to see it twice to grasp it's greatness.

The movie is built solidly around 3 1/2 stories. The first (well 1/2 a story) is the three minute opening scene of the film. It features a love crossed woman (Mary Shelton) and a mysterious man who comes to her rescue (Josh Hartnett). The other three stories (which take place after an amazing opening credit sequence) are when the movie really starts to get interesting. The first is about a hardened super-hero-ish criminal on parole, Marv (Mickey Rourke) who has a one-night stand with a hooker, Goldie (Jamie King), and wakes up later that night to find her murdered. Marv goes on a mission to avenge her death by the hands of an eccentric mute cannibal rapist, Kevin (played by Mr. Frodo himself -- Elijah Wood) and a corrupt Cardinal of the Roman Catholic Church, Cardinal Roark, (Rutger Hauer -- in a scary role.) Interfering with Marv's plans are his lover, Goldie's, hooker friends led by Goldie's sister Wendie (played also by Jamie King) and Marv's parole officer (played by Carla Gugino). This is my favorite segment of the three.

The second (and longest) story involves a battle between a good guy, Dwight (played by Oscar nominee Clive Owen) and a corrupt police lieutenant of Sin City, Jackie Boy (played by Oscar winner Benico Del Toro) which starts as a dispute over a cocktail waitress at a bar, Shellie (Brittany Murphy). This battle involves conflict from the government, mafia, hookers (Alexis Bledel and Rosario Dawson), a nasty female assassin named Miho (played by Devon Aoki) and a crazed gang leader (The Green Mile's Michael Clarke Duncan). This segment involves a scene directed by Quentin Tarantino, in which Dwight has a conversation with a corpse in the front seat of a bright red 65' Cadillac.

The third and final story of this film-noir saga, involves one of Sin City's last clean and honest cops, John Hartigan (Bruce Willis) and his mission to save a beautiful young stripper, Nancy Callahan (Jessica Alba) from a deranged mutated yellow-skinned kiddie rapist/murderer named the Yellow Bastard (played by Carnivale's Nick Stahl). The Yellow Bastard's father is the Senator of Sin City, and brother of Cardinal Roark. In this segment, Hartigan was framed for the rapes and murders of the Yellow Bastard and tries to clear his name, while the Yellow Bastard, Senator Roark (Powers Boothe from HBO's Deadwood) and Hartigan's old partner Bob (Kill Bill Vol. 2's Michael Madsen)try to stop him.

Sin City is excellent in so many different aspects, but it also has some flaws. Some of the film's story is hard to follow because there is so much of it. They literally jam back 2 ¾ hours of material into a 2 hour and six minute film. Although most of the acting is spot-on in Sin City (Willis, Rourke and Owen are spec-tac-ular in the three lead roles -- especially Rourke), some people like Brittany Murphy and Brittany Murphy (whoops did I mention Brittany Murphy?) suck more then a vacuum cleaner. Thank god she had a minimal role so she didn't ruin the movie for me. Brittany Murphy does a poor job, but the villains in the film (Powers Boothe, Michael Madsen, Elijah Wood (oh no, Frodo!), Rutger Hauer, Michael Clarke Duncan  and especially Nick Stahl and Benico Del Toro)are too perfect for words.

All in all Sin City holds the title for me as the best comic book film adaptation of all time. It's a terrific film filled with wonderful surprises and I'd recommend you all to see it (just don't bring kids 11 and under  parents be forewarned it contains sexual situations, gratuitous nudity and extremely graphic and creative violence.) I reserved a spot for Sin City on my end of the year top 10 list. Bring on Sin City 2, with three more stories from Frank Miller's graphic novel series. Grade: A-

title: Sin City the best movie this year
review:
not sure how many words i get but mickey rourke was so good in this movie his character was funny and basically hard to hurt or even kill .

A ton of funny quips hot babes more nudity then i expected but no complaints. !!!

Jessica Alba , rosario Dawson all the woman of old town make you want to go there .

title: i need a little insight
review:
OK so...on the whole this movie was pretty bad ass. not having ever seen or read frank millers comics i got most of this movie. there's just some minor beefs i have with it and i think the might come from me never having read the comics.

who/what is josh hartnett's character? he appears in the very first and very last scenes as a killer but for whom? and why?

i wasn't sure if the stories were all supposed to be connected with each other or not because the only constant in them was shellie and the bar but then i read that its sort of pulp fictiony so that made it OK.

and this is the part part that bothered be the most (my spoilers in hear so i hope to god that no one who hasn't seen sin city reads this) Bruce Willis killing himself was totally pointless to me. i understand that it was a callback from the "an old man dies and a little girl lives" line from the beginning but him dying just to make that line fit was a bit much. if it was me and i was Rourke, Nancy would be dead anyway. if the one guy on earth i wanted to kill more than any other killed himself and i didn't get to do it and there's only one person left to take it out on (Nancy) shed be dead in 2 seconds. at least if he stayed alive he could have tried protecting her. that would have made more sense. but then i thought i might have been missing something from the comics.

so if anyone could clear up the josh hartnett thing and Bruce Willis offing himself id appreciate it. sorry if i ruined this for you.

title: Best comic book movie ever!
review:
I am new to the world of Frank Miller and his work but I did read his Dark Night Return's book which I thought was extremely well written at the time. This movie literally blows away any comic book movie I've seen before both plot wise and artistically. Personally I'm sick of superheros that wear masks and fight some retard bad guy that also has some corny super power.

Sin City is much more satisfying for me due to the fact that its based on a story of vengeance and payback where the enemy deserves to die and the audience roots when justice is delivered. There is a lot of violence and gore to this movie but the good thing is that it all fits in with the storyline and you don't get a feel that its overdone. The acting was great and the movie was ten times better than that of Sky Captain.

So if you want to see a great action/ thriller than this is a must. But be sure to leave the kids at home. Never mind, I saw them in the audience anyway.

title: A fascinating mix of pure brilliance and absolute mediocrity
review: I have not read Frank Miller's "graphic novels", though after seeing Sin City it is obvious that Robert Rodriguez used Miller's frames as a verbatim story board. The result is mixed. I understand that the dialog is supposed to be cheesy and noirish to go with the brilliant visuals, but at times the whole thing was just way too over the top for my tastes. Never have I seen a more gory film, though the presentation is so unique that the disgust level is minimal. Mickey Rourke's performance is Oscar worthy. Jessica Alba's performance is not Oscar worthy, but one that no male will forget soon. It is nowhere near a classic, but a fascinating experiment definitely worth seeing.

title: simply amazing
review: Sin City is the best recent movie I have seen in a long time. This is the very best comic reproduction that's ever been made and may never be beat. An all-star cast portraying outrageous characters from Frank Miller's comic books from the infamous Sin City. The movie is of course in all black and white which gives it the perfect mood for the reaction and attention such a film deserves. There are exceptions when the directors wanted to accentuate something, but it compliments the symbolic meaning it portrays. I won't say anymore other than it is the most explicit movie I have ever seen which may or may not be to a viewer's liking. I have never seen anything like this and hope this is some sort of generational awakening to new movie viewers who like their movies uncensored. Get to the theaters and don't bother with refreshments because you may not hold it down. Prepare for a highly entertaining film unlike anything you've ever seen before. For those of the faint of heart redemption in Sin City is not an option...

title: COOLest movie of 2005
review:
With Rodriguez, Miller, and a little of Quintin, this movie is the coolest film of 2005. If you like violent action with generation x gore, interesting love story that will appeal to both sexes, and a feeling of satisfaction that can only be found after viewing the highest quality of film, then this is the way to go. The black and white filming is clearer and more visually satisfying than almost any other picture i have seen. This is no doubt the best Rodriguez movie ever, the gore, the cinematography, the cast, the look, and Mickey Rourke are just about the greatest things ever to happen to a movie. However if you don't like this, i hear that Miss Congeniality 2, Armed and Fabulous is out and your mommy can definitely buy you a ticket for that.

P.S. The color integration is orgasmic

title: Wow, I've already read this movie...
review:
...and it's still great. But definitely different. I didn't know what exactly to expect after the opening scene with Josh Hartnet, and after seeing it I understand why everyone has said everything they've said about this movie. The acting isn't really a mixed bag, it's just a different style of acting. It's intentionally over the top. Same with the violence and the characters themselves, this isn't a realist film. This way too cool to be a realist film.

What set the tone for me is and was my guide-track for the rest of the flick was Micheal Madsen's portrayal of Hartigan's partner. I couldn't help but gasp in wonder at what I was watching. It seemed off, compared to what I've seen him do before. He's not a bad actor, so why is his performance so laughable in the delivery? Whatever the reason, it was consistent throughout the performance so it obviously was intentionally done in the way it was. Well, beside Madsen's performance, I felt that the acting was great, with Mickey Rourke and Bruce Willis being the standouts. Jessica Alba did fine with what she was given to work with - any problem you've got with the character or the dialog or whatever, that's because it was written like that. I personally found her to fit the character fine and she did a great job.

Another example of this different style of acting was in the scene at the beginning of The Big Fat Kill, where Jacky Boy is trying to get into the apartment and Britney Murphy, with her back to the door, sort of strikes a pose (write out of the comic) and delivers the lines. That sort of took me out of the experience. In fact several moments like that took me out of the movie and made me think of what it was I was watching. There was one shot in particular of Marv spinning in the middle of a spiral pattern that made me realize I was watching the comic.

My only gripe, which goes against the dopes who're complaining that at 2 hours and 6 minutes the movie is way too long (whereas pulp fiction was 2 and a half and the LOTR were all over 3 hours, go figure people), there is one moment near the end of the movie where I thought they should've held on it for an extra 3 seconds or so. If they had done that, then the end wouldn't seem like a drawn out action sequence, but would instead have the audience wanting the hero to take out the villain, to get the happily ever after noir story, which would've made the payoff at the end actually pay off. Sorry if that doesn't make much sense, but I don't want to blow the story for you guys. Other than that it was great and compelling in terms of the story that was being told, and perhaps something was lost in merging the stories together to form the feature film length but it was a hell of a lot of fun.

title: I loved Micky Rourke in this Movie
review:
I just saw the movie last night. I had never heard of Sin City before but caught the movie trailer over Easter weekend and thought it look good.

Wow what a surprise, Micky Rourke was SO GOOD in this movie. It made me remember way I used to like him back in the 80's. What a great performance.

Although some of the volience did make me turn my head a couple of times, I still would highly recommended this movie, if for no other reason then to watch Micky Rourke.

Check out the great way he walks. He's to COOOOOOOOL!

GO SEE THIS MOVIE

title: Someone finally was able to mix Apples and Oranges...
review:
I am a comic book fan. I am also a film/movie fan. And I mostly get involved when the two mediums cross over into one another. But, on occasion they disappoint. Let's take for example Daredevil. I think we can all come to the consensus as film fans that it was not a very well done movie, and us comic book fans register it up there as one of the worst Comic book movies of all time. But Sin City is in a world of it's own.

Before going to the movie, I hadn't read any of Frank Millar's Sin City books. I'd read some of the other stuff he'd done for Batman: Dark Knight, etc, and was impressed by his use of words. I had also seen once upon a time in Mexico, so I thought that the movie would be at least as good as Rodriguez's last film. But after 10 minutes in the theatre I was blown away.

The Shots were near perfect. I'd seen some pictures of the comic in the last Wizard Magtazine I'd been reading, and the panels from the Grapohic Novels look uncannily similar to what you see in the finished film, easy enough to do with a completely digital set. Also, the black and white element with certain things in color to show their importance, was another brilliant feat, and something that I will always wonder how they do in the film medium. So the visuals as I've said, I freakin' loved.

The Script is just as brilliant. It uses all of Millar's wordplay and beautiful descriptors while not having to resort to poor tactics that film usually employs that Comics usually can do in a Narrative or a thought bubble. But if you've gone to see the movie and wonder why there is so much narration, it's because that is how Millar does his comics. it's nearly all narrative, and it is something I believe that film companies are desperately afraid of. They fear we may get bored, walk out, hate the movie, but I think that they don't give us enough credit. If employed like Rodriguez/Millar did in Sin City, there is no time for us to get bored because we are glued to the screen 99.9% of the time.

Lastly, they no holds barred attitude toward the film sealed the deal for me. I only found this out after I'd seen the movie. Afterwards I went out and bought 3 Sin City graphic novels to see what else Millar had written and developed through these characters and was totally amazed at how much they had actually used in th movie. Usually in films about comics, the backgrounds are changed, or specific elements are made different so as to adapt it to our believability of the film. But with Sin City we are expected to use our willing suspension of disbelief and embrace everything that has been on the page that was then transferred to the screen. beautifully done, in my opinion.

Some of you may not like the certain points of dialogue where it sounds stilted, or cheesy, or campy, but the point of Sin City is to have it be Hardboiled Film Noir, and if you read up on the media Sin City (the movie and the Comic) is based on you'll see that it fits right in. Perfect in it's place. And I've also heard some complaints about following the storyline. And all I can say is either go see it again, or take each story as it comes on it's own, independent of ll the other 4. Either way, there is very little about this movie to complain about. Someone may pipe up bashing the fact that all the women in the film are prostitutes, but alas none as we know them.

The movie is a hardboiled, beautiful, visual festival of true comic to movie genius and I hope that people will find the movie as intriguing as I have. The creators of this fill have truly learned how to mix apples and oranges, and turn out a piece of art.

-JYH

title: One of the best movies ever
review: this movie is one of the best movies i have seen and for me that is saying something because i have seen many movies in my life and so far there is only two that i can say are like the best movies ever which is this Sin City and Spider-Man 2. But what i like about this movie is well everything the acting, the filming the black and white scenery and only having a few things in the scene in color and especially the all the actors/characters and the biggest part the story and i think everyone should see this movie. one of my favorite parts is when Jessica Alba was dancing on the stage and got a nice look at her somewhat covered fine ass. what do other people think and i can't wait for Jessica alba's next movie The Fantastic Four

title: Sin and Circumstance
review:
Sin City is an interesting, hyper stylized little film that I can recommend, along with the cautionary heads up notice of the existence of a couple of problems. That's the simplest thing I can say about the movie. There are some great performances in terms of the nailing of characters from the source down perfectly but at the same time, there was one thing about the whole package that bugged me and I realized what it was just before the halfway mark of the movie. The movie is very faithful to the original Frank Miller graphic novels, with most of the film draped in shadows and dialogue that sounds like it was written by Chandler's ghost and while it is admittedly cool as all hell to actually see a project like this on the screen (projected digitally no less...), I couldn't shake the feeling that maybe, just maybe, the film was being a little TOO faithful to the novels. I felt that the movie didn't flow quite as well as it should have, mainly because it seemed to me the filmmakers were a little too obsessed with recreating every frame down to the last detail, so much so that it felt too obvious and aware of itself in a lot of the scenes. I felt like many of the performances were hampered by the restrictions on them placed by having to stick so closely to the graphic novels. Some of the dialogue scenes seemed to go on forever also, dragging the film in between moments of breathless violence, which were pretty intense. Don't get me wrong, it was still really fun to watch some of these pros in action, especially Benicio Del Toro, Bruce Willis, Clive Owen and Elijah Wood who turns in a fantastically creepy turn as a silent cannibal in possession of some serious fighting skills. His character along with Yellow Bastard (Nick Stahl, reminding us that the kid can play a really hateful character as well as the savior of the free world from the machines) gives the film a good amount of energy that good villains can bring to a story. Mickey Rourke gets a special mention from me for his work as Marv and proves as many others have done in the past before him that the world loves a great comeback as much as it loves to watch people get torn down. He's probably the best reason I can give you to watch this film, as he is arguably the heart and soul of it. The best performances come from those you normally expect to deliver, really. Some of the other performances kind of reeked with Michael Madsen coming to mind and Rutger Hauer doing more overacting than usual. Devon Aoki was awesome as Miho and Carla Gugino is going to be remembered fondly after this one, believe me. Jessica Alba didn't impress me too much character wise but damn, she's something to see, moving the way she does. The women are photographed with a lot of love and it's in this way that the movie really works hand and hand with the rest of the visuals. Some of the CGI is a little too obvious for my tastes but the look is perfect for this sort of thing in a way. Technically, the film is awesome but maybe it's just my appreciation for practical effects that makes me wish that there was less computer gimmickery. I can't help but wonder what this film would've been like if it had been shot on location rather than in front of a green screen. It's a cool effect that draws too much attention to itself after a while. In the end though, Robert Rodriguez made up for the all star vomit fest that was Once Upon a Time in Mexico with this. I have to give him credit for attempting something like this and I'd really like to see another Sin City movie done in the same way. Lastly, I also loved the music in the film.

Sin City is a well produced gimmick film that regrettably starts to wear a little thin. I started getting a little tired of the whole idea soon after it started but these are dismissible gripes considering that there were still so many things to enjoy about it then there were to dislike. This is definitely one to see in the theaters, especially if you want to see a different kind of comic book movie and something pretty original.

RATING: ***1/2 out of *****.

title: eat your heart out mickey spillane
review:
having only recently been indoctrinated into the callous world of the sin city comics, i wasn't sure that i would be able to judge the movie fairly. months earlier when i first read them, i loved the overall feel and pace to them and friends and i would discuss how a movie version of this should go off. as information became more available i became more assured that the movie would be great. Robert Rodriguez as director? super. mickey Rourke as Marv? bonanza! but still an inkling of fear remained that the ratings board would nueter the film and derail the overall quality. surprise surprise when this movie came out pound for pound every bit as violent as Natural Born Killlers (a movie that had an infinite amount of problems with the fascist MPAA) and yet raised not an eyebrow.

then the film comes out on April fools day. what a set up. i must say that i have not been this impressed with a comic book movie since the first batman in 1989. robert rodriguez met and exceeded all expectations by dogmatically adhering to the novels themselves. the movie was born free of director and actor ego that often muddles good work. performances by Rourke, Willis, Alba, and the rest are exactly right. the look and feel of the film is wonderful. the violence is far enough over the top and the female nudity sprinkled generously enough that a warm feeling settled in my stomach by movie's end i like the wittle wittle movie oh course, said nudity and violence does seem to slow by the end to a crawl but i think the director planned it that way to reverse the common action picture logic of a final build up of violence/chase sequence/confrontation et cetera. here instead the violence is unleash from the word go, and then the movie changes gears and the director says, "okay, you've seen this, now look at this".

brilliant ten out of ten and hey i'm one of the first voters

title: One of the Best Movies of all time
review: Alright i say Sin City is a flat out 10. u got everything. even Jessica Alba in booty shorts shaking her ass. u also got that miho chick with samurai swords, mickey ripping people in half, Elijah wood as a cannibal, and so much more. the movie itself was perfect. You also have to love the hot famous chicks such as Rosario, Brittany, and ricci in skanky clothes. Christ, u also have Bruce Willis with hair...You even got that punk who was from Terminator 3 as the evil yellow dude. Del Torro also had a kickass role as the cop and Tarentino's one scene was outstanding. the movie was worth the 9.50 i paid in order to go to it. the whole color thing was also badass. every color meant something. i strongly suggest that everyone should see this movie. i even saw some couple bring their 4 year old child into the theater. some call it irresponsibility's, but i call it good parenting.

title: Quite possibly the noirest movie I have ever seen
review:
I'm not going to tell you that *Sin City* is brilliant and the best movie of the year and visually stunning and unlike anything you've ever seen, because I'm sure you've heard it all before. I'm going to tell you why you should see it.

You should see it if you're a fan of the noir genre. This is quite possibly the noirest movie I have ever seen, and this includes actual noir like *Sunset Boulevard* and *The Big Sleep*. It is positively drenched in noir, from the black-and-white look to the hard-boiled characters, stories, and dialogue. I will give one word of warning here: the movie will feel "off" to you in the first ten minutes since it's highly stylized. But you'll get used to it.

You should see it if you're a fan of comics. Because this will let you see how it might look if you literally transferred a graphic novel from the page to the screen, which is essentially what Robert Rodriguez did. As you watch, you can practically see the panels on paper.

You should see it if you love voiceovers. Because there are a hell of a lot of them, so much so that it often feels as if you're being told a story by the characters. This is, of course, a noir convention.

You should see it if you like Carla Gugino's breasts.

You should see it if you love movies. The way that they can transport you to another world, and for two hours or so, they can so completely engross you that nothing in your own life even seems to exist, all that matters is what's transpiring on the screen.

You should see it if you enjoy a bit of the old ultraviolence. This movie is not for children. Do not take your five-year-old sister, for God's sake. But if you can appreciate guns, arrows, grenades, swords, clubs, and ninja swastikas, then you're golden.

You should see it if you can't tell the difference between a hero and an antihero, and maybe you think there's no real distinction.

You should see it if you liked how in *Pulp Fiction*, three self-contained stories ending up being connected.

You should see it if you can handle gore, ranging from missing limbs to...more missing limbs.

You should see it if you want to see Alexis Bledel show a little range.

You should see it if you want to see something different. Not only visually, but stylistically as well, down to the narrative.

You should see it if you want to see a really good movie. Look, maybe I wasn't physically wowed by it, and I'm not feeling all giddy. But you know when every aspect of a movie, from the acting to the writing to the directing to the everything you can possibly think of, is just so spot-on you can't think of anything to complain about? That's *Sin City*. It's extremely solid, and possibly revolutionary. Go see it.

title: visceral, beautiful, brilliant, jarring
review: this is truly an "event" film. the trailers and publicity for this movie have been driving me crazy for months, and tonight was a culmination of a whole lot of anticipation, and a whole lot of hype. i was apprehensive at the start, focusing more on the colorized portions of the shots than any kind of exposition that was beginning, and i must admit, in the first 3 scenes, the all digital background was distracting and false. before i knew it, however, i was 30 minutes into the film without another thought to the fact that no background i was seeing exists outside of a computer. without a doubt one of the most beautiful films i have ever seen. the color, the composition, the black and whites, and the computer generated graphics coupled with costumes and prosthetics made for a thoroughly surprising and aesthetically satisfying experience. this film is not perfect. some of the actors were obviously chosen for looks or prestige rather than acting chops, but no performance is so flat that it draws unnecessary attention from itself, or distracts from other performances (mickey rourke, benicio del toro and bruce willis, notably) that are nothing short of fantastic. this is a bloody, violent, and at times sadistic piece, but the context and the universe that is created makes everything justified, if not still stomach turning. my opinions may differ slightly after a good night's sleep and some time thinking on it, but as i'm sitting here, still wet from the walk home from the theater, i am pleased, surprised, shocked, sated, and overall, satisfied. i can't wait to see it again.

title: wow
review: as the title implies, thats all i can say about this movie. WOW. it is absolutely amazing, a masterpiece even, i think i rank it even higher than pulp fiction on my list and PF is at the top. i'm not here to spoil anything or nothing because i think that everyone needs to go out and experience this incredible movie for themselves. everything about the movie just fell perfectly into place...characters, mood, action, everything. the way it was shot was just outstanding, hats off the robert rodriguez.as much of a movie as it was it had the feel of the comic book and held true to it, something movies based on comics just don't do. ill end by saying that i recommend this movie to everyone, its just that damn good. just don't be takin little kids to see it cuz its not the type of movie for them. i know ill be seeing it several more times while it is still in the theaters.

title: So Good
review: Not only was it visually stunning, the entire movie had this classic feel that I've never seen before. It was like what sky captain and the world of tomorrow should have been. What sky captain lacked this movie had in spades, the story works itself like no other the flow of time is unique and pleasing... Bruce Willis's performance let you know that he will continue to pick great movies and be a star in many movies to come. It may very well be the greatest comic book movie to ever be released, easily better then any of the dark comic book movies such as Constantine or Helboy. It is by far the perfect start to the summer movies, and it is hoped that comic book movies can use this as an example. The darkness that shines through with its gore and nudity and use of vulgar language is a surprising beauty in the times these times that are obsessed with kiddy characters like jar jar binks. Just go see it...

title: Visually stunning, yet...
review:
How do you describe something that on one hand is complete knockout, and on the other hand leaves something to be desired? I'll do my best to tell you.

Sin City is a moving comic book - to call it a "comic book movie" is almost a disservice. For fans of Frank Miller's source-work, it's our dream come true -- the movie we never thought we'd see rendered nearly spot-on to the books we know by heart. The visual style is the storybook panels brought to inky black and vibrant white life. The colors - brief glimpses in most places - aren't terribly distracting and actually serve certain parts well. This is a visually huge film - sit way back in the theater when you go to see it, as you need some distance from the screen to truly soak in what Rodriguez and Miller have accomplished. The CGI is 98% seamless and flawlessly rendered against the reality of the actors, and it makes for one hell of a stunning visual experience.

The gore factor? It's not in the "rivers of red blood" manner you'd expect. Example: bullets leave ragged, meaty holes in their targets, but the blood and spray is rendered in shades of gray, so the depiction is accurate -- but without true "shocking gore." Add to that the campiness of some of the scenes, and you get an almost unintentional comedic tone to the violence at times (when someone gets their face smashed into a wall, it gets literally smashed into the wall).

As for the acting...well, there's a reason I chose to comment on the story and visuals first. It's the part where the movie falls the flattest. While noir dialogue isn't Shakespeare by any stretch, it does allow you to emote - something Alba and Madsen seem not to have learned. The standouts were Rourke (great!), Willis (good), Hauer, Stahl, and Boothe -- and, not surprisingly, creator Frank Miller as a priest. They were the only ones who delivered any appreciable level of conveyed interest in their characters - especially when contrasted against Alba and Madsen, who had less life than the CGI backgrounds created around them.

Bottom Line? Leave the critic at home and let your inner fanboy run wild. Get swept up in the frenetic pace and over-the-top fun of it all. Let the visuals carry you past the acting holes, and enjoy the trip. 8 outta 10.

title: A new standard
review: this movie is everything that the punisher should have been. it takes the genre to a new level - take better than kill bill caliber fighting, badass dialogue, and some of the coolest and craziest cinematography ever and the bar has been raised. this is huge - i have a feeling that in general, movies will start getting a lot better now thanks to this masterpiece. whether it is mickey rourke feeding elijah wood to his wolf, bruce willis manually castrating nick stahl, or devon aoki going commando on some cronie's head with a shiruken, the killing is grotesque, hilarious, and brilliant. The action is the best i have ever seen and the cast is more star riddled than "outbreak." SEE IT NOW.

title: It's Good To 'Sin'
review:
Kay, it's time to talk Sin City, folks.

It's very interesting film indeed. Excellent directorial style/film editing. I love how it was all set up like an old film noir. It was a creative idea how it was mostly a black & white film, but then you'd also see bits of colour throughout, like maybe they'd show someone's eye colour for a moment, etc. Also I think it's the best comic book to screen adaptation I've seen to date. Seriously it played like something you would've read right off the page, (I even started reading some of this very recently, and I have to say all the things I read so far looked and felt familiar to me).

As far as acting goes, EVERYONE did a very good job (with the exception of Alexis Bledel, which aside from her attire I had a hard time picturing her as a hookershe just couldn't leave her role of Rory behind her, AND I've never really even seen the Gilmore Girls to know that's who she is, so I guess perhaps that says a lot). But everyone else was fine. Too be fan-biased of my favourite celebrity momentarily, Elijah Wood's role was, er um, 'different' to say the least. I mean I've seen him get violent in movies before (Ash Wednesday comes to mind here though I must say his costar in that Rosario Dawson did a much, much better job here in Sin City), but uh yeah that was interesting. AND unlike his above mentioned costar Miss Bledel he is proof that stars can move successfully past certain roles. Sure we'll always remember that he is Frodo, but it's not going to stop his career anytime soon because there are no more LOTR movies for him to do (so yep, no Mark Hamill syndrome for him, whew not that I was ever worried about that because he was good in a lot of things even before LOTR came along, but still good to know he's still got it)

So, all in all an excellent movie. Now the film geek in me is just dying to know which scene Tarantino directed, heh.

9/10

title: Visually, artistically evocative with an engaging storyline.
review:
You will hear that Sin City is violent, bloody, and full of sex - the latter isn't entirely true. What makes the movie excellent is its superb story lines, acting and artistic deliverance to the audience.

Sin City's artistry hearkens back to film noir and dark comic books. Its characters offer a gritty, stylized look that will remind you of Pulp Fiction, without seeming as real.

The movie features several stories whose characters intersect briefly with each other, mostly by passing by each other in a single bar, and moving on with their tales. Each character's portrait is well done, and gives you a solid feel for them. There are some real heroes, good guys in this movie, though several are "anti-heroes" they are the good guys, looking out for others in this rotten, dark city-scape. Bruce Willis' character is the only straight arrow in the bunch.

The violence isn't gratuitous because of the black and white delivery. Some truly graphic scenes of flesh rending are shown with white silhouettes on a black background. The violence is inventive, and many times the audience gasped, laughed, or made other noises. In one scene I found myself laughing out loud with the rest of them.

The movie is truly engaging.

Without giving spoilers, it is something you need to see to understand. The story is deep enough, and the acting good enough, to merit viewing without knowing much else.

title: My...god...
review:
If you are offended by ANYTHING, then don't watch this. Truly disturbing stuff.

Otherwise, for the love of god see this movie! I can't really say anything else without spoiling the whole experience. Makes Kill Bill look like Mr. Rogers. I really do not want to spoil anything so I won't go into details, but this has to be the most graphic movie I've ever seen. Reminds me a whole lot of Max Payne, that whole style. 10/10, definitely. Great great movie. I just got back from seeing it, and I'm still is awe of it. Sweet Jesus wow!

See this movie!

title: Well, it was good until....
review: Well, I have to say that I had some great expectations for this movie. But as soon i aw on the opening titles that Quentin Tarantino was a guest director, I knew he would mess up this flick by scrambling the story around like Pulp Fiction, or Kill Bill. That is exactly what happened. I thought that the story and the actual movie itself was good. but that whole order thing hes got going can really aggravate some people, and the actual idea to make the story like that is preposterous. Why would you want to do that to a movie. Well, i have to say that if the movie were any different, i guarantee it would have never gotten an 8.5 or whatever rating it got.

title: Twisted genius
review: Finally, 2005's first brilliant movie. I've been waiting patiently, and it's finally here. I loved every sick, disturbing minute of Frank Miller's comic book-translated film 'Sin City,' for a lot of reasons. I loved that it didn't take itself too seriously; how witty and surprisingly funny the script was; and most of all how no character was completely innocent, there was no hero. everyone was a hooker, or a serial killer, or a bad cop or whatever. The movie is stylistically mesmerizing...had it been translated without any special effects or without the black and white, the excessive violence would have been a thousand times more disturbing, which could have distracted from the movie. The soundtrack was brilliant, even the acting was perfect. This movie obviously isn't for everyone; and its unconventional style and structure clearly caused a lot of critics to dislike it, but from a movie lover's point of view, I enjoyed it thoroughly.

title: A Glorious Film-Noir Nightmare Come to Life
review: Mixing good old-fashioned hard boiled crime movie clichÃ©s with modern day violence and special effects, "Frank Miller's Sin City" explodes onto the screen with all the shock and awe that it's graphic novel source material promised. This movie is a monster: a film-noir classic on steroids raised on B-Movies. It exploits the darkest of the dark, and entertains us with it. It touches all the hungry emotions and acknowledges all the base desires we expect and want from such films. Heck, it is perhaps the ultimate example of such films, and therefore takes its place as a new classic. It is beautiful to look at, bold in its style, comic in its outlandishness, and totally audacious in its violence. The film's aesthetics range from "Double Indemnity" to "Kill Bill" (with thousands more in-between), and it takes the audience to an intoxicating and dangerous new place that feels strangely familiar: Welcome to Sin City.

title: The Most Entertaining Film Since Pulp Fiction
review: Sin City is truly a masterpiece, brought to the screen by master action director, Robert Rodriguez and master comic book writer, Frank Miller. I liked El Mariachi, Desperado, and Once Upon a Time in Mexico, but no other Robert Rodriguez film is as stunning and visually outstanding as Sin City. The black-and-white visuals work extremely well. Some critics panned the film, because they seemed to think that the visual trick gets sort of old. Believe me, they are wrong. The style is great and helps to maintain the feel of Frank Miller's graphic novels. Last year, Quentin Tarantino's Kill Bill amazed me and I never thought I'd be more impressed. Although still impressed with the epic Kill Bill, I found Sin City even more impressive and entertaining. Sin City tells three stories based on the graphic novels by Fank Miller. They are: That Yellow Bastard, A Dame to Kill For, and The Big Fat Kill. My personal favorite is A Dame to Kill For, but like Pulp Fiction(my number one favorite film of all time), the other stories are still fun, creative and highly entertaining. Sin City is tons of fun and highly recommended. One of the best films since Pulp Fiction.

title: Why you should see the movie
review:
-great acting -extremely engaging characters -great cinematography -dialogue unlike any film I have ever seen -excellent plot --> well orchestrated -make sure to see this movie while still in theatres -can't comment on the score, was too engaged in the movie (assume it was great) -very dark movie -highly recommend it if you have no problem with violence and disturbing content

I was going to end it here but apparently you need at least 10 lines of text... So here we go: As far as stylized movies goes the only other one that comes to mind at the present moment is Kill Bill. As far as dark movies go the first that come to mind are early Batman movies. Sin City takes both aspects to a new level. However, the film is not simply style without substance but a very intricate and interwoven plot with unique and interesting characters. The dialogue/monologue and acting are unlike any film I have experienced. They provide precise and concise insights to the character's psyche; either that or over-the-top delivery of dialogue. All of the prementioned aspects however, work in perfect concert, such that before you realize it you have been drawn into a dark, fantastical and surreal world which exists nowhere outside of "Sin City."

title: Sin City- Amazing
review:
I just got back from seeing Sin City. This movie is like nothing else I've ever seen. If you haven't had the chance yet, go RIGHT NOW to a movie theatre and see it. Characters are great, the plot is awesome, and the cinematography is second to none. Tarrantino's scene is great, too.

Plus, not to sound like a typical American male, but I love the amount of violence in the movie. This is up there with Battle Royale, and is by far one of the bloodiest movies ever released in the US.

The cast was amazing, too, though I wish Josh Hartnett had a more developed role. He really caught my attention in the beginning, but kind of fell off the map until the end. Minor flaw, though.

Wow. Can't describe how much I love this movie. Hoping for a sequel!

title: Sin City is a very good movie
review: Regardless of who is credited as the director, Quentin Tarantino had his name written all over Sin City. Not only did it have the blood spewing violence similar to that in Kill Bill but it had stories starting and ending at different points then coming back later in the film just like Pulp Fiction. What kept this film from becoming great was its failure to make connections with each story the way that Pulp Fiction did. Had it done this, I would be talking Oscars. Instead, I'm reviewing a very good movie. Despite the long list of great actors that were in this movie, none of them turned in great performances, in fact none of them were even that good. Interestingly enough, however, due to the nature of this film, good acting was totally unnecessary. The movie was made in such a way that it felt like the actors were just reading the captions of a comic book to us. Unlike Spiderman and all the other comic book movies lately, Sin City was truly a comic book that came to life. Nearly every character's thoughts were portrayed through voice over which in a lot of cases can be considered an easy way out, in this case, it works perfectly. I'd be doing the film a disservice if I didn't comment on how artistic it is. It is clear cut, black and white which colored eyes and red blood. This alone could attract an audience but this film is much more than good looks.

title: A Great Movie
review: This movie is really well done. The actors were great and the scenes were amazing. The black and white definitely added to the production of the picture and the amazing likeness to the comic book. The only part that was confusing was the in the very beginning (doens't spoil anything) when Josh Harttman killed the girl in the red dress...this did not make any sense to me because he was not in the rest of the movie at all except the end. All in all, the movie was fantastic. The "Marv" story was definitely the best one, beginning the movie. The connection to everyone also helped the movie along too. The movie might have been a little long, but i did not care one bit.

title: awesome, what a blood bath
review: anyone who likes a damn good action movie or even a semi psychological movie will like this one. The characters are so crazed and out of control that you wont know what to think about them by the end. (which will keep you thinking for a long time) Mickey Rourke is back with a vengeance, his character Marv was by far my favorite as a killer with a mission, delivering some of the funniest one liners I've ever heard in action films. Although i didn't like the rest of the movie as much thats not saying i didn't think it was awesome i just thought Marv's story was amazing. Go and see this one unless your really squeamish or super moral because anyone with an imagination and respect for the art that is film making cannot deny this film its due, its a truly original, well filmed movie deserved of credit. 10/10 Check this one out

title: Like nothing you've ever seen (unless you've read the comic)
review:
Despite "The Matrix", it took almost 11 years for a movie to give audiences the feeling they got when they first saw "Pulp Fiction". And like "Pulp Fiction" and "The Matrix", "Sin City" is like nothing you've ever seen on screen before. It's the birth of a new genre of movies.

It's absolutely Robert Rodriguez best movie (many people I know hate his movies, but I enjoyed "El Mariachi", "From Dusk Til Dawn" and even in a minor note the first two "Spy Kids" movies), and it possibly will be the zenith of his career.

The movie owns all these qualities to Frank Miller's comic series. The source of this movie is one of the most visually astonishing, cinematic works ever put on print. The fact that the movie is a carbon copy of the comic books it's both a point in its favor and a problem.

Yes, "Sin City" is not perfect.

I believe the movie would have benefited of a slower pace. That would have made the movie too long, but then, Rodriguez and Miller would have used a trick from the Peter Jackson School of Novel Adaptations and cut some scenes from the theatrical version and add it in a DVD for fans. Making the movie a carbon copy of the book also restricted the potential of the film medium. They could have done some scenes not featured in the comic book to connect the stories better. In all, the could have avoided the problem with the "Harry Potter" movies, which are a bit boring because the book to film transition was too literal.

"Sin City" is not for everyone. Many people will cringe to the sometimes gratuitous ultra- violent scenes. It works in comics, but on screen may be too much. "Road to Perdition" was a movie that toned down the action and violence of its comic book source because of the same reasons.

I actually cringed at something different: Elijah Wood and Clive Owen, playing the most agile characters of the movie, display their Chuck Taylors as if they were in a commercial. This was really distracting. It happens than even in a world like nothing you've ever seen, you can't avoid some things of this world.

title: Exceptional Cinematography
review:
Robert Rodriguez has never let me down as a first class director. If you look at the credits of this film, Robert is involved in just about every area. What Sin City offers is a fresh view on comic book adaptation. As we get bombarded by film after film of superheros, it is refreshing, to say the least, to have a film that approaches adaptation strictly from an artist's perspective. Teamed with old buddy Quentin Tarantino and having Frank Miller involved throughout the project offers us an exciting look into the actual artist's concept with excellent directing.

The film itself is a great page turner. It keeps you going from frame to frame as the characters rise and fall against the power of a corrupt government. Even in the end, hope is not secured. The characters in the film do it justice as I would expect from the comic. Parts that were obvious to a fan of Frank's work were apparent throughout the film. Probably none more matched than Mickey Rourke as Marv. Marv had to be my favorite character. Hartigan (Bruce Willis)was a close second in character adaptation. Both, however, had the full package and I cannot imagine anyone else playing these parts.

I would recommend seeing this film more than once. I think that Quentin and Robert did Sin City justice by taking on this project. An excellent job of casting and directing is what can make or break a comic book adaptation and this clearly was the best I have seen.

title: awesome piece of art
review:
In an age where Grand Theft Auto and other violent video games and forms of entertainment are accused of corrupting this nation's youth, "Sin City" explodes into theaters as a movie so violent and visually explicit that it will make Pulp Fiction look like a toned-down episode of the Tellitubies.

I would say with confidence that there are more than twenty graphic be-headings and amputations during the course of this film. Swords are driven through peoples eyes and arms and genitalia are constantly amputated throughout the film. The black and white style of the film is actually probably necessary to make the gratuitous violence at least non-vomit inducing. There are few violent lines that this movie does not cross and no pop-culture no-fly zones that it does not experiment with. A priest is executed in a confessional booth. Nuff said.

The violence being touched upon, I would not say this is a bad movie, or even a so-so movie. This movie excels with the style with which it portrays the graphic and undeniably real subject of Frank Miller's ancient comic books sharing the same name. It is humorous to think of these stories of never-ending violence and sex being sold as the same genre as Superman and Batman comics decades ago. The black an white movie in this modern age is a risk, but it pays off as the color splashes that director Robert Rodriguez throws onto characters at certain points of the movie stylistically characterize the people of Sin City in a way that the vacuous script fails to accomplish. The yellow of serial pedophile and rapist Junior makes the disgusting aura of his character leap off the screen. It becomes almost difficult to view his horribly altered body without flinching. A positive use of color is used with the subtle tan allowed for Jessica Alba's (Nancy) skin. This tan makes Alba look more irresistible than in any other movie she has appeared in because it literally gives here the appearance of being an angel among humans.

The only problem with this movie revolves around the aforementioned vacuous script. Rodriguez allows for extremely long internal voice-over monologues from his heroes to give them appropriate humanity along with visual grit. Now in comic books like the one from which this movie was derived, the dialogue is usually about fifty percent thought bubbles to allow for characterization from otherwise un-personalized archetypes. Rodriguez does what the X-Men and Batman movies avoided doing by placing that huge amount of internal speech in the movie as voice-overs. He makes the script of this movie sound like the reading of an actual comic book, not just a script based on characters and ideas from a comic book. This movie is not based on a comic book but is actually a faithful, life-action representation of a comic book and that in itself should garner Rodriguez credit as a courageous filmmaker because it is an extremely daring thing to attempt. It is not unsuccessful, but there are some problems with such a script. For one, it will turn off fans of traditional movie scripts who have never enjoyed comic books. Furthermore, the voice-overs are occasionally awkwardly worded and provide little person to person acting that modern audiences expect. True, Clive Owen, Bruce Willis, and Mickey Rourke are all in this movie, but don't expect a scene of intense person acting between an enraged Owen and a quiescent Willis. This movie is not about the development of these characters, they are merely the vessels allowing for the creation of a twisted and corrupt Orwellian otherworld, a physical canvas for Rodriguez to play with style upon.

While there were many inventive things bout this movie, there were some aspects that got extremely tired by the end of the movie. When someone is shot 100 times in the chest, do not assume they are dead. I would say that almost every character in this movie appears dead but then is magically resurrected by either the powers of fortune or just simply super-human vitality. I mean, it gets ridiculous when Benecio Del Toro's Jackie Boy continues speaking for about thirty minutes of the movie after he has been brutally beheaded and turned into a pez dispenser of vital fluids. It must be something in the water because every character in Sin City can seemingly jump off of incredibly tall buildings and land on cement without any pain. It is humorous that Willis' character Hartigan checks to see if Junior is dead after being shot directly in the neck. Its only funny because we know that he is not dead even though Willis' finds no pulse. His later appearance is practically expected by that point, even though its supposed to be surprising.

The plots are not very interesting. There are twists and more twists, but the gist of the plot is always the brutal execution of one person or the other. By the time all three sub-stories end, supposed heroes Willis, Rourke, and Owen have killed at least 100 people combined. Rodriguez blends the three stories nicely with coincidences and time and characters linking the stories into a web of chaos. By the end of the movie, you feel like you have been on a whirlwind of violence and scantily clad women. It is a perfect movie for guys in their twenties who lie comics, but I can safely say that outside of that demographic few would stomach this film or at the very least venture to call it an enjoyable experience. For the most part, the movie is trivial and needlessly violent, but always interesting and always (because of Rodriguez's one of a kind style) fun to look at, so I would certainly suggest it for the curious moviegoer. Its probably safer to watch Finding Neverland, but if your in the mood for something wild and out of the ordinary, "Sin City" is guaranteed to hit the spot.

title: Action at it's finest
review: This movie has got to be one of the greatest actions flicks of all time. The pace, the subplots, the characters, and the overall progression of the movie captivated me from beginning to end. There were very interesting moments of comedy, but done in a clever way. I gave this movie the highest rating because of its brilliance. I saw a black and white movie (Followers) that didn't impress me before. This movie blended in the old style of film, and new style with perfection. I definitely recommend it to anyone who likes to be at the edge of their seat from beginning to end.The casting was one of the best I have seen in years that actually lived up to their potential. This one is for the ages for sure.

title: KICK @$$ guy movie
review:
I went to see this movie with my friend opening day, we both got in for free because she works at the theater.

After seeing it, all i can say is WOW, that movie is one of the most visual movies ever made, it looked just like a comic book, although the acting wasn't that great, the directing and even the story made up for it.

i call this a "guy movie" because it has what i call "sensless violence" in it, basically there is no reason for the violence, it just happens and it had very little or even none, i cant remember of the one thing i hate in movies, SEX, from what i remember it had no sex scenes throughout the movie, i did have nudity but no sex scenes, and i like that.

overall, i would give this a 25 on a scale of 1 to 10, thats how much i liked it

title: Outstanding
review: This is a wonderful adaption of the comic book series Sin City. You definitely don't have to have ever read the comic book series to enjoy, heck , you don't even need to know what comics are like. It helps but regardless this is an imaginative, thrill ride that leaves you feeling a little dirty inside. It is a dark guilty pleasure to chuckle at some of the groosome characters and scenes that only a comic book could produce. I loved it for its direct transfer of dynamic detail in the form of simple art work and color as found in the comic. I enjoyed the balance of realism and fiction along with the balance of the occasional bright red lipstick.

title: Let this one go and you'll regret it for the rest of your life
review:
Walking into the theater to see Sin City, you likely fall into one of two camps: (a) those who think (nay, know) the movie will be one of the most spectacular films since Kill Bill Vol. 2; or (b) those who think it will likely be a waste of hard-earned green. Place this reviewer firmly in the former band of movie-goers.

Director Robert Rodriguez and co-director Frank Miller, creator and author of the original graphic novels, clearly show their love for the original works. Frame by frame, one could flip through these novels and find the corresponding frame in the film. While Spider-Man, Hulk, and Daredevil were comic book adaptations, Sin City is the original comic amplified and given a shot of Red Bull and Absinthe.

Those who have doubts about the completely digital nature of the film should not fret. Sin City is almost universally convincing as a living, bustling place that a normal human being wouldn't want to be caught dead in. There are only a handful of occasions that one can notice that a green screen was used. But seriously, who cares? When the action is on, it moves at one hundred miles an hour. This movie is not for the faint of heart (or stomach). It's gritty, hard-boiled, and everything a good noir flick should be. And when the characters trade barbs with one another or narrate through their thoroughly FUBAR situation, we get the feeling that what we are witnessing is cinematography and script-writing at its finest (indeed, the vast majority of the lines are lifted straight from the comics).

The acting here is top-notch, but there are a few actors that outshine the others: specifically, Mickey Rourke as Marv, Bruce Willis as Hartigan and Clive Owen as Dwight. All three of these actors are thoroughly convincing in their respective roles. We feel their anger, their outrage, their despondency. They get shot, punched, bitten, and generally pummeled but still get back up to fight a few more rounds. And we can't help but cheer them on. The three graphic novels used to make up this movie take the viewer on a roller coaster of profanity, violence and (admittedly gratuitous) nudity.

Sin City is a movie for film buffs, comic book geeks, and violence-obsessed Tarantino fans alike. Watch it, absorb it, and toss it over in your mind, just as you might if you were to pore over the graphic novel.

title: Great Movie
review: This movie was great!! I recommend it to anyone who is in a mood for a little bit of humor and some fighting sequences!! All the actors and actresses were great!! It was a little bit long but all together it kept me entertained. Robert Rodrigues' best film yet, he surprised me with all of the great special effects and the lighting of the film was awesome!! One of my favorite parts of the movie was in the the second story, when Miho kicks the ass of all the men in the car!! The way she stabbed all of them; so quick!! I loved it because there was women kicking ass and we need more of that!! More women independence!!! A funny thing about the movie is that you don't know when it will end, or when one of the characters will die. Like when Marv was in the electric chair, he said "is that the best you got" and they had to put more power to kill him that was the great thing about the movie!! I thought Jessica Alba was in it more though, she was in it at the end mainly but still she delivered a good performance. I am so glad that a Mexican directed this movie we need more hispanics in Hollywood, I am also glad that he put a lot of good hispanic actors on screen!!

title: new user
review: i just signed up on IMDb basically because i enjoyed sin city so much and figured this would be a great way to find out about other movies like it. any suggestions? i already think I'm going to re-rent pulp fiction and the kill bills; they were the closest thing i could think of. i think this movie was really great, if for no other reason than its entertainment value. i'm also a girl and didn't find it in any way offensive, misogynistic or overly violent. I just thought it was great. I've seen it twice and will probably see it again. hmm, it wont let me submit this unless i have ten lines. is there some way to get around that?

title: skill and the punk aesthetic
review: this film shows the work of a skilled director, who has vision, technique, and discipline, abandoning convention and letting everything, (and i mean everything) hang out there. from the behind the scenes drama (relinquishing his dga card) to the on screen shock, he tells a sublime story about good and evil, about justice and corruption, about heaven and hell, and about the people that populate those regions, without bowing to the powers that be. i will have to soak this film in and see it a couple of more times to place it in a catechism order, but right now, moments after my first screening, "sin city" is about as "right" a movie as i have seen.

title: Jessica Alba is so hot :)
review:
I love her and she was so hot as always in Sin City ;)Anyways I wanna talk about the movie :). 1st of , I'm not really sure If I loved this movie, it was obviously different and much better than the junks they've been making for a long time..I somewhat found it similar to Kill Bill at least some of the action scenes, also the story of it was a little bit all over the place.. It was stylish and I recommend that people should see it. It's a different experience..By the way what was the deal with Goldie's sister what happened to her.I didn't quite catch that part..Overall Sin City is a enjoyable and entertaining you guys should definitely see it..

Peace

title: The most fun I've had at the movies in a long time!
review: I knew pretty much nothing about this movie but the trailers had intrigued me and I like a lot of the actors so I went to see it opening night on a whim. I have been thinking about it all day, especially Mickey Rourke and Benecio del Toro. It is a wonderfully constructed and entertaining movie, and I can tell it was made with great care and affection. The rich black and white mingled with the highlights of color was beautiful to look at. There were many scenes I could tell were lifted right off the pages of Miller's books. The opening credits are a who's who of interesting and cool talent. I already want to see it again before it leaves the theaters!

title: That's a Mighty Fine Coat
review:
Greetings again from the darkness. Very loyal adaptation of the graphic novels of Frank Miller, who also receives directing credit and is seen in the movie as a priest. The driving force behind the movie is the always fascinating Robert Rodriguez ("Once Upon a Time In Mexico"). Legend has it that the opening scene with Josh Hartnett and Marley Shelton was filmed by Rodriguez and delivered as a gift to Miller in an effort to gain the writer's approval to make this film. What we see here is the total Rodriguez vision.

The incredibly deep cast jumps in with both feet and we do get the real feel of the graphic novels (don't call them comic books!). Rodriguez uses color sparingly to prevent the ad nauseum view of blood and to capitalize on the always night, always rainy scenes. The splashes of color are very dramatic and are usually red (blood, sheets, cars) with a few exceptions, such as the crystal blue eyes of Alexis Bledel ("Tuck Everlasting" "Gilmore Girls").

A few of the many characters really stand out. Mickey Rourke, Benecio del Toro and Brittany Murphy all nail their characters and it is always a pleasure to watch Michael Madsen pull off another twisted character. The weaker links are Jessica Alba (yeah, I know, who cares if she can't act) and Rosario Dawson. Bruce Willis and Powers Boothe are fine in their roles, but the most delightful character is Miho played by stoic Chanel model Devon Aoki (daughter of Benihana founder Rocky Aoki). Not sure how much Elijah Wood got paid, but it had to be the easiest money he ever made. My biggest complaint with the film is the miscasting of Clive Owen as Dwight.

Overall, Rodriguez delivers another signature, unique film with great characters, music and cars. He has such a visual style that it is always an education to watch his films. Doesn't hurt to have his best bud, QT, listed a guest director!

title: Shockingly Beautiful
review:
This is one of the only movies I've seen since Pulp Fiction in which such gory, horrific violence is portrayed so artfully. With its gushing white blood and achingly painful torture sequences, this movie both shocked and amazed me.

This will definitely go down in my book as one of the coolest, craziest movies I've ever had the privilege of seeing. Though I wouldn't recommend this movie to the faint of heart, people who love a good noir with lots of amazingly talented actors simply must see this. I understand now why Rodriguez was will to leave the Guild for this movie.

title: Welcome to Sin City(Population: Fading Fast)
review: I had never read Frank Miller's short stories, nor anything else pertaining to Sin City, so I went into the theater tonight with a clear mind. And I think it helped. I loved it because it was all so new to me and if were familiar with his works, then I would have critiqued and pointed out every meticulous detail that differed from the comics. This really felt like an honest-to-God comic book coming to life what with the narration and black and white(save for a few colors) settings. This film featured a huge ensemble cast and each one brought something different to the table. My favorite performance was Mickey Rourke as Marv and I had no idea that was him underneath the make-up. Jessica Alba,Bruce Willis,Michael Madsen,Elijah Wood,Benicio Del Toro,Rosario Dawson(so damn hot!) all fit in nicely. I will not spoil anything because there is too much to cover but the basic premise is Marv looking for the killer of a prostitute named Goldie that had befriended him. There is a lot of violence in this film, but nothing over the top that would be considered controversial. 3 separate stories intertwine to make up an interesting and fresh movie. Destined to become a cult classic and a sequel would be hard-pressed not to be made.

title: Sin City disgraces the name of film noir.
review: Sin City is the worst movie I have seen in a long time. Robert Rodriguez put up Frank Miller's graphic novels almost to the point. His classic comics have been portrayed in a horrible adaptation of black and white where the blood goes back and forth between pigeon poop and red goo. Too be fair you must know Tarantino is my favorite director, but this is not even worthy of his name. It is played and in three different stories that do not come together. Pulp Fiction, which also was Tarantino, was great in how at the end everything made sense, something this movie did not. Most of the characters were not even fully described, which probably means they're hoping to pump out another one of these. The most you could ever hope to get out of this movie is a few laughs.

title: Really Bada$$
