review: this is by far the most interesting and best movie that has been released recently. i have not read any of millers work, however this movie caught me from he very beginning and didn't let go. when the movie first starts you are intrigued as to what is going to happen or how everything fits together. I have to say that Marv is by far, the baddest mother i have ever seen portrayed on screen. the editing is marvelous and the visual effects are stunning. the voice over sound is semi-entertaining, however it fits the movie very well. the movie is very humorous and at times cheesy, but i believe that these elements add to the overall appeal of such a movie, based on comics after all. anyone who watches this movie should go into it pretending to read a comic, and you'll do fine. finally, the colour scheme is perfect, kudos to whoever's idea that was. a perfect 10.

title: A little too long, and not as thrilling and excellent as everyone says, but still pretty darn good
review:
(MINOR SPOILERS) My first experience with Sin City was actually the sexy poster portraying Jessica Alba as Nancy, the exotic dancer. I saw the poster on sale at a horror convention, and thought "hmm that's a movie I'll probably want to see". Then when I saw commercials for it, it looked really good. I was hearing nothing but good things about the movie, which made me all the more excited. But as usual, all they hype behind this movie made my expectations soar, and the movie wasn't as mind-blowing as expected. It was still pretty good and certainly something different, but I was expecting it to be better.

Now I'm pretty sure that I am getting bashed by the reader of this comment, but let me just say that I gave this film a 7.5 out of 10, which I rounded up to an 8. The major complaint I have with the movie is that it was a bit too long; maybe an hour and 40 minutes would have been better, rather than 2 hours and 6 minutes. Some of the scenes were a little boring, but were always followed up with a cool action scene. Other than the longevity, it was a pretty good movie, and certainly original.

Sin City is like a collection of different stories, depicting certain situations of the characters. Bruce Willis is a detective who saves 11 year old Nancy Callahan from an evil child molester, played by Nick Stahl. Then the story is shifted to Marv (played to perfection by Mickey Rourke), a man with a slightly deformed face who falls in love with a hooker, only for her to be murdered while they are passed out drunk. He seeks brutal revenge on the people who murdered the only person who ever really cared about him. Next we move on to Clive Owen's character Dwight, who is now the boyfriend of bar wench Brittany Murphy. Her ex boyfriend appears to be an abusive jerk, so Dwight and his gang of hookers hunt him and his little crew down and also get their gory revenge. We then go back to Willis's character, who is finally released out of jail and fearing that now 19 year old Nancy is in danger. He finds out that she is now an exotic dancer, and is in love with him since he saved her life all those years ago. They are chased down by Nick Stahl's character, who has turned into a hideous yellow monstrosity, thanks to some bad medicine he had to take.

Overall this was a pretty good movie. All the acting was great, especially Mickey Rourke's character. Elijah Wood's Kevin character never speaks, and is just downright creepy. Jessica Alba is certainly sexy as exotic flashdancer (if you will) Nancy Callahan, and Brittany Murphy was actually pretty good herself. The movie is loaded with violence, but since the majority of the film is black and white, the blood is bright white and is not really that gross. There really isn't as much nudity as everyone is saying, just a few short topless scenes and that's about it. This was definitely a good comic book movie, and reminded me of Kill Bill in a way. I recommend this movie, but not if you have a weak stomach.

title: Perfect adaptation
review: I have read all of Frank Millers Sin City books, several times each. I went in and was very critical about this movie. Yes I would have loved to see the scene where Hartigan fantasizes that he has the strenght of Hercules, but other that than the move was perfect. Marv moved the way you figured he would in the book. Dwight was as calm and cool as you hope he would be, and Hartigan as tortured. Yes I swear I could even smell the Yellow Bastard! Perfect! I especially loved watching the first chapter of the Hard Goodbye on screen. Marv busts through the door and makes a run for it, it was like watching the pages come to life. I never would have imagined Mickey Rourke for this role, and I was afraid he would look cheesy...NO WAY, he is right on. He was Marv and will always be Marv for me. Clive Owen was a great Dwight too. I pray for some sort of Oscar on this one!

title: Great movie, loved it but confused on something... (maybe a spoiler)
review: Hey guys question four ya'll are Dwight and Marv the same person? I mean because at times during the Marv Storyline, they were saying stuff your face changed and thats right you are fast and what not? And the similarities between the 2 are kinda a like. Also Mr. Frodo... Hats off to u for your performance! There is like after you become a hobbit! Oh and Bruce Willis and Jessica Alba stole the cake! And brought the whole story together from beginning to end. I own a lot of Movies, and say a lot of movies are good, but i have never seen a movie this good in such a while. Its like one of my favorite movies now its one of my top 10...I'll probably see it a couple more times in theater and can't wait for the DVD!

title: More Than Just All Eye Candy...
review:
I saw this today and it's the first ever R rated movie I've seen in theaters and that I've snuck into. (Just felt like putting that in here.)

The movie has beautiful visual effects. The cinematography was original and great, the sound score was great too, as was the stellar big name cast, and the plot was a good one but it seemed to get stretched out at the end in my opinion.

The big name cast drew me in when I first saw the promos for it, I figured it must be at least decent if it has that many big name actors and the cinematography from the promos also drew me in to want to see this.

I liked how the cinematography was mostly black and white but would have such lively, bright colors. The blood being assorted colors was cool too.

The acting is great (for the most part) but I thought Brittany Murphy's and that other actor's who was in her segment with her (didn't recognize him) their acting could've been a bit better I thought.

I especially liked how all of the ladies of O Town ruled the streets especially Miho with her swords and spears and Gail and those guns (hah, no pun intended!)

I thought towards the end it got a bit stretched out but the more I think about it I really enjoyed it and I'm so tempted to go out and see it 5 times again!

A must see! It's probably a definite that it'll become a classic! Great, original cinematography, amazing all star cast, and amazing plot! This'll be one that people will be talking about for years to come!

Though I thought the ending got stretched out I'm going to give this a 10 just because the more I think about it the more I love it and the more I want to see it again and again!

10/10

title: Sin City pretty good...for Hollywood
review: saw it last night. Pretty cool. most of it was pretty good. the Clive Owen/Rosario Dawson/Brittany Murphy vignette is pretty weak however as none of those three could act their way out of a wet paper bag. Not even Benicio Del Toro could save this one. The other "star" in that particular vignette is Michael Clarke Duncan who also cant act. But the rest was pretty cool. Tons of hot chicks and at times, really over the top especially the violence. i loved it. I was trying to figure out which part Tarantino directed. if it was the Clive Owen part, then thats weak, because we already met "Miho" the first time when she was called "Gogo" in Kill Bill vol.1 (i know its not the same actress, but they are essentially the same character, with Gogo being the better, more original one). so I'm hoping it was one of the other two that directed that part. I also think its funny how the washed up past his prime old man would-be hero type protagonist seems to proliferate Frank Millers work. The Dark Knight Returned again and again in this movie. The whole thing plays out a lot like "Pulp Fiction" in the way the characters and story lines interweave. Also in the half assed attempt at "irreverant" casting. No surprise there I'm sure. The biggest difference in the cast of "Sin City" and the cast of "Pulp Fiction" is that at least in Pulp Fiction, everyone was a good actor. This is NOT the case with Sin City, as it seems for every quality actor cast, there was a crappy worthless "actor" cast. A little too much of Hollywood trying to pass off "actors" who are hot and in right now, instead of actors who can act. Just like the bathroom, you can spray as much deodorizer as you want, and it still smells like sh1t and roses.In addition, of all the comic book (fuckk calling them "graphic novels") silver screen adaptations that Hollywood is pumping out right now this one is the most authentic to the comic of all of them. For example i enjoyed both X-men movies, however i always feel like they are the Hollywood movie adaptation of a comic book, Sin City feels like the actual comic book is on the screen. very authentic feeling which is a real coup for director Roberto Rodriguez. I guess he had some kind of falling out with the Directors Guild of America over sharing the directors credit with Frank Miller. so i guess preserving the integrity of the book was paramount to senor rodriguez. so i give Sin City like a 6 out of 10.

title: Hardcore Adult Roller-coaster
review: Having never read the graphic novels, I went into Sin City only seeing the trailers and some behind-the-scenes extras on a DVD at Best Buy. The cinematography is sharp, crisp and stands out from the use of black and white film (with hints of color at appropriate times.) If anything, the way the flashes of color pull your eyes across the screen really makes you feel you are being coerced into the stories. Black and white seems to befit a Sin City world full of grays. The film also utilizes narration in ways that I have yet to see on screen where even the narrator shifts from one character to another in one sequence. The acting was strong for this film although I do think that Michael Madsen could have sounded less stiff (as if he were reading a teleprompter.) Major kudos for Mickey Rourke's portrayal of Marv. Beautiful women (Alba, Gugino, Rosario, King, Murphey and many more) abound in the film with tons of imperfect men. This is a genre-busting film that firmly portrays the underbelly of civilized man. Not a film for the dainty, as this could definitely be filed as a horror film (the dead bodies become difficult to count) with sharp wit, well-directed action sequences and touching moments. For the first time in my life, I'm upset that I didn't go right back in to see the movie again.

title: Excellent film
review: I saw Sin City the other night and I was simply blown away. From the opening and closing scenes, I loved every minute. I had previously read the graphic novels on which the film was based, so I knew the story lines and the characters. Yet despite this, I was still amazed at how well done everything was. I think many people in the theater were disappointed, but I really couldn't understand why. People certainly thought it was bloodier than they expected, but I knew that the graphic novels created by Frank Miller were full of gore and I was thus prepared for what I saw on screen. The film-noir style of the movie worked really well with the black and white cinematography and the color coding of certain objects drew the eye to every detail. This film was true to the graphic novel in almost every aspect, save for a few changes which were both necessary and beneficial in the end. Even the dialogue spoken by the characters, though at times wooden, was taken directly from the graphic novels. As I said, the dialogue was at points "cheesy," but this film is a film-noir and I felt the dialogue was actually better than what I have heard from the old 1930-1950s gangster films, where lines like "I'll get him good" are quite common. Keep in mind that if you hear a few lines that make you cringe, more than likely they are done like that ON PURPOSE. Sin City was a beautiful film, it has everything for everybody. The cinematography will satisfy people who think they know everything about the aesthetics of film-making, the story runs smoothly throughout (some people may get confused with so many characters and plots, but just try and pay attention) and the action is practically non-stop throughout, for those who go to see films to watch things "blow up." However, this movie is not for the squeamish. It is filled with blood and gore and children should not even be let into the theaters showing this film. In conclusion, I thought Sin City was great. Though looking at things realistically, I think people are either going to love it or hate it. People who have read the graphic novels will love it, those who haven't (with some exceptions) will probably scratch their heads and wonder what the big deal is.

title: Well worth the hype!
review: I've never read a Frank Miller graphic novel, but I was intrigued by the seemingly endless promotions for this film on SpikeTV. After catching a matinÃ©e today, I have to say that this is one of those very rare films that lives up to the hype. Though there were moments when I found the dialog a bit cheesy, the stories, the characters and the amazing cinematography were more than enough to keep me interested. I made a point of not doing any pre-viewing net research, so I was blown away by Mickey Rourke as Marv. I don't even like Mickey R. but I thought he was fantastic in this film. If you're looking to disassociate from reality for a while and you want a roller coaster of a ride, get thee to the nearest showing of Sin City.

title: More hard boiled than a 90 minute egg!
review:
Frank Miller's Sin City series of graphic novels are stark tales of hard boiled men, tough dames, nasty villains, corrupt cops, and steely-eyed killers. It was inspired by the works of Jim Thompson, James M. Cain, Mickey Spillane, Dashiell Hammett, and Raymond Chandler; film noir, and the works of Bernard Kriegsten. They are told in black and white, with occasional splashes of color, in an almost impressionistic style. Miller made a name for himself working on costumed heroes, like Daredevil and Batman, instilling them with his love of crime fiction. When he created his own stories, he left the costumes behind and went full-tilt noir.

Sin City, the movie, perfectly captures the look and tone of Miller's stories, with identical staging and the use of stark contrast in lighting. There are flashes of color, which have greater impact after the noirish scenery. The violence is over the top, in keeping with the comic origins. The characters look the part and the world exists in its own time and place.

The dialogue is pure Miller and sounds like it could have been spoken by Bogart or Cagney. That does present a slight problem, after years of more realistic dialogue in crime dramas. However, the actors deliver it with conviction, although it is a bit shaky in the opening scenes. It gets better as the film progresses. Much of it is delivered as monologue voice-over, in keeping with the traditions.

Mickey Rourke and Bruce Willis are the stand-outs, both able to convincing deliver the dialogue and carry the character. They dominate their scenes, although they have the best material to work from. Clive Owen and Benicio Del Toro are good, but their segment is a bit weaker. The various actresses perform their parts well, but the women of Sin City are a bit lacking in depth. There are no Barbara Stanwycks here.

Robert Rodriguez has captured the look and feel of the source well. The use of digital imagery captures the noir look, without the need for complex sets and lighting. However, it does tend to give everything an artificial aura. Real noir presented a harsh, fantastic world, but it always had substance. Despite advances in technology, the human eye still detects the artifice of CGI.

Overall, the film is quite entertaining, although extremely violent. This is not a date movie (unless your idea of romance is Natural Born Killers). It is modern noir, with the cynicism, corruption, depravity and vice. It's also a hell of a ride! The film is being compared to Pulp Fiction, but they are two different entities. Tarrantino's was a slicked-up homage to pulp storytelling; this is pure pulp. So, grab your favorite coat, a pack of smokes, a blue-steeled automatic, and enter the chiaroscuro world of Sin City.

title: Congrats Frank Miller, Hollywood didn't wreak this one!
review:
I'll admit right now, I've never read the graphic novel of which this film is based and ,being a fan of mystery and noir, am surprised I didn't hear of this series sooner up until the trailers. But a little digging got me caught up and interested in what this movie had to offer (that and the fact that Texas own, Robert Rodriguez, was directing the film :)).

Premise: Based of three tales of the series (That Yellow Bastard, Hard Goodbye, and Big Fat Kill) Sin City follows the "heroes" of their stories as they deal with their situations in the famed city of hard (VERY hard) knocks.

The first act, Hard Goodbye, is my personal favorite of the three. The main character is just so likable and the surprises (saving that you've never read the comics) really come fast. It has a bittersweet ending but around this point, you'll be glad to know that this poor sap went out happy.

Second act, Big Fat Kill, will probably be the most enjoyed of the audience. There's a lot more energy and action here plus the deadpan narration of this story's hero really is worth a chuckle.

Lastly is the final act, That Yellow Bastard, which really is more of a traditional noir tale then the first two and bit of a hard act to follow. However the grip of this hero situation pulls you in and, like Hard Goodbye, it has a very bittersweet end. Still a very well done story.

I'll admit that some of the effects, quick cuts and acting can be a little silly (most of it was done in green screen after all) but the style and beauty of the work more then make up for it, never mind the fact that its done in b&w (if anything it enhances the mood of the stories plus those white on black silhouettes KICK ASS!) Not to mention the A-list actors here and no, for all you haters out there, it more then just attracting an audience. They all really seemed to really get into their roles and bring out the characters. Seriously, for once I was thinking about the characters rather then the actors who WERE the characters. This is a bunch who took the movie's source seriously. Nice and my hats off to them for their hard work.

Definitely one of the best movies of 2005. I wouldn't know if its as good as its source and quite frankly I don't care, it came out good to me anyway. Still if your a fan of the series, check it out. If not, give it a watch anyway though be warned this is a EXTREMELY graphic movie. So if you don't have a stomach for it, I wouldn't bother. And haters if you can look beyond the blood, gore, action, etc...You might just enjoy it.

Overall, a excellent way to kill two hours and enjoy yourself. Check it out!

title: A super-cool film that is perhaps easy to forget...
review:
Sin City is a direct interpretation of Frank Miller's graphic novels of the same name. It shows. Everything is done in a comic-book like fashion. The violence is very much stylized and the characters posses superhuman strength and ability. This is not necessarily a bad thing. The overall style of the film is something I have never seen in films before. The environments pull you into the twisted world that is 'Sin City'. And this city is dark...very dark. One of the main issues surrounding this movie is its adult content. I personally don't think that the excessive violence was offensive because it is shown in such an over-the-top way that it is often comical. There is a huge difference between comic-book violence and real-life violence. For example, in Sin City a main character is able to take ten bullets to the chest and keep on ticking. One of my favorite things about this movie is that it made me laugh when people were dying the most horrible of deaths (which is one of the reasons I think people who have a problem with the content will not enjoy this film at all). However I did have one problem with the violence. By the end of the film, so many characters had died that the important deaths of main characters had no effect on me whatsoever. Some of the dialogue was also so over-the-top that I found myself laughing when I shouldn't have. Specifically Michael Madsen (who I love), sounded like he was reading his lines directly from the pages of the comic-book. I would have liked to see some straying from the exact duplication of Frank Miller's works. It was also clear that each shot in the film was based on a frame from the comic. This means that the camera hardly moved (beautiful camera movement is what Robert Rodriguez does best in my opinion), and when it did move I was amazed at how nice that shot looked.

Overall I have to say that Sin City is a cool movie that is definitely worth seeing (maybe not remembering) if you don't have a problem with the content.

title: Excellent!!!!!!
review: I love the comic books, so I loved this movie. I have never been so excited to see the film adaptation of a comic book- It was great. I don't care anything for Robert Rodriguez, but I gotta give him a huge thumbs up. This movie is word for word and action for action. He did not stray, he remained true, and gave the fans what they want. I think this is one of the best comic book movies ever, besides Tim Burton's Batman. All the actors did a good job and even though I don't consider many of them great actors, they portrayed the parts and were very believable. The dialogue and actions were outlandish and extreme, but that is Sin City. It is two hours of bliss in my opinion, and I wish Mickey Rourke would win something for his portrayal of Marv- Superb! Elijah Wood was a perfect Kevin as well. I am a young female, and the violence did not bother me. Most are saying this movie is for guys, but it isn't. It is for fans, and I say the more decapitations the better!

title: No one can make a film of Frank Miller's graphic novels!
review: I love Frank Miller's graphic novels. When I heard that a film was coming, my thoughts were: "No one can make a film of Frank Miller's graphic novels...and do them justice." Well, after catching the 10 AM Saturday showing of "Sin City", all I can say now is "Wow!". Rodriguez--with Miller at his side--hit it out of the park...out of the city...off the planet! If you're a fan of Rodriguez &/or Tarantino, this is what it is all about...THIS IS THE REAL SH*T!!! The Male 'Heroes' are gritty, dirty and violent. The Ladies are lovely & lethal. The Villains deserve all they get. This film truly captures the mood, feel, pace and spirit of Miller's works. I wanted it to be good...it was better than that. If you fancied "Pulp Fiction"...this will blow you away. Did I mention that I like the film? Thanks, Marv!

title: Sin City - Instant Classic
review: Now, I've came out of movies with a high that clouded my judgment and caused me to believe I had just seen the most badass movie of all-time (The Matrix Reloaded being the most recent culprit). But I can say with all the assurance in the world that Sin City is one of the most innovative movies of all-time, and was captivating from the first frame until the last one. It's easy to pigeonhole this as Pulp Fiction for comic freaks, but that's unfair: Sin City stands on its own as a modern cinematic masterpiece of comic-noir that will be unrivaled for years to come. Coming from a huge Robert Rodriguez fan, this is easily his best movie, and probably will remain his best. If Rodriguez can do any better than this, I'd make sweet love to him.

title: Sin City was OK-- contains (very)small spoiler
review: I LOVE movies but I didn't LOVE this movie. It was OK. I saw it last night and I will say it is rated R for a reason. If you are at all squeamish or don't like sex in movies then don't see this one. The story was OK but I didn't understand it until afterwards. Keep in mind that all of it (excluding the beginning with Bruce) is happening at the same time. Maybe it will help in the understanding. The best part of the movie, since it was in black and white, was the great usage of spot colors. It added a lot. The colors and lighting and directing angles were awesome!! The actors were great in it and the bits of comedy was a lot of relief for a serious movie. Go watch it, it was good but not the best..in my opinion. I guess it depends on the movies you like. Would I see it again? Yeah. Buy It? Prolly not.

title: Visually Stunning / Brilliantly Conceived Comic Book World
review:
This movie sweeps through the graphic novel world of Sin City, without faltering or once removing us from the reality of that world... a gritty dark world of violence, perversion, and BEAUTY.

The highest praise is that there really isn't a movie to compare Sin City with. It faithfully transforms Frank Miller's world and exceptional casting brings his characters to life.

There are a few plot holes and some dialogue that probably read better on the page but when a movie is as original and has the raw beauty of Sin City...I can forgive many sins.

This is one of those movies you will want to see on the BIG screen...probably more than once.

title: This Decade's "Pulp Fiction"
review:
"Sin City" rocks! It's the "Pulp Fiction" of this decade, yet still cinematicly groundbreaking. Robert Rodriquez has emerged as the greatest director of his generation. I truly believe that within a few more years his name will be right up there with Hitchcock and Spielberg.

Another similarity to "Pulp Fiction" is that this film may do for Mickey Rourke's career what PF did for John Travolta's. Rourke is terrific behind facial prosthetics that give him a "graphic novel" (the current politically correct term for "comic book") profile with a nose that remains to its tip in a perfect straight line with the forehead. Benicio Del Toro, while appearing less of a physical caricature than Rourke's character "Marv", is even more unrecognizable under his makeup. Bruce Willis perfectly inhabits his role as a tough but sensitive cop like he has done countless times before. Clive Owen shines in his heroic role as well.

And as for the ladies... what can I say, I'm now in love with Carla Gugino! Marv gets a view of her nearly naked backside as she leans over a sink - he can't stop staring (and neither could I). Not to mention what we see of her other side - whoa! Jessica Alba, Rosario Dawson, Brittany Murphy, et al - all dressed to accentuate their curves. Got to admit that this film got my loins to tingling several times.

Be warned, there's lots of stylish violence in the "Kill Bill" vein. If that and some nudity and sexual situations don't bother you, by all means, GO SEE "SIN CITY"!!!

title: SIN CITY *minor spoilers*
review: I was so excited for this movie for weeks and last night I finally saw it and, I'm happy to say, it did not disappoint. Being a big Robert Rodriguez fan as well as a fan of comics, I already had the fan boy thing going but I think even non-fans will find something they like. Firstly, the look of the film is amazing and will get most of the press. It really does look like Frank Miller's drawings come to life, even down to the stylized white (or in some cases yellow) blood. The flashes of color add much to the stark black and gray. But what I was most impressed with was how well the stories unraveled. Each of the leads held their own, though Marv (played masterfully by Mickey Rourke)is the heart of the film. His story has the highest body count but Marv is still the most sympathetic character of the bunch. The action is phenomenal and as graphic as the novel. This film is dripping with noir and despite the entirely computer generated environment, it was easy to forget Sin City isn't a real place. I found myself so immersed in the City that afterwards I unconsciously began to narrate the walk to the car and wishing corrupt cops would pull up and attack. This is one of the most innovative and downright awesome films I've seen in recent years. Rodriguez and Miller's film accomplishes much cinematic ally without sacrificing any of the graphic novel's integrity. The scene Quentin Tarantino directs (I'll leave it to you to pick it out) fits perfectly within the film. Kudos to all involved. 9.8/10 (no movie gets a 10)

title: unique and amazing
review: This is the first movie I've seen in years that is so unique that it really has no basis for comparison. It has no resemblance to other comic book movies and projects the feel and imagery of a comic better than anything I've ever seen (including many comics). I enjoyed everything about this movie from the dialogue and scenery to the action and gore. It was all handled in a very artistic and creative manner that really sets it apart from any other film to date. There were some weaker points in the film but very few, and the overall positives vastly outweigh the negatives. It is also a very violent movie with no lack of death and dismemberment so if you can't handle that kind of thing then it may not be for you. This movie also has so many recognizable faces throughout the whole movie that it's really a credit to the actors and the directors that it doesn't become a distraction. Every character fits and no one seems out of place. Mickey Rourke in particular was absolutely perfect. This was a wonderful movie.

title: One of the coolest movies you will ever watch
review: While some of you who pretend to be appalled by this travesty of a movie, others will dazzle at its overwhelming success. From the first minute to the very end, my friends and I, along with the entire theatre, were laughing, cringing, cheering, and having a blast. It's a fun movie for the not so easy-eyed audience. Compare it to Kill Bill and Pulp Fiction. This raw movie turned out to be unbelievable. The cast was superb, the action was intense, and the story line was flat out sweet. Marv kicked ass, and Bruce Willis did a perfect job. So suck it up, pay the ticket, and have some fun with this movie. Stop letting your conformity take over your kid side and just enjoy what the directors intended you to enjoy. I give this movie 10/10, and would recommend it to anyone!

title: Impressive
review: I saw "Sin City" last night and was amazed at how much I really enjoyed it. I am not a comic book lover and never have been, I have nothing against them, I just always wrote them off as a guy thing. After seeing this movie though, I find myself wanting to go to the book store and checking out some of the other graphic novels out there. I thought Mickey Rourke did a fantastic job. He hasn't exactly been on the top of the A-list in the last several years, but I think this movie will put him higher up on the Hollywood food chain. The movie was over-the-top to say the least. It has a ridiculous quality to it that is easily overlooked as long as the viewer keeps in mind that it is based on a comic book. My only criticism of the film is Alexis Bledel. I just don't think she was right for the role of "Becky". I credit my dislike of her in this movie, however, to the fact that I am an avid Gilmore Girls watcher so it was hard for me to separate her from that character and visualize her as a hooker. Visually I was stunned at the way the film was shot. At different points during the movie I could actually see these characters on the page of a comic book. Without a doubt I think this is one of the best movies I've seen so far this year. People complained about the violence and the moral deficiency portrayed on screen without any real inspirational message at the end. Frank Miller created a world where even being good can mean having to be bad and I loved that about it. I go to the movies for escapism. I can't say I watch movies to learn anything or to be taught a moral lesson, I watch them to entertained without any regard to subject matter. Sex and violence in a movie doesn't bother me as long as at the end I felt like I had taken a trip somewhere else while never leaving the theater seat and "Sin City" did that for me.

title: True to the Comic book version
review:
Very impressive this movie is an exact rendition of the original comic book version.

Words for words they even kept the same camera angles relative to the comic book panel shots.

Go find a copy of the comic book and read it.

In fact you will need to read three books.

Comic 1991: Sin City: The Hard Goodbye Comic 1994: Sin City: The Big Fat Kill Comic 1996: Sin City: That Yellow Bastard

Enjoy some of Frank's finest work.

Do a search for 'Frank Miller Comic books' There's tons of other great stories written and draw by this remarkable creator.

Don't wait for the movie version to come out read the real thing.

title: My thoughts on the film..
review: This film is visually stunning, and although I've only glanced once at the graphic novels from which it is inspired, the parallels in appearance and action are incredible. The characters seem to have stepped right off the page. The gory scenes hold nothing back, but still find a way to be beautiful. It is like paint is being sloshed around on a canvas, not blood all over victims. If you are not into these type of violent, action films, I would still recommend seeing it in the theater solely for visual purposes. The only other thing I would like to say is that after critiquing beautifully made, ingenious films, made solely from the film itself and raw materials, it is hard for me to feel like the filmmakers didn't cheat with this one by using state-of-the-art equipment, an unbelievable budget, and numerous experts to perfect every detail. However, it would be a shame to never see the true possibilities of today's film-making technology, and although there is something to be said for a filmmaker who makes a stunning film by himself with the money in his/her pocket, this movie is quite frankly, cool as hell.

title: Sin City is a masterpiece!
review:
Robert Rodriguez has spent his entire career looking for the best way to deliver stylized mayhem to audiences. He's found it.

His unholy alliance with comic book superstar Frank Miller has yielded a truly great film, a triumph on all fronts. It is beautiful to look at, stimulating to listen to, performed with zest and power by a fantastic cast. Sin City is a ride, a dark journey into the depths of a world first seen in Miller's classic comics.

The film is so faithful to the comics that it feels like a comic book come to life. The characters appearances are so similar to the comic book images that at times it is difficult to tell the difference. But as great as Miller's understanding of comic books and the need for comic movies to be faithful to them is, Rodriguez' understanding of movies rivals it. He knows the technology, he knows the process, and he loves it.

It's this love that comes across on the screen. Sin City cannot truly be described, it can only be experienced. Enjoy!

title: Words cannot describe this Movie
review: I was amazed at so many different aspects of this film. The way its filmed alone is unique in comparison to any other movie you will ever see. The use of black and white imagery and vivid color on specific parts combine to make a unique and lasting visual experience. This movie presents the watchers with a truly amazing look at possibly the most corrupt place ever imagined. It is after all "Sin CIty" and after you leave the theater you will find yourself pondering some of the gruesome images you have seen, because there is nothing else out there like this movie. Thats all that can be said is that this movie is unique and all i can hope is that there is more movies like this to come. I want to start a Sin city fan club. I will be seeing it again soon and that is no lie.

title: nerd alert!
review: for all you comic nerds out there that complain that the movies don't follow the books closely enough, this one is for you. we're talking PANEL BY PANEL here. almost all the dialogue is word for word as well, and when yer adapting something from a Frank Miller book, that's a damn good idea! not a perfect movie, but a buttload of fun, and the audience was totally absorbed. i haven't been in a crowd that quite in a long time. i heard a rumor that they plan to make two more of them, as well....as long as the same people are involved, i'm all for it! if you want to see something different in the movie theater, go see this movie! p.s.--Mickey Rourke is amazing as Marv, and watch for Frank Miller's cameo.

title: Dead on.
review:
Ever since I saw the trailer I've been waiting to see this movie. Just the look of it caught my eye, and it has addicted me ever since. After seeing the movie, I can say that Sin City definitely did not let me down. I read the graphic novels awhile back, but after seeing the trailers I had to go revisit them to get ready for the movie. Even in the first scene of the movie, you can tell that a movie has finally retained the artistry of a graphic novel in its conversion to cinema. Finally, the spirit of a comic book has been kept alive in the transition. Finally, a movie has been made that is incredible faithful to the material it is based off of. Finally, a movie has been made of which you have a hard time saying, "The book was better." Well, to clear things up, this movie is definitely not for the faint of heart. It is chock full of violence, has a bit of nudity (though not really sexual), and is full of those themes we love to hate such as pedophilia, prostitution, torture, etc. Yet, the movie doesn't really hold any of things seriously. It's hard to explain. In some way, they were able to make this movie full of glorified violence (though much of it is "comic-booky" meaning lots of fake blood spurts, think Kill Bill Vol. 1) and immoral EVERYTHING and do it in a properly tongue in cheek manner. If you let yourself laugh, instead of sitting there shaking your head at how the world is going to hell because of movies like this, you will enjoy yourself.

Finally, the movie is good at telling the story. You would think that the plot would get lost in all the bloodbath, but it doesn't. Of course, the plot isn't incredibly deep full of twists and turns, but it gets the job done in that properly retro-noir flavor. And for once the big name actors are there for a reason. They can almost make you take seriously the purposefully cheesy dialogue that hearkens back to old Film Noir movies. And even though I knew what was going to happen, they kept me glued every minute.

If you are looking for a visually stunning and incredibly entertaining action flick, go see Sin City. But leave your morals at the door and not take everything so seriously, and you'll be in for a hell of a ride.

9.5/10

title: The greatest recreation ever!
review: Holy crap! Sin City is the sweetest movie I've ever seen. The story line is great, it has everything. There is action from beginning to end. The sub plots come together perfectly into one. You are immediately a fan of every new character within the first minute they hit the screen. Sin City pushes every line without crossing any. The action scenes are unbelievable, the sequences perfectly emulate comic book like stunts but never look totally unrealistic or cartoonie. There is plenty of comedy but never tips over into being corny. And you have to love all the hot chicks and plentiful ass shots. Sin City is visual perfect!! The writing is excellent, and this would be a sure win for best direction if not for having more than one director. If you are on here to see what others said then I don't need to tell you anymore. If you are seeing what people say before you see it, then stop reading right now and go to the theater. I am sure I will be there a few more times, and I have never seen a movie twice in the theater.

title: Fantastic, yet morbid.
review: Sin City is a great film, with more than enough bloodshed, violence, and exposed women to satisfy any testosterone-fueled moviegoer. However, what is really surprising is the subtle intellect that waits beneath the surface. This film is witty and poignant, the script is fantastic. However, the few complaints that I do have can be overlooked. Personally, I thought that there was too much blood. Then I realized that this movie is based on a comic. One should go to this movie expecting to see gallons of blood and almost non-stop violence. In short, the cast is fantastic, the acting almost flawless, and one of the best endings to a movie I've seen in quite a while. Highly recommended for action fans.

title: Faithful, maybe too faithful, adaptation of the comic
review: After hearing that this movie was going to be shot against green screens, and then presented in black and white, with splotches of color, and was not going to divert from the comics at all, I was a little dismayed, that is a big undertaking and I didn't think anybody could do that. Well, Rob and Frank did, and I absolutely loved the movie. A little over the top, a little too much violence, and sometimes the narration really wasn't needed. As a fan of the comics, I think that Rob and Frank surpassed the comics and made a very good movie that should rank up there with the best, if not for the feel of the entire movie. To all of the Carla Gugino fans out there, wow, what a body! IMHO, the best part of the movie is when we first see her. WOW.

title: For Comic Book and Action Fans, a Must-See
review:
What an incredible, unique, intense, and stylish film.

Based on Frank Millers original comic book, Sin City, this movie is a collection of three vignettes all taking place within the same time-span and in the same location in Sin City, where it is perpetually raining and overflowing with corruption, prostitution, and murder. Each of these vignettes are relatively independent of each other, yet this is a wise choice. This movie moves with incredible speed, much like a comic book would, jumping from scene to scene. At this rate, having three stories is appropriate and keeps it interesting.

In the movie, we follow the conquests of Marv out for revenge for his one true love, Hardigan trying to play the good cop in a bad city, and Dwight as he meddles in the affairs of prostitutes.

As can be told by the previews, the movie is done completely in black and white, except for a few artistic choices for color. Sometimes blood is red, certain eyes are blue or green, and the Yellow Bastard is yellow in complete. This follows the style of the comic book, but is a wise and stylistic decision - the grays make the city even more dim, with the few hints of color act as a wonderful contrast. Furthermore, the movie makes a lot of daring shots that are almost frame-for-frame like you would see in a comic book, also adding to the atmosphere. Overall, Sin City is an artistic masterpiece and original in it's cinematography choices.

What I loved most about this movie were the characters and the acting. Each of the characters had something unique and intriguing to give to the screen...a past, a trait, or merely their unique appearance. You only get a few spare minutes with many of the bit players, but you find yourself wanting to know more about each of them, villains included, so you find yourself intrigued for the entirety of the movie. Furthermore, the casting was right on target. Though star-studded, which can be critical death for many box office hits, each person was placed in the right character, and they pull it off expertly.

I am particularly intrigued by Elijah Wood's character and the fact that he was chosen for it; watch and see for yourselves what I mean.

The directing and writing of this movie are excellent. Indeed, if you are a fan of the Sin City comics, you will be pleased by the accuracy of this movie...certain scenes are frame-for-frame and word-for-word from the original comic book. The story lines plots keep you guessing and on the edge of your seat for the movie's entirety. The dialogue is smart and edgy, and the inner plots will have you wanting more by the end.

Indeed, Sin City does an amazing job at creating an atmosphere and a world that will make you feel transported into it's grim world. You leave the theater half expecting/half wanting for the lobby and streets to be black and white.

As a disclaimer, the movie is very violent and has quite a lot of nakedness. After all, a great number of the characters are prostitutes, and Quentin Tarantino guest-directed, which might say something about the violence level. (Think Kill Bill.) But, that said, if you can handle the R rating and a little bit of blood, Sin City is Must See.

title: Excellent in Almost Every Way
review: This movie is superb all the way across the board. The performances were spot-on and even occasionally over the top, especially with the characters of Clive Owen and Bruce Willis. But, seeing as how the movie is based on a graphic novel, the performances are appropriate. The movie is a 130 minute thrill ride, shocking the viewers (who haven't read the graphic novels) roughly every 10 minutes, if not more frequently than that. My only beef is with the dialogue. Rodriguez claims that he didn't even write a script, that he just transcribed what was in Miller's graphic novels. As such, the dialogue, not always, but occasionally, can be a little cheesy or melodramatic; sometimes, graphic novel dialogue doesn't always translate well onto the big screen. Other than this, the movie is spotless.

title: Great!
review: I must say this was one of the most enjoyable movies I have seen since Pulp Fiction. The cast is amazing, a cool mix of old school Hollywood giants and fresh talented faces. What I must comment on is that how happy I was to see Mickey Rourke back on a major role like this. He is simply one of the greats of the American cinema, I put him right next to Brando, Di Nero, and the others. The magic he creates is amazing. In this maximum film he had put out an Oscar worthy performance. On the other hand to watch Bruce Willis is like watching Al Pacino, he delivers big and makes it worth it. The perfect mix of the other characters, beautiful cinematography, erotica, and score made this clearly the best film of the year so far. I am ready for the DVD.

title: amazing
review:
As a 15 year old girl, I think this movie was amazing. There was a lot of violence and nudity, but hey, the titles read "Based on Graphic Novels by Frank Miller". The colors (or lack there-of) were perfect. Everything was great. The narration was very good. Very clichÃ© to some though. But it's based on a comic book. The direction was very good. The movie had a few plot-points and story lines, but it all tied in perfectly in the end. Bruce Willis was never in a bad movie. Jessica Alba is beautiful, I thought she'd be better than a stripper though after what she had been through. I was very surprised about how she tied in. That one made me say "Wow". You'll see what I'm talking about when you see the movie. The acting was pretty decent. I liked basically everything. It's a very good movie so go out and see it.

-Christine

title: the best comic book adaptation ever!
review: its Friday and I'm going to see sin city we get to the theater... i awake Saturday glad i spent my money on this movie... OK let me start first of all everyone in this movie were great they really captured the spirit of the comic story(as many have said this movie has 3 stories each connected to the other but the beginning and the end both have the hit-man (hartman) who has a very creepy look and sound to him (i for one will be using the *can i offer you a smoke* pickup line from now on) we then jump to more boobs and sex in 5-6 minutes than most porn movies... Marv awakes to Goldie dead and so begins the beautiful action scenes the violence in this movie has 3 styles "mild, over the top,and plain out disgusting" Marv actually jumps through a windshield and you see the cuts bleeding constantly sometime red sometimes white after we meet his parolee officer we finally see one of the most creepy characters i have ever seen in a movie (wood) who is a cannibal with long sharpened fingernails with silence of a ninja and the claws of a angry female after Marv's story (which ends nicely) we move on to the most entertaining of the 3 stories (old town) a town ruled by women (valkries) we are then introduced to *jackie-boy*(toro) who is a *** and a woman beater with a voice so deep you would think Vader is in his soul but he gets his 3 or 4 times in a row skimming over the really good parts just know you can definitely tell when Terantino jumps in *give ya a hint think pulp fiction reservoir dogs and kill bill* and comes MIHO Miho is absolutely the coolest chick in this movie killing with a animal like instinct but keeping with the group SOON we get along to the final story about what happened to old Mr.Hartigan who saved little Nancy but was back-stabbed by his partner jeez that yellow bastard he gets what coming to him... frank miller did a great thing letting this movie be made this is probably one of the best movies to see in theaters and i definitely suggest seeing it

title: Amazing!!! (11/10)
review: This movie was absolutely amazing. Each of the characters had their own unique personality. The stories sucked you in from the beginning. Robert Rodriguez brought his own form of film-making to this project and it was really well worth the wait. Marv couldn't have been played by anybody other than Mickey Rourke. The visuals were stunning!!! They emphasized the colors wonderfully!! Each actor/actress was perfect for their part. You were basically just watching the comic books on-screen flipping the pages in your head!! From the beginning, I thought this movie was gonna be amazing but not this amazing. I especially like Elijah Wood's character Kevin. Definitely one of the greatest movies I've ever seen!!!!!!! (11/10)

title: 'Sin City' is sinfully and simply wonderful...
review: When I saw this trailer a month early, I have to say that I was more than excited and more than ready to see it. And before I go on any further, it must be said that Frank Miller is a comic genius. Anyone who can think of a simple storyline and create it into something like that deserves to be mentioned. I thought "Sin City" was probably as good as it could have gotten. However, when I first saw the movie, I was expecting a little more--but, hey? Who doesn't expect that from a movie?? I think the critics' review of "It's a comic book brought to life and pumped with steroids!" is probably the perfect and best way to describe it. I'll probably be there the first day it hits DVD because I was there for it on opening night. This is probably going to go down as a movie to remember on MY list.

title: Best Movie Period
review: As a loyal fan of the Sin City comics, I can confidently and proudly say that the movie is even better. In one word the movie is FLAWLESS. Rodriguez has created a surreal world that is jaw-dropping to see. But unlike other popular movies like Spiderman, you never notice that you are watching special effects and it all feels real.The action is stunning and hilarious at the same time. The actors bring their characters to life better than I hoped for and Mickey Rourke and Benicio Del Toro are particularly phenomenal. I could not ask for more from this absolutely ass-kicking, smart, funny,wild ride that even features gorgeous women that even the morons who don't appreciate this movie will like.

title: Stunning, perfectly executed
review:
A great movie, Sin City isn't like your average comic book movie were it's just the comic characters and some of the story turned into a movie, it is as if the actual pages of the comic book came alive. Extremely stylish. The movie is in black & white, with touches of primary and secondary color. Like a dress in red, or blonde hair yellow, eyes blue. It in the most unique movie I've ever seen, not just for the style, but the way things played out. They didn't pull any punches, it is extremely violent/gory, but not in a gruesome way. The violence is done with style, not as over the top as Kill Bill Vol.1, but it has some humor to it. I don't think there is anything about Sin City that could have been done better, everything was executed perfectly. But it isn't all style, the characters feel so authentic - in a comic book way. They are not simply going through the motions, you knew why they are doing what they are doing, it is in their character. The cast is excellent, good acting all around. And beautiful female nudity.

If you like anything Quentin Tarantino's done, you'll love this movie. But if you think it's just some comic book based movie to take the kids to, don't.

title: Wicked, brutal fun!
review:
Sin City is without a doubt the single most loyal comic book adaptation ever filmed, a distinction previously held by The Rocketeer. How did such a loyal adaptation come out of the notoriously fickle and haphazard Hollywood movie machine? Easy...it didn't. Director Robert Rodriguez shot the film independent of Hollywood influence, securing the financing on his own and shooting the film his own way. Sin City also has the benefit of direct, hands-on involvement by series creator Frank Miller, who actually co-directed the film alongside Rodriguez (a move that cost Rodriguez his membership in the Director's Guild and his next scheduled job at Paramount). The original Sin City graphic novels were used as storyboards for the film, with Miller drawing some new bits to make sure the storyboards were as complete as possible. The entire film is shot digitally in front of a green screen, allowing the filmmakers to create the locations and car chases using CGI, which maintains the comics' surreal flair. These factors combine with a stellar cast to make an incredibly peculiar movie, but a great one nonetheless.

Adapted from three of the Sin City graphic novels (and one of the numerous short stories Miller has produced over the years), the storyline is actually quite simple--the various tarnished champions of this "town without pity" find themselves in conflict with the power brokers of their extremely corrupt city, and violence ensues--but its non-linear storytelling sets it apart from the typical revenge play. Each story in Sin City has some connection to the others, adding the dimension of an Easter egg hunt to the proceedings as the audience figures out just what takes place when. There is quite a bit of repetition, both thematic and situational, but said repetition is obviously intentional, driving home the sheer brutality of the film's titular setting.

The cast is sheer genius, from the smallest parts to the leads. Bruce Willis, Mickey Rourke, Jessica Alba, Benicio del Toro, Clive Owen, Rosario Dawson, and a dozen more avowed fans of the original comics literally bring Miller's characters to life, warts and all, for better or for worse. The performances are over-blown in the classic film noir model, creating an atmosphere that is in no way realistic...but realism isn't Sin City's goal. This is crime fiction gone off the deep end, and it's a riot. You see, here's the thing about Sin City: it's an absurdly overwrought, unapologetically brutal riff on the pulp fiction of a bygone era, and it's incredibly over-the-top...maybe even "hammy." In fact, despite its violence (which is extreme and pervasive) and its sex (handled with much more restraint than the violence, although there is quite a bit of nudity), Sin City is positively hilarious...provided you come into it knowing what the movie is supposed to be. Luckily, the cast and filmmakers are obviously very aware of what made the original comics such a guilty pleasure in the first place.

In short, if you like the Sin City comics, Sin City the movie will not disappoint. If you don't like the comics, you won't like the movie.

It doesn't get much simpler than that, really...

title: Thank You Robert ,Thank You Frank,Thank You Cast !!
review:
As I sat at the well- respected theater ( the kind that serves beer ) that was kind enough to show this film at 12 o'clock am 4-1-05, I contemplated, will this be it? Will this be the film that the real comic( or should I say graphic novel ) fans have waited for? Was it now worth sitting through the previous comic-book movie attempts Hollywood had given us?( minus the good ones X-2,Daredevil,Hellboy,Blade2,League of Ex..,and Spiderman2) Then it happened. The lights dimmed. The previews started. These were the hardest thing to sit through!! ( except I can say I deeply enjoyed the EpIII trailer )Then I saw the flames. As the Troublemaker Studios screen came on I held my Todd McFarlane: Marv-holding-Kevin's-head action-figure close, I kissed my( 8 months- pregnant) wife sitting next to me and spoke these words "I'll see you in 2 hours!". Then this 32 year old comic fan sat for the aforementioned 2 hours and felt every emotion and every word that these two creators placed in front of me (us). This work of art is the reason that films show motion and play sound. This joy is the proof that real talent and determination have finally showed their faces, larger than life,on film. Thank you Robert,Thank you Frank.That's what a comic-book looks like when it moves!!!! ( I guess that I have found new reasons to complete my massive tattoo habit with more quality comic art!!!)

Sin-cerely,

Roberto Florencio Gil

Another voice from Texas!!! Baytown!!!

title: Fantastic
review: I have always been a big fan of Frank Miller's comic books, and I am not disappointed by his writing here, which is as solid as anything else he's done, but what is surprising is how well the visual side of things was done, but I suppose that a lot of credit would have to go to co-director Robert Rodriguez. Besides co-direction Rodriguez also shot, edited, and helped score the film. The acting was top notch with great turns by Clive Owen, Mickey Rourke, Bruce Willis, and Benicio Del Toro, but I felt that the Ladies in the film Rosario Dawson, Britney Murphy and Jessica Alba, had little more to do than be damsels in distress and really, really, effective eye candy. The place where the acting and writing really shines is in the voice over dialog, it seems as if plucked right out of a 1950's film noir, the right mix of grit and nerve with some tenderness and a feeling of wanting to do something right. There are three vignettes in the film each focusing on Rourke, Owen, and Willis, and they all fit together eventually, as any serpentine plot should! What I really appreciated was that while each was from different sides of law enforcement, each seem to have a similar thought pattern, manner of speech, and ideology, showing that while their methods are different essentially these are just guys down on their luck and looking to help somebody out. Overall I though this film was really strong, excellent use of color and sound to help give a comic book feel and look and excellent performances, unfortunately only from the males in this case, and an overall cohesiveness in a pretty disjointed narrative. I really hope that Miller decides to put out another film and if there is a God it will be Dark Knight Returns. Brandon

title: Episodic Hardcore Unrelenting
review:
The movie starts off strong with a classically Noir situation of an over-the-hill cop letting things get personal, then speeds up quickly with an unrelentingly disturbing and awe inspiring revenge plot. The entire movie is essentially driven by the inner turmoil of the three main characters.

The book-ending episode featuring Bruce Willis might qualify as the most touching, but for me nothing's better than the completely raw visceral ride that Mickey Rourke's episode takes us on. For this episode, I think I can count on one hand the number of shots that don't include nudity, sex, blood, babes, or awesomely drenching rain. That is to say, this episode rocks.

The Clive Owen episode brings this roller-coaster to a screeching halt, not so much because it's less action, but moreso because it's boring. Granted, this episode would probably rock on its own as a short, but in following the Marv episode, this episode totally drags on and on and on with no character motivation other than "I don't want somebody to get hurt or be in a specific location," and negatively-motivated spine plots always suck.

The movie is also bookended by a Josh Hartnett thing, but that's just a tangent. The real heart of this movie for me was the Marv (Mickey Rourke) section which is essentially a very awesome, totally ass-kicking romp where every character we meet dies by the end. This is what moody comic-book adaptations should be: cold, violent, and dizzyingly fast-paced, not some BS involving a see-saw (AKA Daredevil).

Go see it, if only for the section starring Mickey Rourke.

title: What a cool, kick-ass fun flick
review: Robert Rodriguez scores big with Sin City. And good thing, too, after Once Upon a Time in Mexico. The film was a treat. Part campy, part old-time noir, part comic book, visually stunning & ALL GOOD. The acting seems a little stiff in parts, but I think that's by design, as all of the characters try not to show too much emotion, though we get the feeling (especially in Mickey Rourke's case) that they are FULL of emotion. The make-up could have been a little better on Rourke, but everything else in the film is pretty much flawless. It's definitely destined to be a classic that people will want to watch many times over. And Carla Gugino shows us her "WOW, I DIDN'T KNOW SHE HAS THOSE" rack. 'Nuff Said.

title: Finally!!!
review: Hollywood has grown its balls back. I haven't seen a movie this over the top and true to its roots in too long. This is the movie I've asked for ever since I became the loser I am today. If you want a movie done right maybe you should let the creator co direct. Of course having Quentin around doesn't hurt either, of course I'm totally biased so feel free to disregard that part. Thank you Robert Rodriguez thank you for throwing that freaking MPAA book back in their stupid MPAA faces... sorry I'm ranting and raving like a madman i know, ill wrap this up. I've waited a long time for this and its just too much of what Hollywood is lacking. All i have left to say is if you haven't seen this movie your missing out. FRANK MILLER FOR LIFE. sorry that just slipped out...

title: STUNNING!!! but untied knots
review: Sin City was FABULOUS!!!! and i can't stress this enough...the direction was very well thought out. I really liked how the black and white was REALLY black and white, no grey. The CGI background definitely tied the entire movie together...although it would only work for a comic book. I really enjoyed the different plot lines and how they came together. but i had some questions about it: What was the point of including the two extra plots (dwight and marv)? I really enjoyed it but i didn't really understand how they tied together...I also didn't really understand Josh Hartnett's role....was he supposed to be a hit-man? Overall i highly recommend this even if its just for the stunning visual effects. But i believe that the plots will pull you in as well....i guess i will just have to read the comic boooks!!!

title: Bizarre must awesome want
review: I can only say awesome so many times without sounding like an asshole. This movie was totally worth seeing in the theatre. I'll probably go and see it again, just so i can relish the pure grit and gore. Gritty is the only word i can think of to explain the images you will see. DON'T BRING KIDS. This may be a comic book movie but its definitely for adults. Every actor in this movie was fantastic, i especially enjoyed Elijah Woods. His character is disturbing in a way that will stop you from blinking, you cant stop watching the screen. When you see the movie you'll know what I'm talking about. Everyone needs a dog like the one Elijah's character has. This movie is true writing, its true to the characters presented and there is never a crappy Hollywood cheese moment. No happy Hollywood endings where the characters get married and everyone lives happily ever after. This movie is far from anything Hollywood. This movie is pure love for the comic and its characters. EVERYONE SHOULD SEE THIS MOVIE.

title: The best movie I've seen in a while
review: Three amazing slightly intertwining story arcs make for one of the best movies I've seen in recent memory. This is a stylistic powerhouse of a movie - from beginning to end, almost every shot was taken directly from a frame within the pages of "Sin City." This is evident in some rather unconventional camera angles and color accents that add up to a refreshingly new and different viewing experience. The amazing black and white accents in blood and on Kevin's glasses and other such nuances are nothing short of impressive and really accent the few bits of color strewn about the movie, making clear the character's realities are, for brief moments in time, something more than the black and white, live or die realities they've grown all too used to. The dialogue is occasionally a bit campy and overdone, but this is understandable and almost necessary given the moody backdrop. Every actor and actress plays their part to perfection, and it doesn't hurt to have had a few scenes "guest" directed by Mr. Quentin Tarantino either (when you go see it, try and guess which ones! Not that it's very hard to tell). All this makes for one of the most unique, consistently stylistic movies I've ever seen, and (thus far) the only comic book/graphic novel adaptation really worth seeing. For that, I give a 10/10

title: Unbelievable
review:
This film is truly spectacular. The photography is amazing and is very possibly the nearest film and graphic novel have ever come, while not distracting from the continuity of film. Definitely worth seeing IN the theater. Don't wait, you'll regret not seeing this on the big screen.

The acting at first seems forced, but it's supposed to be, and it very quickly becomes enjoyable. The characters are colorful (ha, that's a pun), and for anyone who enjoys the comics, the motion-picture versions of your favorites will not let you down. You forget that the entire movie was shot on a green screen in Texas; I was pulled entirely into the reality of Sin City.

A real achievement. An inkling into the future of cinema and what technology allows us to do (artistically!). Enthusiastically one of the best comic book adaptations ever.

title: Sin City
review: Great movie! I won't say what happens but I will comment on how it was made. It was made a bit like Kerry Conran's Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow with green screen. You completely buy that you are there. The action is nearly nonstop there are no long lags in story pacing like some movies have and it seems to cover presumably the whole initial Trade paper Back series. I doubt there will be a sequel unless Frank Miller writes another one though. That's not to spoil the movie Its truly an experience to be had one word of advice though don't talk or comment through the movie or you'll ruin the plot twists for everyone else. If you haven't seen go see it. If you have go see it again a second viewing may help straighten out the chronology and some realizations in plot for you.

title: In Sin City, heroism comes at a price...
review:
Visually stunning and glossy, this gripping and action-packed drama enthralls and entertains. Its character development and action sequences are everything to be expected of a Tarantino, Rodriguez, and Miller collaboration. Rigid at first, the viewer must embrace the experience of a live action comic to become engrossed in the stories. Emotionally charged and graphic, this is not for young viewers, the squeamish, or anyone seeking any shred of realism. But this movie, ripe with lessons in morality, sacrifice, and poignant violence, seamlessly transitions from newsprint to the big screen.

5 stars

title: Comic Geek approves!
review: I was skeptical of Sin city at first. Being a comic book and graphic novel fan for years I was less then thrilled to find out of the movie "Sin city." We "geeks" can be very critical of every detail, especially when we have seen in the past how transferring between the two mediums can be difficult and many times disappointing ex:(League of extraordinary gentleman). Never the less I became more hopefull when I heard of Frank Millers involvement in the film. the opening credits reveals a magnificent cast who did not let me down. i can say that "Sin City" in the truest "comic to movie" film I have ever seen. The job done by the cast and crew who worked on the film was nothing short of fantastic.Its about time!

title: A two hour comic book.
review:
The critics were right, "Sin City" is a visual mind-job. The blacks, the whites, the colors on top of that. The Neo-Noir feel, the internal dialogs, the dames in distress, all read like a flick out of the forties. At the same time, the over-violent fight scenes, the bombshell ladies, the extreme amount of fishnet, leather, thongs, and other random bondage gear, in addition to the guns, slightly impractical (yet ever so familiar) storyline; Sin City is probably one of the greatest comic book (or 'graphic novel', if you are ever so picky) adaptations that I have ever seen.

And the inclusion of Jessica Alba didn't hurt either.

If you are really into comic books, don't miss it. If you are a guy, go see it. If you are a girl, go surprise your guy by taking him to go see it.

title: Truelly one of Robert Rodriguez greatest films!
review: I don't want to give anything away as to try not to even ruin a little bit of the movie for anyone! O I thought this movie was fantastic! Visually stunning with a great story, and they seem to hold nothing back on the violence! I never really got to read any of the graphic novels but I sure want to check them out now! Everyone was stunning in this movie! I especially like CLive Owen, Bruce Willis, Elijah Wood, and Mickey Rourge's characters, and their portrayal of them was excellent! I thought Brittany Murphy over played it, but the lines she had were horrible, and it didn't help that she seemed to be reading them! Still a great great film! Somebody needs an Oscar for something in this!

title: Sin is In
review: Wow....I just exited Sin City and it is nothing short of amazing. The most hyped aspect of the film, the visuals, grab you immediately, and just when you think you've seen every trick in the directors' bag, something else leaps out at you, whether it is an unexpected permutation of color or some camera movement that simply wouldn't be possible in the real world. The advantages to shooting in HD on the digital back lot are very apparent from the opening shot, and if Sky Captain didn't sell you on the technology (it didn't exactly do it for me), then this movie will. However, it wouldn't have any impact if we, the audience, didn't care about the characters. Dwight..Hartigan...The Yellow Bastard...Miho...Nancy...all are names that will reside in your head instantly. Special mention goes to Mickey Rourke as Marv, who personifies a bad-ass street tough with his gravelly inflection and wonderfully weathered, prosthetic face. Again, I can't stress enough how visually pleasing the film is, and even if you don't care for the extreme violence or hard-boiled dialog, at least treat your eyes to something special.

title: Not too Shabby
review:
I just returned home from watching Sin City and I have to say I was impressed. For all those that have read the comics before, this movie may seem pretty familiar. I have only read a few of the comics before going to this film, and the comic "That Yellow Bastard" is Brude Willis' story line. I could've quoted the entire parts because they were almost word for word the same as the comic series.

Considering the other movies that were based on comic book series (ie. Hulk, Daredevil, and the terrible Elektra), it was refreshing to see a comic series that actually followed the series and not making a movie that is based on the characters.

Let's not forget about the film techniques. The entire movie filmed in front of a green screen couldn't have been a better idea. The original comics are almost completely in black and white and the green screen was able to provide the effect perfectly. It's not the first movie to do this, but they still use the effect perfectly.

Overall, the movie was pretty good. The casting was excellent, the action was heart-stopping and the technique of filming was excellent. Enjoy!

title: This movie was great!
review: Roderiguez brings Frank Miller's noir collection of "Sin City" comics to life in fitting adaptation. What can I say? I loved this movie. The characters are tough-as-nails and gritty just like the underworld they inhabit. The whole cast is dead-on and the cinematography is amazing. Don't let some other adaptations from graphic novels (Punisher, anyone?) dissuade you from seeing this movie. It's a roller coaster ride of a movie and I loved every minute of it. Following in the tradition of Pulp Fiction, the story-line follows the stories of many characters in a series of loosely tied together vignettes. Every hero is an anti-hero as they try to serve out their own brand of justice to a corrupt city and it rulers.

title: Best. Comicbook. Movie. EVER.
review: Any comments on this extreme work of art pale in contrast to the judgment delivered by this film. Any comments on this extreme work of art pale in contrast to the judgment delivered by this film. Any comments on this extreme work of art pale in contrast to the judgment delivered by this film. Any comments on this extreme work of art pale in contrast to the judgment delivered by this film. Any comments on this extreme work of art pale in contrast to the judgment delivered by this film. Any comments on this extreme work of art pale in contrast to the judgment delivered by this film. Any comments on this extreme work of art pale in contrast to the judgment delivered by this film. Any comments on this extreme work of art pale in contrast to the judgment delivered by this film. Any comments on this extreme work of art pale in contrast to the judgment delivered by this film. Any comments on this extreme work of art pale in contrast to the judgment delivered by this film.

title: Pulp Fiction in a Comic Book Storyboard
review:
Crossing story lines interwoven through a series of unfortunate events; a Tarantino signature. Sin City is a story of vengeance and justice set in a comic book world. The action is quite brutal, the cinematography is excellent, and with a company of good actors Sin City delivers a fast paced and interesting experience.

Not the best movie you'll ever see, the depth just isn't there to make you contemplate anything, (except maybe how fun whipping Jessica Alba in a nightie might be) but that's not what this movie tried to be. As far as being an action flick it's pretty good: good storyline, good acting, good characters. I gave it an eight because I took into consideration the kind of story it was trying to tell and its unique delivery.

I'd recommend it, and I am picky.

title: Nancy Callahan, the love of my life...
review: Wow. That is my first reaction after seeing Sin City. This movie is, from start to finish, a stylized romance with everything that most movies shy away from, a museum of torture and depravity that relishes in its own seedy underbelly. Me and my friends occasionally have what we call "Sin Nights," nights out where we succumb to any sin we wish as long as it's legal and doesn't involve more than three different stores to find. Sin Night is a time when you have that extra cheeseburger, buy that book you've had your eye on, or finally try out that new ice cream spot. You do what you have to to fulfill an inner need, and in the end you feel happy and gleeful. SIn City was the movie equivalent of Sin Night, and how appropriate that name has become. It is violent, it is brutal, it shows you things most movies would come close to. Dismemberment, nudity, and torture; these are throwaway pieces of the film. And one of the best line's I've ever heard in a movie, "...Is that all you've got?" See this, trust me. If you let yourself indulge in the guilty pleasure of this moral vacuum, you'll have a blast.

title: beautiful in its monstrosity
review: I had high hopes for Sin City, and I was definitely not disappointed. I have always enjoyed films by Robert Rodriguez; I love his dark humor and his appreciation of the grotesque. I think Sin City is a movie that pulls no punches - Mickey Rourke did a great job as Marv, shading his turn as a killer with degrees of humanity and pathos. Many other fine performances here; loved Bruce Willis, Rutger Hauer(creepy), Elijah Wood (creepier), and many others. The pulpy dialogue was perfect, and I couldn't take my eyes off the gorgeous cinematography. The violence was cartoonlike (what a surprise!); my husband and I laughed through most of it, and we weren't the only ones. If you have ever seen any movies by Robert Rodriguez, you know what to expect; he has an uncompromising vision that we could use more of in film today.

title: Sin City Full of Sin...Total Win
review: While I have not read any of Frank Miller's Sin City graphic novels I must say that he, Robert Rodriguez and Quentin Tarintino put this movie together quite well. Not only is the story and acting superb but the editing and shots they use are truly amazing. With the exception of Michael Clark Duncan's character I felt that all of the characters were given a well amount of time to work their character into the story and show where he or she is coming from within the Sin City universe. I also liked Elijah Wood's character Kevin I felt that he brought a very creepy mysterious element to it that the rest didn't also the darkness that cloaks the evil in this movie is quite well put together also with a Cardinal, Senator (and his son), and a crooked cop as the main baddie element in the story. Over all i give this movie a superb 10/10 anything better would have made my head spin rapidly and explode in a theater near you.

title: Phenomenal
review: Sin City blew me away. Visually, it was one of the coolest movies I have ever seen. The film is in black & white, with color interspersed in certain items (such as a girl's blue eyes or a woman's red dress). I thought it was pretty fascinating to see a major film shot this way. Some of the scenes are very comic-book (it is based on Frank Miller's graphic novels) and I loved that. The movie was very over-the-top...but in a way that I really enjoyed. Very interesting plot lines and I was as interested as could be throughout the entire film. Though make sure you know...the movie is very graphic and has just a tad bit of blood. It's mostly done in an over-the-top way, as mentioned, but be aware. In any case, for my money, Sin City is a must-see.
