title: Movie Review
review:
The Movie Sin City was an awesome story of love,hate,and revenge. The characters mixed and mingled together quiet nicely. The story's are extremely devoted to the graphic novels. The actors playing them are perfect for the characters maybe expect Clive Owen but was he OK. The parts of the story's were not confusing and you could figure out which one was which. Also even though Jessica Alba wasn't nude she doesn't have to be in order to play the role well. Also all the main men in comics were fully nude but who want's to see that. The movie is stunning and visually appealing. The blood could have been all red for my taste but for get the point anyway. The movie should hopefully make most if not all it's money back and should have a sequel to finish it off. I give the comic to movie adaptation 98%.

9 out of 10

title: Sin City
review: Sin City, is based upon the comics of the same name by Frank Miller, who also co-directed the film. The film is in black and white and looks like a film noir from the 40's. All the male characters are tough as nails and smoke and wear trench coats and all the female characters are scantily dressed prostitutes. There is only some things in the movie that show colour such as a character's blue eyes or a red dress on a character. The story has several different stories all involving a lot of action and a lot of energy. Sin City, has good direction. a good script, good performances from everyone involved, good original music, good cinematography, good film editing, good set decoration and good makeup and visual effects. Sin City, is an excellent looking movie with it's costumes, sets, makeup and black and white cinematography that looks like it has come right out of the 40's. It should definitely be nominated for some awards just for the way the film looks. The film took a little while for me to get into because it starts right off with a bang and has non stop action which at first I found hard to get into because it was hard to get character development and concentrate on one thing for too long. But by the third story starring Clive Owen, and Benicio Del Toro, I was into the movie and was enjoying this very exciting and energy pumped ride. The film is extremely unique and original, is well made, has great dialogue, has interesting characters, is an interesting film to look at, is a very entertaining film, is fun, exhilarating, has some funny moments and is a visually stunning and entertaining film. The film is very violent and is not for young kids but I have been told it is very faithful to the comic books it is based on and having not liked many movies based on comic books I can tell you that this one holds out, and it holds out well and is really a very good film. One of the most entertaining films of the year so far and also one of the most original.

title: Stylish and exciting
review:
When I heard that a "Sin City" movie was being made, I was shocked, and even upset. How could they turn these classic, beautiful, graphic novels, into anything even comparable? Well, they did it.

The movie is grotesque, vulgar, and should not be seen by people under 17. But those of you who meet the requirment, attend the movie quick. The acting is wonderful, you've already heard it, "the actors were made for the roles," blah blah blah. The art, characters, and dialouge are all brought to the screen successfully. I also loved the creative ending Rodriquez tagged on.

Either way, Micky Rourke and Bruce Willis are top-notch. Everything seemed in good form.

9/10

title: Sin City
review: Sin City begins as though the viewer were watching Pulp Fiction: a scene of slick discussion between a man and a woman, ending in a twist. However, whereas Tarantino uses realism throughout Pulp, Robert Rodriguez and Frank Miller use a fantastical world in which ridiculous events occur. The events are so ridiculous, in fact, that the viewer can not help but smile at it. In this regard, Sin City is a cross between Pulp Fiction and Spiderman. The characters are the low-lifes of Pulp Fiction, and yet the action and high-definition filming is that of Spiderman. The unique difference that makes Sin City different is the way that Rodriguez portrays the movie as if it were a comic book. The actors deliver their lines as though you were watching a B-rate movie from the 1950's, and the narration is like a crime movie, with a cop taking care of the situation. Some may not like the way that Rodriguez does this, but it is new to watch, as other comic book movies have not achieved as much as Sin City. Much of this is thanks to Miller, who wrote the graphic material not seen in a comic book movie like Spiderman or The Incredible Hulk. The dramatic way that Rodriguez brings a book to the screen is enough to keep the viewer paying attention throughout the movie, and therefore is not as boring as many critics suggest. Rodriguez's gift is that he takes a comic book and makes it a film noir that can even be mentioned in the same breath as Pulp Fiction, a movie many consider to be a textbook in film noir. All in all the movie is entertaining and interesting, not only for the way that Rodriguez intertwines the stories, but in the way that the actors portray their respective characters. The cast includes Clive Owen, Bruce Willis, Mickey Rourke, Jessica Alba, Elijah Wood, Michael Madsen, Brittany Murphy, and Benicio Del Toro, among others.

title: This Movie is awe inspiring
review: Sin City is the best movie of 2005. It includes an all star cast who work brilliantly together and know each others strengths and weaknesses. The way the movie is filmed is just breathtaking; Robert Rodriguez did an excellent job of portraying Frank Miller's graphic novel to the greatest extent. Although it might be a bit gory, it is a movie that any fan of comic book movies should see. Fans of any Tarantino movie or fans of any film noir style films should enjoy the mastery of the filming style that Rodriguez utilizes. This movie is the best movie of 2005, as of right now, and should be a hit all around the world.

title: Incredible
review:
Cinematography: Is surreal, mainly monochrome with some intense lighting (contrast) effects, with vivid and subtle splashes of chrominance. From what I read before seeing the movie, it was shot to mimic the fine details of the comic artwork, it does, I have never seen anything like it.

Storyline: When the graphic violence spills onto the screen it is like nothing I have ever seen in a movie. It is so gratuitous it makes Pulp Fiction look like a Disney G movie. After the first 15 minutes I finally realized "this is a representation of a DARK comic book" I am 45 years old and it was very reminiscent of the Batman TV series of the 60's with the Biff!!! and Pow!! replaced with Frank Miller's incredible vision of action.

Acting: At first glance it appears cheesy. However, once you begin to connect with the characters one begins to realize the requirement this film had for the well seasoned actors. I believe it is sometimes more difficult for an actor to pull off a wildly fictional role and have it appear matter-of-factly than it is to fall into a serious persona and just appear normal to the role.

Entertainment Factor: Well... I experienced everything from indigestion (I just ate before the film and was not quite ready for the gore) to arousal (quite possibly some of the best "art" photography of the female form) and even a few Guffaws (If you told me that I would be laughing out loud by the end of the film five minutes into it I would never have believed you)

Probably not an Acadamy Award winner, But, definitely a visual masterpiece for what it is. Miller definitely did what he came to do, it is like watching a comic.

title: Scene for scene frame for frame its was the comic.
review:
Sin City has always been one of my favorite comics. What amazed me the most was how true down to so small and trivial details it was exactly like the comic. Of course not all the actors could look like the way Miller drew them but that is nothing that can be helped.

In an attempt to be super true to the comic they pulled off the visuals is a wonderful way. Cuz in the end it's a film not a comic and some things just won't be right unless maybe they animated it. They made a mistake I think though in trying to use word for word dialogue. Many of the actors seemed strained to repeat them and it didn't always seem natural. The best at it was Jessica Alba, maybe because she didn't have so many "one liners".

on another note it is an extremely violent movie anyone who can't stomache such things should probably stay away. I wouldn't bring the kids.

As far as people who have read the comic I think you will be happy with it but a few scenes from the comic are not in the movie. which does change a few things but not much.

All and all though an excellent adaptation 9/10

title: My Kind of Town...
review:
Sin City is a visually stunning addition to the genre of film noir movies. Gritty and highly stylized, this is perhaps the first "comic book movie" that stays true to the original model. There are darkly inspired acting performances by a dedicated cast, and Elijah Wood is especially frightening as Kevin.

I'm not one to get drawn into a movie just because it's popular; it has to be truly special for me to like it. Given that, please believe me when I say this is the best film I've seen since The Usual Suspects, and that's pretty high praise as far as I'm concerned.

One final note, special props should go out to director Rodriguez for giving Frank Miller a well-deserved co-directing credit at the cost of his guild membership. More people today should have such strong convictions.

title: Dirty, yet oh so delightful...
review: With some of the most obscene vulgarities probably ever brought to screen, Sin City is not for the faint. But shot masterfully in black and white showing only accents of color occasionally, artistically, it is really is a spectacle to behold. Yes, it's gruesome and hard to stomach at times, but it also highly entertaining and good for a laugh if you can handle the humor. Many of the performances were also unforgettable, especially Benicio Del Toro and Mickey Rourke who were simply hilarious. All in all, its very well done and quite worth the movie going experience. I give it a 9 out of 10 because it felt a whole lot longer than it actually was, which is odd because there was never a dull moment.

title: Frank Miller is god and his art is absolutely magnificent
review:
It is an honor to see such a great film from such a great creator. Frank Miller's comics were and are brilliant but there was always something missing. In all of his work there was an element that did not come through in the comics. You could see it and feel it. You knew what Miller was trying to do and even though it was 99% there, that extra little touch or element that would put it over the top and make it a masterpiece was missing ... after seeing Sin City I know what that missing element was. Frank Miller's work is meant to be on the big screen and seen and appreciated as a movie ... if you loved or even liked Millers work in the comic books you will be blown away with the movie.

Hands down, no one comes close, it is what others have tried and failed to achieve ... Frank Miller's Sin City is absolutely the best comic book ever to see the screen.

I will be watching this movie many more times before it is taken away from the movie theaters where it is meant to be seen.

This movie will (or I should say should) win the best movie of the year, the best screen play, the best script, the best director, the best cinematography, the best set, the best special effects and the best supporting actor and actress roles including the best actor role for Mickey Rourke.

Brilliant Brilliant Brilliant ... a masterpiece ... like watching Mozart play for the first time. The first 2 minutes made me want to cry i was so happy, and after 15 minutes I knew that I was watching something that is so rare in movies that it made me want to weep.

Mr. Miller, you have just written yourself in the pages of history as a genius and it is well deserved. Thank you for you work

title: Amazing. Brilliant. Sinful.
review:
The minute this film started, I told my friend--who loves to add comments to just about every scene of a movie--to just hush this time. I was too immersed in the dark, luring world created before my eyes. The edgy, bloody mood engulfed me within seconds, and I didn't let go of my seat until the ride was completely over.

Acting was amazing. Marv is my personal favorite character. Mickey Rourke played it to the hilt, and left me wanting more. Bruce Willis fits his role just as you would expect, and all the girls are great. I can honestly say I wasn't disappointed by a single act of this wonderful film.

And as far as being true to the comics...without so much as hesitating I can promise you that this is the most true-to-form, stylish and perfect comic book adaption I've ever seen on film. It's a bloody good ride and I'm almost as excited about the DVD as I am about going to watch it again tomorrow!

title: A gorgeous film
review:
From the stunning beauty of the actresses to the incredible cinematography and moods, this movie is a work of art. It was so simple to believe that I was watching a comic book made real, with the sometimes cheesy dialogue, over-the-top violence (which while gory, was never TOO much, in my opinion) and well done camera angles, which is easy to miss in comics, but sometimes makes the scene.

I thought it felt like a Mickey Spillane book, as thrown through the ringer by Edgar Allen Poe. Don't hold your breath for happy endings, but I guess that's also depends on your point of view.

Another well-done touch was the black-and-white with splashes of color. It was perfectly done, kind of like that one girl in "Schindler's List." "Sin City" made far more use of color, but again it always tended to either give extra depth to characters or increase a scene's impact.

Boy, is this NOT a date movie.

title: Sin City's sins are Gluttony and Sloth, but forgivable...
review:
Sin City lives up to its sleazy moniker with high gloss and style. As expected, there's nary a shred of redemption in this hard-boiled film adaptation of Frank Miller's Sin City series, however, it carries with it a feeling of guilty pleasure, no matter how brutal and sadistic.

That said, the violence is highly stylized and defined by comic book physics. Characters are exploded, bullet blasted, even emphatically mutilated. No one dies until they're deliberately written out. The flick is literally pieced together by the panels that make up the graphic novels. It's shot in high contrast black and white with vibrant splotches of color to accentuate specific objects. The world this effect intones is completely convincing, unforgiving, and *cool*.

The cast can get away with a lot of toss away lines because they're in such a cool movie. Understanding that this was a very faithful adaptation,it would take a really stellar talent to pull off lines like "Kill him for me. Kill him good..."or "I've been killin my way to the truth...". But it is what it is. These words were born in little white bubbles.

On the performance side, Mickey Rourke makes this movie likable. He brings a lot of charm to the hulking, ugly brute Marv. His takes gleeful delight in the Hard Goodbye he gives to his Hooker With the Heart of Gold's murderers. Marv won over the theater audience who were pretty wary up till his entrance in the first of four lisle entwined sequences.. After him, it's hard to find characters to get behind, even though they're familiar faces. You kind of have to side with Bruce Willis's Hartigan, but he's trying to save a little girl from the rape murder promised by That Yellow Bastard, so what choice do you have?

The rest of the cast is suitable, even if it does feel like cameos. the story is self aware so it doesn't leave them much room for preening in like say, Oceans Tweleve. Bencio Del Toro will freak you out yet again. There's lots of Sin here. Plenty of lust, greed, and wrath. Lots and lots of wrath. Sin City comes close to drowning in it's own blood, though, as it recycles it's themes of Pride and revenge through constant, detached monologue. Fortunately, the visuals and high intensity atmosphere make Sin City the ride a comic book flick should be.

title: A translation of Frank Millers acclaimed graphic novels. Three of Miller's stories make up the bulk of the film: The Hard Goodbye, The Big Fat Kill, and That Yellow Bastard.
review: Sin City is an unabashed "translation" of Frank Miller's acclaimed comic series of the same name. I use the word "translation" because that is exactly what it is, it is merely the comic panels brought to life. And boy does it work, the dazzling visuals and powerful imagery create a vivid portrait of a city that no one ever wants to visit. The streets and alley ways are overflowing with corruption and perversion. The film presents its subject matter in unapologetic form, presenting the violence and garishness as it is, in your face and uncensored. Needless to say I loved every second of it. From the melodramatic dialogue (I feel like a palsy victim doing brain surgery with a lead pipe, a line Bruce Willis utters in one of his narratives), to the over the top characters (Elijah Wood's character, Kevin, being among my favorites). The movie, mostly in black and white, has sporadic splashes of color that are used to accentuate a part of the film. The blood was so vivid in some scenes you could almost taste it. Frank Miller has said that he uses color as a weapon, and nothing could be more true. I just hope that Hollywood sits up and takes notice, and starts to realize that it does not have to put out formula film after formula film, that inventiveness and art is not a bad thing. Walk down the right back alley in sin city and you can find anything, even a great film.

title: The first real, innovative movie of the 21st century
review: Dead men don't wear plaid mates with Pulp Fiction! everything about this movie is exhilarating its everything Sky Captain and the world of tomorrow was not. Bruce Willis, Mickey Rourke & Clive Owen are the three most sleaziest, most vile anti=hero's that you can't help but root for. The music and cinematography are spot on. Is there anything Robert Rodriguez can't do? And how doe's Elijah Wood not say a word and still be the creepiest bad guy in a movie full of bad guys? A thoroughly enjoyable 2 hours that i give a 9 to but i'm reserving a 10 for the end of the year (in case P.T.Anderson has something coming out.) It is one of those films that you know after the opening scene that you can not wait for whats to come!

title: Amazing adaptation of excellent source material
review:
If you've read Frank Miller's work, I'm sure you were worried about the quality of the adaptation. Rest assured, the work is amazing. Rodriguez does an amazing job of bringing the series of loosely-related stories together. At times laugh-out-loud funny, sad, sappy, and savagely brutal, this is the closest thing to a modern day epic you'll find.

Mickey Roark steals the show early on, but Bruce Willis does an incredible job in finishing up the show on a high note. In between, there's a bit of a lag, but only because it's being compared to some incredible work. I give it a 10/10 and cannot recommend it highly enough.

title: Outstanding achievement
review:
A stunning, outstanding achievement. Will be remembered as a classic.

Easy to follow episodes difficult to fit together as a single story. Tarintino style plotting not strictly as necessary for this movie as it was for Pulp Fiction. True, though, this gives a certain graphic novel 'tight episode' feel to the story.

At least for me there was not that same degree of epiphany that comes when a non-sequential plot becomes clear(er). There is a moment that creates some of that emotional irony, but it feels more like it was in the service of knitting together the graphic novels' story lines, as opposed pulling together an emotional story line.

Still, this one should get some academy award nominations for truly inspired art direction and make up. Characters are brilliantly translated from the graphic to the cinematic.

Dialogue toys with the viewers' knowledge of 'comic book' and detective writing clichÃ©s, verging on the silly but with just enough self-mockery to redeem itself. In clear contrast to this word play, this is the most seriously and brutally violent exploration of the depths of human corruption put on screen within the realms of fiction.

Definitely a film for grown ups.

title: A treat for newcomers and fans alike
review:
Firstly, let me say that if you aren't familiar with Sin City, make sure you can stomach violence. A lot of it.

Miller and Rodriguez's creation boasts plenty of it, all deftly green-screen shot and painted with stark blacks and whites, save the odd splash of color. Many of the notable actors featured in the film boast prosthetic makeup, surprising costumes, or simply no dialog for their characters.

Does this mean you won't enjoy the movie? Hell no. Sin City, as a film, is comprised of three story-arcs from the comic series of the same name. The three stories are presented non-linearly (think Pulp Fiction) and bleed into each other at the edges, providing what may be a jarring narrative for newcomers, but one that ultimately makes sense.

Look past the bloodshed of each one, and you'll find that each story's core is a romance. THe characters speak in larger-than-life dialog, with Miller's writing more deft than most in the business today. There is no traditional "good guy" in Sin City, but the villains levels of depravity make the crimes of the "heroes" seem insubstantial.

Elmore Leonard's "Payback" is a wonderful example of this on two levels. Firstly, the inner monologue of the protagonist provides a method, a reasoning for the actions that drive them. And secondly, when all the pieces have fallen into place, you find yourself genuinely rooting for the "heroes" in the face of their injustices.

While longtime fans of the comics will notice several things that are slightly changed (primarily in That Yellow Bastard) the film as a whole is, to date, the most successful direct translation of a comic i've seen, as well as one of the most enjoyable. So get a babysitter for the kids and go wallow in some Sin.

title: The greatest stylized violence ever....
review: Sure there's been more violent movies made, and there's been films rendered to more extreme measures before, but this particular combination of guns, guts and broads combined with hyper-stylized direction makes it a morbidly delightful treat for the eyes and the mind. Not recommended for the squeamish or the easily shocked, Sin City is a non-stop wave of over the top ridiculousness sure to please anyone looking for a dark, funny, unbelievably violent film. I don't even know what Tarantino, listed as a guest director, had to do with this movie, maybe he just wanted to hang out while it was being made. The movie was credited as being the child of Robert Rodriguez, but maybe old Q just wanted to be on set and throw in the occasional idea, eventually getting him his "special guest director" credit. I can't say I blame him though, this movie was fun to watch, and, for the right director, probably fun to make. Grade: A

title: Stylized Brilliance
review:
This film...this film is unlike anything I've ever seen. And I've seen far more movies than can be healthy.

The visual style, well, there isn't a single style. This film is made in such varying ways of seeing things that for once, you truly cannot take your eyes from the screen. It's mesmerizing in a way.

Of course, there will be many detractors saying that there is little character development and a flimsy storyline to each of the stories. But you've got to realize one thing: this was not made as a comic book adaptation, it was made as comic books come to life. In this, it succeeds, and incredibly.

The acting is good overall, nobody plays it like it's Shakespere, and in this film, that's a very good thing. Mickey Rourke plays his part to the hilt, and shows a talent we haven't seen in full bloom for years.

In wrapping this up, allow me to say this: If you want a heartfelt piece of thought provoking work, go see something else. If you want something that will glue your eyes to the screen and speed up your heart rate, welcome to Sin City.

title: Masterful
review:
Cinematography: Perfect. Acting: Perfect. Casting: Perfect. Music: Perfect. Storyline: Perfect. Direction: Perfect.

One of the best movies I've seen in years. It's very violent, but that seems to only make it better. It's stylized almost like a film noir only one that was directed by Tarantino. I would recommend this movie to anyone who can stomach some gore, because if you can get past that, you're in for an amazing story.

Films like this break the barriers and set a new expectation for what a good film really is. I can't think of a single thing I would change in this movie to make it any better.

title: Booze, Broads, and Bullets...Photography, Acting, Writing and Directing...it's all here in spades in Frank Miller's Sin City.
review:
Robert Rodriguez has finally made a worthwhile film and not just a movie with some cool scenes. I really think it was Frank Miller's involvement because Frank Miller is, quite simply, a genius. He can now say that the amalgamation of film and comic can co-exist, if done right.

Incredible photography. Good music. Spot on directing from Rodriguez, Miller, and Tarantino. Great acting from all parties involved, but I have to say that Mickey Rourke is the man. Mickey Rourke is back. He plays Marv and puts his heart and soul into the part. A truly memorable performance.

I only have two problems with Sin City: (one)Some of the jump-cuts don't work well and (two)The ending needs some work. Other than that, I loved it.

You'll be shocked, you'll be amazed, and you'll laugh you're head off. The best movie of the new year. Cool as hell. It sizzles on the screen: ssssssssss.....hot.

title: Sin City a.k.a THE GREATEST FILM
review:
Where to start on how magnificent this movie this. I loved it...no not loved...LOVED!!! IT.

Frank Miller helped created one of the most aw taking films of all time, this makes i believe any film that comes out this year look like garbage. Sin City is my movie of 2k5 and i just don't know what to say that hasn't been said...SEE THIS MOVIe..

The Style this movie has will never be duplicated by any other movie i think, its the telling of three stories from Frank Millers Graphic Novel, Sin City and each one is brought to life perfectly from page to screen. Movie like his makes me LOVe that i am a film major and want to be a director and writer.

Thank you, cast, crew, writers, director, producers, editors...EVERYONE, for giving us this flick. *runs to see it again.*

title: Best Comic Book movie since "Batman"
review:
Five minutes into SIN CITY, I was pretty sure that I had stumbled into a baaaaaaad movie. I defy anyone to sit through the opening scene-- a man and woman standing on a balcony spouting typical private-eye time dialog with typical private-eye first-person narration-- and not be reminded of a recent commercial for "Flonase". As the opening scenes progress, the elaborate visual style comic-noir only seemed to make the narrative seem more slap-dash and hyperbolic, a caricature. The artifice took me farther away, not closer to the story. I couldn't stop being aware that the actors were standing in front of wind machines, and that drove me crazy. I wondered if I would be walking out.

Fortunately, I stayed, and I was gradually seduced into accepting this film on its own special terms-- and I loved it. "Sin City" may be a classic of "pure cinema", meaning that it builds on everything that the cinema has always been about, from George Melies to Eisenstein to John Woo. It's not about characters-- it's about images, motion and magic. It's also just about the most violent thing since Homer's Iliad-- but the violence is brilliantly realized-- frightening and witty by turns. Like a Jackie Chan action film, or a keystone cops short, it doesn't give you much to think about when you leave the theater. But I'm pretty sure that I'll be seeing it again.

title: Captivating!
review: Frank Miller's Graphic Novels are brought to life, in a way, in this anthology reminiscent of Pulp Fiction but uniquely different. This highly imaginative, violent, and provocative movie is set in the alternate reality of Basin City whose inhabitants are shades of grey to very black. Tough guys of dubious character, put their lives on the line defending or being defended by amazingly strong and deadly beauties. Filled with frames and photo works that are living portrayals of Miller's graphic novels, this movie will keep you hooked from the very beginning to its surprise ending! You'll be talking and thinking about this one, long after the credits have scrolled by.

title: original, sexy, and demoniacally excellent
review:
right from the opening scene this movie had me hooked. the story is not about the characters, but about the city they live in. it follows the lives of about four or five main characters, all whom seem to have one thing in common: Nancy Calahan. whether they actually knew her or just saw her dancing at the club, she is the one thing that ties their stories together.

like i said, right from the beginning, i was hooked. i'm a bit of a fan of both Rodriguez and Tarantino (even if Tarantino only directed one scene), so this was quite a treat for me. the style is simply amazing. everything about it just blows your mind. unfortunately, i've never gotten a chance to read any of the comic books...sorry, "graphic novels"...but watching this is enough to make me want to go out and buy anything i can get my little mitts on as long as it has Frank Miller's name on it.

Rodriguez's amazing adaption of this already outstanding story (or so i hear) is instantly among my top ten movies, and is certainly one of the best movies i've seen in months.

but the direction isn't everything, the actors were given the chance to show off everything they had. Mickey Rourke certainly gives one of his best performances as Marv the heart- broken bad ass. Bruce Willis also gives quite a spectacular performance. but i think my favorite was Clive Owen and his bright red Converses. he was lovably insane (especially in the car with Benicio Del Toro) and i think everything he did with the character was awesome.

all-in-all this is exactly what we movie lovers have needed for the past year or so. something original, inspiring, and something that's overall breathtaking. it does everything right, and waiting for the movie will be seem like heaven compared to the hell of waiting for the DVD.

title: Best movie yet of the 21st Century.
review: This movie is by far the best comic based movie to come out. I also believe it will be voted the best movie of the year, let alone the best movie I have seen yet this decade. Go and see this movie while it's in the theaters, don't wait for it to come out on DVD. It has superior acting, directing, and special affects. Everything in it is done perfectly, all the right camera angles, all the right lighting. It sets new standards for movies everywhere. The story is constantly in motion, no boring stops or tricks, it keeps you entertained through out. Its one of those movies where you never want it to end, but when it does, it ends on a very well done note. I underestimated this movie to be more along the lines of whats been coming out lately, but its very different.

title: Just.... WOW
review: I walked into this movie not even sure what to expect other then that i knew a awesome list of actors and actresses were in it. And i was like if anyhting i'll see my favorite actress (jessica alba). And that i was intrigued by the cinematography. It was very appealing in a way that i hadn't seen a movie filmed like that before, although Sky Captins from the world of tomorrow was close. But this movie was so much better! Everything was just great from visually to acting, and just the way it was cut! I saw this last night around midnight or so. And i soooo want to see this again. It was just amazing and puts this movie as one of my all time favorites. The story line is fantastic, i love how it develops through out the movie.

title: You will love Sin City or hate it, no in-between
review:
Sin City comes to life on the screen directly off the pages of Frank Miller's comic book series. Sin City (Basin City) is a violent city where the police are crooked, crime is rampant in the streets, and the women are beautiful and deadly. The film is a collection of three story lines that connect all the characters to Sin City. The main character is Marv (Mickey Rourke) a street thug who is framed for the murder of a gorgeous and kind prostitute, Goldie (Jaime King), while she was asleep in his bed. To avenge the death of Goldie, Marv sets out on a mission of violence where no one better get in his way. The second storyline is Dwight (Clive Owen) a friend and old flame of the head of the Sin City hookers, who gets caught up in the killing of a corrupt cop and must cover it up to save the girls. The third storyline is about a policeman, Hartigan (Bruce Willis), who was only one hour away from early retirement, but instead of retiring, is shot and arrested and put in jail for 8 years for a crime he didn't commit.

The movie was shot in black-and-white and some color to give the look and tone reflective of the pen and ink of the comic book pages. It is loaded with nudity and violence and is not recommended to the squeamish. The violence doesn't look that bad, even with several killing scenes and body parts flying everywhere. You don't notice the horror as much, because the color of the blood isn't red. You can also tell that the story lines are from comic books, because all the heroes are either shot, run over by a car, tortured and beaten to a pulp, but still survive. I think Marv, the character Mickey Rourke played, was the best of the three stories. This movie was entertaining and not your typical movie; you will either love it or hate it, no in-between. (Dimension Films, Run time 2:06, Rated R)(10/10)

title: Fantastic Movie but not for everyone
review:
I just saw Sin City and would like to say that anyone who has had the pleasure of reading Frank Miller's books should really run out and see this one. It's a great re-imagining of Miller's three best novels. Though there are some noticeable omissions, I found the movie to be quite complete and throughly enjoyable.

Note of caution though: To people that don't know Miller's work or don't appreciate the film noir style, this movie might not be for you. The hokey dialog will throw off some and make otherwise tense moments laughable. So take it all with a grain of salt and if you can wrap your head around the way the film is presented and if you can appreciate the style in which Miller writes, then you should love it.

Solid flick! 8/10

title: Best Movie of the Year
review:
This is easily the best movie of the year from start to finish. Sin City is the most awesome film to ever grace my unworthy eyes. Not only have I never seen a movie like this before, but I entirely doubt I will ever see one like it again. The cast of the movie was incredible and the style and progression was simply fantastic. I seriously doubt there will be a sitting of this movie that doesn't get some type of reaction from the audience... Call it "shock value", call it "gruesome" or "gorey", call it whatever you want...but the movie provokes an amazing response that kept me wanting to see more and more.

This movie makes Kill Bill 1&2, Once Upon a Time in Mexico, and just about any other amazingly action-packed, gore-filled and violent flick look something like Bambi.

I definitely recommend this movie to anyone with a stomach for violence and a love for a great movie. You'll find it difficult to spend 2 hours and 6 minutes better at a theater, and I can guarantee it won't be a film anywhere near as good.

title: Guest Director Quentin
review:
Sin City is the next Pulp Fiction. I saw the sneak peak tonight - one night before its release. I can see it now, teenagers pouring into the theatres to see the latest eye candy suspense thriller, not to mention the gorgeous, emphasize gorgeous, women, and continuous yet humorous violence. And let me be one of the first to tell you...ITS EYE CANDY. I could not get over the whole artsy fartsy aspect of the film. It honestly looks like a comic book. Frank Miller really outdid himself. Truly one of the best films I've seen in a while. You become so entangled in the story that by the end you just gasp for air because you've been holding your breath so long. The film is divided into three distinct sequences, following a different part of the story and told from a different character but magically all tied together in the end, similar to Pulp Fiction.

How involved was Quentin?

title: Graphic but good
review: I saw the movie on a sneak preview. I was a fan from the novels before but the movie did it some justice. You have to know what your getting into before you step into the movie. The movie is written well & the actors are very good. Some are worse than others. But hey its a movie. You have to form your own opinion about it. One thing that bugged me about the movie was that it kept going from color to black & white. They should have picked one & stuck to it. Another thing was Elijah Wood as some killer that wasn't very realistic @ all. The special effects were awesome. It looked like Quentin directed most of the movie instead of guest director. I liked how the movie came full circle from the beginning to the end, it tied it all together. very well done.

title: The perfect evolution of graphic novel and cinema
review:
Most experts believe that when we dream, we dream in black and white. If that's the case, when Frank Miller dreams, that black and white world is splattered with red violence and yellow fear and the gray that accompany the inner turmoil of characters straddling good and evil. In Sin City, the film adaptation of three of a series of Miller's graphic novels of the same name, Robert Rodriguez duplicates the essence of those dreams and takes the art of film to a place it has never been.

In a panel by panel homage to the art and vision of Miller, Sin City rips the ink right out of the comic book and injects it into your bloodstream. Clearly influenced, if not replicating, the spirit and cadence of classic film noir, Miller's stories are visceral and ache in the pain of the anti-heroes of each of the three stories. Told in a disjointed Pulp Fiction style timeline, the three stories are always held together by the dark, wet backdrop of Sin City itself.

Bruce Willis plays a half-dead cop wanting to do the right thing for a young girl one last time at any cost. In the second vignette, Mickey Rourke transforms himself brilliantly into a gentle, lumbering chunk of violence searching for vengeance and beauty in the filthy hole that is his world. Lastly Clive Owen channels a reluctant hero caught in a web of violence and obligation. Each character is flawed and fractured and ultimately human in an extraordinary way. Littered with an amazing blend of talent surrounding them, all of the characters in Sin City bleed, cry, kill and die like only good comic book characters can.

Dripping with stylized film noir dialogue and syrupy, tactile visuals, Sin City transports the audience into the world of the comic, and blends the two art forms in a way that has been attempted many times but never accomplished. However, this is a film that will either be loved or hated. Sin City is excessively violent. Rodriguez doesn't flinch the camera from scenes that, although cartoonish in nature, are at their core depraved. The dialogue also can seem campy if the vision of what the film is trying to be gets lost.

Ultimately Sin City is like no other move you have ever seen, and will most certainly go down as Rodriguez's best film to date. It is bare, and bold, and necessary. In the end, Rodriguez shows us Miller's Sin City dream world and creates something new and disturbingly exciting in the process.

title: A great stylized film noir, gripping, and intense.
review: This movie is intense, and therefore not for everybody. However, if you can handle it, and you want a gritty film noir in your face journey, boy has Robert Rodriguez cooked up a T-Bone. Besides the Brilliant, innovative, and cinematic ally orgasmic visual effects, this movie has a lot to offer. The acting is phenomenal, especially by Bruce Willis, and Benicio Del Torro, the suspense is edge of your seat. In addition, the stories, as they are in the comics, are gripping and get you going right along with the characters, which are rich in personality. The movie is simply magnificent and sets the bar for its style, if not reinventing it altogether. There are those who wont like it, buts that's because they can't handle this type of movie, or they're just into other genres, but either way this one will leave some scars. The Hype: For those of you who are fans of Robert Rodriguez and/or Quentin Terantino work, you will be blown away. For those of you who are comic book fans you will be blown away, for this is as true to Frank Miller's masterpiece as can be got.

title: David Lynch on acid -- is that possible?
review:
I honestly wasn't thrilled about seeing this film until I was invited to an advanced screening. I knew that the cinematography would be striking, but the whole picture was breathtaking on screen. The images were like delicacies for the audience to savor in every shot. The story skips around in a seemingly abrupt fashion, but is woven together through progression. I think I'll have to see it again to grasp the connection between the first and last scenes, though. The whole film had an inkling of Lynchian flavor to it, especially with the usage of sexuality, violence, and some of the creative characters (like the "Yellow Bastard" -- something about him reminded me of Michael J. Anderson in Mulholland Drive). The wavering mental state of Dwight (Clive Owen) and Marv (Mickey Rourke) also brought back some Lynch themes.

I'll definitely have to see it again.

title: Absolutely awesome!
review:
Saw the preview screening last night and the review title says it all. Never have a seen a film that actually retains the feel and style of the original source. From the very first scene, you know that you're in a surreal place where anything can, and does, happen. The performances are tight and the storyline arcs wonderfully. The only thing you want from this film is more! Even though Willis is type-cast; it's perfect. Elijah Wood's performance is not only surprising but downright creepy. I expect that a lot of the tone of the film was because Frank Miller had a direct hand in its making. Couple that with Robert Rodriguez's craftsmanship and it's practically unstoppable.

Dark, nasty, gritty and mean, this film is not for the faint-of-heart. It is, however, one of the best made films I've seen in years. Those folks who raved over "Saw" will get blown away by this film. This is a standard for the new breed of film noir.

title: Film Noir with a little comic book feel
review:
A good friend of mine had tickets for an advanced screening of Sin City and was nice enough to invite me along. I owe him big-time. As you've probably heard by now, the movie is based off of the "graphic novel" (read: comic book) by Frank Miller. I've read maybe 10 comic books in my lifetime, and this wasn't one of them, so I was a little skeptical going into the movie even after seeing the visually enticing previews. I had nothing to worry about. There were no cheesy shots that imitated a comic book page layout or mutant villains (which had worried me after seeing the yellow guy in the previews). All in all, it was well written with complex characters and an engaging plot, and had no one told me it was based off of a comic book, I would never have thought it on my own.

Visually, the film is a masterpiece. It seems more like Film Noir than any of the movies that created the genre. The blacks of the shadows are absolute, and some of the whites are so pure that they stand out completely from the shadows, even if the rest of the object can't been seen at all. And it's this uncompromising and drastic portrayal of chiaroscuro that creates such a visual feast. It feels five times darker than any film noir while stylistically hinting at the movie's comic book origins. Another visual aspect of the film is the splashes of color in this otherwise black & white film. I was concerned this might come off hokey, but it is done so well that after a while, I forgot some of the more prevalent ones were even there (much like watching a b&w movie and forgetting it's not in color). The splashes of color would force me to focus on an important character of one his/her characteristics, and then sneak out of my consciousness. Of course, there are some times when color is used to shock, but otherwise it seemed wonderfully subtle.

As for the plot, it's a throwback to the days of pulp fiction (50's detective magazines, not the movie with S. L. Jackson and Travolta). I'm a huge fan of the genre and that's probably why I ended up giving this movie 10 stars. There was at least one scene that seemed to have been ripped directly from one of Raymond Chadler's books. Other aspects of the plot seemed to take on a more modern detective story flair, like something from a John Sanford or Michael Connelly novel. However, unlike many of these books, which usually end up investigating an act of violence that has already happened, Sin City is almost non-stop violence from the beginning, setting a tone for the entire movie. And while the violence is certainly prevalent, it is by no means overbearing. In fact, I found myself anticipating many acts of violence and rooting them on. A few violent scenes even provoked laughter from the audience. And speaking of humour, this movie was surprisingly humorous, often allowing the audience a slight reprieve between tense scenes. Despite all the violence though, it really wasn't very bloody. When blood was called for it was certainly used, but many times times the blood wasn't even colored, only that pure splash of white.

Anyone who enjoys a good detective/crime/revenge story should definitely see this movie. Actually, I would even suggest Sin City to anyone who enjoys striking visuals and would like to experience a truly unique style which we rarely get see anymore. Seeing Sin City for the first time is probably a lot like seeing movies such as Metropolis, Star Wars, Who Framed Roger Rabbit, and The Matrix when they first came out. And, of course, any Tarantino (who was a "guest director" for Sin City, and it shows) fan can't miss this movie. Most importantly though, don't be scared off from seeing Sin City in the theater because you heard it was based off of a comic book. Because even though the story will hold up on your DVD player at home, the visual experience on a full-sized screen should not be missed.
